Title: Tess of the d``Urbervilles A Pure Woman

Author: Thomas Hardy

Release Date: February, 1994 -LSB-eBook #110-RSB- This edition 11 released June 17, 2005 Most recently updated: October 13, 2013

Language: English

***START OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK TESS OF THE D``URBERVILLES***

E-text transcribed by Steve Menyhert, proof-read by Meredith Ricker and John Hamm, and revised by Joseph E. Loewenstein, M.D.

TESS OF THE D``URBERVILLES

A Pure Woman

Faithfully presented by

THOMAS HARDY

Contents

Phase the First: The Maiden, I-XI

Phase the Second: Maiden No More, XII-XV

Phase the Third: The Rally, XVI-XXIV

Phase the Fourth: The Consequence, XXV-XXXIV

Phase the Fifth: The Woman Pays, XXXV-XLIV

Phase the Sixth: The Convert, XLV-LII

Phase the Seventh: Fulfilment, LIII-LIX

Phase the First: The Maiden

I

On an evening in the latter part of May a middle-aged man was walking homeward from Shaston to the village of Marlott, in the adjoining Vale of Blakemore, or Blackmoor. The pair of legs that carried him (Blakemore) were rickety, and there was a bias in his (Blakemore) gait which inclined him (Blakemore) somewhat to the left of a straight line. He (Blakemore) occasionally gave a smart nod, as if in confirmation of some opinion, though he (Blakemore) was not thinking of anything in particular. An empty egg-basket was slung upon his (Blakemore) arm, the nap of his (Blakemore) hat was ruffled, a patch being quite worn away at its brim where his (Blakemore) thumb came in taking it off. Presently he (Blakemore) was met by an elderly parson astride on a gray mare, who, as he (Blakemore) rode, hummed a wandering tune.

``Good night t`ee,'' (the man)
said the man with the basket.

``Good night, Sir John,'' (the parson)
said the parson.

The pedestrian, after another pace or two, halted, and turned round.

``Now, sir, begging your pardon; we met last market-day on this road about this time, and I said ``Good night,

'' and you made reply '_Good night, Sir John_,'' (unknown)
as now.''

``I did,'' (the parson)
said the parson.

``And once before that--near a month ago.'' (unknown)

``I may have.'' (unknown)

``Then what might your meaning be in calling me

``Sir John' these different times, when I be plain Jack Durbeyfield, the haggler?'' (The parson)

The parson rode a step or two nearer.

``It was only my whim,'' (he)
he (parson) said; and, after a moment's hesitation: ``It was on account of a discovery I made some little time ago, whilst I was hunting up pedigrees for the new county history. I am Parson Tringham, the antiquary, of Stagfoot Lane. Don't you really know, Durbeyfield, that you are the lineal representative of the ancient and knightly family of the d``Urbervilles, who derive their descent from Sir Pagan d
``Urberville, that renowned knight who came from Normandy with William the Conqueror, as appears by Battle Abbey Roll?'' (Pagan)

``Never heard it before, sir!'' (unknown)

``Well it's true. Throw up your chin a moment, so that I may catch the profile of your face better. Yes, that's the d

``Urberville nose and chin--a little debased. Your ancestor was one of the twelve knights who assisted the Lord of Estremavilla in Normandy in his (Lord) conquest of Glamorganshire. Branches of your family held manors over all this part of England; their names appear in the Pipe Rolls in the time of King Stephen. In the reign of King John one of them was rich enough to give a manor to the Knights Hospitallers; and in Edward the Second's time your forefather Brian was summoned to Westminster to attend the great Council there. You declined a little in Oliver Cromwell's time, but to no serious extent, and in Charles the Second's reign you were made Knights of the Royal Oak for your loyalty. Aye, there have been generations of Sir Johns among you, and if knighthood were hereditary, like a baronetcy, as it practically was in old times, when men were knighted from father to son, you would be Sir John now.'' (unknown)

``Ye don't say so!'' (unknown)

``In short,'' (the parson)
concluded the parson, decisively smacking his (parson) leg with his (parson) switch,
``there's hardly such another family in England.'' (the parson)

``Daze my eyes, and isn't there?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Durbeyfield.
``And here have I been knocking about, year after year, from pillar to post, as if I was no more than the commonest feller in the parish... And how long hev this news about me been knowed, Pa`son Tringham?'' (The clergyman)

The clergyman explained that, as far as he (parson) was aware, it had quite died out of knowledge, and could hardly be said to be known at all. His (parson) own investigations had begun on a day in the preceding spring when, having been engaged in tracing the vicissitudes of the d``Urberville family, he (son) had observed Durbeyfield's name on his (son) waggon, and had thereupon been led to make inquiries about his (son) father and grandfather till he (son) had no doubt on the subject.

``At first I resolved not to disturb you with such a useless piece of information,'' (he)
said he (parson).
``However, our impulses are too strong for our judgement sometimes. I thought you might perhaps know something of it all the while.'' (unknown)

``Well, I have heard once or twice, `tis true, that my family had seen better days afore they came to Blackmoor. But I took no notice o`t, thinking it to mean that we had once kept two horses where we now keep only one. I've got a wold silver spoon, and a wold graven seal at home, too; but, Lord, what's a spoon and seal? ... And to think that I and these noble d``Urbervilles were one flesh all the time. ``Twas said that my gr`t-granfer had secrets, and didn't care to talk of where he (Lord) came from... And where do we raise our smoke, now, parson, if I may make so bold; I mean, where do we d

``Urbervilles live?'' (unknown)

``You don't live anywhere. You are extinct--as a county family.'' (unknown)

``That's bad.'' (unknown)

``Yes--what the mendacious family chronicles call extinct in the male line--that is, gone down--gone under.'' (unknown)

``Then where do we lie?'' (unknown)

``At Kingsbere-sub-Greenhill: rows and rows of you in your vaults, with your effigies under Purbeck-marble canopies.'' (unknown)

``And where be our family mansions and estates?'' (unknown)

``You haven't any.'' (unknown)

``Oh? No lands neither?'' (unknown)

``None; though you once had 'em in abundance, as I said, for you family consisted of numerous branches. In this county there was a seat of yours at Kingsbere, and another at Sherton, and another in Millpond, and another at Lullstead, and another at Wellbridge.'' (unknown)

``And shall we ever come into our own again?'' (unknown)

``Ah--that I can't tell!'' (unknown)

``And what had I better do about it, sir?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
asked Durbeyfield, after a pause.

``Oh--nothing, nothing; except chasten yourself with the thought of `how are the mighty fallen.'' (the historian genealogist)
It is a fact of some interest to the local historian and genealogist, nothing more. There are several families among the cottagers of this county of almost equal lustre. Good night.''

``But you'll turn back and have a quart of beer wi' me on the strength o`t, Pa`son Tringham? There's a very pretty brew in tap at The Pure Drop--though, to be sure, not so good as at Rolliver's.'' (unknown)

``No, thank you--not this evening, Durbeyfield. You've had enough already.'' (the parson)
Concluding thus, the parson rode on his (parson) way, with doubts as to his (parson) discretion in retailing this curious bit of lore.

When he (parson) was gone, Durbeyfield walked a few steps in a profound reverie, and then sat down upon the grassy bank by the roadside, depositing his (parson) basket before him (parson). In a few minutes a youth appeared in the distance, walking in the same direction as that which had been pursued by Durbeyfield. The latter, on seeing him (parson), held up his (parson) hand, and the lad quickened his (parson) pace and came near.

``Boy, take up that basket! I want `ee to go on an errand for me.'' (unknown)

The lath-like stripling frowned.

``Who be you, then, John Durbeyfield, to order me about and call me `boy'? You know my name as well as I know yours!'' (unknown)

``Do you, do you? That's the secret--that's the secret! Now obey my orders, and take the message I'm going to charge `ee wi'... Well, Fred, I don't mind telling you that the secret is that I'm one of a noble race--it has been just found out by me this present afternoon, P.M.'' (he)
And as he (parson) made the announcement, Durbeyfield, declining from his (parson) sitting position, luxuriously stretched himself out upon the bank among the daisies.

The lad stood before Durbeyfield, and contemplated his (lad) length from crown to toe.

``Sir John d``Urberville--that's who I am,'' continued the prostrate man. ``That is if knights were baronets--which they be.

``Tis recorded in history all about me. Dost know of such a place, lad, as Kingsbere-sub-Greenhill?'' (unknown)

``Ees. I've been there to Greenhill Fair.'' (unknown)

``Well, under the church of that city there lie--'' (unknown)

''`Tisn't a city, the place I mean; leastwise `twaddn' when I was there--'twas a little one-eyed, blinking sort o' place.'' (unknown)

``Never you mind the place, boy, that's not the question before us. Under the church of that there parish lie my ancestors--hundreds of 'em--in coats of mail and jewels, in gr't lead coffins weighing tons and tons. There's not a man in the county o' South-Wessex that's got grander and nobler skillentons in his (man) family than I.'' (unknown)

``Oh?'' (unknown)

``Now take up that basket, and goo on to Marlott, and when you've come to The Pure Drop Inn, tell 'em to send a horse and carriage to me immed`ately, to carry me hwome. And in the bottom o' the carriage they be to put a noggin o' rum in a small bottle, and chalk it up to my account. And when you've done that goo on to my house with the basket, and tell my wife to put away that washing, because she (wife) needn't finish it, and wait till I come hwome, as I've news to tell her (wife).'' (the lad)

As the lad stood in a dubious attitude, Durbeyfield put his (lad) hand in his (lad) pocket, and produced a shilling, one of the chronically few that he (lad) possessed.

``Here's for your labour, lad.'' (the man)

This made a difference in the young man's estimate of the position.

``Yes, Sir John. Thank `ee. Anything else I can do for `ee, Sir John?'' (unknown)

``Tell 'em at hwome that I should like for supper,--well, lamb's fry if they can get it; and if they can't, black-pot; and if they can't get that, well chitterlings will do.'' (unknown)

``Yes, Sir John.'' (The boy)

The boy took up the basket, and as he (boy) set out the notes of a brass band were heard from the direction of the village.

``What's that?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Durbeyfield.
``Not on account o' I?'' (unknown)

''`Tis the women's club-walking, Sir John. Why, your da`ter is one o' the members.'' (unknown)

``To be sure--I'd quite forgot it in my thoughts of greater things! Well, vamp on to Marlott, will ye, and order that carriage, and maybe I'll drive round and inspect the club.'' (The lad)

The lad departed, and Durbeyfield lay waiting on the grass and daisies in the evening sun. Not a soul passed that way for a long while, and the faint notes of the band were the only human sounds audible within the rim of blue hills.

II

The village of Marlott lay amid the north-eastern undulations of the beautiful Vale of Blakemore, or Blackmoor, aforesaid, an engirdled and secluded region, for the most part untrodden as yet by tourist or landscape-painter, though within a four hours' journey from London.

It is a vale whose acquaintance is best made by viewing it from the summits of the hills that surround it--except perhaps during the droughts of summer. An unguided ramble into its recesses in bad weather is apt to engender dissatisfaction with its narrow, tortuous, and miry ways.

This fertile and sheltered tract of country, in which the fields are never brown and the springs never dry, is bounded on the south by the bold chalk ridge that embraces the prominences of Hambledon Hill, Bulbarrow, Nettlecombe-Tout, Dogbury, High Stoy, and Bubb Down. The traveller from the coast, who, after plodding northward for a score of miles over calcareous downs and corn-lands, suddenly reaches the verge of one of these escarpments, is surprised and delighted to behold, extended like a map beneath him (traveller), a country differing absolutely from that which he (traveller) has passed through. Behind him (traveller) the hills are open, the sun blazes down upon fields so large as to give an unenclosed character to the landscape, the lanes are white, the hedges low and plashed, the atmosphere colourless. Here, in the valley, the world seems to be constructed upon a smaller and more delicate scale; the fields are mere paddocks, so reduced that from this height their hedgerows appear a network of dark green threads overspreading the paler green of the grass. The atmosphere beneath is languorous, and is so tinged with azure that what artists call the middle distance partakes also of that hue, while the horizon beyond is of the deepest ultramarine. Arable lands are few and limited; with but slight exceptions the prospect is a broad rich mass of grass and trees, mantling minor hills and dales within the major. Such is the Vale of Blackmoor.

The district is of historic, no less than of topographical interest. The Vale was known in former times as the Forest of White Hart, from a curious legend of King Henry III's reign, in which the killing by a certain Thomas de la Lynd of a beautiful white hart which the king had run down and spared, was made the occasion of a heavy fine. In those days, and till comparatively recent times, the country was densely wooded. Even now, traces of its earlier condition are to be found in the old oak copses and irregular belts of timber that yet survive upon its slopes, and the hollow-trunked trees that shade so many of its pastures.

The forests have departed, but some old customs of their shades remain. Many, however, linger only in a metamorphosed or disguised form. The May-Day dance, for instance, was to be discerned on the afternoon under notice, in the guise of the club revel, or

``club-walking,'' (unknown)
as it was there called.

It was an interesting event to the younger inhabitants of Marlott, though its real interest was not observed by the participators in the ceremony. Its singularity lay less in the retention of a custom of walking in procession and dancing on each anniversary than in the members being solely women. In men's clubs such celebrations were, though expiring, less uncommon; but either the natural shyness of the softer sex, or a sarcastic attitude on the part of male relatives, had denuded such women's clubs as remained -LRB-if any other did-RRB- or this their glory and consummation. The club of Marlott alone lived to uphold the local Cerealia. It had walked for hundreds of years, if not as benefit-club, as votive sisterhood of some sort; and it walked still.

The banded ones were all dressed in white gowns--a gay survival from Old Style days, when cheerfulness and May-time were synonyms--days before the habit of taking long views had reduced emotions to a monotonous average. Their first exhibition of themselves was in a processional march of two and two round the parish. Ideal and real clashed slightly as the sun lit up their figures against the green hedges and creeper-laced house-fronts; for, though the whole troop wore white garments, no two whites were alike among them. Some approached pure blanching; some had a bluish pallor; some worn by the older characters -LRB-which had possibly lain by folded for many a year-RRB- inclined to a cadaverous tint, and to a Georgian style.

In addition to the distinction of a white frock, every woman and girl carried in her (woman) right hand a peeled willow wand, and in her (woman) left a bunch of white flowers. The peeling of the former, and the selection of the latter, had been an operation of personal care.

There were a few middle-aged and even elderly women in the train, their silver-wiry hair and wrinkled faces, scourged by time and trouble, having almost a grotesque, certainly a pathetic, appearance in such a jaunty situation. In a true view, perhaps, there was more to be gathered and told of each anxious and experienced one, to whom the years were drawing nigh when she (woman) should say,

``I have no pleasure in them,'' (she)
than of her (woman) juvenile comrades. But let the elder be passed over here for those under whose bodices the life throbbed quick and warm.

The young girls formed, indeed, the majority of the band, and their heads of luxuriant hair reflected in the sunshine every tone of gold, and black, and brown. Some had beautiful eyes, others a beautiful nose, others a beautiful mouth and figure: few, if any, had all. A difficulty of arranging their lips in this crude exposure to public scrutiny, an inability to balance their heads, and to dissociate self-consciousness from their features, was apparent in them, and showed that they were genuine country girls, unaccustomed to many eyes.

And as each and all of them were warmed without by the sun, so each had a private little sun for her (their) soul to bask in; some dream, some affection, some hobby, at least some remote and distant hope which, though perhaps starving to nothing, still lived on, as hopes will. They were all cheerful, and many of them merry.

They came round by The Pure Drop Inn, and were turning out of the high road to pass through a wicket-gate into the meadows, when one of the women said--

``The Load-a-Lord! Why, Tess Durbeyfield, if there isn't thy father riding hwome in a carriage!'' (the women)

A young member of the band turned her (their) head at the exclamation. She (their) was a fine and handsome girl--not handsomer than some others, possibly--but her (their) mobile peony mouth and large innocent eyes added eloquence to colour and shape. She (their) wore a red ribbon in her (their) hair, and was the only one of the white company who could boast of such a pronounced adornment. As she (their) looked round Durbeyfield was seen moving along the road in a chaise belonging to The Pure Drop, driven by a frizzle-headed brawny damsel with her (damsel) gown-sleeves rolled above her (damsel) elbows. This was the cheerful servant of that establishment, who, in her (damsel) part of factotum, turned groom and ostler at times. Durbeyfield, leaning back, and with his (ostler) eyes closed luxuriously, was waving his (ostler) hand above his (ostler) head, and singing in a slow recitative--

``I've-got-a-gr`t-family-vault-at-Kingsbere--and knighted-forefathers-in-lead-coffins-there!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

The clubbists tittered, except the girl called Tess--in whom a slow heat seemed to rise at the sense that her (Tess) father was making himself foolish in their eyes.

``He (father)'s tired, that's all,'' (she)
she (Tess) said hastily,
``and he (father) has got a lift home, because our own horse has to rest to-day.'' (she)

``Bless thy simplicity, Tess,'' (companions)
said her (Tess) companions.
``He (father)'s got his (father) market-nitch. Haw-haw!'' (unknown)

``Look here; I won't walk another inch with you, if you say any jokes about him (father)!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
Tess cried, and the colour upon her (Tess) cheeks spread over her (Tess) face and neck. In a moment her (Tess) eyes grew moist, and her (Tess) glance drooped to the ground. Perceiving that they had really pained her (Tess) they said no more, and order again prevailed. Tess's pride would not allow her (Tess) to turn her (Tess) head again, to learn what her (Tess) father's meaning was, if he (father) had any; and thus she (Tess) moved on with the whole body to the enclosure where there was to be dancing on the green. By the time the spot was reached she (Tess) has recovered her (Tess) equanimity, and tapped her (Tess) neighbour with her (Tess) wand and talked as usual.

Tess Durbeyfield at this time of her (Durbeyfield) life was a mere vessel of emotion untinctured by experience. The dialect was on her (Durbeyfield) tongue to some extent, despite the village school: the characteristic intonation of that dialect for this district being the voicing approximately rendered by the syllable UR, probably as rich an utterance as any to be found in human speech. The pouted-up deep red mouth to which this syllable was native had hardly as yet settled into its definite shape, and her (Durbeyfield) lower lip had a way of thrusting the middle of her (Durbeyfield) top one upward, when they closed together after a word.

Phases of her (Durbeyfield) childhood lurked in her (Durbeyfield) aspect still. As she (Durbeyfield) walked along to-day, for all her (Durbeyfield) bouncing handsome womanliness, you could sometimes see her (Durbeyfield) twelfth year in her (Durbeyfield) cheeks, or her (Durbeyfield) ninth sparkling from her (Durbeyfield) eyes; and even her (Durbeyfield) fifth would flit over the curves of her (Durbeyfield) mouth now and then.

Yet few knew, and still fewer considered this. A small minority, mainly strangers, would look long at her (Durbeyfield) in casually passing by, and grow momentarily fascinated by her (Durbeyfield) freshness, and wonder if they would ever see her (Durbeyfield) again: but to almost everybody she (Durbeyfield) was a fine and picturesque country girl, and no more.

Nothing was seen or heard further of Durbeyfield in his (Durbeyfield) triumphal chariot under the conduct of the ostleress, and the club having entered the allotted space, dancing began. As there were no men in the company, the girls danced at first with each other, but when the hour for the close of labour drew on, the masculine inhabitants of the village, together with other idlers and pedestrians, gathered round the spot, and appeared inclined to negotiate for a partner.

Among these on-lookers were three young men of a superior class, carrying small knapsacks strapped to their shoulders, and stout sticks in their hands. Their general likeness to each other, and their consecutive ages, would almost have suggested that they might be, what in fact they were, brothers. The eldest wore the white tie, high waistcoat, and thin-brimmed hat of the regulation curate; the second was the normal undergraduate; the appearance of the third and youngest would hardly have been sufficient to characterize him (ages); there was an uncribbed, uncabined aspect in his (ages) eyes and attire, implying that he (ages) had hardly as yet found the entrance to his (ages) professional groove. That he (ages) was a desultory tentative student of something and everything might only have been predicted of him (student).

These three brethren told casual acquaintance that they were spending their Whitsun holidays in a walking tour through the Vale of Blackmoor, their course being south-westerly from the town of Shaston on the north-east.

They leant over the gate by the highway, and inquired as to the meaning of the dance and the white-frocked maids. The two elder of the brothers were plainly not intending to linger more than a moment, but the spectacle of a bevy of girls dancing without male partners seemed to amuse the third, and make him (student) in no hurry to move on. He (student) unstrapped his (student) knapsack, put it, with his (student) stick, on the hedge-bank, and opened the gate.

``What are you going to do, Angel?'' (unknown)
asked the eldest.

``I am inclined to go and have a fling with them. Why not all of us--just for a minute or two--it will not detain us long?'' (unknown)

``No--no; nonsense!'' (unknown)
said the first.
``Dancing in public with a troop of country hoydens--suppose we should be seen! Come along, or it will be dark before we get to Stourcastle, and there's no place we can sleep at nearer than that; besides, we must get through another chapter of _A Counterblast to Agnosticism_ before we turn in, now I have taken the trouble to bring the book.'' (unknown)

``All right--I'll overtake you and Cuthbert in five minutes; don't stop; I give my word that I will, Felix.'' (him)

The two elder reluctantly left him (student) and walked on, taking their brother's knapsack to relieve him (brother) in following, and the youngest entered the field.

``This is a thousand pities,'' (he)
he (brother) said gallantly, to two or three of the girls nearest him (brother), as soon as there was a pause in the dance.
``Where are your partners, my dears?'' (unknown)

``They've not left off work yet,'' (unknown)
answered one of the boldest.
``They'll be here by and by. Till then, will you be one, sir?'' (unknown)

``Certainly. But what's one among so many!'' (unknown)

``Better than none.

``Tis melancholy work facing and footing it to one of your own sort, and no clipsing and colling at all. Now, pick and choose.'' (unknown)

''`Ssh--don't be so for`ard!'' (a shyer girl)
said a shyer girl.

The young man, thus invited, glanced them over, and attempted some discrimination; but, as the group were all so new to him (man), he (man) could not very well exercise it. He (man) took almost the first that came to hand, which was not the speaker, as she (girl) had expected; nor did it happen to be Tess Durbeyfield. Pedigree, ancestral skeletons, monumental record, the d``Urberville lineaments, did not help Tess in her (Tess) life's battle as yet, even to the extent of attracting to her (Tess) a dancing-partner over the heads of the commonest peasantry. So much for Norman blood unaided by Victorian lucre.

The name of the eclipsing girl, whatever it was, has not been handed down; but she (girl) was envied by all as the first who enjoyed the luxury of a masculine partner that evening. Yet such was the force of example that the village young men, who had not hastened to enter the gate while no intruder was in the way, now dropped in quickly, and soon the couples became leavened with rustic youth to a marked extent, till at length the plainest woman in the club was no longer compelled to foot it on the masculine side of the figure.

The church clock struck, when suddenly the student said that he (student) must leave--he (student) had been forgetting himself--he (student) had to join his (student) companions. As he (student) fell out of the dance his (student) eyes lighted on Tess Durbeyfield, whose own large orbs wore, to tell the truth, the faintest aspect of reproach that he (student) had not chosen her (Durbeyfield). He (student), too, was sorry then that, owing to her (Durbeyfield) backwardness, he (student) had not observed her (Durbeyfield); and with that in his (student) mind he (student) left the pasture.

On account of his (student) long delay he (student) started in a flying-run down the lane westward, and had soon passed the hollow and mounted the next rise. He (student) had not yet overtaken his (student) brothers, but he (student) paused to get breath, and looked back. He (student) could see the white figures of the girls in the green enclosure whirling about as they had whirled when he (student) was among them. They seemed to have quite forgotten him (student) already.

All of them, except, perhaps, one. This white shape stood apart by the hedge alone. From her (student) position he (student) knew it to be the pretty maiden with whom he (student) had not danced. Trifling as the matter was, he (student) yet instinctively felt that she (student) was hurt by his (student) oversight. He (student) wished that he (student) had asked her (student); he (student) wished that he (student) had inquired her (student) name. She (student) was so modest, so expressive, she (student) had looked so soft in her (student) thin white gown that he (student) felt he (student) had acted stupidly.

However, it could not be helped, and turning, and bending himself to a rapid walk, he (student) dismissed the subject from his (student) mind.

III

As for Tess Durbeyfield, she (Durbeyfield) did not so easily dislodge the incident from her (Durbeyfield) consideration. She (Durbeyfield) had no spirit to dance again for a long time, though she (Durbeyfield) might have had plenty of partners; but ah! they did not speak so nicely as the strange young man had done. It was not till the rays of the sun had absorbed the young stranger's retreating figure on the hill that she (Durbeyfield) shook off her (Durbeyfield) temporary sadness and answered her (Durbeyfield) would-be partner in the affirmative.

She (Durbeyfield) remained with her (Durbeyfield) comrades till dusk, and participated with a certain zest in the dancing; though, being heart-whole as yet, she (Durbeyfield) enjoyed treading a measure purely for its own sake; little divining when she (Durbeyfield) saw

``the soft torments, the bitter sweets, the pleasing pains, and the agreeable distresses'' (she)
of those girls who had been wooed and won, what she (Durbeyfield) herself was capable of in that kind. The struggles and wrangles of the lads for her (Durbeyfield) hand in a jig were an amusement to her (Durbeyfield)--no more; and when they became fierce she (Durbeyfield) rebuked them.

She (Durbeyfield) might have stayed even later, but the incident of her (Durbeyfield) father's odd appearance and manner returned upon the girl's mind to make her (Durbeyfield) anxious, and wondering what had become of him (father) she (Durbeyfield) dropped away from the dancers and bent her (Durbeyfield) steps towards the end of the village at which the parental cottage lay.

While yet many score yards off, other rhythmic sounds than those she (Durbeyfield) had quitted became audible to her (Durbeyfield); sounds that she (Durbeyfield) knew well--so well. They were a regular series of thumpings from the interior of the house, occasioned by the violent rocking of a cradle upon a stone floor, to which movement a feminine voice kept time by singing, in a vigorous gallopade, the favourite ditty of

``The Spotted Cow'' (I)
--

I saw her (Durbeyfield) lie do'-own in yon'-der green gro'-ove; Come, love!

'' and I'll tell' you where!'' (I)

The cradle-rocking and the song would cease simultaneously for a moment, and an exclamation at highest vocal pitch would take the place of the melody.

``God bless thy diment eyes! And thy waxen cheeks! And thy cherry mouth! And thy Cubit's thighs! And every bit o' thy blessed body!'' (unknown)

After this invocation the rocking and the singing would recommence, and the

``Spotted Cow'' (unknown)
proceed as before. So matters stood when Tess opened the door and paused upon the mat within it, surveying the scene.

The interior, in spite of the melody, struck upon the girl's senses with an unspeakable dreariness. From the holiday gaieties of the field--the white gowns, the nosegays, the willow-wands, the whirling movements on the green, the flash of gentle sentiment towards the stranger--to the yellow melancholy of this one-candled spectacle, what a step! Besides the jar of contrast there came to her (girl) a chill self-reproach that she (girl) had not returned sooner, to help her (girl) mother in these domesticities, instead of indulging herself out-of-doors.

There stood her (girl) mother amid the group of children, as Tess had left her (Tess), hanging over the Monday washing-tub, which had now, as always, lingered on to the end of the week. Out of that tub had come the day before--Tess felt it with a dreadful sting of remorse--the very white frock upon her (Tess) back which she (Tess) had so carelessly greened about the skirt on the damping grass--which had been wrung up and ironed by her (Tess) mother's own hands.

As usual, Mrs Durbeyfield was balanced on one foot beside the tub, the other being engaged in the aforesaid business of rocking her (Durbeyfield) youngest child. The cradle-rockers had done hard duty for so many years, under the weight of so many children, on that flagstone floor, that they were worn nearly flat, in consequence of which a huge jerk accompanied each swing of the cot, flinging the baby from side to side like a weaver's shuttle, as Mrs Durbeyfield, excited by her (Durbeyfield) song, trod the rocker with all the spring that was left in her (Durbeyfield) after a long day's seething in the suds.

Nick-knock, nick-knock, went the cradle; the candle-flame stretched itself tall, and began jigging up and down; the water dribbled from the matron's elbows, and the song galloped on to the end of the verse, Mrs Durbeyfield regarding her (Durbeyfield) daughter the while. Even now, when burdened with a young family, Joan Durbeyfield was a passionate lover of tune. No ditty floated into Blackmoor Vale from the outer world but Tess's mother caught up its notation in a week.

There still faintly beamed from the woman's features something of the freshness, and even the prettiness, of her (woman) youth; rendering it probable that the personal charms which Tess could boast of were in main part her (Tess) mother's gift, and therefore unknightly, unhistorical.

``I'll rock the cradle for `ee, mother,'' (the daughter)
said the daughter gently.
``Or I'll take off my best frock and help you wring up? I thought you had finished long ago.'' (mother)

Her (Tess) mother bore Tess no ill-will for leaving the housework to her (Tess) single-handed efforts for so long; indeed, Joan seldom upbraided her (Joan) thereon at any time, feeling but slightly the lack of Tess's assistance whilst her (Tess) instinctive plan for relieving herself of her (Tess) labours lay in postponing them. To-night, however, she (Tess) was even in a blither mood than usual. There was a dreaminess, a pre-occupation, an exaltation, in the maternal look which the girl could not understand.

``Well, I'm glad you've come,'' (mother)
her (girl) mother said, as soon as the last note had passed out of her (mother).
``I want to go and fetch your father; but what's more'n that, I want to tell `ee what have happened. Y'll be fess enough, my poppet, when th`st know!'' (Mrs)
-LRB-Mrs Durbeyfield habitually spoke the dialect; her (Mrs) daughter, who had passed the Sixth Standard in the National School under a London-trained mistress, spoke two languages: the dialect at home, more or less; ordinary English abroad and to persons of quality.-RRB-

``Since I've been away?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
Tess asked.

``Ay!'' (unknown)

``Had it anything to do with father's making such a mommet of himself in thik carriage this afternoon? Why did `er? I felt inclined to sink into the ground with shame!'' (unknown)

``That wer all a part of the larry! We've been found to be the greatest gentlefolk in the whole county--reaching all back long before Oliver Grumble's time--to the days of the Pagan Turks--with monuments, and vaults, and crests, and `scutcheons, and the Lord knows what all. In Saint Charles's days we was made Knights o' the Royal Oak, our real name being d``Urberville! ... Don't that make your bosom plim?

``Twas on this account that your father rode home in the vlee; not because he (father)'d been drinking, as people supposed.'' (unknown)

``I'm glad of that. Will it do us any good, mother?'' (unknown)

``O yes!

``Tis thoughted that great things may come o`t. No doubt a mampus of volk of our own rank will be down here in their carriages as soon as `tis known. Your father learnt it on his (father) way hwome from Shaston, and he (father) has been telling me the whole pedigree of the matter.'' (unknown)

``Where is father now?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
asked Tess suddenly.

Her (Tess) mother gave irrelevant information by way of answer:

``He (father) called to see the doctor to-day in Shaston. It is not consumption at all, it seems. It is fat round his (father) heart, 'a says. There, it is like this.'' (mother)
Joan Durbeyfield, as she (Durbeyfield) spoke, curved a sodden thumb and forefinger to the shape of the letter C, and used the other forefinger as a pointer.
''`At the present moment,'' (she)
he (Tess) says to your father, `your heart is enclosed all round there, and all round there; this space is still open,'' 'a says. ``As soon as it do meet, so,'
''--Mrs Durbeyfield closed her (Durbeyfield) fingers into a circle complete--'' (Mr)
`off you will go like a shadder, Mr Durbeyfield,'' 'a says.
``You mid last ten years; you mid go off in ten months, or ten days.''' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess looked alarmed. Her (Tess) father possibly to go behind the eternal cloud so soon, notwithstanding this sudden greatness!

``But where IS father?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked again.

Her (Tess) mother put on a deprecating look.

``Now don't you be bursting out angry! The poor man--he (man) felt so rafted after his (man) uplifting by the pa`son's news--that he (man) went up to Rolliver's half an hour ago. He (man) do want to get up his (man) strength for his (man) journey to-morrow with that load of beehives, which must be delivered, family or no. He (man)'ll have to start shortly after twelve to-night, as the distance is so long.'' (unknown)

``Get up his (man) strength!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess impetuously, the tears welling to her (Tess) eyes.
``O my God! Go to a public-house to get up his (man) strength! And you as well agreed as he (man), mother!'' (children)

Her (Tess) rebuke and her (Tess) mood seemed to fill the whole room, and to impart a cowed look to the furniture, and candle, and children playing about, and to her (Tess) mother's face.

``No,'' (unknown)
said the latter touchily,
``I be not agreed. I have been waiting for `ee to bide and keep house while I go fetch him (man).'' (unknown)

``I'll go.'' (unknown)

``O no, Tess. You see, it would be no use.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess did not expostulate. She (Tess) knew what her (Tess) mother's objection meant. Mrs Durbeyfield's jacket and bonnet were already hanging slily upon a chair by her (Durbeyfield) side, in readiness for this contemplated jaunt, the reason for which the matron deplored more than its necessity.

``And take the _Compleat Fortune-Teller_ to the outhouse,'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)
Joan continued, rapidly wiping her (Joan) hands, and donning the garments.

The _Compleat Fortune-Teller_ was an old thick volume, which lay on a table at her (Joan) elbow, so worn by pocketing that the margins had reached the edge of the type. Tess took it up, and her (Tess) mother started.

This going to hunt up her (Tess) shiftless husband at the inn was one of Mrs Durbeyfield's still extant enjoyments in the muck and muddle of rearing children. To discover him (husband) at Rolliver's, to sit there for an hour or two by his (husband) side and dismiss all thought and care of the children during the interval, made her (Rolliver) happy. A sort of halo, an occidental glow, came over life then. Troubles and other realities took on themselves a metaphysical impalpability, sinking to mere mental phenomena for serene contemplation, and no longer stood as pressing concretions which chafed body and soul. The youngsters, not immediately within sight, seemed rather bright and desirable appurtenances than otherwise; the incidents of daily life were not without humorousness and jollity in their aspect there. She (Rolliver) felt a little as she (Rolliver) had used to feel when she (Rolliver) sat by her (Rolliver) now wedded husband in the same spot during his (husband) wooing, shutting her (Rolliver) eyes to his (husband) defects of character, and regarding him (husband) only in his (husband) ideal presentation as lover.

Tess, being left alone with the younger children, went first to the outhouse with the fortune-telling book, and stuffed it into the thatch. A curious fetishistic fear of this grimy volume on the part of her (Tess) mother prevented her (Tess) ever allowing it to stay in the house all night, and hither it was brought back whenever it had been consulted. Between the mother, with her (mother) fast-perishing lumber of superstitions, folk-lore, dialect, and orally transmitted ballads, and the daughter, with her (daughter) trained National teachings and Standard knowledge under an infinitely Revised Code, there was a gap of two hundred years as ordinarily understood. When they were together the Jacobean and the Victorian ages were juxtaposed.

Returning along the garden path Tess mused on what the mother could have wished to ascertain from the book on this particular day. She (mother) guessed the recent ancestral discovery to bear upon it, but did not divine that it solely concerned herself. Dismissing this, however, she (mother) busied herself with sprinkling the linen dried during the day-time, in company with her (mother) nine-year-old brother Abraham, and her (mother) sister Eliza-Louisa of twelve and a half, called

''`Liza-Lu,'' (sister)
the youngest ones being put to bed. There was an interval of four years and more between Tess and the next of the family, the two who had filled the gap having died in their infancy, and this lent her (Tess) a deputy-maternal attitude when she (Tess) was alone with her (Tess) juniors. Next in juvenility to Abraham came two more girls, Hope and Modesty; then a boy of three, and then the baby, who had just completed his (boy) first year.

All these young souls were passengers in the Durbeyfield ship--entirely dependent on the judgement of the two Durbeyfield adults for their pleasures, their necessities, their health, even their existence. If the heads of the Durbeyfield household chose to sail into difficulty, disaster, starvation, disease, degradation, death, thither were these half-dozen little captives under hatches compelled to sail with them--six helpless creatures, who had never been asked if they wished for life on any terms, much less if they wished for it on such hard conditions as were involved in being of the shiftless house of Durbeyfield. Some people would like to know whence the poet whose philosophy is in these days deemed as profound and trustworthy as his (poet) song is breezy and pure, gets his (poet) authority for speaking of

``Nature's holy plan.'' (the poet)

It grew later, and neither father nor mother reappeared. Tess looked out of the door, and took a mental journey through Marlott. The village was shutting its eyes. Candles and lamps were being put out everywhere: she (Tess) could inwardly behold the extinguisher and the extended hand.

Her (Tess) mother's fetching simply meant one more to fetch. Tess began to perceive that a man in indifferent health, who proposed to start on a journey before one in the morning, ought not to be at an inn at this late hour celebrating his (man) ancient blood.

``Abraham,'' (she)
she (Tess) said to her (Tess) little brother,
``do you put on your hat--you bain't afraid?--and go up to Rolliver's, and see what has gone wi' father and mother.'' (brother)

The boy jumped promptly from his (boy) seat, and opened the door, and the night swallowed him (boy) up. Half an hour passed yet again; neither man, woman, nor child returned. Abraham, like his (Abraham) parents, seemed to have been limed and caught by the ensnaring inn.

``I must go myself,'' (she)
she (woman) said.

``Liza-Lu then went to bed, and Tess, locking them all in, started on her (Tess) way up the dark and crooked lane or street not made for hasty progress; a street laid out before inches of land had value, and when one-handed clocks sufficiently subdivided the day.

IV

Rolliver's inn, the single alehouse at this end of the long and broken village, could only boast of an off-licence; hence, as nobody could legally drink on the premises, the amount of overt accommodation for consumers was strictly limited to a little board about six inches wide and two yards long, fixed to the garden palings by pieces of wire, so as to form a ledge. On this board thirsty strangers deposited their cups as they stood in the road and drank, and threw the dregs on the dusty ground to the pattern of Polynesia, and wished they could have a restful seat inside.

Thus the strangers. But there were also local customers who felt the same wish; and where there's a will there's a way.

In a large bedroom upstairs, the window of which was thickly curtained with a great woollen shawl lately discarded by the landlady, Mrs Rolliver, were gathered on this evening nearly a dozen persons, all seeking beatitude; all old inhabitants of the nearer end of Marlott, and frequenters of this retreat. Not only did the distance to the The Pure Drop, the fully-licensed tavern at the further part of the dispersed village, render its accommodation practically unavailable for dwellers at this end; but the far more serious question, the quality of the liquor, confirmed the prevalent opinion that it was better to drink with Rolliver in a corner of the housetop than with the other landlord in a wide house.

A gaunt four-post bedstead which stood in the room afforded sitting-space for several persons gathered round three of its sides; a couple more men had elevated themselves on a chest of drawers; another rested on the oak-carved

``cwoffer'' (men)
; two on the wash-stand; another on the stool; and thus all were, somehow, seated at their ease. The stage of mental comfort to which they had arrived at this hour was one wherein their souls expanded beyond their skins, and spread their personalities warmly through the room. In this process the chamber and its furniture grew more and more dignified and luxurious; the shawl hanging at the window took upon itself the richness of tapestry; the brass handles of the chest of drawers were as golden knockers; and the carved bedposts seemed to have some kinship with the magnificent pillars of Solomon's temple.

Mrs Durbeyfield, having quickly walked hitherward after parting from Tess, opened the front door, crossed the downstairs room, which was in deep gloom, and then unfastened the stair-door like one whose fingers knew the tricks of the latches well. Her (Tess) ascent of the crooked staircase was a slower process, and her (Tess) face, as it rose into the light above the last stair, encountered the gaze of all the party assembled in the bedroom.

''--Being a few private friends I've asked in to keep up club-walking at my own expense,'' (the party)
the landlady exclaimed at the sound of footsteps, as glibly as a child repeating the Catechism, while she (landlady) peered over the stairs.
``Oh, `tis you, Mrs Durbeyfield--Lard--how you frightened me!--I thought it might be some gaffer sent by Gover`ment.'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)

Mrs Durbeyfield was welcomed with glances and nods by the remainder of the conclave, and turned to where her (Durbeyfield) husband sat. He (husband) was humming absently to himself, in a low tone:

``I be as good as some folks here and there! I've got a great family vault at Kingsbere-sub-Greenhill, and finer skillentons than any man in Wessex!'' (He)

``I've something to tell `ee that's come into my head about that--a grand projick!'' (wife)
whispered his (husband) cheerful wife.
``Here, John, don't `ee see me?'' (She)
She (wife) nudged him (husband), while he (husband), looking through her (wife) as through a window-pane, went on with his (husband) recitative.

``Hush! Don't `ee sing so loud, my good man,'' (the landlady)
said the landlady;
``in case any member of the Gover`ment should be passing, and take away my licends.'' (the landlady)

``He (member)'s told `ee what's happened to us, I suppose?'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)
asked Mrs Durbeyfield.

``Yes--in a way. D'ye think there's any money hanging by it?'' (unknown)

``Ah, that's the secret,'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)
said Joan Durbeyfield sagely.
``However, `tis well to be kin to a coach, even if you don't ride in `en.'' (She)
She (Durbeyfield) dropped her (Durbeyfield) public voice, and continued in a low tone to her (Durbeyfield) husband:
``I've been thinking since you brought the news that there's a great rich lady out by Trantridge, on the edge o' The Chase, of the name of d'Urberville.'' (husband)

``Hey--what's that?'' (John/St John)
said Sir John.

She (Durbeyfield) repeated the information.

``That lady must be our relation,'' (she)
she (Durbeyfield) said.
``And my projick is to send Tess to claim kin.'' (unknown)

``There IS a lady of the name, now you mention it,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Durbeyfield.
``Pa`son Tringham didn't think of that. But she (lady)'s nothing beside we--a junior branch of us, no doubt, hailing long since King Norman's day.'' (Abraham)

While this question was being discussed neither of the pair noticed, in their preoccupation, that little Abraham had crept into the room, and was awaiting an opportunity of asking them to return.

``She (lady) is rich, and she (lady)'d be sure to take notice o' the maid,'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)
continued Mrs Durbeyfield;
``and `twill be a very good thing. I don't see why two branches o' one family should not be on visiting terms.'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)

``Yes; and we'll all claim kin!'' (Abraham)
said Abraham brightly from under the bedstead.
``And we'll all go and see her (lady) when Tess has gone to live with her (Tess); and we'll ride in her (Tess) coach and wear black clothes!'' (unknown)

``How do you come here, child? What nonsense be ye talking! Go away, and play on the stairs till father and mother be ready! ... Well, Tess ought to go to this other member of our family. She (Tess)'d be sure to win the lady--Tess would; and likely enough `twould lead to some noble gentleman marrying her (Tess). In short, I know it.'' (unknown)

``How?'' (unknown)

``I tried her (Tess) fate in the _Fortune-Teller_, and it brought out that very thing! ... You should ha' seen how pretty she (Tess) looked to-day; her (Tess) skin is as sumple as a duchess'.'' (unknown)

``What says the maid herself to going?'' (unknown)

``I've not asked her (maid). She (maid) don't know there is any such lady-relation yet. But it would certainly put her (maid) in the way of a grand marriage, and she (maid) won't say nay to going.'' (unknown)

``Tess is queer.'' (unknown)

``But she (Tess)'s tractable at bottom. Leave her (Tess) to me.'' (folks)

Though this conversation had been private, sufficient of its import reached the understandings of those around to suggest to them that the Durbeyfields had weightier concerns to talk of now than common folks had, and that Tess, their pretty eldest daughter, had fine prospects in store.

``Tess is a fine figure o' fun, as I said to myself to-day when I zeed her (Tess) vamping round parish with the rest,'' (the boozers)
observed one of the elderly boozers in an undertone.
``But Joan Durbeyfield must mind that she (Durbeyfield) don't get green malt in floor.'' (unknown)
It was a local phrase which had a peculiar meaning, and there was no reply.

The conversation became inclusive, and presently other footsteps were heard crossing the room below.

''--Being a few private friends asked in to-night to keep up club-walking at my own expense.'' (The landlady)
The landlady had rapidly re-used the formula she (landlady) kept on hand for intruders before she (landlady) recognized that the newcomer was Tess.

Even to her (Tess) mother's gaze the girl's young features looked sadly out of place amid the alcoholic vapours which floated here as no unsuitable medium for wrinkled middle-age; and hardly was a reproachful flash from Tess's dark eyes needed to make her (Tess) father and mother rise from their seats, hastily finish their ale, and descend the stairs behind her (Tess), Mrs Rolliver's caution following their footsteps.

``No noise, please, if ye'll be so good, my dears; or I mid lose my licends, and be summons'd, and I don't know what all!

``Night t`ye!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

They went home together, Tess holding one arm of her (Tess) father, and Mrs Durbeyfield the other. He (father) had, in truth, drunk very little--not a fourth of the quantity which a systematic tippler could carry to church on a Sunday afternoon without a hitch in his (father) eastings or genuflections; but the weakness of Sir John's constitution made mountains of his (John) petty sins in this kind. On reaching the fresh air he (John) was sufficiently unsteady to incline the row of three at one moment as if they were marching to London, and at another as if they were marching to Bath--which produced a comical effect, frequent enough in families on nocturnal homegoings; and, like most comical effects, not quite so comic after all. The two women valiantly disguised these forced excursions and countermarches as well as they could from Durbeyfield, their cause, and from Abraham, and from themselves; and so they approached by degrees their own door, the head of the family bursting suddenly into his (Abraham) former refrain as he (Abraham) drew near, as if to fortify his (Abraham) soul at sight of the smallness of his (Abraham) present residence--

``I've got a fam--ily vault at Kingsbere!'' (he)

``Hush--don't be so silly, Jacky,'' (wife)
said his (Abraham) wife.
``Yours is not the only family that was of `count in wold days. Look at the Anktells, and Horseys, and the Tringhams themselves--gone to seed a`most as much as you--though you was bigger folks than they, that's true. Thank God, I was never of no family, and have nothing to be ashamed of in that way!'' (unknown)

``Don't you be so sure o' that. From you nater `tis my belief you've disgraced yourselves more than any o' us, and was kings and queens outright at one time.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess turned the subject by saying what was far more prominent in her (Tess) own mind at the moment than thoughts of her (Tess) ancestry--

``I am afraid father won't be able to take the journey with the beehives to-morrow so early.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

``I? I shall be all right in an hour or two,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Durbeyfield.

It was eleven o'clock before the family were all in bed, and two o'clock next morning was the latest hour for starting with the beehives if they were to be delivered to the retailers in Casterbridge before the Saturday market began, the way thither lying by bad roads over a distance of between twenty and thirty miles, and the horse and waggon being of the slowest. At half-past one Mrs Durbeyfield came into the large bedroom where Tess and all her (Tess) little brothers and sisters slept.

``The poor man can't go,'' (she)
she (Tess) said to her (Tess) eldest daughter, whose great eyes had opened the moment her (Tess) mother's hand touched the door.

Tess sat up in bed, lost in a vague interspace between a dream and this information.

``But somebody must go,'' (she)
she (Tess) replied.
``It is late for the hives already. Swarming will soon be over for the year; and it we put off taking 'em till next week's market the call for 'em will be past, and they'll be thrown on our hands.'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)

Mrs Durbeyfield looked unequal to the emergency.

``Some young feller, perhaps, would go? One of them who were so much after dancing with `ee yesterday,'' (she)
she (Durbeyfield) presently suggested.

``O no--I wouldn't have it for the world!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
declared Tess proudly.
``And letting everybody know the reason--such a thing to be ashamed of! I think _I_ could go if Abraham could go with me to kip me company.'' (mother)

Her (Tess) mother at length agreed to this arrangement. Little Abraham was aroused from his (Abraham) deep sleep in a corner of the same apartment, and made to put on his (Abraham) clothes while still mentally in the other world. Meanwhile Tess had hastily dressed herself; and the twain, lighting a lantern, went out to the stable. The rickety little waggon was already laden, and the girl led out the horse, Prince, only a degree less rickety than the vehicle.

The poor creature looked wonderingly round at the night, at the lantern, at their two figures, as if he (Prince) could not believe that at that hour, when every living thing was intended to be in shelter and at rest, he (Prince) was called upon to go out and labour. They put a stock of candle-ends into the lantern, hung the latter to the off-side of the load, and directed the horse onward, walking at his (Prince) shoulder at first during the uphill parts of the way, in order not to overload an animal of so little vigour. To cheer themselves as well as they could, they made an artificial morning with the lantern, some bread and butter, and their own conversation, the real morning being far from come. Abraham, as he (Abraham) more fully awoke -LRB-for he (Abraham) had moved in a sort of trance so far-RRB-, began to talk of the strange shapes assumed by the various dark objects against the sky; of this tree that looked like a raging tiger springing from a lair; of that which resembled a giant's head.

When they had passed the little town of Stourcastle, dumbly somnolent under its thick brown thatch, they reached higher ground. Still higher, on their left, the elevation called Bulbarrow, or Bealbarrow, well-nigh the highest in South Wessex, swelled into the sky, engirdled by its earthen trenches. From hereabout the long road was fairly level for some distance onward. They mounted in front of the waggon, and Abraham grew reflective.

``Tess!'' (he)
he (Abraham) said in a preparatory tone, after a silence.

``Yes, Abraham.'' (unknown)

``Bain't you glad that we've become gentlefolk?'' (unknown)

``Not particular glad.'' (unknown)

``But you be glad that you 'm going to marry a gentleman?'' (unknown)

``What?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess, lifting her (Tess) face.

``That our great relation will help `ee to marry a gentleman.'' (unknown)

``I? Our great relation? We have no such relation. What has put that into your head?'' (unknown)

``I heard 'em talking about it up at Rolliver's when I went to find father. There's a rich lady of our family out at Trantridge, and mother said that if you claimed kin with the lady, she (lady)'d put `ee in the way of marrying a gentleman.'' (sister)

His (Abraham) sister became abruptly still, and lapsed into a pondering silence. Abraham talked on, rather for the pleasure of utterance than for audition, so that his (Abraham) sister's abstraction was of no account. He (Abraham) leant back against the hives, and with upturned face made observations on the stars, whose cold pulses were beating amid the black hollows above, in serene dissociation from these two wisps of human life. He (Abraham) asked how far away those twinklers were, and whether God was on the other side of them. But ever and anon his (God) childish prattle recurred to what impressed his (God) imagination even more deeply than the wonders of creation. If Tess were made rich by marrying a gentleman, would she (Tess) have money enough to buy a spyglass so large that it would draw the stars as near to her (Tess) as Nettlecombe-Tout?

The renewed subject, which seemed to have impregnated the whole family, filled Tess with impatience.

``Never mind that now!'' (she)
she (Tess) exclaimed.

``Did you say the stars were worlds, Tess?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``All like ours?'' (unknown)

``I don't know; but I think so. They sometimes seem to be like the apples on our stubbard-tree. Most of them splendid and sound--a few blighted.'' (unknown)

``Which do we live on--a splendid one or a blighted one?'' (unknown)

``A blighted one.'' (unknown)

''`Tis very unlucky that we didn't pitch on a sound one, when there were so many more of 'em!'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Is it like that REALLY, Tess?'' (Abraham)
said Abraham, turning to her (Tess) much impressed, on reconsideration of this rare information.
``How would it have been if we had pitched on a sound one?'' (unknown)

``Well, father wouldn't have coughed and creeped about as he (father) does, and wouldn't have got too tipsy to go on this journey; and mother wouldn't have been always washing, and never getting finished.'' (unknown)

``And you would have been a rich lady ready-made, and not have had to be made rich by marrying a gentleman?'' (unknown)

``O Aby, don't--don't talk of that any more!'' (Abraham)

Left to his (Abraham) reflections Abraham soon grew drowsy. Tess was not skilful in the management of a horse, but she (Tess) thought that she (Tess) could take upon herself the entire conduct of the load for the present and allow Abraham to go to sleep if he (Abraham) wished to do so. She (Tess) made him (Abraham) a sort of nest in front of the hives, in such a manner that he (Abraham) could not fall, and, taking the reins into her (Tess) own hands, jogged on as before.

Prince required but slight attention, lacking energy for superfluous movements of any sort. With no longer a companion to distract her (Tess), Tess fell more deeply into reverie than ever, her (Tess) back leaning against the hives. The mute procession past her (Tess) shoulders of trees and hedges became attached to fantastic scenes outside reality, and the occasional heave of the wind became the sigh of some immense sad soul, conterminous with the universe in space, and with history in time.

Then, examining the mesh of events in her (Tess) own life, she (Tess) seemed to see the vanity of her (Tess) father's pride; the gentlemanly suitor awaiting herself in her (Tess) mother's fancy; to see him (father) as a grimacing personage, laughing at her (Tess) poverty and her (Tess) shrouded knightly ancestry. Everything grew more and more extravagant, and she (Tess) no longer knew how time passed. A sudden jerk shook her (Tess) in her (Tess) seat, and Tess awoke from the sleep into which she (Tess), too, had fallen.

They were a long way further on than when she (Tess) had lost consciousness, and the waggon had stopped. A hollow groan, unlike anything she (Tess) had ever heard in her (Tess) life, came from the front, followed by a shout of

``Hoi there!'' (she)

The lantern hanging at her (Tess) waggon had gone out, but another was shining in her (Tess) face--much brighter than her (Tess) own had been. Something terrible had happened. The harness was entangled with an object which blocked the way.

In consternation Tess jumped down, and discovered the dreadful truth. The groan had proceeded from her (Tess) father's poor horse Prince. The morning mail-cart, with its two noiseless wheels, speeding along these lanes like an arrow, as it always did, had driven into her (Tess) slow and unlighted equipage. The pointed shaft of the cart had entered the breast of the unhappy Prince like a sword, and from the wound his (Prince) life's blood was spouting in a stream, and falling with a hiss into the road.

In her (Tess) despair Tess sprang forward and put her (Tess) hand upon the hole, with the only result that she (Tess) became splashed from face to skirt with the crimson drops. Then she (Tess) stood helplessly looking on. Prince also stood firm and motionless as long as he (Prince) could; till he (Prince) suddenly sank down in a heap.

By this time the mail-cart man had joined her (Tess), and began dragging and unharnessing the hot form of Prince. But he (Prince) was already dead, and, seeing that nothing more could be done immediately, the mail-cart man returned to his (man) own animal, which was uninjured.

``You was on the wrong side,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``I am bound to go on with the mail-bags, so that the best thing for you to do is bide here with your load. I'll send somebody to help you as soon as I can. It is getting daylight, and you have nothing to fear.'' (He)

He (man) mounted and sped on his (man) way; while Tess stood and waited. The atmosphere turned pale, the birds shook themselves in the hedges, arose, and twittered; the lane showed all its white features, and Tess showed hers, still whiter. The huge pool of blood in front of her (Tess) was already assuming the iridescence of coagulation; and when the sun rose a hundred prismatic hues were reflected from it. Prince lay alongside, still and stark; his (Prince) eyes half open, the hole in his (Prince) chest looking scarcely large enough to have let out all that had animated him (Prince).

''`Tis all my doing--all mine!'' (him)
the girl cried, gazing at the spectacle.
``No excuse for me--none. What will mother and father live on now? Aby, Aby!'' (She)
She (girl) shook the child, who had slept soundly through the whole disaster.
``We can't go on with our load--Prince is killed!'' (Abraham)

When Abraham realized all, the furrows of fifty years were extemporized on his (Abraham) young face.

``Why, I danced and laughed only yesterday!'' (she)
she (girl) went on to herself.
``To think that I was such a fool!'' (unknown)

''`Tis because we be on a blighted star, and not a sound one, isn't it, Tess?'' (Abraham)
murmured Abraham through his (Abraham) tears.

In silence they waited through an interval which seemed endless. At length a sound, and an approaching object, proved to them that the driver of the mail-car had been as good as his (driver) word. A farmer's man from near Stourcastle came up, leading a strong cob. He (man) was harnessed to the waggon of beehives in the place of Prince, and the load taken on towards Casterbridge.

The evening of the same day saw the empty waggon reach again the spot of the accident. Prince had lain there in the ditch since the morning; but the place of the blood-pool was still visible in the middle of the road, though scratched and scraped over by passing vehicles. All that was left of Prince was now hoisted into the waggon he (Prince) had formerly hauled, and with his (Prince) hoofs in the air, and his (Prince) shoes shining in the setting sunlight, he (Prince) retraced the eight or nine miles to Marlott.

Tess had gone back earlier. How to break the news was more than she (Tess) could think. It was a relief to her (Tess) tongue to find from the faces of her (Tess) parents that they already knew of their loss, though this did not lessen the self-reproach which she (Tess) continued to heap upon herself for her (Tess) negligence.

But the very shiftlessness of the household rendered the misfortune a less terrifying one to them than it would have been to a thriving family, though in the present case it meant ruin, and in the other it would only have meant inconvenience. In the Durbeyfield countenances there was nothing of the red wrath that would have burnt upon the girl from parents more ambitious for her (girl) welfare. Nobody blamed Tess as she (Tess) blamed herself.

When it was discovered that the knacker and tanner would give only a very few shillings for Prince's carcase because of his (Prince) decrepitude, Durbeyfield rose to the occasion.

``No,'' (he)
said he (Prince) stoically, ``I won't sell his (fool) old body. When we d
``Urbervilles was knights in the land, we didn't sell our chargers for cat's meat. Let 'em keep their shillings! He (fool)'ve served me well in his (fool) lifetime, and I won't part from him (fool) now.'' (He)

He (Prince) worked harder the next day in digging a grave for Prince in the garden than he (Prince) had worked for months to grow a crop for his (Prince) family. When the hole was ready, Durbeyfield and his (Prince) wife tied a rope round the horse and dragged him (Prince) up the path towards it, the children following in funeral train. Abraham and ``Liza-Lu sobbed, Hope and Modesty discharged their griefs in loud blares which echoed from the walls; and when Prince was tumbled in they gathered round the grave. The bread-winner had been taken away from them; what would they do?

``Is he (Prince) gone to heaven?'' (Abraham)
asked Abraham, between the sobs.

Then Durbeyfield began to shovel in the earth, and the children cried anew. All except Tess. Her (Tess) face was dry and pale, as though she (Tess) regarded herself in the light of a murderess.

V

The haggling business, which had mainly depended on the horse, became disorganized forthwith. Distress, if not penury, loomed in the distance. Durbeyfield was what was locally called a slack-twisted fellow; he (fellow) had good strength to work at times; but the times could not be relied on to coincide with the hours of requirement; and, having been unaccustomed to the regular toil of the day-labourer, he (fellow) was not particularly persistent when they did so coincide.

Tess, meanwhile, as the one who had dragged her (Tess) parents into this quagmire, was silently wondering what she (Tess) could do to help them out of it; and then her (Tess) mother broached her (Tess) scheme.

``We must take the ups wi' the downs, Tess,'' (she)
said she (Tess); ``and never could your high blood have been found out at a more called-for moment. You must try your friends. Do ye know that there is a very rich Mrs d
``Urberville living on the outskirts o' The Chase, who must be our relation? You must go to her (Mrs) and claim kin, and ask for some help in our trouble.'' (unknown)

``I shouldn't care to do that,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
says Tess.
``If there is such a lady, `twould be enough for us if she (lady) were friendly--not to expect her (lady) to give us help.'' (unknown)

``You could win her (lady) round to do anything, my dear. Besides, perhaps there's more in it than you know of. I've heard what I've heard, good-now.'' (she)

The oppressive sense of the harm she (Tess) had done led Tess to be more deferential than she (Tess) might otherwise have been to the maternal wish; but she (Tess) could not understand why her (Tess) mother should find such satisfaction in contemplating an enterprise of, to her (Tess), such doubtful profit. Her (Tess) mother might have made inquiries, and have discovered that this Mrs d``Urberville was a lady of unequalled virtues and charity. But Tess's pride made the part of poor relation one of particular distaste to her (Tess).

``I'd rather try to get work,'' (she)
she (Mrs) murmured.

``Durbeyfield, you can settle it,'' (wife)
said his (Tess) wife, turning to where he (Tess) sat in the background.
``If you say she (Tess) ought to go, she (Tess) will go.'' (unknown)

``I don't like my children going and making themselves beholden to strange kin,'' (he)
murmured he (Tess).
``I'm the head of the noblest branch o' the family, and I ought to live up to it.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

His (Tess) reasons for staying away were worse to Tess than her (Tess) own objections to going.

``Well, as I killed the horse, mother,'' (she)
she (Tess) said mournfully,
``I suppose I ought to do something. I don't mind going and seeing her (mother), but you must leave it to me about asking for help. And don't go thinking about her (mother) making a match for me--it is silly.'' (she)

``Very well said, Tess!'' (father)
observed her (Tess) father sententiously.

``Who said I had such a thought?'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)
asked Joan.

``I fancy it is in your mind, mother. But I'll go.'' (she)

Rising early next day she (Tess) walked to the hill-town called Shaston, and there took advantage of a van which twice in the week ran from Shaston eastward to Chaseborough, passing near Trantridge, the parish in which the vague and mysterious Mrs d``Urberville had her (mother) residence.

Tess Durbeyfield's route on this memorable morning lay amid the north-eastern undulations of the Vale in which she (mother) had been born, and in which her (mother) life had unfolded. The Vale of Blackmoor was to her (mother) the world, and its inhabitants the races thereof. From the gates and stiles of Marlott she (mother) had looked down its length in the wondering days of infancy, and what had been mystery to her (mother) then was not much less than mystery to her (mother) now. She (mother) had seen daily from her (mother) chamber-window towers, villages, faint white mansions; above all, the town of Shaston standing majestically on its height; its windows shining like lamps in the evening sun. She (mother) had hardly ever visited the place, only a small tract even of the Vale and its environs being known to her (mother) by close inspection. Much less had she (mother) been far outside the valley. Every contour of the surrounding hills was as personal to her (mother) as that of her (mother) relatives' faces; but for what lay beyond, her (mother) judgment was dependent on the teaching of the village school, where she (mother) had held a leading place at the time of her (mother) leaving, a year or two before this date.

In those early days she (mother) had been much loved by others of her (mother) own sex and age, and had used to be seen about the village as one of three--all nearly of the same year--walking home from school side by side; Tess the middle one--in a pink print pinafore, of a finely reticulated pattern, worn over a stuff frock that had lost its original colour for a nondescript tertiary--marching on upon long stalky legs, in tight stockings which had little ladder-like holes at the knees, torn by kneeling in the roads and banks in search of vegetable and mineral treasures; her (Tess) then earth-coloured hair hanging like pot-hooks; the arms of the two outside girls resting round the waist of Tess; her (Tess) arms on the shoulders of the two supporters.

As Tess grew older, and began to see how matters stood, she (Tess) felt quite a Malthusian towards her (Tess) mother for thoughtlessly giving her (Tess) so many little sisters and brothers, when it was such a trouble to nurse and provide for them. Her (nurse) mother's intelligence was that of a happy child: Joan Durbeyfield was simply an additional one, and that not the eldest, to her (Durbeyfield) own long family of waiters on Providence.

However, Tess became humanely beneficent towards the small ones, and to help them as much as possible she (Tess) used, as soon as she (Tess) left school, to lend a hand at haymaking or harvesting on neighbouring farms; or, by preference, at milking or butter-making processes, which she (Tess) had learnt when her (Tess) father had owned cows; and being deft-fingered it was a kind of work in which she (Tess) excelled.

Every day seemed to throw upon her (Tess) young shoulders more of the family burdens, and that Tess should be the representative of the Durbeyfields at the d``Urberville mansion came as a thing of course. In this instance it must be admitted that the Durbeyfields were putting their fairest side outward.

She (Tess) alighted from the van at Trantridge Cross, and ascended on foot a hill in the direction of the district known as The Chase, on the borders of which, as she (Tess) had been informed, Mrs d``Urberville's seat, The Slopes, would be found. It was not a manorial home in the ordinary sense, with fields, and pastures, and a grumbling farmer, out of whom the owner had to squeeze an income for himself and his (owner) family by hook or by crook. It was more, far more; a country-house built for enjoyment pure and simple, with not an acre of troublesome land attached to it beyond what was required for residential purposes, and for a little fancy farm kept in hand by the owner, and tended by a bailiff.

The crimson brick lodge came first in sight, up to its eaves in dense evergreens. Tess thought this was the mansion itself till, passing through the side wicket with some trepidation, and onward to a point at which the drive took a turn, the house proper stood in full view. It was of recent erection--indeed almost new--and of the same rich red colour that formed such a contrast with the evergreens of the lodge. Far behind the corner of the house--which rose like a geranium bloom against the subdued colours around--stretched the soft azure landscape of The Chase--a truly venerable tract of forest land, one of the few remaining woodlands in England of undoubted primaeval date, wherein Druidical mistletoe was still found on aged oaks, and where enormous yew-trees, not planted by the hand of man grew as they had grown when they were pollarded for bows. All this sylvan antiquity, however, though visible from The Slopes, was outside the immediate boundaries of the estate.

Everything on this snug property was bright, thriving, and well kept; acres of glass-houses stretched down the inclines to the copses at their feet. Everything looked like money--like the last coin issued from the Mint. The stables, partly screened by Austrian pines and evergreen oaks, and fitted with every late appliance, were as dignified as Chapels-of-Ease. On the extensive lawn stood an ornamental tent, its door being towards her (its).

Simple Tess Durbeyfield stood at gaze, in a half-alarmed attitude, on the edge of the gravel sweep. Her (Durbeyfield) feet had brought her (Durbeyfield) onward to this point before she (Durbeyfield) had quite realized where she (Durbeyfield) was; and now all was contrary to her (Durbeyfield) expectation.

``I thought we were an old family; but this is all new!'' (she)
she (Mrs) said, in her (Mrs) artlessness. She (Mrs) wished that she (Mrs) had not fallen in so readily with her (Mrs) mother's plans for
``claiming kin,'' (mother)
and had endeavoured to gain assistance nearer home.

The d``Urbervilles--or Stoke-d``Urbervilles, as they at first called themselves--who owned all this, were a somewhat unusual family to find in such an old-fashioned part of the country. Parson Tringham had spoken truly when he (Parson) said that our shambling John Durbeyfield was the only really lineal representative of the old d``Urberville family existing in the county, or near it; he (Parson) might have added, what he (Parson) knew very well, that the Stoke-d``Urbervilles were no more d``Urbervilles of the true tree then he (Parson) was himself. Yet it must be admitted that this family formed a very good stock whereon to regraft a name which sadly wanted such renovation.

When old Mr Simon Stoke, latterly deceased, had made his (Stoke) fortune as an honest merchant -LRB-some said money-lender-RRB- in the North, he (Stoke) decided to settle as a county man in the South of England, out of hail of his (Stoke) business district; and in doing this he (Stoke) felt the necessity of recommencing with a name that would not too readily identify him (Stoke) with the smart tradesman of the past, and that would be less commonplace than the original bald, stark words. Conning for an hour in the British Museum the pages of works devoted to extinct, half-extinct, obscured, and ruined families appertaining to the quarter of England in which he (Stoke) proposed to settle, he (Stoke) considered that _d``Urberville_ looked and sounded as well as any of them: and d``Urberville accordingly was annexed to his (Stoke) own name for himself and his (Stoke) heirs eternally. Yet he (Stoke) was not an extravagant-minded man in this, and in constructing his (Stoke) family tree on the new basis was duly reasonable in framing his (Stoke) inter-marriages and aristocratic links, never inserting a single title above a rank of strict moderation.

Of this work of imagination poor Tess and her (Tess) parents were naturally in ignorance--much to their discomfiture; indeed, the very possibility of such annexations was unknown to them; who supposed that, though to be well-favoured might be the gift of fortune, a family name came by nature.

Tess still stood hesitating like a bather about to make his (bather) plunge, hardly knowing whether to retreat or to persevere, when a figure came forth from the dark triangular door of the tent. It was that of a tall young man, smoking.
