He (man) had an almost swarthy complexion, with full lips, badly moulded, though red and smooth, above which was a well-groomed black moustache with curled points, though his (man) age could not be more than three- or four-and-twenty. Despite the touches of barbarism in his (man) contours, there was a singular force in the gentleman's face, and in his (man) bold rolling eye.

``Well, my Beauty, what can I do for you?'' (he)
said he (father), coming forward. And perceiving that she (Mrs) stood quite confounded: ``Never mind me. I am Mr d
``Urberville. Have you come to see me or my mother?'' (unknown)

This embodiment of a d``Urberville and a namesake differed even more from what Tess had expected than the house and grounds had differed. She (Tess) had dreamed of an aged and dignified face, the sublimation of all the d``Urberville lineaments, furrowed with incarnate memories representing in hieroglyphic the centuries of her (Tess) family's and England's history. But she (Tess) screwed herself up to the work in hand, since she (Tess) could not get out of it, and answered--

``I came to see your mother, sir.'' (she)

``I am afraid you cannot see her (mother)--she (mother) is an invalid,'' (the representative)
replied the present representative of the spurious house; for this was Mr Alec, the only son of the lately deceased gentleman.
``Cannot I answer your purpose? What is the business you wish to see her (mother) about?'' (unknown)

``It isn't business--it is--I can hardly say what!'' (unknown)

``Pleasure?'' (unknown)

``Oh no. Why, sir, if I tell you, it will seem--'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess's sense of a certain ludicrousness in her (Tess) errand was now so strong that, notwithstanding her (Tess) awe of him (gentleman), and her (Tess) general discomfort at being here, her (Tess) rosy lips curved towards a smile, much to the attraction of the swarthy Alexander.

``It is so very foolish,'' (she)
she (Tess) stammered;
``I fear can't tell you!'' (she)

``Never mind; I like foolish things. Try again, my dear,'' (he)
said he (Alexander) kindly.

``Mother asked me to come,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
Tess continued;
``and, indeed, I was in the mind to do so myself likewise. But I did not think it would be like this. I came, sir, to tell you that we are of the same family as you.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

``Ho! Poor relations?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Stokes?'' (unknown)

``No; d'Urbervilles.'' (unknown)

``Ay, ay; I mean d'Urbervilles.'' (unknown)

``Our names are worn away to Durbeyfield; but we have several proofs that we are d

``Urbervilles. Antiquarians hold we are,--and--and we have an old seal, marked with a ramping lion on a shield, and a castle over him (Stokes). And we have a very old silver spoon, round in the bowl like a little ladle, and marked with the same castle. But it is so worn that mother uses it to stir the pea-soup.'' (unknown)

``A castle argent is certainly my crest,'' (he)
said he (Alexander) blandly.
``And my arms a lion rampant.'' (unknown)

``And so mother said we ought to make ourselves beknown to you--as we've lost our horse by a bad accident, and are the oldest branch o' the family.'' (unknown)

``Very kind of your mother, I'm sure. And I, for one, don't regret her (mother) step.'' (Alec)
Alec looked at Tess as he (Alec) spoke, in a way that made her (Tess) blush a little.
``And so, my pretty girl, you've come on a friendly visit to us, as relations?'' (unknown)

``I suppose I have,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
faltered Tess, looking uncomfortable again.

``Well--there's no harm in it. Where do you live? What are you?'' (She)

She (Tess) gave him (Alec) brief particulars; and responding to further inquiries told him (Alec) that she (Tess) was intending to go back by the same carrier who had brought her (Tess).

``It is a long while before he (us) returns past Trantridge Cross. Supposing we walk round the grounds to pass the time, my pretty Coz?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess wished to abridge her (Tess) visit as much as possible; but the young man was pressing, and she (Tess) consented to accompany him (man). He (man) conducted her (Tess) about the lawns, and flower-beds, and conservatories; and thence to the fruit-garden and greenhouses, where he (man) asked her (Tess) if she (Tess) liked strawberries.

``Yes,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess,
``when they come.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

``They are already here.'' (unknown)
D``Urberville began gathering specimens of the fruit for her (girl), handing them back to her (girl) as he (Coz) stooped; and, presently, selecting a specially fine product of the
``British Queen'' (unknown)
variety, he (man) stood up and held it by the stem to her (Tess) mouth.

``No--no!'' (she)
she (Tess) said quickly, putting her (Tess) fingers between his (man) hand and her (Tess) lips.
``I would rather take it in my own hand.'' (unknown)

``Nonsense!'' (he)
he (man) insisted; and in a slight distress she (Tess) parted her (Tess) lips and took it in.

They had spent some time wandering desultorily thus, Tess eating in a half-pleased, half-reluctant state whatever d``Urberville offered her (Queen). When she (Queen) could consume no more of the strawberries he (Coz) filled her (Queen) little basket with them; and then the two passed round to the rose-trees, whence he (Coz) gathered blossoms and gave her (Queen) to put in her (Queen) bosom. She (Queen) obeyed like one in a dream, and when she (Queen) could affix no more he (Coz) himself tucked a bud or two into her (Queen) hat, and heaped her (Queen) basket with others in the prodigality of his (Coz) bounty. At last, looking at his (Coz) watch, he (Coz) said,

``Now, by the time you have had something to eat, it will be time for you to leave, if you want to catch the carrier to Shaston. Come here, and I'll see what grub I can find.'' (Stoke)

Stoke d``Urberville took her (Urberville) back to the lawn and into the tent, where he (Coz) left her (Urberville), soon reappearing with a basket of light luncheon, which he (Coz) put before her (Urberville) himself. It was evidently the gentleman's wish not to be disturbed in this pleasant _tte--tte_ by the servantry.

``Do you mind my smoking?'' (he)
he (man) asked.

``Oh, not at all, sir.'' (He)

He (man) watched her (Tess) pretty and unconscious munching through the skeins of smoke that pervaded the tent, and Tess Durbeyfield did not divine, as she (Durbeyfield) innocently looked down at the roses in her (Durbeyfield) bosom, that there behind the blue narcotic haze was potentially the

``tragic mischief'' (she)
of her (Durbeyfield) drama--one who stood fair to be the blood-red ray in the spectrum of her (Durbeyfield) young life. She (Durbeyfield) had an attribute which amounted to a disadvantage just now; and it was this that caused Alec d``Urberville's eyes to rivet themselves upon her (Urberville). It was a luxuriance of aspect, a fulness of growth, which made her (Urberville) appear more of a woman than she (Urberville) really was. She (Urberville) had inherited the feature from her (Urberville) mother without the quality it denoted. It had troubled her (Urberville) mind occasionally, till her (Urberville) companions had said that it was a fault which time would cure.

She (Urberville) soon had finished her (Urberville) lunch.

``Now I am going home, sir,'' (she)
she (Durbeyfield) said, rising.

``And what do they call you?'' (he)
he (Alec) asked, as he (Alec) accompanied her (Durbeyfield) along the drive till they were out of sight of the house.

``Tess Durbeyfield, down at Marlott.'' (unknown)

``And you say your people have lost their horse?'' (unknown)

``I--killed him (Urberville)!'' (she)
she (Durbeyfield) answered, her (Durbeyfield) eyes filling with tears as she (Durbeyfield) gave particulars of Prince's death.
``And I don't know what to do for father on account of it!'' (unknown)

``I must think if I cannot do something. My mother must find a berth for you. But, Tess, no nonsense about

``d'Urberville';--`Durbeyfield' only, you know--quite another name.'' (unknown)

``I wish for no better, sir,'' (she)
said she (Durbeyfield) with something of dignity.

For a moment--only for a moment--when they were in the turning of the drive, between the tall rhododendrons and conifers, before the lodge became visible, he (Prince) inclined his (Prince) face towards her (Durbeyfield) as if--but, no: he (Prince) thought better of it, and let her (Durbeyfield) go.

Thus the thing began. Had she (Durbeyfield) perceived this meeting's import she (Durbeyfield) might have asked why she (Durbeyfield) was doomed to be seen and coveted that day by the wrong man, and not by some other man, the right and desired one in all respects--as nearly as humanity can supply the right and desired; yet to him (man) who amongst her (Durbeyfield) acquaintance might have approximated to this kind, she (Durbeyfield) was but a transient impression, half forgotten.

In the ill-judged execution of the well-judged plan of things the call seldom produces the comer, the man to love rarely coincides with the hour for loving. Nature does not often say

``See!'' (creature)
to her (Durbeyfield) poor creature at a time when seeing can lead to happy doing; or reply
``Here!'' (creature)
to a body's cry of
``Where?'' (unknown)
till the hide-and-seek has become an irksome, outworn game. We may wonder whether at the acme and summit of the human progress these anachronisms will be corrected by a finer intuition, a closer interaction of the social machinery than that which now jolts us round and along; but such completeness is not to be prophesied, or even conceived as possible. Enough that in the present case, as in millions, it was not the two halves of a perfect whole that confronted each other at the perfect moment; a missing counterpart wandered independently about the earth waiting in crass obtuseness till the late time came. Out of which maladroit delay sprang anxieties, disappointments, shocks, catastrophes, and passing-strange destinies.

When d``Urberville got back to the tent he (father) sat down astride on a chair, reflecting, with a pleased gleam in his (father) face. Then he (father) broke into a loud laugh.

``Well, I'm damned! What a funny thing! Ha-ha-ha! And what a crumby girl!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

VI

Tess went down the hill to Trantridge Cross, and inattentively waited to take her (Tess) seat in the van returning from Chaseborough to Shaston. She (Tess) did not know what the other occupants said to her (Tess) as she (Tess) entered, though she (Tess) answered them; and when they had started anew she (Tess) rode along with an inward and not an outward eye.

One among her (Tess) fellow-travellers addressed her (Tess) more pointedly than any had spoken before:

``Why, you be quite a posy! And such roses in early June!'' (fellow-travellers)

Then she (Tess) became aware of the spectacle she (Tess) presented to their surprised vision: roses at her (Tess) breasts; roses in her (Tess) hat; roses and strawberries in her (Tess) basket to the brim. She (Tess) blushed, and said confusedly that the flowers had been given to her (Tess). When the passengers were not looking she (Tess) stealthily removed the more prominent blooms from her (Tess) hat and placed them in the basket, where she (Tess) covered them with her (Tess) handkerchief. Then she (Tess) fell to reflecting again, and in looking downwards a thorn of the rose remaining in her (Tess) breast accidentally pricked her (Tess) chin. Like all the cottagers in Blackmoor Vale, Tess was steeped in fancies and prefigurative superstitions; she (Tess) thought this an ill omen--the first she (Tess) had noticed that day.

The van travelled only so far as Shaston, and there were several miles of pedestrian descent from that mountain-town into the vale to Marlott. Her (Tess) mother had advised her (Tess) to stay here for the night, at the house of a cottage-woman they knew, if she (Tess) should feel too tired to come on; and this Tess did, not descending to her (Tess) home till the following afternoon.

When she (Tess) entered the house she (Tess) perceived in a moment from her (Tess) mother's triumphant manner that something had occurred in the interim.

``Oh yes; I know all about it! I told `ee it would be all right, and now `tis proved!'' (unknown)

``Since I've been away? What has?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess rather wearily.

Her (Tess) mother surveyed the girl up and down with arch approval, and went on banteringly:

``So you've brought 'em round!'' (the girl)

``How do you know, mother?'' (unknown)

``I've had a letter.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess then remembered that there would have been time for this.

``They say--Mrs d

``Urberville says--that she (Urberville) wants you to look after a little fowl-farm which is her (Urberville) hobby. But this is only her (Urberville) artful way of getting `ee there without raising your hopes. She (Urberville)'s going to own `ee as kin--that's the meaning o`t.'' (unknown)

``But I didn't see her (Urberville).'' (kin)

``You zid somebody, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``I saw her (Urberville) son.'' (unknown)

``And did he (son) own `ee?'' (unknown)

``Well--he (son) called me Coz.'' (unknown)

``An' I knew it! Jacky--he (son) called her (Urberville) Coz!'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)
cried Joan to her (Joan) husband.
``Well, he (son) spoke to his (son) mother, of course, and she (mother) do want `ee there.'' (unknown)

``But I don't know that I am apt at tending fowls,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said the dubious Tess.

``Then I don't know who is apt. You've be'n born in the business, and brought up in it. They that be born in a business always know more about it than any `prentice. Besides, that's only just a show of something for you to do, that you midn't feel beholden.'' (unknown)

``I don't altogether think I ought to go,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess thoughtfully.
``Who wrote the letter? Will you let me look at it?'' (unknown)

``Mrs d

``Urberville wrote it. Here it is.'' (the person)

The letter was in the third person, and briefly informed Mrs Durbeyfield that her (Durbeyfield) daughter's services would be useful to that lady in the management of her (Durbeyfield) poultry-farm, that a comfortable room would be provided for her (Durbeyfield) if she (Durbeyfield) could come, and that the wages would be on a liberal scale if they liked her (Durbeyfield).

``Oh--that's all!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``You couldn't expect her (Urberville) to throw her (Urberville) arms round `ee, an' to kiss and to coll `ee all at once.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess looked out of the window.

``I would rather stay here with father and you,'' (she)
she (Tess) said.

``But why?'' (unknown)

``I'd rather not tell you why, mother; indeed, I don't quite know why.'' (she)

A week afterwards she (Tess) came in one evening from an unavailing search for some light occupation in the immediate neighbourhood. Her (Tess) idea had been to get together sufficient money during the summer to purchase another horse. Hardly had she (Tess) crossed the threshold before one of the children danced across the room, saying,

``The gentleman's been here!'' (the children)

Her (Tess) mother hastened to explain, smiles breaking from every inch of her (Tess) person. Mrs d``Urberville's son had called on horseback, having been riding by chance in the direction of Marlott. He (son) had wished to know, finally, in the name of his (son) mother, if Tess could really come to manage the old lady's fowl-farm or not; the lad who had hitherto superintended the birds having proved untrustworthy. ``Mr d

``Urberville says you must be a good girl if you are at all as you appear; he (Mr) knows you must be worth your weight in gold. He (Mr) is very much interested in `ee--truth to tell.'' (Mr)

Tess seemed for the moment really pleased to hear that she (Tess) had won such high opinion from a stranger when, in her (Tess) own esteem, she (Tess) had sunk so low.

``It is very good of him (Mr) to think that,'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured;
``and if I was quite sure how it would be living there, I would go any-when.'' (she)

``He (Mr) is a mighty handsome man!'' (unknown)

``I don't think so,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess coldly.

``Well, there's your chance, whether or no; and I'm sure he (Mr) wears a beautiful diamond ring!'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Abraham)
said little Abraham, brightly, from the window-bench;
``and I seed it! and it did twinkle when he (Mr) put his (Mr) hand up to his (Mr) mistarshers. Mother, why did our grand relation keep on putting his (Mr) hand up to his (Mr) mistarshers?'' (Abraham)

``Hark at that child!'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)
cried Mrs Durbeyfield, with parenthetic admiration.

``Perhaps to show his (Mr) diamond ring,'' (John/St John)
murmured Sir John, dreamily, from his (John) chair.

``I'll think it over,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess, leaving the room.

``Well, she (Mother)'s made a conquest o' the younger branch of us, straight off,'' (the matron)
continued the matron to her (Tess) husband,
``and she (Mother)'s a fool if she (Mother) don't follow it up.'' (husband)

``I don't quite like my children going away from home,'' (unknown)
said the haggler.
``As the head of the family, the rest ought to come to me.'' (unknown)

``But do let her (Mother) go, Jacky,'' (wife)
coaxed his (husband) poor witless wife.
``He (fool)'s struck wi' her (Mother)--you can see that. He (fool) called her (Mother) Coz! He (fool)'ll marry her (Mother), most likely, and make a lady of her (Mother); and then she (Mother)'ll be what her (Mother) forefathers was.'' (John Durbeyfield)

John Durbeyfield had more conceit than energy or health, and this supposition was pleasant to him (Durbeyfield).

``Well, perhaps that's what young Mr d``Urberville means,'' he (Durbeyfield) admitted;

``and sure enough he (Mr) mid have serious thoughts about improving his (Mr) blood by linking on to the old line. Tess, the little rogue! And have she (Tess) really paid 'em a visit to such an end as this?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Meanwhile Tess was walking thoughtfully among the gooseberry-bushes in the garden, and over Prince's grave. When she (Tess) came in her (Tess) mother pursued her (Tess) advantage.

``Well, what be you going to do?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked.

``I wish I had seen Mrs d'Urberville,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``I think you mid as well settle it. Then you'll see her (Mrs) soon enough.'' (father)

Her (Tess) father coughed in his (father) chair.

``I don't know what to say!'' (the girl)
answered the girl restlessly. ``It is for you to decide. I killed the old horse, and I suppose I ought to do something to get ye a new one. But--but--I don't quite like Mr d
``Urberville being there!'' (The children)

The children, who had made use of this idea of Tess being taken up by their wealthy kinsfolk -LRB-which they imagined the other family to be-RRB- as a species of dolorifuge after the death of the horse, began to cry at Tess's reluctance, and teased and reproached her (Tess) for hesitating.

``Tess won't go-o-o and be made a la-a-dy of!--no, she (Tess) says she (Tess) wo-o-on`t!'' (unknown)
they wailed, with square mouths.
``And we shan't have a nice new horse, and lots o' golden money to buy fairlings! And Tess won't look pretty in her (Tess) best cloze no mo-o-ore!'' (mother)

Her (Tess) mother chimed in to the same tune: a certain way she (Tess) had of making her (Tess) labours in the house seem heavier than they were by prolonging them indefinitely, also weighed in the argument. Her (Tess) father alone preserved an attitude of neutrality.

``I will go,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess at last.

Her (Tess) mother could not repress her (Tess) consciousness of the nuptial vision conjured up by the girl's consent.

``That's right! For such a pretty maid as `tis, this is a fine chance!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess smiled crossly.

``I hope it is a chance for earning money. It is no other kind of chance. You had better say nothing of that silly sort about parish.'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)

Mrs Durbeyfield did not promise. She (Tess) was not quite sure that she (Tess) did not feel proud enough, after the visitor's remarks, to say a good deal.

Thus it was arranged; and the young girl wrote, agreeing to be ready to set out on any day on which she (girl) might be required. She (girl) was duly informed that Mrs d``Urberville was glad of her (Urberville) decision, and that a spring-cart should be sent to meet her (Urberville) and her (Urberville) luggage at the top of the Vale on the day after the morrow, when she (Urberville) must hold herself prepared to start. Mrs d``Urberville's handwriting seemed rather masculine.

``A cart?'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)
murmured Joan Durbeyfield doubtingly.
``It might have been a carriage for her (Mrs) own kin!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Having at last taken her (Durbeyfield) course Tess was less restless and abstracted, going about her (Tess) business with some self-assurance in the thought of acquiring another horse for her (Tess) father by an occupation which would not be onerous. She (Tess) had hoped to be a teacher at the school, but the fates seemed to decide otherwise. Being mentally older than her (Tess) mother she (Tess) did not regard Mrs Durbeyfield's matrimonial hopes for her (Durbeyfield) in a serious aspect for a moment. The light-minded woman had been discovering good matches for her (woman) daughter almost from the year of her (woman) birth.

VII

On the morning appointed for her (woman) departure Tess was awake before dawn--at the marginal minute of the dark when the grove is still mute, save for one prophetic bird who sings with a clear-voiced conviction that he (Tess) at least knows the correct time of day, the rest preserving silence as if equally convinced that he (Tess) is mistaken. She (Tess) remained upstairs packing till breakfast-time, and then came down in her (Tess) ordinary week-day clothes, her (Tess) Sunday apparel being carefully folded in her (Tess) box.

Her (Tess) mother expostulated.

``You will never set out to see your folks without dressing up more the dand than that?'' (unknown)

``But I am going to work!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``Well, yes,'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)
said Mrs Durbeyfield; and in a private tone,
``at first there mid be a little pretence o't ... But I think it will be wiser of `ee to put your best side outward,'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)
she (Durbeyfield) added.

``Very well; I suppose you know best,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
replied Tess with calm abandonment.

And to please her (Tess) parent the girl put herself quite in Joan's hands, saying serenely--

``Do what you like with me, mother.'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)

Mrs Durbeyfield was only too delighted at this tractability. First she (Durbeyfield) fetched a great basin, and washed Tess's hair with such thoroughness that when dried and brushed it looked twice as much as at other times. She (Tess) tied it with a broader pink ribbon than usual. Then she (Tess) put upon her (Tess) the white frock that Tess had worn at the club-walking, the airy fulness of which, supplementing her (Tess) enlarged _coiffure_, imparted to her (Tess) developing figure an amplitude which belied her (Tess) age, and might cause her (Tess) to be estimated as a woman when she (Tess) was not much more than a child.

``I declare there's a hole in my stocking-heel!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``Never mind holes in your stockings--they don't speak! When I was a maid, so long as I had a pretty bonnet the devil might ha' found me in heels.'' (mother)

Her (Tess) mother's pride in the girl's appearance led her (Tess) to step back, like a painter from his (painter) easel, and survey her (Tess) work as a whole.

``You must zee yourself!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried.
``It is much better than you was t`other day.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

As the looking-glass was only large enough to reflect a very small portion of Tess's person at one time, Mrs Durbeyfield hung a black cloak outside the casement, and so made a large reflector of the panes, as it is the wont of bedecking cottagers to do. After this she (Durbeyfield) went downstairs to her (Durbeyfield) husband, who was sitting in the lower room.

``I'll tell `ee what `tis, Durbeyfield,'' (she)
said she (Durbeyfield) exultingly;
``he (devil)'ll never have the heart not to love her (maid). But whatever you do, don't zay too much to Tess of his (devil) fancy for her (Tess), and this chance she (Tess) has got. She (Tess) is such an odd maid that it mid zet her (Tess) against him (devil), or against going there, even now. If all goes well, I shall certainly be for making some return to pa`son at Stagfoot Lane for telling us--dear, good man!'' (she)

However, as the moment for the girl's setting out drew nigh, when the first excitement of the dressing had passed off, a slight misgiving found place in Joan Durbeyfield's mind. It prompted the matron to say that she (matron) would walk a little way--as far as to the point where the acclivity from the valley began its first steep ascent to the outer world. At the top Tess was going to be met with the spring-cart sent by the Stoke-d``Urbervilles, and her (Tess) box had already been wheeled ahead towards this summit by a lad with trucks, to be in readiness.

Seeing their mother put on her (mother) bonnet, the younger children clamoured to go with her (mother).

``I do want to walk a little-ways wi' Sissy, now she (Sissy)'s going to marry our gentleman-cousin, and wear fine cloze!'' (unknown)

``Now,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess, flushing and turning quickly,
``I'll hear no more o' that! Mother, how could you ever put such stuff into their heads?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

``Going to work, my dears, for our rich relation, and help get enough money for a new horse,'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)
said Mrs Durbeyfield pacifically.

``Goodbye, father,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess, with a lumpy throat.

``Goodbye, my maid,'' (John/St John)
said Sir John, raising his (John) head from his (John) breast as he (John) suspended his (John) nap, induced by a slight excess this morning in honour of the occasion.
``Well, I hope my young friend will like such a comely sample of his (friend) own blood. And tell`n, Tess, that being sunk, quite, from our former grandeur, I'll sell him (friend) the title--yes, sell it--and at no onreasonable figure.'' (unknown)

``Not for less than a thousand pound!'' (Lady)
cried Lady Durbeyfield.

``Tell`n--I'll take a thousand pound. Well, I'll take less, when I come to think o`t. He (friend)'ll adorn it better than a poor lammicken feller like myself can. Tell'n he (friend) shall hae it for a hundred. But I won't stand upon trifles--tell'n he (friend) shall hae it for fifty--for twenty pound! Yes, twenty pound--that's the lowest. Dammy, family honour is family honour, and I won't take a penny less!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess's eyes were too full and her (Tess) voice too choked to utter the sentiments that were in her (Tess). She (Tess) turned quickly, and went out.

So the girls and their mother all walked together, a child on each side of Tess, holding her (Tess) hand and looking at her (Tess) meditatively from time to time, as at one who was about to do great things; her (Tess) mother just behind with the smallest; the group forming a picture of honest beauty flanked by innocence, and backed by simple-souled vanity. They followed the way till they reached the beginning of the ascent, on the crest of which the vehicle from Trantridge was to receive her (Tess), this limit having been fixed to save the horse the labour of the last slope. Far away behind the first hills the cliff-like dwellings of Shaston broke the line of the ridge. Nobody was visible in the elevated road which skirted the ascent save the lad whom they had sent on before them, sitting on the handle of the barrow that contained all Tess's worldly possessions.

``Bide here a bit, and the cart will soon come, no doubt,'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)
said Mrs Durbeyfield.
``Yes, I see it yonder!'' (the boy)

It had come--appearing suddenly from behind the forehead of the nearest upland, and stopping beside the boy with the barrow. Her (Durbeyfield) mother and the children thereupon decided to go no farther, and bidding them a hasty goodbye, Tess bent her (Tess) steps up the hill.

They saw her (Tess) white shape draw near to the spring-cart, on which her (Tess) box was already placed. But before she (Tess) had quite reached it another vehicle shot out from a clump of trees on the summit, came round the bend of the road there, passed the luggage-cart, and halted beside Tess, who looked up as if in great surprise.

Her (Tess) mother perceived, for the first time, that the second vehicle was not a humble conveyance like the first, but a spick-and-span gig or dog-cart, highly varnished and equipped. The driver was a young man of three- or four-and-twenty, with a cigar between his (driver) teeth; wearing a dandy cap, drab jacket, breeches of the same hue, white neckcloth, stick-up collar, and brown driving-gloves--in short, he (driver) was the handsome, horsey young buck who had visited Joan a week or two before to get her (Joan) answer about Tess.

Mrs Durbeyfield clapped her (Durbeyfield) hands like a child. Then she (Durbeyfield) looked down, then stared again. Could she (Durbeyfield) be deceived as to the meaning of this?

``Is dat the gentleman-kinsman who'll make Sissy a lady?'' (the child)
asked the youngest child.

Meanwhile the muslined form of Tess could be seen standing still, undecided, beside this turn-out, whose owner was talking to her (Tess). Her (Tess) seeming indecision was, in fact, more than indecision: it was misgiving. She (Tess) would have preferred the humble cart. The young man dismounted, and appeared to urge her (Tess) to ascend. She (Tess) turned her (Tess) face down the hill to her (Tess) relatives, and regarded the little group. Something seemed to quicken her (Tess) to a determination; possibly the thought that she (Tess) had killed Prince. She (Tess) suddenly stepped up; he (Prince) mounted beside her (Tess), and immediately whipped on the horse. In a moment they had passed the slow cart with the box, and disappeared behind the shoulder of the hill.

Directly Tess was out of sight, and the interest of the matter as a drama was at an end, the little ones' eyes filled with tears. The youngest child said,

``I wish poor, poor Tess wasn't gone away to be a lady!'' (The child)
and, lowering the corners of his (Prince) lips, burst out crying. The new point of view was infectious, and the next child did likewise, and then the next, till the whole three of them wailed loud.

There were tears also in Joan Durbeyfield's eyes as she (Durbeyfield) turned to go home. But by the time she (Durbeyfield) had got back to the village she (Durbeyfield) was passively trusting to the favour of accident. However, in bed that night she (Durbeyfield) sighed, and her (Durbeyfield) husband asked her (Durbeyfield) what was the matter.

``Oh, I don't know exactly,'' (she)
she (Durbeyfield) said.
``I was thinking that perhaps it would ha' been better if Tess had not gone.'' (unknown)

``Oughtn't ye to have thought of that before?'' (unknown)

``Well, `tis a chance for the maid--Still, if `twere the doing again, I wouldn't let her (maid) go till I had found out whether the gentleman is really a good-hearted young man and choice over her (maid) as his (man) kinswoman.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you ought, perhaps, to ha' done that,'' (John/St John)
snored Sir John.

Joan Durbeyfield always managed to find consolation somewhere:

``Well, as one of the genuine stock, she (maid) ought to make her (maid) way with `en, if she (maid) plays her (maid) trump card aright. And if he (man) don't marry her (maid) afore he (man) will after. For that he (man)'s all afire wi' love for her (maid) any eye can see.'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)

``What's her (maid) trump card? Her (maid) d

``Urberville blood, you mean?'' (unknown)

``No, stupid; her (maid) face--as 'twas mine.'' (her)

VIII

Having mounted beside her (Durbeyfield), Alec d``Urberville drove rapidly along the crest of the first hill, chatting compliments to Tess as they went, the cart with her (Tess) box being left far behind. Rising still, an immense landscape stretched around them on every side; behind, the green valley of her (Tess) birth, before, a gray country of which she (Tess) knew nothing except from her (Tess) first brief visit to Trantridge. Thus they reached the verge of an incline down which the road stretched in a long straight descent of nearly a mile.

Ever since the accident with her (Tess) father's horse Tess Durbeyfield, courageous as she (Durbeyfield) naturally was, had been exceedingly timid on wheels; the least irregularity of motion startled her (Durbeyfield). She (Durbeyfield) began to get uneasy at a certain recklessness in her (Durbeyfield) conductor's driving.

``You will go down slow, sir, I suppose?'' (she)
she (Durbeyfield) said with attempted unconcern.

D``Urberville looked round upon her (Durbeyfield), nipped his (conductor) cigar with the tips of his (conductor) large white centre-teeth, and allowed his (conductor) lips to smile slowly of themselves.

``Why, Tess,'' (he)
he (Alec) answered, after another whiff or two,
``it isn't a brave bouncing girl like you who asks that? Why, I always go down at full gallop. There's nothing like it for raising your spirits.'' (he)

``But perhaps you need not now?'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (he)
he (Alec) said, shaking his (Alec) head,
``there are two to be reckoned with. It is not me alone. Tib has to be considered, and she (Tess) has a very queer temper.'' (he)

``Who?'' (unknown)

``Why, this mare. I fancy she (mare) looked round at me in a very grim way just then. Didn't you notice it?'' (unknown)

``Don't try to frighten me, sir,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess stiffly.

``Well, I don't. If any living man can manage this horse I can: I won't say any living man can do it--but if such has the power, I am he (man).'' (unknown)

``Why do you have such a horse?'' (unknown)

``Ah, well may you ask it! It was my fate, I suppose. Tib has killed one chap; and just after I bought her (man) she (man) nearly killed me. And then, take my word for it, I nearly killed her (man). But she (man)'s touchy still, very touchy; and one's life is hardly safe behind her (man) sometimes.'' (unknown)

They were just beginning to descend; and it was evident that the horse, whether of her (Tess) own will or of his (Alec) -LRB-the latter being the more likely-RRB-, knew so well the reckless performance expected of her (Tess) that she (Tess) hardly required a hint from behind.

Down, down, they sped, the wheels humming like a top, the dog-cart rocking right and left, its axis acquiring a slightly oblique set in relation to the line of progress; the figure of the horse rising and falling in undulations before them. Sometimes a wheel was off the ground, it seemed, for many yards; sometimes a stone was sent spinning over the hedge, and flinty sparks from the horse's hoofs outshone the daylight. The aspect of the straight road enlarged with their advance, the two banks dividing like a splitting stick; one rushing past at each shoulder.

The wind blew through Tess's white muslin to her (Tess) very skin, and her (Tess) washed hair flew out behind. She (Tess) was determined to show no open fear, but she (Tess) clutched d``Urberville's rein-arm.

``Don't touch my arm! We shall be thrown out if you do! Hold on round my waist!'' (She)

She (Tess) grasped his (them) waist, and so they reached the bottom.

``Safe, thank God, in spite of your fooling!'' (she)
said she (Tess), her (Tess) face on fire.

``Tess--fie! that's temper!'' (unknown)
said d``Urberville.

''`Tis truth.'' (unknown)

``Well, you need not let go your hold of me so thanklessly the moment you feel yourself our of danger.'' (She)

She (Tess) had not considered what she (Tess) had been doing; whether he (them) were man or woman, stick or stone, in her (Tess) involuntary hold on him (them). Recovering her (Tess) reserve, she (Tess) sat without replying, and thus they reached the summit of another declivity.

``Now then, again!'' (unknown)
said d``Urberville.

``No, no!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.
``Show more sense, do, please.'' (unknown)

``But when people find themselves on one of the highest points in the county, they must get down again,'' (he)
he (them) retorted.

He (them) loosened rein, and away they went a second time. D``Urberville turned his (God) face to her (Tess) as they rocked, and said, in playful raillery:

``Now then, put your arms round my waist again, as you did before, my Beauty.'' (unknown)

``Never!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess independently, holding on as well as she (Tess) could without touching him (them).

``Let me put one little kiss on those holmberry lips, Tess, or even on that warmed cheek, and I'll stop--on my honour, I will!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess, surprised beyond measure, slid farther back still on her (Tess) seat, at which he (them) urged the horse anew, and rocked her (Tess) the more.

``Will nothing else do?'' (she)
she (Tess) cried at length, in desperation, her (Tess) large eyes staring at him (them) like those of a wild animal. This dressing her (Tess) up so prettily by her (Tess) mother had apparently been to lamentable purpose.

``Nothing, dear Tess,'' (he)
he (them) replied.

``Oh, I don't know--very well; I don't mind!'' (she)
she (Tess) panted miserably.

He (them) drew rein, and as they slowed he (them) was on the point of imprinting the desired salute, when, as if hardly yet aware of her (Tess) own modesty, she (Tess) dodged aside. His (them) arms being occupied with the reins there was left him (them) no power to prevent her (Tess) manoeuvre.

``Now, damn it--I'll break both our necks!'' (companion)
swore her (Tess) capriciously passionate companion.
``So you can go from your word like that, you young witch, can you?'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess,
``I'll not move since you be so determined! But I--thought you would be kind to me, and protect me, as my kinsman!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

``Kinsman be hanged! Now!'' (unknown)

``But I don't want anybody to kiss me, sir!'' (she)
she (Tess) implored, a big tear beginning to roll down her (Tess) face, and the corners of her (Tess) mouth trembling in her (Tess) attempts not to cry.
``And I wouldn't ha' come if I had known!'' (He)

He (companion) was inexorable, and she (Tess) sat still, and d``Urberville gave her (witch) the kiss of mastery. No sooner had he (kinsman) done so than she (witch) flushed with shame, took out her (witch) handkerchief, and wiped the spot on her (witch) cheek that had been touched by his (kinsman) lips. His (kinsman) ardour was nettled at the sight, for the act on her (witch) part had been unconsciously done.

``You are mighty sensitive for a cottage girl!'' (the man)
said the young man.

Tess made no reply to this remark, of which, indeed, she (Tess) did not quite comprehend the drift, unheeding the snub she (Tess) had administered by her (Tess) instinctive rub upon her (Tess) cheek. She (Tess) had, in fact, undone the kiss, as far as such a thing was physically possible. With a dim sense that he (man) was vexed she (Tess) looked steadily ahead as they trotted on near Melbury Down and Wingreen, till she (Tess) saw, to her (Tess) consternation, that there was yet another descent to be undergone.

``You shall be made sorry for that!'' (he)
he (man) resumed, his (man) injured tone still remaining, as he (man) flourished the whip anew.
``Unless, that is, you agree willingly to let me do it again, and no handkerchief.'' (She)

She (Tess) sighed.

``Very well, sir!'' (she)
she (Tess) said.
``Oh--let me get my hat!'' (unknown)

At the moment of speaking her (Tess) hat had blown off into the road, their present speed on the upland being by no means slow. D``Urberville pulled up, and said he (kinsman) would get it for her (girl), but Tess was down on the other side.

She (Tess) turned back and picked up the article.

``You look prettier with it off, upon my soul, if that's possible,'' (he)
he (man) said, contemplating her (Tess) over the back of the vehicle.
``Now then, up again! What's the matter?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

The hat was in place and tied, but Tess had not stepped forward.

``No, sir,'' (she)
she (Tess) said, revealing the red and ivory of her (Tess) mouth as her (Tess) eye lit in defiant triumph;
``not again, if I know it!'' (she)

``What--you won't get up beside me?'' (unknown)

``No; I shall walk.'' (unknown)

''`Tis five or six miles yet to Trantridge.'' (unknown)

``I don't care if `tis dozens. Besides, the cart is behind.'' (unknown)

``You artful hussy! Now, tell me--didn't you make that hat blow off on purpose? I'll swear you did!'' (unknown)

Her (Tess) strategic silence confirmed his (man) suspicion.

Then d``Urberville cursed and swore at her (you), and called her (you) everything he (me) could think of for the trick. Turning the horse suddenly he (me) tried to drive back upon her (you), and so hem her (you) in between the gig and the hedge. But he (me) could not do this short of injuring her (you).

``You ought to be ashamed of yourself for using such wicked words!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
cried Tess with spirit, from the top of the hedge into which she (Tess) had scrambled.
``I don't like `ee at all! I hate and detest you! I'll go back to mother, I will!'' (unknown)

D``Urberville's bad temper cleared up at sight of hers; and he (me) laughed heartily.

``Well, I like you all the better,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``Come, let there be peace. I'll never do it any more against your will. My life upon it now!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Still Tess could not be induced to remount. She (Tess) did not, however, object to his (man) keeping his (man) gig alongside her (Tess); and in this manner, at a slow pace, they advanced towards the village of Trantridge. From time to time d``Urberville exhibited a sort of fierce distress at the sight of the tramping he (me) had driven her (mother) to undertake by his (me) misdemeanour. She (mother) might in truth have safely trusted him (me) now; but he (me) had forfeited her (mother) confidence for the time, and she (mother) kept on the ground progressing thoughtfully, as if wondering whether it would be wiser to return home. Her (mother) resolve, however, had been taken, and it seemed vacillating even to childishness to abandon it now, unless for graver reasons. How could she (mother) face her (mother) parents, get back her (mother) box, and disconcert the whole scheme for the rehabilitation of her (mother) family on such sentimental grounds?

A few minutes later the chimneys of The Slopes appeared in view, and in a snug nook to the right the poultry-farm and cottage of Tess' destination.

IX

The community of fowls to which Tess had been appointed as supervisor, purveyor, nurse, surgeon, and friend made its headquarters in an old thatched cottage standing in an enclosure that had once been a garden, but was now a trampled and sanded square. The house was overrun with ivy, its chimney being enlarged by the boughs of the parasite to the aspect of a ruined tower. The lower rooms were entirely given over to the birds, who walked about them with a proprietary air, as though the place had been built by themselves, and not by certain dusty copyholders who now lay east and west in the churchyard. The descendants of these bygone owners felt it almost as a slight to their family when the house which had so much of their affection, had cost so much of their forefathers' money, and had been in their possession for several generations before the d``Urbervilles came and built here, was indifferently turned into a fowl-house by Mrs Stoke-d``Urberville as soon as the property fell into hand according to law.

'''Twas good enough for Christians in grandfather's time,'' (generations)
they said.

The rooms wherein dozens of infants had wailed at their nursing now resounded with the tapping of nascent chicks. Distracted hens in coops occupied spots where formerly stood chairs supporting sedate agriculturists. The chimney-corner and once-blazing hearth was now filled with inverted beehives, in which the hens laid their eggs; while out of doors the plots that each succeeding householder had carefully shaped with his (householder) spade were torn by the cocks in wildest fashion.

The garden in which the cottage stood was surrounded by a wall, and could only be entered through a door.

When Tess had occupied herself about an hour the next morning in altering and improving the arrangements, according to her (Tess) skilled ideas as the daughter of a professed poulterer, the door in the wall opened and a servant in white cap and apron entered. She (Tess) had come from the manor-house.

``Mrs d``Urberville wants the fowls as usual,'' she (Tess) said; but perceiving that Tess did not quite understand, she (Tess) explained,

``Mis`ess is a old lady, and blind.'' (unknown)

``Blind!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

Almost before her (Tess) misgiving at the news could find time to shape itself she (Tess) took, under her (Tess) companion's direction, two of the most beautiful of the Hamburghs in her (Tess) arms, and followed the maid-servant, who had likewise taken two, to the adjacent mansion, which, though ornate and imposing, showed traces everywhere on this side that some occupant of its chambers could bend to the love of dumb creatures--feathers floating within view of the front, and hen-coops standing on the grass.

In a sitting-room on the ground-floor, ensconced in an armchair with her (Tess) back to the light, was the owner and mistress of the estate, a white-haired woman of not more than sixty, or even less, wearing a large cap. She (woman) had the mobile face frequent in those whose sight has decayed by stages, has been laboriously striven after, and reluctantly let go, rather than the stagnant mien apparent in persons long sightless or born blind. Tess walked up to this lady with her (Tess) feathered charges--one sitting on each arm.

``Ah, you are the young woman come to look after my birds?'' (Mrs)
said Mrs d``Urberville, recognizing a new footstep.
``I hope you will be kind to them. My bailiff tells me you are quite the proper person. Well, where are they? Ah, this is Strut! But he (bailiff) is hardly so lively to-day, is he (bailiff)? He (bailiff) is alarmed at being handled by a stranger, I suppose. And Phena too--yes, they are a little frightened--aren't you, dears? But they will soon get used to you.'' (the lady)

While the old lady had been speaking Tess and the other maid, in obedience to her (Tess) gestures, had placed the fowls severally in her (Tess) lap, and she (Tess) had felt them over from head to tail, examining their beaks, their combs, the manes of the cocks, their wings, and their claws. Her (Tess) touch enabled her (Tess) to recognize them in a moment, and to discover if a single feather were crippled or draggled. She (Tess) handled their crops, and knew what they had eaten, and if too little or too much; her (Tess) face enacting a vivid pantomime of the criticisms passing in her (Tess) mind.

The birds that the two girls had brought in were duly returned to the yard, and the process was repeated till all the pet cocks and hens had been submitted to the old woman--Hamburghs, Bantams, Cochins, Brahmas, Dorkings, and such other sorts as were in fashion just then--her (woman) perception of each visitor being seldom at fault as she (woman) received the bird upon her (woman) knees.

It reminded Tess of a Confirmation, in which Mrs d``Urberville was the bishop, the fowls the young people presented, and herself and the maid-servant the parson and curate of the parish bringing them up. At the end of the ceremony Mrs d``Urberville abruptly asked Tess, wrinkling and twitching her (Tess) face into undulations,

``Can you whistle?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

``Whistle, Ma'am?'' (unknown)

``Yes, whistle tunes.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess could whistle like most other country-girls, though the accomplishment was one which she (Tess) did not care to profess in genteel company. However, she (Tess) blandly admitted that such was the fact.

``Then you will have to practise it every day. I had a lad who did it very well, but he (lad) has left. I want you to whistle to my bullfinches; as I cannot see them, I like to hear them, and we teach 'em airs that way. Tell her (Tess) where the cages are, Elizabeth. You must begin to-morrow, or they will go back in their piping. They have been neglected these several days.'' (unknown)

``Mr d

``Urberville whistled to 'em this morning, ma'am,'' (unknown)
said Elizabeth.

``He (Mr)! Pooh!'' (The lady)

The old lady's face creased into furrows of repugnance, and she (Elizabeth) made no further reply.

Thus the reception of Tess by her (Tess) fancied kinswoman terminated, and the birds were taken back to their quarters. The girl's surprise at Mrs d``Urberville's manner was not great; for since seeing the size of the house she (Elizabeth) had expected no more. But she (Elizabeth) was far from being aware that the old lady had never heard a word of the so-called kinship. She (lady) gathered that no great affection flowed between the blind woman and her (lady) son. But in that, too, she (lady) was mistaken. Mrs d``Urberville was not the first mother compelled to love her (Mrs) offspring resentfully, and to be bitterly fond.

In spite of the unpleasant initiation of the day before, Tess inclined to the freedom and novelty of her (Tess) new position in the morning when the sun shone, now that she (Tess) was once installed there; and she (Tess) was curious to test her (Tess) powers in the unexpected direction asked of her (Tess), so as to ascertain her (Tess) chance of retaining her (Tess) post. As soon as she (Tess) was alone within the walled garden she (Tess) sat herself down on a coop, and seriously screwed up her (Tess) mouth for the long-neglected practice. She (Tess) found her (Tess) former ability to have degenerated to the production of a hollow rush of wind through the lips, and no clear note at all.

She (Tess) remained fruitlessly blowing and blowing, wondering how she (Tess) could have so grown out of the art which had come by nature, till she (Tess) became aware of a movement among the ivy-boughs which cloaked the garden-wall no less then the cottage. Looking that way she (Tess) beheld a form springing from the coping to the plot. It was Alec d``Urberville, whom she (Tess) had not set eyes on since he (Alec) had conducted her (Tess) the day before to the door of the gardener's cottage where she (Tess) had lodgings.

``Upon my honour!'' (he)
cried he (It), ``there was never before such a beautiful thing in Nature or Art as you look, ``Cousin' Tess -LRB-
``Cousin' had a faint ring of mockery-RRB-. I have been watching you from over the wall--sitting like IM-patience on a monument, and pouting up that pretty red mouth to whistling shape, and whooing and whooing, and privately swearing, and never being able to produce a note. Why, you are quite cross because you can't do it.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

``I may be cross, but I didn't swear.'' (unknown)

``Ah! I understand why you are trying--those bullies! My mother wants you to carry on their musical education. How selfish of her (mother)! As if attending to these curst cocks and hens here were not enough work for any girl. I would flatly refuse, if I were you.'' (unknown)

``But she (girl) wants me particularly to do it, and to be ready by to-morrow morning.'' (unknown)

``Does she (girl)? Well then--I'll give you a lesson or two.'' (unknown)

``Oh no, you won't!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess, withdrawing towards the door.

``Nonsense; I don't want to touch you. See--I'll stand on this side of the wire-netting, and you can keep on the other; so you may feel quite safe. Now, look here; you screw up your lips too harshly. There `tis--so.'' (He)

He (It) suited the action to the word, and whistled a line of

``Take, O take those lips away.'' (He)
But the allusion was lost upon Tess.

``Now try,'' (She)
said d``Urberville.

She (girl) attempted to look reserved; her (girl) face put on a sculptural severity. But he (girl) persisted in his (girl) demand, and at last, to get rid of him (girl), she (girl) did put up her (girl) lips as directed for producing a clear note; laughing distressfully, however, and then blushing with vexation that she (girl) had laughed.

He (girl) encouraged her (girl) with

``Try again!'' (her)

Tess was quite serious, painfully serious by this time; and she (Tess) tried--ultimately and unexpectedly emitting a real round sound. The momentary pleasure of success got the better of her (Tess); her (Tess) eyes enlarged, and she (Tess) involuntarily smiled in his (It) face.

``That's it! Now I have started you--you'll go on beautifully. There--I said I would not come near you; and, in spite of such temptation as never before fell to mortal man, I'll keep my word... Tess, do you think my mother a queer old soul?'' (unknown)

``I don't know much of her (mother) yet, sir.'' (unknown)

``You'll find her (mother) so; she (mother) must be, to make you learn to whistle to her (mother) bullfinches. I am rather out of her (mother) books just now, but you will be quite in favour if you treat her (mother) live-stock well. Good morning. If you meet with any difficulties and want help here, don't go to the bailiff, come to me.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

It was in the economy of this _rgime_ that Tess Durbeyfield had undertaken to fill a place. Her (Durbeyfield) first day's experiences were fairly typical of those which followed through many succeeding days. A familiarity with Alec d``Urberville's presence--which that young man carefully cultivated in her (mother) by playful dialogue, and by jestingly calling her (mother) his (man) cousin when they were alone--removed much of her (mother) original shyness of him (man), without, however, implanting any feeling which could engender shyness of a new and tenderer kind. But she (mother) was more pliable under his (man) hands than a mere companionship would have made her (mother), owing to her (mother) unavoidable dependence upon his (man) mother, and, through that lady's comparative helplessness, upon him (man).

She (mother) soon found that whistling to the bullfinches in Mrs d``Urberville's room was no such onerous business when she (Mrs) had regained the art, for she (Mrs) had caught from her (Mrs) musical mother numerous airs that suited those songsters admirably. A far more satisfactory time than when she (Mrs) practised in the garden was this whistling by the cages each morning. Unrestrained by the young man's presence she (Mrs) threw up her (Mrs) mouth, put her (Mrs) lips near the bars, and piped away in easeful grace to the attentive listeners.

Mrs d``Urberville slept in a large four-post bedstead hung with heavy damask curtains, and the bullfinches occupied the same apartment, where they flitted about freely at certain hours, and made little white spots on the furniture and upholstery. Once while Tess was at the window where the cages were ranged, giving her (Tess) lesson as usual, she (Tess) thought she (Tess) heard a rustling behind the bed. The old lady was not present, and turning round the girl had an impression that the toes of a pair of boots were visible below the fringe of the curtains. Thereupon her (girl) whistling became so disjointed that the listener, if such there were, must have discovered her (girl) suspicion of his (listener) presence. She (girl) searched the curtains every morning after that, but never found anybody within them. Alec d``Urberville had evidently thought better of his (Alec) freak to terrify her (girl) by an ambush of that kind.

X

Every village has its idiosyncrasy, its constitution, often its own code of morality. The levity of some of the younger women in and about Trantridge was marked, and was perhaps symptomatic of the choice spirit who ruled The Slopes in that vicinity. The place had also a more abiding defect; it drank hard. The staple conversation on the farms around was on the uselessness of saving money; and smock-frocked arithmeticians, leaning on their ploughs or hoes, would enter into calculations of great nicety to prove that parish relief was a fuller provision for a man in his (man) old age than any which could result from savings out of their wages during a whole lifetime.

The chief pleasure of these philosophers lay in going every Saturday night, when work was done, to Chaseborough, a decayed market-town two or three miles distant; and, returning in the small hours of the next morning, to spend Sunday in sleeping off the dyspeptic effects of the curious compounds sold to them as beer by the monopolizers of the once-independent inns.

For a long time Tess did not join in the weekly pilgrimages. But under pressure from matrons not much older than herself--for a field-man's wages being as high at twenty-one as at forty, marriage was early here--Tess at length consented to go. Her (Tess) first experience of the journey afforded her (Tess) more enjoyment than she (Tess) had expected, the hilariousness of the others being quite contagious after her (Tess) monotonous attention to the poultry-farm all the week. She (Tess) went again and again. Being graceful and interesting, standing moreover on the momentary threshold of womanhood, her (Tess) appearance drew down upon her (Tess) some sly regards from loungers in the streets of Chaseborough; hence, though sometimes her (Tess) journey to the town was made independently, she (Tess) always searched for her (Tess) fellows at nightfall, to have the protection of their companionship homeward.

This had gone on for a month or two when there came a Saturday in September, on which a fair and a market coincided; and the pilgrims from Trantridge sought double delights at the inns on that account. Tess's occupations made her (Tess) late in setting out, so that her (Tess) comrades reached the town long before her (Tess). It was a fine September evening, just before sunset, when yellow lights struggle with blue shades in hairlike lines, and the atmosphere itself forms a prospect without aid from more solid objects, except the innumerable winged insects that dance in it. Through this low-lit mistiness Tess walked leisurely along.

She (Tess) did not discover the coincidence of the market with the fair till she (Tess) had reached the place, by which time it was close upon dusk. Her (Tess) limited marketing was soon completed; and then as usual she (Tess) began to look about for some of the Trantridge cottagers.

At first she (Tess) could not find them, and she (Tess) was informed that most of them had gone to what they called a private little jig at the house of a hay-trusser and peat-dealer who had transactions with their farm. He (Tess) lived in an out-of-the-way nook of the townlet, and in trying to find her (Tess) course thither her (Tess) eyes fell upon Mr d``Urberville standing at a street corner.

``What--my Beauty? You here so late?'' (he)
he (Alec) said.

She (Durbeyfield) told him (Alec) that she (Durbeyfield) was simply waiting for company homeward.

``I'll see you again,'' (he)
said he (Alec) over her (Durbeyfield) shoulder as she (Durbeyfield) went on down the back lane.

Approaching the hay-trussers, she (Durbeyfield) could hear the fiddled notes of a reel proceeding from some building in the rear; but no sound of dancing was audible--an exceptional state of things for these parts, where as a rule the stamping drowned the music. The front door being open she (Durbeyfield) could see straight through the house into the garden at the back as far as the shades of night would allow; and nobody appearing to her (Durbeyfield) knock, she (Durbeyfield) traversed the dwelling and went up the path to the outhouse whence the sound had attracted her (Durbeyfield).

It was a windowless erection used for storage, and from the open door there floated into the obscurity a mist of yellow radiance, which at first Tess thought to be illuminated smoke. But on drawing nearer she (Tess) perceived that it was a cloud of dust, lit by candles within the outhouse, whose beams upon the haze carried forward the outline of the doorway into the wide night of the garden.

When she (Tess) came close and looked in she (Tess) beheld indistinct forms racing up and down to the figure of the dance, the silence of their footfalls arising from their being overshoe in

``scroff'' (she)
--that is to say, the powdery residuum from the storage of peat and other products, the stirring of which by their turbulent feet created the nebulosity that involved the scene. Through this floating, fusty _debris_ of peat and hay, mixed with the perspirations and warmth of the dancers, and forming together a sort of vegeto-human pollen, the muted fiddles feebly pushed their notes, in marked contrast to the spirit with which the measure was trodden out. They coughed as they danced, and laughed as they coughed. Of the rushing couples there could barely be discerned more than the high lights--the indistinctness shaping them to satyrs clasping nymphs--a multiplicity of Pans whirling a multiplicity of Syrinxes; Lotis attempting to elude Priapus, and always failing.

At intervals a couple would approach the doorway for air, and the haze no longer veiling their features, the demigods resolved themselves into the homely personalities of her (themselves) own next-door neighbours. Could Trantridge in two or three short hours have metamorphosed itself thus madly!

Some Sileni of the throng sat on benches and hay-trusses by the wall; and one of them recognized her (themselves).

``The maids don't think it respectable to dance at The Flower-de-Luce,'' (he)
he (itself) explained.
``They don't like to let everybody see which be their fancy-men. Besides, the house sometimes shuts up just when their jints begin to get greased. So we come here and send out for liquor.'' (unknown)

``But when be any of you going home?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
asked Tess with some anxiety.

``Now--a`most directly. This is all but the last jig.'' (She)

She (Tess) waited. The reel drew to a close, and some of the party were in the mind of starting. But others would not, and another dance was formed. This surely would end it, thought Tess. But it merged in yet another. She (Tess) became restless and uneasy; yet, having waited so long, it was necessary to wait longer; on account of the fair the roads were dotted with roving characters of possibly ill intent; and, though not fearful of measurable dangers, she (Tess) feared the unknown. Had she (Tess) been near Marlott she (Tess) would have had less dread.

``Don't ye be nervous, my dear good soul,'' (a man)
expostulated, between his (Tess) coughs, a young man with a wet face and his (Tess) straw hat so far back upon his (Tess) head that the brim encircled it like the nimbus of a saint.
``What's yer hurry? To-morrow is Sunday, thank God, and we can sleep it off in church-time. Now, have a turn with me?'' (She)

She (Tess) did not abhor dancing, but she (Tess) was not going to dance here. The movement grew more passionate: the fiddlers behind the luminous pillar of cloud now and then varied the air by playing on the wrong side of the bridge or with the back of the bow. But it did not matter; the panting shapes spun onwards.

They did not vary their partners if their inclination were to stick to previous ones. Changing partners simply meant that a satisfactory choice had not as yet been arrived at by one or other of the pair, and by this time every couple had been suitably matched. It was then that the ecstasy and the dream began, in which emotion was the matter of the universe, and matter but an adventitious intrusion likely to hinder you from spinning where you wanted to spin.

Suddenly there was a dull thump on the ground: a couple had fallen, and lay in a mixed heap. The next couple, unable to check its progress, came toppling over the obstacle. An inner cloud of dust rose around the prostrate figures amid the general one of the room, in which a twitching entanglement of arms and legs was discernible.

``You shall catch it for this, my gentleman, when you get home!'' (the partner)
burst in female accents from the human heap--those of the unhappy partner of the man whose clumsiness had caused the mishap; she (its) happened also to be his (man) recently married wife, in which assortment there was nothing unusual at Trantridge as long as any affection remained between wedded couples; and, indeed, it was not uncustomary in their later lives, to avoid making odd lots of the single people between whom there might be a warm understanding.

A loud laugh from behind Tess's back, in the shade of the garden, united with the titter within the room. She (Tess) looked round, and saw the red coal of a cigar: Alec d``Urberville was standing there alone. He (gentleman) beckoned to her (me), and she (me) reluctantly retreated towards him (gentleman).

``Well, my Beauty, what are you doing here?'' (She)

She (Tess) was so tired after her (Tess) long day and her (Tess) walk that she (Tess) confided her (Tess) trouble to him (Alec)--that she (Tess) had been waiting ever since he (Alec) saw her (Tess) to have their company home, because the road at night was strange to her (Tess).

``But it seems they will never leave off, and I really think I will wait no longer.'' (unknown)

``Certainly do not. I have only a saddle-horse here to-day; but come to The Flower-de-Luce, and I'll hire a trap, and drive you home with me.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess, though flattered, had never quite got over her (Tess) original mistrust of him (Alec), and, despite their tardiness, she (Tess) preferred to walk home with the work-folk. So she (Tess) answered that she (Tess) was much obliged to him (Alec), but would not trouble him (Alec).

``I have said that I will wait for 'em, and they will expect me to now.'' (unknown)

``Very well, Miss Independence. Please yourself... Then I shall not hurry... My good Lord, what a kick-up they are having there!'' (He)

He (Alec) had not put himself forward into the light, but some of them had perceived him (Alec), and his (Alec) presence led to a slight pause and a consideration of how the time was flying. As soon as he (Alec) had re-lit a cigar and walked away the Trantridge people began to collect themselves from amid those who had come in from other farms, and prepared to leave in a body. Their bundles and baskets were gathered up, and half an hour later, when the clock-chime sounded a quarter past eleven, they were straggling along the lane which led up the hill towards their homes.

It was a three-mile walk, along a dry white road, made whiter to-night by the light of the moon.

Tess soon perceived as she (Tess) walked in the flock, sometimes with this one, sometimes with that, that the fresh night air was producing staggerings and serpentine courses among the men who had partaken too freely; some of the more careless women also were wandering in their gait--to wit, a dark virago, Car Darch, dubbed Queen of Spades, till lately a favourite of d``Urberville's; Nancy, her (Nancy) sister, nicknamed the Queen of Diamonds; and the young married woman who had already tumbled down. Yet however terrestrial and lumpy their appearance just now to the mean unglamoured eye, to themselves the case was different. They followed the road with a sensation that they were soaring along in a supporting medium, possessed of original and profound thoughts, themselves and surrounding nature forming an organism of which all the parts harmoniously and joyously interpenetrated each other. They were as sublime as the moon and stars above them, and the moon and stars were as ardent as they.

Tess, however, had undergone such painful experiences of this kind in her (Tess) father's house that the discovery of their condition spoilt the pleasure she (Tess) was beginning to feel in the moonlight journey. Yet she (Tess) stuck to the party, for reasons above given.

In the open highway they had progressed in scattered order; but now their route was through a field-gate, and the foremost finding a difficulty in opening it, they closed up together.

This leading pedestrian was Car the Queen of Spades, who carried a wicker-basket containing her (Queen) mother's groceries, her (Queen) own draperies, and other purchases for the week. The basket being large and heavy, Car had placed it for convenience of porterage on the top of her (Queen) head, where it rode on in jeopardized balance as she (Queen) walked with arms akimbo.

``Well--whatever is that a-creeping down thy back, Car Darch?'' (unknown)
said one of the group suddenly.

All looked at Car. Her (Queen) gown was a light cotton print, and from the back of her (Queen) head a kind of rope could be seen descending to some distance below her (Queen) waist, like a Chinaman's queue.

''`Tis her (Queen) hair falling down,'' (a Chinaman)
said another.

No; it was not her (Queen) hair: it was a black stream of something oozing from her (Queen) basket, and it glistened like a slimy snake in the cold still rays of the moon.

''`Tis treacle,'' (an matron)
said an observant matron.

Treacle it was. Car's poor old grandmother had a weakness for the sweet stuff. Honey she (grandmother) had in plenty out of her (grandmother) own hives, but treacle was what her (grandmother) soul desired, and Car had been about to give her (grandmother) a treat of surprise. Hastily lowering the basket the dark girl found that the vessel containing the syrup had been smashed within.

By this time there had arisen a shout of laughter at the extraordinary appearance of Car's back, which irritated the dark queen into getting rid of the disfigurement by the first sudden means available, and independently of the help of the scoffers. She (queen) rushed excitedly into the field they were about to cross, and flinging herself flat on her (queen) back upon the grass, began to wipe her (queen) gown as well as she (queen) could by spinning horizontally on the herbage and dragging herself over it upon her (queen) elbows.

The laughter rang louder; they clung to the gate, to the posts, rested on their staves, in the weakness engendered by their convulsions at the spectacle of Car. Our heroine, who had hitherto held her (heroine) peace, at this wild moment could not help joining in with the rest.

It was a misfortune--in more ways than one. No sooner did the dark queen hear the soberer richer note of Tess among those of the other work-people than a long-smouldering sense of rivalry inflamed her (queen) to madness. She (queen) sprang to her (queen) feet and closely faced the object of her (queen) dislike.

``How darest th' laugh at me, hussy!'' (she)
she (queen) cried.

``I couldn't really help it when t`others did,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
apologized Tess, still tittering.

``Ah, th`st think th' beest everybody, dostn't, because th' beest first favourite with He (everybody) just now! But stop a bit, my lady, stop a bit! I'm as good as two of such! Look here--here's at `ee!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

To Tess's horror the dark queen began stripping off the bodice of her (queen) gown--which for the added reason of its ridiculed condition she (queen) was only too glad to be free of--till she (queen) had bared her (queen) plump neck, shoulders, and arms to the moonshine, under which they looked as luminous and beautiful as some Praxitelean creation, in their possession of the faultless rotundities of a lusty country-girl. She (queen) closed her (queen) fists and squared up at Tess.

``Indeed, then, I shall not fight!'' (unknown)
said the latter majestically;
``and if I had know you was of that sort, I wouldn't have so let myself down as to come with such a whorage as this is!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

The rather too inclusive speech brought down a torrent of vituperation from other quarters upon fair Tess's unlucky head, particularly from the Queen of Diamonds, who having stood in the relations to d``Urberville that Car had also been suspected of, united with the latter against the common enemy. Several other women also chimed in, with an animus which none of them would have been so fatuous as to show but for the rollicking evening they had passed. Thereupon, finding Tess unfairly browbeaten, the husbands and lovers tried to make peace by defending her (Tess); but the result of that attempt was directly to increase the war.

Tess was indignant and ashamed. She (Tess) no longer minded the loneliness of the way and the lateness of the hour; her (Tess) one object was to get away from the whole crew as soon as possible. She (Tess) knew well enough that the better among them would repent of their passion next day. They were all now inside the field, and she (Tess) was edging back to rush off alone when a horseman emerged almost silently from the corner of the hedge that screened the road, and Alec d``Urberville looked round upon them.

``What the devil is all this row about, work-folk?'' (he)
he (queen) asked.

The explanation was not readily forthcoming; and, in truth, he (queen) did not require any. Having heard their voices while yet some way off he (queen) had ridden creepingly forward, and learnt enough to satisfy himself.

Tess was standing apart from the rest, near the gate. He (queen) bent over towards her (Tess).

``Jump up behind me,'' (he)
he (queen) whispered,
``and we'll get shot of the screaming cats in a jiffy!'' (he)

She (Tess) felt almost ready to faint, so vivid was her (Tess) sense of the crisis. At almost any other moment of her (Tess) life she (Tess) would have refused such proffered aid and company, as she (Tess) had refused them several times before; and now the loneliness would not of itself have forced her (Tess) to do otherwise. But coming as the invitation did at the particular juncture when fear and indignation at these adversaries could be transformed by a spring of the foot into a triumph over them, she (Tess) abandoned herself to her (Tess) impulse, climbed the gate, put her (Tess) toe upon his (Tess) instep, and scrambled into the saddle behind him (Tess). The pair were speeding away into the distant gray by the time that the contentious revellers became aware of what had happened.

The Queen of Spades forgot the stain on her (Queen) bodice, and stood beside the Queen of Diamonds and the new-married, staggering young woman--all with a gaze of fixity in the direction in which the horse's tramp was diminishing into silence on the road.

``What be ye looking at?'' (a man)
asked a man who had not observed the incident.

``Ho-ho-ho!'' (unknown)
laughed dark Car.

``Hee-hee-hee!'' (the bride)
laughed the tippling bride, as she (bride) steadied herself on the arm of her (bride) fond husband.

``Heu-heu-heu!'' (Car mother)
laughed dark Car's mother, stroking her (bride) moustache as she (bride) explained laconically:
``Out of the frying-pan into the fire!'' (she)

Then these children of the open air, whom even excess of alcohol could scarce injure permanently, betook themselves to the field-path; and as they went there moved onward with them, around the shadow of each one's head, a circle of opalized light, formed by the moon's rays upon the glistening sheet of dew. Each pedestrian could see no halo but his (pedestrian) or her (bride) own, which never deserted the head-shadow, whatever its vulgar unsteadiness might be; but adhered to it, and persistently beautified it; till the erratic motions seemed an inherent part of the irradiation, and the fumes of their breathing a component of the night's mist; and the spirit of the scene, and of the moonlight, and of Nature, seemed harmoniously to mingle with the spirit of wine.

XI

The twain cantered along for some time without speech, Tess as she (Tess) clung to him (pedestrian) still panting in her (Tess) triumph, yet in other respects dubious. She (Tess) had perceived that the horse was not the spirited one he (pedestrian) sometimes rose, and felt no alarm on that score, though her (Tess) seat was precarious enough despite her (Tess) tight hold of him (pedestrian). She (Tess) begged him (pedestrian) to slow the animal to a walk, which Alec accordingly did.

``Neatly done, was it not, dear Tess?'' (he)
he (Alec) said by and by.

``Yes!'' (she)
said she (Tess).
``I am sure I ought to be much obliged to you.'' (unknown)

``And are you?'' (She)

She (Tess) did not reply.

``Tess, why do you always dislike my kissing you?'' (unknown)

``I suppose--because I don't love you.'' (unknown)

``You are quite sure?'' (unknown)

``I am angry with you sometimes!'' (unknown)

``Ah, I half feared as much.'' (Alec)
Nevertheless, Alec did not object to that confession. He (Alec) knew that anything was better then frigidity.
``Why haven't you told me when I have made you angry?'' (unknown)

``You know very well why. Because I cannot help myself here.'' (unknown)

``I haven't offended you often by love-making?'' (unknown)

``You have sometimes.'' (unknown)

``How many times?'' (unknown)

``You know as well as I--too many times.'' (unknown)

``Every time I have tried?'' (She)

She (Tess) was silent, and the horse ambled along for a considerable distance, till a faint luminous fog, which had hung in the hollows all the evening, became general and enveloped them. It seemed to hold the moonlight in suspension, rendering it more pervasive than in clear air. Whether on this account, or from absent-mindedness, or from sleepiness, she (Tess) did not perceive that they had long ago passed the point at which the lane to Trantridge branched from the highway, and that her (Tess) conductor had not taken the Trantridge track.

She (Tess) was inexpressibly weary. She (Tess) had risen at five o'clock every morning of that week, had been on foot the whole of each day, and on this evening had in addition walked the three miles to Chaseborough, waited three hours for her (Tess) neighbours without eating or drinking, her (Tess) impatience to start them preventing either; she (Tess) had then walked a mile of the way home, and had undergone the excitement of the quarrel, till, with the slow progress of their steed, it was now nearly one o'clock. Only once, however, was she (Tess) overcome by actual drowsiness. In that moment of oblivion her (Tess) head sank gently against him (Tess).

D``Urberville stopped the horse, withdrew his (I) feet from the stirrups, turned sideways on the saddle, and enclosed her (you) waist with his (I) arm to support her (you).

This immediately put her (you) on the defensive, and with one of those sudden impulses of reprisal to which she (you) was liable she (you) gave him (I) a little push from her (you).
