In his (I) ticklish position he (I) nearly lost his (I) balance and only just avoided rolling over into the road, the horse, though a powerful one, being fortunately the quietest he (I) rode.

``That is devilish unkind!'' (he)
he (Tess) said.
``I mean no harm--only to keep you from falling.'' (She)

She (Tess) pondered suspiciously, till, thinking that this might after all be true, she (Tess) relented, and said quite humbly,

``I beg your pardon, sir.'' (she)

``I won't pardon you unless you show some confidence in me. Good God!'' (he)
he (Tess) burst out,
``what am I, to be repulsed so by a mere chit like you? For near three mortal months have you trifled with my feelings, eluded me, and snubbed me; and I won't stand it!'' (he)

``I'll leave you to-morrow, sir.'' (unknown)

``No, you will not leave me to-morrow! Will you, I ask once more, show your belief in me by letting me clasp you with my arm? Come, between us two and nobody else, now. We know each other well; and you know that I love you, and think you the prettiest girl in the world, which you are. Mayn't I treat you as a lover?'' (She)

She (Tess) drew a quick pettish breath of objection, writhing uneasily on her (Tess) seat, looked far ahead, and murmured,

``I don't know--I wish--how can I say yes or no when--'' (She)

He (Tess) settled the matter by clasping his (Tess) arm round her (Tess) as he (Tess) desired, and Tess expressed no further negative. Thus they sidled slowly onward till it struck her (Tess) they had been advancing for an unconscionable time--far longer than was usually occupied by the short journey from Chaseborough, even at this walking pace, and that they were no longer on hard road, but in a mere trackway.

``Why, where be we?'' (she)
she (Tess) exclaimed.

``Passing by a wood.'' (unknown)

``A wood--what wood? Surely we are quite out of the road?'' (unknown)

``A bit of The Chase--the oldest wood in England. It is a lovely night, and why should we not prolong our ride a little?'' (unknown)

``How could you be so treacherous!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess, between archness and real dismay, and getting rid of his (Tess) arm by pulling open his (Tess) fingers one by one, though at the risk of slipping off herself.
``Just when I've been putting such trust in you, and obliging you to please you, because I thought I had wronged you by that push! Please set me down, and let me walk home.'' (unknown)

``You cannot walk home, darling, even if the air were clear. We are miles away from Trantridge, if I must tell you, and in this growing fog you might wander for hours among these trees.'' (unknown)

``Never mind that,'' (she)
she (Tess) coaxed.
``Put me down, I beg you. I don't mind where it is; only let me get down, sir, please!'' (unknown)

``Very well, then, I will--on one condition. Having brought you here to this out-of-the-way place, I feel myself responsible for your safe-conduct home, whatever you may yourself feel about it. As to your getting to Trantridge without assistance, it is quite impossible; for, to tell the truth, dear, owing to this fog, which so disguises everything, I don't quite know where we are myself. Now, if you will promise to wait beside the horse while I walk through the bushes till I come to some road or house, and ascertain exactly our whereabouts, I'll deposit you here willingly. When I come back I'll give you full directions, and if you insist upon walking you may; or you may ride--at your pleasure.'' (She)

She (Tess) accepted these terms, and slid off on the near side, though not till he (Tess) had stolen a cursory kiss. He (Tess) sprang down on the other side.

``I suppose I must hold the horse?'' (she)
said she (Tess).

``Oh no; it's not necessary,'' (Alec)
replied Alec, patting the panting creature.
``He (I)'s had enough of it for to-night.'' (He)

He (Alec) turned the horse's head into the bushes, hitched him (Alec) on to a bough, and made a sort of couch or nest for her (Tess) in the deep mass of dead leaves.

``Now, you sit there,'' (he)
he (Alec) said.
``The leaves have not got damp as yet. Just give an eye to the horse--it will be quite sufficient.'' (He)

He (Alec) took a few steps away from her (Tess), but, returning, said,

``By the bye, Tess, your father has a new cob to-day. Somebody gave it to him (father).'' (her)

``Somebody? You!'' (unknown)

D``Urberville nodded.

``O how very good of you that is!'' (she)
she (Tess) exclaimed, with a painful sense of the awkwardness of having to thank him (Alec) just then.

``And the children have some toys.'' (unknown)

``I didn't know--you ever sent them anything!'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured, much moved.
``I almost wish you had not--yes, I almost wish it!'' (unknown)

``Why, dear?'' (unknown)

``It--hampers me so.'' (unknown)

``Tessy--don't you love me ever so little now?'' (unknown)

``I'm grateful,'' (she)
she (Tess) reluctantly admitted.
``But I fear I do not--'' (she)
The sudden vision of his (Alec) passion for herself as a factor in this result so distressed her (Tess) that, beginning with one slow tear, and then following with another, she (Tess) wept outright.

``Don't cry, dear, dear one! Now sit down here, and wait till I come.'' (She)
She (Tess) passively sat down amid the leaves he (Alec) had heaped, and shivered slightly.
``Are you cold?'' (he)
he (Alec) asked.

``Not very--a little.'' (He)

He (Alec) touched her (Tess) with his (Alec) fingers, which sank into her (Tess) as into down.

``You have only that puffy muslin dress on--how's that?'' (unknown)

``It's my best summer one.

``Twas very warm when I started, and I didn't know I was going to ride, and that it would be night.'' (unknown)

``Nights grow chilly in September. Let me see.'' (He)
He (Alec) pulled off a light overcoat that he (Alec) had worn, and put it round her (Tess) tenderly.
``That's it--now you'll feel warmer,'' (he)
he (Alec) continued.
``Now, my pretty, rest there; I shall soon be back again.'' (he)

Having buttoned the overcoat round her (Tess) shoulders he (Alec) plunged into the webs of vapour which by this time formed veils between the trees. She (Tess) could hear the rustling of the branches as he (Alec) ascended the adjoining slope, till his (Alec) movements were no louder than the hopping of a bird, and finally died away. With the setting of the moon the pale light lessened, and Tess became invisible as she (Tess) fell into reverie upon the leaves where he (Alec) had left her (Tess).

In the meantime Alec d``Urberville had pushed on up the slope to clear his (I) genuine doubt as to the quarter of The Chase they were in. He (Chase) had, in fact, ridden quite at random for over an hour, taking any turning that came to hand in order to prolong companionship with her (me), and giving far more attention to Tess's moonlit person than to any wayside object. A little rest for the jaded animal being desirable, he (Chase) did not hasten his (Chase) search for landmarks. A clamber over the hill into the adjoining vale brought him (Chase) to the fence of a highway whose contours he (Chase) recognized, which settled the question of their whereabouts. D``Urberville thereupon turned back; but by this time the moon had quite gone down, and partly on account of the fog The Chase was wrapped in thick darkness, although morning was not far off. He (Chase) was obliged to advance with outstretched hands to avoid contact with the boughs, and discovered that to hit the exact spot from which he (Chase) had started was at first entirely beyond him (Chase). Roaming up and down, round and round, he (Chase) at length heard a slight movement of the horse close at hand; and the sleeve of his (Chase) overcoat unexpectedly caught his (Chase) foot.

``Tess!'' (unknown)
said d``Urberville.

There was no answer. The obscurity was now so great that he (Chase) could see absolutely nothing but a pale nebulousness at his (Chase) feet, which represented the white muslin figure he (Chase) had left upon the dead leaves. Everything else was blackness alike. D``Urberville stooped; and heard a gentle regular breathing. He (Chase) knelt and bent lower, till her (Tess) breath warmed his (Chase) face, and in a moment his (Chase) cheek was in contact with hers. She (Tess) was sleeping soundly, and upon her (Tess) eyelashes there lingered tears.

Darkness and silence ruled everywhere around. Above them rose the primeval yews and oaks of The Chase, in which there poised gentle roosting birds in their last nap; and about them stole the hopping rabbits and hares. But, might some say, where was Tess's guardian angel? where was the providence of her (Tess) simple faith? Perhaps, like that other god of whom the ironical Tishbite spoke, he (god) was talking, or he (god) was pursuing, or he (god) was in a journey, or he (god) was sleeping and not to be awaked.

Why it was that upon this beautiful feminine tissue, sensitive as gossamer, and practically blank as snow as yet, there should have been traced such a coarse pattern as it was doomed to receive; why so often the coarse appropriates the finer thus, the wrong man the woman, the wrong woman the man, many thousand years of analytical philosophy have failed to explain to our sense of order. One may, indeed, admit the possibility of a retribution lurking in the present catastrophe. Doubtless some of Tess d``Urberville's mailed ancestors rollicking home from a fray had dealt the same measure even more ruthlessly towards peasant girls of their time. But though to visit the sins of the fathers upon the children may be a morality good enough for divinities, it is scorned by average human nature; and it therefore does not mend the matter.

As Tess's own people down in those retreats are never tired of saying among each other in their fatalistic way:

``It was to be.'' (Tess people)
There lay the pity of it. An immeasurable social chasm was to divide our heroine's personality thereafter from that previous self of hers who stepped from her (heroine) mother's door to try her (heroine) fortune at Trantridge poultry-farm.

END OF PHASE THE FIRST

Phase the Second: Maiden No More

XII

The basket was heavy and the bundle was large, but she (heroine) lugged them along like a person who did not find her (heroine) especial burden in material things. Occasionally she (heroine) stopped to rest in a mechanical way by some gate or post; and then, giving the baggage another hitch upon her (heroine) full round arm, went steadily on again.

It was a Sunday morning in late October, about four months after Tess Durbeyfield's arrival at Trantridge, and some few weeks subsequent to the night ride in The Chase. The time was not long past daybreak, and the yellow luminosity upon the horizon behind her (Durbeyfield) back lighted the ridge towards which her (Durbeyfield) face was set--the barrier of the vale wherein she (Durbeyfield) had of late been a stranger--which she (Durbeyfield) would have to climb over to reach her (Durbeyfield) birthplace. The ascent was gradual on this side, and the soil and scenery differed much from those within Blakemore Vale. Even the character and accent of the two peoples had shades of difference, despite the amalgamating effects of a roundabout railway; so that, though less than twenty miles from the place of her (Durbeyfield) sojourn at Trantridge, her (Durbeyfield) native village had seemed a far-away spot. The field-folk shut in there traded northward and westward, travelled, courted, and married northward and westward, thought northward and westward; those on this side mainly directed their energies and attention to the east and south.

The incline was the same down which d``Urberville had driven her (Tess) so wildly on that day in June. Tess went up the remainder of its length without stopping, and on reaching the edge of the escarpment gazed over the familiar green world beyond, now half-veiled in mist. It was always beautiful from here; it was terribly beautiful to Tess to-day, for since her (Tess) eyes last fell upon it she (Tess) had learnt that the serpent hisses where the sweet birds sing, and her (Tess) views of life had been totally changed for her (Tess) by the lesson. Verily another girl than the simple one she (Tess) had been at home was she (Tess) who, bowed by thought, stood still here, and turned to look behind her (Tess). She (Tess) could not bear to look forward into the Vale.

Ascending by the long white road that Tess herself had just laboured up, she (Tess) saw a two-wheeled vehicle, beside which walked a man, who held up his (man) hand to attract her (Tess) attention.

She (Tess) obeyed the signal to wait for him (man) with unspeculative repose, and in a few minutes man and horse stopped beside her (Tess).

``Why did you slip away by stealth like this?'' (unknown)
said d``Urberville, with upbraiding breathlessness;
``on a Sunday morning, too, when people were all in bed! I only discovered it by accident, and I have been driving like the deuce to overtake you. Just look at the mare. Why go off like this? You know that nobody wished to hinder your going. And how unnecessary it has been for you to toil along on foot, and encumber yourself with this heavy load! I have followed like a madman, simply to drive you the rest of the distance, if you won't come back.'' (unknown)

``I shan't come back,'' (she)
said she (Durbeyfield).

``I thought you wouldn't--I said so! Well, then, put up your basket, and let me help you on.'' (She)

She (Durbeyfield) listlessly placed her (Durbeyfield) basket and bundle within the dog-cart, and stepped up, and they sat side by side. She (Durbeyfield) had no fear of him (Durbeyfield) now, and in the cause of her (Durbeyfield) confidence her (Durbeyfield) sorrow lay.

D``Urberville mechanically lit a cigar, and the journey was continued with broken unemotional conversation on the commonplace objects by the wayside. He (madman) had quite forgotten his (madman) struggle to kiss her (I) when, in the early summer, they had driven in the opposite direction along the same road. But she (I) had not, and she (I) sat now, like a puppet, replying to his (madman) remarks in monosyllables. After some miles they came in view of the clump of trees beyond which the village of Marlott stood. It was only then that her (I) still face showed the least emotion, a tear or two beginning to trickle down.

``What are you crying for?'' (he)
he (Durbeyfield) coldly asked.

``I was only thinking that I was born over there,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
murmured Tess.

``Well--we must all be born somewhere.'' (unknown)

``I wish I had never been born--there or anywhere else!'' (unknown)

``Pooh! Well, if you didn't wish to come to Trantridge why did you come?'' (She)

She (Tess) did not reply.

``You didn't come for love of me, that I'll swear.'' (unknown)

''`Tis quite true. If I had gone for love o' you, if I had ever sincerely loved you, if I loved you still, I should not so loathe and hate myself for my weakness as I do now! ... My eyes were dazed by you for a little, and that was all.'' (He)

He (Durbeyfield) shrugged his (Durbeyfield) shoulders. She (Tess) resumed--

``I didn't understand your meaning till it was too late.'' (She)

``That's what every woman says.'' (unknown)

``How can you dare to use such words!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried, turning impetuously upon him (Durbeyfield), her (Tess) eyes flashing as the latent spirit -LRB-of which he (Durbeyfield) was to see more some day-RRB- awoke in her (Tess).
``My God! I could knock you out of the gig! Did it never strike your mind that what every woman says some women may feel?'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (he)
he (Durbeyfield) said, laughing;
``I am sorry to wound you. I did wrong--I admit it.'' (he)
He (Durbeyfield) dropped into some little bitterness as he (Durbeyfield) continued:
``Only you needn't be so everlastingly flinging it in my face. I am ready to pay to the uttermost farthing. You know you need not work in the fields or the dairies again. You know you may clothe yourself with the best, instead of in the bald plain way you have lately affected, as if you couldn't get a ribbon more than you earn.'' (he)

Her (Tess) lip lifted slightly, though there was little scorn, as a rule, in her (Tess) large and impulsive nature.

``I have said I will not take anything more from you, and I will not--I cannot! I SHOULD be your creature to go on doing that, and I won't!'' (unknown)

``One would think you were a princess from your manner, in addition to a true and original d

``Urberville--ha! ha! Well, Tess, dear, I can say no more. I suppose I am a bad fellow--a damn bad fellow. I was born bad, and I have lived bad, and I shall die bad in all probability. But, upon my lost soul, I won't be bad towards you again, Tess. And if certain circumstances should arise--you understand--in which you are in the least need, the least difficulty, send me one line, and you shall have by return whatever you require. I may not be at Trantridge--I am going to London for a time--I can't stand the old woman. But all letters will be forwarded.'' (She)

She (Tess) said that she (Tess) did not wish him (Durbeyfield) to drive her (Tess) further, and they stopped just under the clump of trees. D``Urberville alighted, and lifted her (woman) down bodily in his (you) arms, afterwards placing her (woman) articles on the ground beside her (woman). She (woman) bowed to him (you) slightly, her (woman) eye just lingering in his (you); and then she (woman) turned to take the parcels for departure.

Alec d``Urberville removed his (Alec) cigar, bent towards her (woman), and said--

``You are not going to turn away like that, dear! Come!'' (Alec)

``If you wish,'' (she)
she (Tess) answered indifferently.
``See how you've mastered me!'' (She)

She (Tess) thereupon turned round and lifted her (Tess) face to his (Durbeyfield), and remained like a marble term while he (Durbeyfield) imprinted a kiss upon her (Tess) cheek--half perfunctorily, half as if zest had not yet quite died out. Her (Tess) eyes vaguely rested upon the remotest trees in the lane while the kiss was given, as though she (Tess) were nearly unconscious of what he (Durbeyfield) did.

``Now the other side, for old acquaintance' sake.'' (She)

She (Tess) turned her (Tess) head in the same passive way, as one might turn at the request of a sketcher or hairdresser, and he (Durbeyfield) kissed the other side, his (Durbeyfield) lips touching cheeks that were damp and smoothly chill as the skin of the mushrooms in the fields around.

``You don't give me your mouth and kiss me back. You never willingly do that--you'll never love me, I fear.'' (unknown)

``I have said so, often. It is true. I have never really and truly loved you, and I think I never can.'' (She)
She (hairdresser) added mournfully,
``Perhaps, of all things, a lie on this thing would do the most good to me now; but I have honour enough left, little as `tis, not to tell that lie. If I did love you, I may have the best o' causes for letting you know it. But I don't.'' (She)

He (Durbeyfield) emitted a laboured breath, as if the scene were getting rather oppressive to his (Durbeyfield) heart, or to his (Durbeyfield) conscience, or to his (Durbeyfield) gentility.

``Well, you are absurdly melancholy, Tess. I have no reason for flattering you now, and I can say plainly that you need not be so sad. You can hold your own for beauty against any woman of these parts, gentle or simple; I say it to you as a practical man and well-wisher. If you are wise you will show it to the world more than you do before it fades... And yet, Tess, will you come back to me! Upon my soul, I don't like to let you go like this!'' (unknown)

``Never, never! I made up my mind as soon as I saw--what I ought to have seen sooner; and I won't come.'' (unknown)

``Then good morning, my four months' cousin--good-bye!'' (He)

He (Durbeyfield) leapt up lightly, arranged the reins, and was gone between the tall red-berried hedges.

Tess did not look after him (Durbeyfield), but slowly wound along the crooked lane. It was still early, and though the sun's lower limb was just free of the hill, his (Durbeyfield) rays, ungenial and peering, addressed the eye rather than the touch as yet. There was not a human soul near. Sad October and her (Tess) sadder self seemed the only two existences haunting that lane.

As she (Tess) walked, however, some footsteps approached behind her (Tess), the footsteps of a man; and owing to the briskness of his (man) advance he (man) was close at her (Tess) heels and had said

``Good morning'' (he)
before she (Tess) had been long aware of his (man) propinquity. He (man) appeared to be an artisan of some sort, and carried a tin pot of red paint in his (man) hand. He (man) asked in a business-like manner if he (man) should take her (Tess) basket, which she (Tess) permitted him (man) to do, walking beside him (man).

``It is early to be astir this Sabbath morn!'' (he)
he (man) said cheerfully.

``Yes,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``When most people are at rest from their week's work.'' (She)

She (Tess) also assented to this.

``Though I do more real work to-day than all the week besides.'' (unknown)

``Do you?'' (unknown)

``All the week I work for the glory of man, and on Sunday for the glory of God. That's more real than the other--hey? I have a little to do here at this stile.'' (The man)
The man turned, as he (man) spoke, to an opening at the roadside leading into a pasture.
``If you'll wait a moment,'' (he)
he (man) added,
``I shall not be long.'' (he)

As he (man) had her (Tess) basket she (Tess) could not well do otherwise; and she (Tess) waited, observing him (man). He (man) set down her (Tess) basket and the tin pot, and stirring the paint with the brush that was in it began painting large square letters on the middle board of the three composing the stile, placing a comma after each word, as if to give pause while that word was driven well home to the reader's heart--

THY, DAMNATION, SLUMBERETH, NOT. 2 Pet. ii. 3.

Against the peaceful landscape, the pale, decaying tints of the copses, the blue air of the horizon, and the lichened stile-boards, these staring vermilion words shone forth. They seemed to shout themselves out and make the atmosphere ring. Some people might have cried

``Alas, poor Theology!'' (Some people)
at the hideous defacement--the last grotesque phase of a creed which had served mankind well in its time. But the words entered Tess with accusatory horror. It was as if this man had known her (Tess) recent history; yet he (man) was a total stranger.

Having finished his (man) text he (man) picked up her (Tess) basket, and she (Tess) mechanically resumed her (Tess) walk beside him (man).

``Do you believe what you paint?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked in low tones.

``Believe that tex? Do I believe in my own existence!'' (unknown)

``But,'' (she)
said she (Tess) tremulously,
``suppose your sin was not of your own seeking?'' (she)

He (man) shook his (man) head.

``I cannot split hairs on that burning query,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``I have walked hundreds of miles this past summer, painting these texes on every wall, gate, and stile the length and breadth of this district. I leave their application to the hearts of the people who read 'em.'' (unknown)

``I think they are horrible,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.
``Crushing! Killing!'' (unknown)

``That's what they are meant to be!'' (he)
he (man) replied in a trade voice.
``But you should read my hottest ones--them I kips for slums and seaports. They'd make ye wriggle! Not but what this is a very good tex for rural districts. ... Ah--there's a nice bit of blank wall up by that barn standing to waste. I must put one there--one that it will be good for dangerous young females like yerself to heed. Will ye wait, missy?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
said she (Tess); and taking her (Tess) basket Tess trudged on. A little way forward she (Tess) turned her (Tess) head. The old gray wall began to advertise a similar fiery lettering to the first, with a strange and unwonted mien, as if distressed at duties it had never before been called upon to perform. It was with a sudden flush that she (Tess) read and realized what was to be the inscription he (man) was now halfway through--

THOU, SHALT, NOT, COMMIT--

Her (Tess) cheerful friend saw her (Tess) looking, stopped his (friend) brush, and shouted--

``If you want to ask for edification on these things of moment, there's a very earnest good man going to preach a charity-sermon to-day in the parish you are going to--Mr Clare of Emminster. I'm not of his (Clare) persuasion now, but he (Clare)'s a good man, and he (Clare)'ll expound as well as any parson I know.

``Twas he (Clare) began the work in me.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

But Tess did not answer; she (Tess) throbbingly resumed her (Tess) walk, her (Tess) eyes fixed on the ground.

``Pooh--I don't believe God said such things!'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured contemptuously when her (Tess) flush had died away.

A plume of smoke soared up suddenly from her (Tess) father's chimney, the sight of which made her (Tess) heart ache. The aspect of the interior, when she (Tess) reached it, made her (Tess) heart ache more. Her (Tess) mother, who had just come down stairs, turned to greet her (Tess) from the fireplace, where she (Tess) was kindling barked-oak twigs under the breakfast kettle. The young children were still above, as was also her (Tess) father, it being Sunday morning, when he (father) felt justified in lying an additional half-hour.

``Well!--my dear Tess!'' (mother)
exclaimed her (Tess) surprised mother, jumping up and kissing the girl.
``How be ye? I didn't see you till you was in upon me! Have you come home to be married?'' (unknown)

``No, I have not come for that, mother.'' (unknown)

``Then for a holiday?'' (unknown)

``Yes--for a holiday; for a long holiday,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``What, isn't your cousin going to do the handsome thing?'' (unknown)

``He (cousin)'s not my cousin, and he (cousin)'s not going to marry me.'' (mother)

Her (Tess) mother eyed her (Tess) narrowly.

``Come, you have not told me all,'' (she)
she (Tess) said.

Then Tess went up to her (Tess) mother, put her (Tess) face upon Joan's neck, and told.

``And yet th`st not got him (cousin) to marry `ee!'' (mother)
reiterated her (Tess) mother.
``Any woman would have done it but you, after that!'' (unknown)

``Perhaps any woman would except me.'' (unknown)

``It would have been something like a story to come back with, if you had!'' (Mrs Durbeyfield)
continued Mrs Durbeyfield, ready to burst into tears of vexation.
``After all the talk about you and him (cousin) which has reached us here, who would have expected it to end like this! Why didn't ye think of doing some good for your family instead o' thinking only of yourself? See how I've got to teave and slave, and your poor weak father with his (father) heart clogged like a dripping-pan. I did hope for something to come out o' this! To see what a pretty pair you and he (father) made that day when you drove away together four months ago! See what he (father) has given us--all, as we thought, because we were his (father) kin. But if he (father)'s not, it must have been done because of his (father) love for `ee. And yet you've not got him (father) to marry!'' (Alec)

Get Alec d``Urberville in the mind to marry her (father)! He (father) marry HER! On matrimony he (father) had never once said a word. And what if he (father) had? How a convulsive snatching at social salvation might have impelled her (father) to answer him (father) she (father) could not say. But her (father) poor foolish mother little knew her (mother) present feeling towards this man. Perhaps it was unusual in the circumstances, unlucky, unaccountable; but there it was; and this, as she (mother) had said, was what made her (mother) detest herself. She (mother) had never wholly cared for him (man); she (mother) did not at all care for him (man) now. She (mother) had dreaded him (man), winced before him (man), succumbed to adroit advantages he (man) took of her (mother) helplessness; then, temporarily blinded by his (man) ardent manners, had been stirred to confused surrender awhile: had suddenly despised and disliked him (man), and had run away. That was all. Hate him (man) she (mother) did not quite; but he (man) was dust and ashes to her (mother), and even for her (mother) name's sake she (mother) scarcely wished to marry him (man).

``You ought to have been more careful if you didn't mean to get him (man) to make you his (man) wife!'' (unknown)

``O mother, my mother!'' (the girl)
cried the agonized girl, turning passionately upon her (girl) parent as if her (girl) poor heart would break.
``How could I be expected to know? I was a child when I left this house four months ago. Why didn't you tell me there was danger in men-folk? Why didn't you warn me? Ladies know what to fend hands against, because they read novels that tell them of these tricks; but I never had the chance o' learning in that way, and you did not help me!'' (mother)

Her (girl) mother was subdued.

``I thought if I spoke of his (man) fond feelings and what they might lead to, you would be hontish wi' him (man) and lose your chance,'' (she)
she (girl) murmured, wiping her (girl) eyes with her (girl) apron. ``Well, we must make the best of it, I suppose.
``Tis nater, after all, and what do please God!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

XIII

The event of Tess Durbeyfield's return from the manor of her (Durbeyfield) bogus kinsfolk was rumoured abroad, if rumour be not too large a word for a space of a square mile. In the afternoon several young girls of Marlott, former schoolfellows and acquaintances of Tess, called to see her (Tess), arriving dressed in their best starched and ironed, as became visitors to a person who had made a transcendent conquest -LRB-as they supposed-RRB-, and sat round the room looking at her (Tess) with great curiosity. For the fact that it was this said thirty-first cousin, Mr d``Urberville, who had fallen in love with her (they), a gentleman not altogether local, whose reputation as a reckless gallant and heartbreaker was beginning to spread beyond the immediate boundaries of Trantridge, lent Tess's supposed position, by its fearsomeness, a far higher fascination that it would have exercised if unhazardous.

Their interest was so deep that the younger ones whispered when her (Tess) back was turned--

``How pretty she (Tess) is; and how that best frock do set her (Tess) off! I believe it cost an immense deal, and that it was a gift from him (gentleman).'' (the ones)

Tess, who was reaching up to get the tea-things from the corner-cupboard, did not hear these commentaries. If she (Tess) had heard them, she (Tess) might soon have set her (Tess) friends right on the matter. But her (Tess) mother heard, and Joan's simple vanity, having been denied the hope of a dashing marriage, fed itself as well as it could upon the sensation of a dashing flirtation. Upon the whole she (Tess) felt gratified, even though such a limited and evanescent triumph should involve her (Tess) daughter's reputation; it might end in marriage yet, and in the warmth of her (Tess) responsiveness to their admiration she (Tess) invited her (Tess) visitors to stay to tea.

Their chatter, their laughter, their good-humoured innuendoes, above all, their flashes and flickerings of envy, revived Tess's spirits also; and, as the evening wore on, she (Tess) caught the infection of their excitement, and grew almost gay. The marble hardness left her (Tess) face, she (Tess) moved with something of her (Tess) old bounding step, and flushed in all her (Tess) young beauty.

At moments, in spite of thought, she (Tess) would reply to their inquiries with a manner of superiority, as if recognizing that her (Tess) experiences in the field of courtship had, indeed, been slightly enviable. But so far was she (Tess) from being, in the words of Robert South,

``in love with her (Tess) own ruin,'' (Robert)
that the illusion was transient as lightning; cold reason came back to mock her (Tess) spasmodic weakness; the ghastliness of her (Tess) momentary pride would convict her (Tess), and recall her (Tess) to reserved listlessness again.

And the despondency of the next morning's dawn, when it was no longer Sunday, but Monday; and no best clothes; and the laughing visitors were gone, and she (Tess) awoke alone in her (Tess) old bed, the innocent younger children breathing softly around her (Tess). In place of the excitement of her (Tess) return, and the interest it had inspired, she (Tess) saw before her (Tess) a long and stony highway which she (Tess) had to tread, without aid, and with little sympathy. Her (Tess) depression was then terrible, and she (Tess) could have hidden herself in a tomb.

In the course of a few weeks Tess revived sufficiently to show herself so far as was necessary to get to church one Sunday morning. She (Tess) liked to hear the chanting--such as it was--and the old Psalms, and to join in the Morning Hymn. That innate love of melody, which she (Tess) had inherited from her (Tess) ballad-singing mother, gave the simplest music a power over her (Tess) which could well-nigh drag her (Tess) heart out of her (Tess) bosom at times.

To be as much out of observation as possible for reasons of her (Tess) own, and to escape the gallantries of the young men, she (Tess) set out before the chiming began, and took a back seat under the gallery, close to the lumber, where only old men and women came, and where the bier stood on end among the churchyard tools.

Parishioners dropped in by twos and threes, deposited themselves in rows before her (Tess), rested three-quarters of a minute on their foreheads as if they were praying, though they were not; then sat up, and looked around. When the chants came on, one of her (Tess) favourites happened to be chosen among the rest--the old double chant

``Langdon'' (she)
--but she (Tess) did not know what it was called, though she (Tess) would much have liked to know. She (Tess) thought, without exactly wording the thought, how strange and god-like was a composer's power, who from the grave could lead through sequences of emotion, which he (composer) alone had felt at first, a girl like her (girl) who had never heard of his (composer) name, and never would have a clue to his (composer) personality.

The people who had turned their heads turned them again as the service proceeded; and at last observing her (girl), they whispered to each other. She (girl) knew what their whispers were about, grew sick at heart, and felt that she (girl) could come to church no more.

The bedroom which she (girl) shared with some of the children formed her (girl) retreat more continually than ever. Here, under her (girl) few square yards of thatch, she (girl) watched winds, and snows, and rains, gorgeous sunsets, and successive moons at their full. So close kept she (girl) that at length almost everybody thought she (girl) had gone away.

The only exercise that Tess took at this time was after dark; and it was then, when out in the woods, that she (Tess) seemed least solitary. She (Tess) knew how to hit to a hair's-breadth that moment of evening when the light and the darkness are so evenly balanced that the constraint of day and the suspense of night neutralize each other, leaving absolute mental liberty. It is then that the plight of being alive becomes attenuated to its least possible dimensions. She (Tess) had no fear of the shadows; her (Tess) sole idea seemed to be to shun mankind--or rather that cold accretion called the world, which, so terrible in the mass, is so unformidable, even pitiable, in its units.

On these lonely hills and dales her (Tess) quiescent glide was of a piece with the element she (Tess) moved in. Her (Tess) flexuous and stealthy figure became an integral part of the scene. At times her (Tess) whimsical fancy would intensify natural processes around her (Tess) till they seemed a part of her (Tess) own story. Rather they became a part of it; for the world is only a psychological phenomenon, and what they seemed they were. The midnight airs and gusts, moaning amongst the tightly-wrapped buds and bark of the winter twigs, were formulae of bitter reproach. A wet day was the expression of irremediable grief at her (Tess) weakness in the mind of some vague ethical being whom she (Tess) could not class definitely as the God of her (Tess) childhood, and could not comprehend as any other.

But this encompassment of her (Tess) own characterization, based on shreds of convention, peopled by phantoms and voices antipathetic to her (Tess), was a sorry and mistaken creation of Tess's fancy--a cloud of moral hobgoblins by which she (Tess) was terrified without reason. It was they that were out of harmony with the actual world, not she (Tess). Walking among the sleeping birds in the hedges, watching the skipping rabbits on a moonlit warren, or standing under a pheasant-laden bough, she (Tess) looked upon herself as a figure of Guilt intruding into the haunts of Innocence. But all the while she (Tess) was making a distinction where there was no difference. Feeling herself in antagonism, she (Tess) was quite in accord. She (Tess) had been made to break an accepted social law, but no law known to the environment in which she (Tess) fancied herself such an anomaly.

XIV

It was a hazy sunrise in August. The denser nocturnal vapours, attacked by the warm beams, were dividing and shrinking into isolated fleeces within hollows and coverts, where they waited till they should be dried away to nothing.

The sun, on account of the mist, had a curious sentient, personal look, demanding the masculine pronoun for its adequate expression. His (Tess) present aspect, coupled with the lack of all human forms in the scene, explained the old-time heliolatries in a moment. One could feel that a saner religion had never prevailed under the sky. The luminary was a golden-haired, beaming, mild-eyed, God-like creature, gazing down in the vigour and intentness of youth upon an earth that was brimming with interest for him (luminary).

His (luminary) light, a little later, broke though chinks of cottage shutters, throwing stripes like red-hot pokers upon cupboards, chests of drawers, and other furniture within; and awakening harvesters who were not already astir.

But of all ruddy things that morning the brightest were two broad arms of painted wood, which rose from the margin of yellow cornfield hard by Marlott village. They, with two others below, formed the revolving Maltese cross of the reaping-machine, which had been brought to the field on the previous evening to be ready for operations this day. The paint with which they were smeared, intensified in hue by the sunlight, imparted to them a look of having been dipped in liquid fire.

The field had already been

``opened'' (unknown)
; that is to say, a lane a few feet wide had been hand-cut through the wheat along the whole circumference of the field for the first passage of the horses and machine.

Two groups, one of men and lads, the other of women, had come down the lane just at the hour when the shadows of the eastern hedge-top struck the west hedge midway, so that the heads of the groups were enjoying sunrise while their feet were still in the dawn. They disappeared from the lane between the two stone posts which flanked the nearest field-gate.

Presently there arose from within a ticking like the love-making of the grasshopper. The machine had begun, and a moving concatenation of three horses and the aforesaid long rickety machine was visible over the gate, a driver sitting upon one of the hauling horses, and an attendant on the seat of the implement. Along one side of the field the whole wain went, the arms of the mechanical reaper revolving slowly, till it passed down the hill quite out of sight. In a minute it came up on the other side of the field at the same equable pace; the glistening brass star in the forehead of the fore horse first catching the eye as it rose into view over the stubble, then the bright arms, and then the whole machine.

The narrow lane of stubble encompassing the field grew wider with each circuit, and the standing corn was reduced to a smaller area as the morning wore on. Rabbits, hares, snakes, rats, mice, retreated inwards as into a fastness, unaware of the ephemeral nature of their refuge, and of the doom that awaited them later in the day when, their covert shrinking to a more and more horrible narrowness, they were huddled together, friends and foes, till the last few yards of upright wheat fell also under the teeth of the unerring reaper, and they were every one put to death by the sticks and stones of the harvesters.

The reaping-machine left the fallen corn behind it in little heaps, each heap being of the quantity for a sheaf; and upon these the active binders in the rear laid their hands--mainly women, but some of them men in print shirts, and trousers supported round their waists by leather straps, rendering useless the two buttons behind, which twinkled and bristled with sunbeams at every movement of each wearer, as if they were a pair of eyes in the small of his (harvesters) back.

But those of the other sex were the most interesting of this company of binders, by reason of the charm which is acquired by woman when she (woman) becomes part and parcel of outdoor nature, and is not merely an object set down therein as at ordinary times. A field-man is a personality afield; a field-woman is a portion of the field; she (woman) had somehow lost her (woman) own margin, imbibed the essence of her (woman) surrounding, and assimilated herself with it.

The women--or rather girls, for they were mostly young--wore drawn cotton bonnets with great flapping curtains to keep off the sun, and gloves to prevent their hands being wounded by the stubble. There was one wearing a pale pink jacket, another in a cream-coloured tight-sleeved gown, another in a petticoat as red as the arms of the reaping-machine; and others, older, in the brown-rough

``wropper'' (others dress)
or over-all--the old-established and most appropriate dress of the field-woman, which the young ones were abandoning. This morning the eye returns involuntarily to the girl in the pink cotton jacket, she (girl) being the most flexuous and finely-drawn figure of them all. But her (girl) bonnet is pulled so far over her (girl) brow that none of her (girl) face is disclosed while she (girl) binds, though her (girl) complexion may be guessed from a stray twine or two of dark brown hair which extends below the curtain of her (girl) bonnet. Perhaps one reason why she (girl) seduces casual attention is that she (girl) never courts it, though the other women often gaze around them.

Her (girl) binding proceeds with clock-like monotony. From the sheaf last finished she (girl) draws a handful of ears, patting their tips with her (girl) left palm to bring them even. Then, stooping low, she (girl) moves forward, gathering the corn with both hands against her (girl) knees, and pushing her (girl) left gloved hand under the bundle to meet the right on the other side, holding the corn in an embrace like that of a lover. She (girl) brings the ends of the bond together, and kneels on the sheaf while she (girl) ties it, beating back her (girl) skirts now and then when lifted by the breeze. A bit of her (girl) naked arm is visible between the buff leather of the gauntlet and the sleeve of her (girl) gown; and as the day wears on its feminine smoothness becomes scarified by the stubble and bleeds.

At intervals she (girl) stands up to rest, and to retie her (girl) disarranged apron, or to pull her (girl) bonnet straight. Then one can see the oval face of a handsome young woman with deep dark eyes and long heavy clinging tresses, which seem to clasp in a beseeching way anything they fall against. The cheeks are paler, the teeth more regular, the red lips thinner than is usual in a country-bred girl.

It is Tess Durbeyfield, otherwise d``Urberville, somewhat changed--the same, but not the same; at the present stage of her (Tess) existence living as a stranger and an alien here, though it was no strange land that she (Tess) was in. After a long seclusion she (Tess) had come to a resolve to undertake outdoor work in her (Tess) native village, the busiest season of the year in the agricultural world having arrived, and nothing that she (Tess) could do within the house being so remunerative for the time as harvesting in the fields.

The movements of the other women were more or less similar to Tess's, the whole bevy of them drawing together like dancers in a quadrille at the completion of a sheaf by each, every one placing her (Tess) sheaf on end against those of the rest, till a shock, or

``stitch'' (dancers)
as it was here called, of ten or a dozen was formed.

They went to breakfast, and came again, and the work proceeded as before. As the hour of eleven drew near a person watching her (Durbeyfield) might have noticed that every now and then Tess's glance flitted wistfully to the brow of the hill, though she (Tess) did not pause in her (Tess) sheafing. On the verge of the hour the heads of a group of children, of ages ranging from six to fourteen, rose over the stubbly convexity of the hill.

The face of Tess flushed slightly, but still she (Tess) did not pause.

The eldest of the comers, a girl who wore a triangular shawl, its corner draggling on the stubble, carried in her (Tess) arms what at first sight seemed to be a doll, but proved to be an infant in long clothes. Another brought some lunch. The harvesters ceased working, took their provisions, and sat down against one of the shocks. Here they fell to, the men plying a stone jar freely, and passing round a cup.

Tess Durbeyfield had been one of the last to suspend her (Durbeyfield) labours. She (Durbeyfield) sat down at the end of the shock, her (Durbeyfield) face turned somewhat away from her (Durbeyfield) companions. When she (Durbeyfield) had deposited herself a man in a rabbit-skin cap, and with a red handkerchief tucked into his (man) belt, held the cup of ale over the top of the shock for her (Durbeyfield) to drink. But she (Durbeyfield) did not accept his (man) offer. As soon as her (Durbeyfield) lunch was spread she (Durbeyfield) called up the big girl, her (Durbeyfield) sister, and took the baby of her (Durbeyfield), who, glad to be relieved of the burden, went away to the next shock and joined the other children playing there. Tess, with a curiously stealthy yet courageous movement, and with a still rising colour, unfastened her (Tess) frock and began suckling the child.

The men who sat nearest considerately turned their faces towards the other end of the field, some of them beginning to smoke; one, with absent-minded fondness, regretfully stroking the jar that would no longer yield a stream. All the women but Tess fell into animated talk, and adjusted the disarranged knots of their hair.

When the infant had taken its fill, the young mother sat it upright in her (mother) lap, and looking into the far distance, dandled it with a gloomy indifference that was almost dislike; then all of a sudden she (mother) fell to violently kissing it some dozens of times, as if she (mother) could never leave off, the child crying at the vehemence of an onset which strangely combined passionateness with contempt.

``She (Tess)'s fond of that there child, though she (Tess) mid pretend to hate en, and say she (Tess) wishes the baby and her (Tess) too were in the churchyard,'' (the woman)
observed the woman in the red petticoat.

``She (Tess)'ll soon leave off saying that,'' (unknown)
replied the one in buff.
``Lord, `tis wonderful what a body can get used to o' that sort in time!'' (unknown)

``A little more than persuading had to do wi' the coming o`t, I reckon. There were they that heard a sobbing one night last year in The Chase; and it mid ha' gone hard wi' a certain party if folks had come along.'' (unknown)

``Well, a little more, or a little less, 'twas a thousand pities that it should have happened to she (Lord), of all others. But `tis always the comeliest! The plain ones be as safe as churches--hey, Jenny?'' (The speaker)
The speaker turned to one of the group who certainly was not ill-defined as plain.

It was a thousand pities, indeed; it was impossible for even an enemy to feel otherwise on looking at Tess as she (Tess) sat there, with her (Tess) flower-like mouth and large tender eyes, neither black nor blue nor grey nor violet; rather all those shades together, and a hundred others, which could be seen if one looked into their irises--shade behind shade--tint beyond tint--around pupils that had no bottom; an almost standard woman, but for the slight incautiousness of character inherited from her (woman) race.

A resolution which had surprised herself had brought her (woman) into the fields this week for the first time during many months. After wearing and wasting her (woman) palpitating heart with every engine of regret that lonely inexperience could devise, common sense had illuminated her (woman). She (woman) felt that she (woman) would do well to be useful again--to taste anew sweet independence at any price. The past was past; whatever it had been, it was no more at hand. Whatever its consequences, time would close over them; they would all in a few years be as if they had never been, and she (woman) herself grassed down and forgotten. Meanwhile the trees were just as green as before; the birds sang and the sun shone as clearly now as ever. The familiar surroundings had not darkened because of her (woman) grief, nor sickened because of her (woman) pain.

She (woman) might have seen that what had bowed her (woman) head so profoundly--the thought of the world's concern at her (woman) situation--was founded on an illusion. She (woman) was not an existence, an experience, a passion, a structure of sensations, to anybody but herself. To all humankind besides, Tess was only a passing thought. Even to friends she (Tess) was no more than a frequently passing thought. If she (Tess) made herself miserable the livelong night and day it was only this much to them--

``Ah, she (Jenny) makes herself unhappy.'' (she)
If she (Tess) tried to be cheerful, to dismiss all care, to take pleasure in the daylight, the flowers, the baby, she (Tess) could only be this idea to them--
``Ah, she (Jenny) bears it very well.'' (she)
Moreover, alone in a desert island would she (Tess) have been wretched at what had happened to her (Tess)? Not greatly. If she (Tess) could have been but just created, to discover herself as a spouseless mother, with no experience of life except as the parent of a nameless child, would the position have caused her (Tess) to despair? No, she (Tess) would have taken it calmly, and found pleasure therein. Most of the misery had been generated by her (Tess) conventional aspect, and not by her (Tess) innate sensations.

Whatever Tess's reasoning, some spirit had induced her (Tess) to dress herself up neatly as she (Tess) had formerly done, and come out into the fields, harvest-hands being greatly in demand just then. This was why she (Tess) had borne herself with dignity, and had looked people calmly in the face at times, even when holding the baby in her (Tess) arms.

The harvest-men rose from the shock of corn, and stretched their limbs, and extinguished their pipes. The horses, which had been unharnessed and fed, were again attached to the scarlet machine. Tess, having quickly eaten her (Tess) own meal, beckoned to her (Tess) eldest sister to come and take away the baby, fastened her (Tess) dress, put on the buff gloves again, and stooped anew to draw a bond from the last completed sheaf for the tying of the next.

In the afternoon and evening the proceedings of the morning were continued, Tess staying on till dusk with the body of harvesters. Then they all rode home in one of the largest wagons, in the company of a broad tarnished moon that had risen from the ground to the eastwards, its face resembling the outworn gold-leaf halo of some worm-eaten Tuscan saint. Tess's female companions sang songs, and showed themselves very sympathetic and glad at her (Tess) reappearance out of doors, though they could not refrain from mischievously throwing in a few verses of the ballad about the maid who went to the merry green wood and came back a changed state. There are counterpoises and compensations in life; and the event which had made of her (maid) a social warning had also for the moment made her (maid) the most interesting personage in the village to many. Their friendliness won her (maid) still farther away from herself, their lively spirits were contagious, and she (maid) became almost gay.

But now that her (maid) moral sorrows were passing away a fresh one arose on the natural side of her (maid) which knew no social law. When she (maid) reached home it was to learn to her (maid) grief that the baby had been suddenly taken ill since the afternoon. Some such collapse had been probable, so tender and puny was its frame; but the event came as a shock nevertheless.

The baby's offence against society in coming into the world was forgotten by the girl-mother; her (maid) soul's desire was to continue that offence by preserving the life of the child. However, it soon grew clear that the hour of emancipation for that little prisoner of the flesh was to arrive earlier than her (maid) worst misgiving had conjectured. And when she (maid) had discovered this she (maid) was plunged into a misery which transcended that of the child's simple loss. Her (maid) baby had not been baptized.

Tess had drifted into a frame of mind which accepted passively the consideration that if she (Tess) should have to burn for what she (Tess) had done, burn she (Tess) must, and there was an end of it. Like all village girls, she (Tess) was well grounded in the Holy Scriptures, and had dutifully studied the histories of Aholah and Aholibah, and knew the inferences to be drawn therefrom. But when the same question arose with regard to the baby, it had a very different colour. Her (Tess) darling was about to die, and no salvation.

It was nearly bedtime, but she (Tess) rushed downstairs and asked if she (Tess) might send for the parson. The moment happened to be one at which her (Tess) father's sense of the antique nobility of his (father) family was highest, and his (father) sensitiveness to the smudge which Tess had set upon that nobility most pronounced, for he (father) had just returned from his (father) weekly booze at Rolliver's Inn. No parson should come inside his (parson) door, he (parson) declared, prying into his (parson) affairs, just then, when, by her (Rolliver) shame, it had become more necessary than ever to hide them. He (parson) locked the door and put the key in his (parson) pocket.

The household went to bed, and, distressed beyond measure, Tess retired also. She (Tess) was continually waking as she (Tess) lay, and in the middle of the night found that the baby was still worse. It was obviously dying--quietly and painlessly, but none the less surely.

In her (Tess) misery she (Tess) rocked herself upon the bed. The clock struck the solemn hour of one, that hour when fancy stalks outside reason, and malignant possibilities stand rock-firm as facts. She (Tess) thought of the child consigned to the nethermost corner of hell, as its double doom for lack of baptism and lack of legitimacy; saw the arch-fiend tossing it with his (Tess) three-pronged fork, like the one they used for heating the oven on baking days; to which picture she (Tess) added many other quaint and curious details of torment sometimes taught the young in this Christian country. The lurid presentment so powerfully affected her (Tess) imagination in the silence of the sleeping house that her (Tess) nightgown became damp with perspiration, and the bedstead shook with each throb of her (Tess) heart.

The infant's breathing grew more difficult, and the mother's mental tension increased. It was useless to devour the little thing with kisses; she (Tess) could stay in bed no longer, and walked feverishly about the room.

``O merciful God, have pity; have pity upon my poor baby!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried.
``Heap as much anger as you want to upon me, and welcome; but pity the child!'' (She)

She (Tess) leant against the chest of drawers, and murmured incoherent supplications for a long while, till she (Tess) suddenly started up.

``Ah! perhaps baby can be saved! Perhaps it will be just the same!'' (She)

She (Tess) spoke so brightly that it seemed as though her (Tess) face might have shone in the gloom surrounding her (Tess). She (Tess) lit a candle, and went to a second and a third bed under the wall, where she (Tess) awoke her (Tess) young sisters and brothers, all of whom occupied the same room. Pulling out the washing-stand so that she (Tess) could get behind it, she (Tess) poured some water from a jug, and made them kneel around, putting their hands together with fingers exactly vertical. While the children, scarcely awake, awe-stricken at her (Tess) manner, their eyes growing larger and larger, remained in this position, she (Tess) took the baby from her (Tess) bed--a child's child--so immature as scarce to seem a sufficient personality to endow its producer with the maternal title. Tess then stood erect with the infant on her (Tess) arm beside the basin; the next sister held the Prayer-Book open before her (sister), as the clerk at church held it before the parson; and thus the girl set about baptizing her (girl) child.

Her (girl) figure looked singularly tall and imposing as she (girl) stood in her (girl) long white nightgown, a thick cable of twisted dark hair hanging straight down her (girl) back to her (girl) waist. The kindly dimness of the weak candle abstracted from her (girl) form and features the little blemishes which sunlight might have revealed--the stubble scratches upon her (girl) wrists, and the weariness of her (girl) eyes--her (girl) high enthusiasm having a transfiguring effect upon the face which had been her (girl) undoing, showing it as a thing of immaculate beauty, with a touch of dignity which was almost regal. The little ones kneeling round, their sleepy eyes blinking and red, awaited her (girl) preparations full of a suspended wonder which their physical heaviness at that hour would not allow to become active.

The most impressed of them said:

``Be you really going to christen him (Heap), Tess?'' (unknown)

The girl-mother replied in a grave affirmative.

``What's his (Heap) name going to be?'' (She)

She (girl) had not thought of that, but a name suggested by a phrase in the book of Genesis came into her (girl) head as she (girl) proceeded with the baptismal service, and now she (girl) pronounced it:

``SORROW, I baptize thee in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.'' (she)

She (girl) sprinkled the water, and there was silence.

``Say ``Amen,

'' children.'' (unknown)

The tiny voices piped in obedient response,

``Amen!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess went on:

``We receive this child'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
--and so forth--
``and do sign him (Son) with the sign of the Cross.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Here she (Tess) dipped her (Tess) hand into the basin, and fervently drew an immense cross upon the baby with her (Tess) forefinger, continuing with the customary sentences as to his (girl) manfully fighting against sin, the world, and the devil, and being a faithful soldier and servant unto his (soldier) life's end. She (Tess) duly went on with the Lord's Prayer, the children lisping it after her (Tess) in a thin gnat-like wail, till, at the conclusion, raising their voices to clerk's pitch, they again piped into silence,

``Amen!'' (clerk)

Then their sister, with much augmented confidence in the efficacy of the sacrament, poured forth from the bottom of her (sister) heart the thanksgiving that follows, uttering it boldly and triumphantly in the stopt-diapason note which her (sister) voice acquired when her (sister) heart was in her (sister) speech, and which will never be forgotten by those who knew her (sister). The ecstasy of faith almost apotheosized her (sister); it set upon her (sister) face a glowing irradiation, and brought a red spot into the middle of each cheek; while the miniature candle-flame inverted in her (sister) eye-pupils shone like a diamond. The children gazed up at her (sister) with more and more reverence, and no longer had a will for questioning. She (sister) did not look like Sissy to them now, but as a being large, towering, and awful--a divine personage with whom they had nothing in common.

Poor Sorrow's campaign against sin, the world, and the devil was doomed to be of limited brilliancy--luckily perhaps for himself, considering his (devil) beginnings. In the blue of the morning that fragile soldier and servant breathed his (soldier) last, and when the other children awoke they cried bitterly, and begged Sissy to have another pretty baby.

The calmness which had possessed Tess since the christening remained with her (Tess) in the infant's loss. In the daylight, indeed, she (Tess) felt her (Tess) terrors about his (soldier) soul to have been somewhat exaggerated; whether well founded or not, she (Tess) had no uneasiness now, reasoning that if Providence would not ratify such an act of approximation she (Tess), for one, did not value the kind of heaven lost by the irregularity--either for herself or for her (Tess) child.

So passed away Sorrow the Undesired--that intrusive creature, that bastard gift of shameless Nature, who respects not the social law; a waif to whom eternal Time had been a matter of days merely, who knew not that such things as years and centuries ever were; to whom the cottage interior was the universe, the week's weather climate, new-born babyhood human existence, and the instinct to suck human knowledge.

Tess, who mused on the christening a good deal, wondered if it were doctrinally sufficient to secure a Christian burial for the child. Nobody could tell this but the parson of the parish, and he (parson) was a new-comer, and did not know her (Tess). She (Tess) went to his (parson) house after dusk, and stood by the gate, but could not summon courage to go in. The enterprise would have been abandoned if she (Tess) had not by accident met him (parson) coming homeward as she (Tess) turned away. In the gloom she (Tess) did not mind speaking freely.

``I should like to ask you something, sir.'' (He)

He (parson) expressed his (parson) willingness to listen, and she (Tess) told the story of the baby's illness and the extemporized ordinance.

``And now, sir,'' (she)
she (Tess) added earnestly,
``can you tell me this--will it be just the same for him (Son) as if you had baptized him (Son)?'' (she)

Having the natural feelings of a tradesman at finding that a job he (tradesman) should have been called in for had been unskilfully botched by his (tradesman) customers among themselves, he (tradesman) was disposed to say no. Yet the dignity of the girl, the strange tenderness in her (girl) voice, combined to affect his (tradesman) nobler impulses--or rather those that he (tradesman) had left in him (tradesman) after ten years of endeavour to graft technical belief on actual scepticism. The man and the ecclesiastic fought within him (man), and the victory fell to the man.

``My dear girl,'' (he)
he (man) said,
``it will be just the same.'' (he)

``Then will you give him (Son) a Christian burial?'' (she)
she (girl) asked quickly.

The Vicar felt himself cornered. Hearing of the baby's illness, he (Vicar) had conscientiously gone to the house after nightfall to perform the rite, and, unaware that the refusal to admit him (Vicar) had come from Tess's father and not from Tess, he (Vicar) could not allow the plea of necessity for its irregular administration.

``Ah--that's another matter,'' (he)
he (Vicar) said.

``Another matter--why?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
asked Tess, rather warmly.

``Well--I would willingly do so if only we two were concerned. But I must not--for certain reasons.'' (unknown)

``Just for once, sir!'' (unknown)

``Really I must not.'' (unknown)

``O sir!'' (She)
She (Tess) seized his (Vicar) hand as she (Tess) spoke.

He (Vicar) withdrew it, shaking his (Vicar) head.

``Then I don't like you!'' (she)
she (Tess) burst out,
``and I'll never come to your church no more!'' (she)

``Don't talk so rashly.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps it will be just the same to him (your) if you don't? ... Will it be just the same? Don't for God's sake speak as saint to sinner, but as you yourself to me myself--poor me!'' (the Vicar)

How the Vicar reconciled his (Vicar) answer with the strict notions he (Vicar) supposed himself to hold on these subjects it is beyond a layman's power to tell, though not to excuse. Somewhat moved, he (Vicar) said in this case also--

``It will be just the same.'' (he)

So the baby was carried in a small deal box, under an ancient woman's shawl, to the churchyard that night, and buried by lantern-light, at the cost of a shilling and a pint of beer to the sexton, in that shabby corner of God's allotment where He (God) lets the nettles grow, and where all unbaptized infants, notorious drunkards, suicides, and others of the conjecturally damned are laid. In spite of the untoward surroundings, however, Tess bravely made a little cross of two laths and a piece of string, and having bound it with flowers, she (Tess) stuck it up at the head of the grave one evening when she (Tess) could enter the churchyard without being seen, putting at the foot also a bunch of the same flowers in a little jar of water to keep them alive. What matter was it that on the outside of the jar the eye of mere observation noted the words

``Keelwell's Marmalade'' (unknown)
? The eye of maternal affection did not see them in its vision of higher things.

XV

``By experience,'' (XV)
says Roger Ascham,
``we find out a short way by a long wandering.'' (Roger Ascham)
Not seldom that long wandering unfits us for further travel, and of what use is our experience to us then? Tess Durbeyfield's experience was of this incapacitating kind. At last she (Durbeyfield) had learned what to do; but who would now accept her (Durbeyfield) doing?

If before going to the d``Urbervilles' she (saint) had vigorously moved under the guidance of sundry gnomic texts and phrases known to her (saint) and to the world in general, no doubt she (saint) would never have been imposed on. But it had not been in Tess's power--nor is it in anybody's power--to feel the whole truth of golden opinions while it is possible to profit by them. She (Tess)--and how many more--might have ironically said to God with Saint Augustine:

``Thou hast counselled a better course than Thou hast permitted.'' (She)

She (Durbeyfield) remained at her (Durbeyfield) father's house during the winter months, plucking fowls, or cramming turkeys and geese, or making clothes for her (Durbeyfield) sisters and brothers out of some finery which d``Urberville had given her (Augustine), and she (Augustine) had put by with contempt. Apply to him (God) she (Augustine) would not. But she (Augustine) would often clasp her (Augustine) hands behind her (Augustine) head and muse when she (Augustine) was supposed to be working hard.

She (Augustine) philosophically noted dates as they came past in the revolution of the year; the disastrous night of her (Augustine) undoing at Trantridge with its dark background of The Chase; also the dates of the baby's birth and death; also her (Augustine) own birthday; and every other day individualized by incidents in which she (Augustine) had taken some share. She (Augustine) suddenly thought one afternoon, when looking in the glass at her (Augustine) fairness, that there was yet another date, of greater importance to her (Augustine) than those; that of her (Augustine) own death, when all these charms would have disappeared; a day which lay sly and unseen among all the other days of the year, giving no sign or sound when she (Augustine) annually passed over it; but not the less surely there. When was it? Why did she (Augustine) not feel the chill of each yearly encounter with such a cold relation? She (Augustine) had Jeremy Taylor's thought that some time in the future those who had known her (Augustine) would say:

``It is the --th, the day that poor Tess Durbeyfield died'' (her)
; and there would be nothing singular to their minds in the statement. Of that day, doomed to be her (Durbeyfield) terminus in time through all the ages, she (Durbeyfield) did not know the place in month, week, season or year.

Almost at a leap Tess thus changed from simple girl to complex woman. Symbols of reflectiveness passed into her (Tess) face, and a note of tragedy at times into her (Tess) voice. Her (Tess) eyes grew larger and more eloquent. She (Tess) became what would have been called a fine creature; her (Tess) aspect was fair and arresting; her (Tess) soul that of a woman whom the turbulent experiences of the last year or two had quite failed to demoralize. But for the world's opinion those experiences would have been simply a liberal education.

She (Tess) had held so aloof of late that her (Tess) trouble, never generally known, was nearly forgotten in Marlott. But it became evident to her (Tess) that she (Tess) could never be really comfortable again in a place which had seen the collapse of her (Tess) family's attempt to

``claim kin'' (family)
--and, through her (Tess), even closer union--with the rich d``Urbervilles. At least she (Durbeyfield) could not be comfortable there till long years should have obliterated her (Durbeyfield) keen consciousness of it. Yet even now Tess felt the pulse of hopeful life still warm within her (Tess); she (Tess) might be happy in some nook which had no memories. To escape the past and all that appertained thereto was to annihilate it, and to do that she (Tess) would have to get away.

Was once lost always lost really true of chastity? she (Tess) would ask herself. She (Tess) might prove it false if she (Tess) could veil bygones. The recuperative power which pervaded organic nature was surely not denied to maidenhood alone.

She (Tess) waited a long time without finding opportunity for a new departure. A particularly fine spring came round, and the stir of germination was almost audible in the buds; it moved her (Tess), as it moved the wild animals, and made her (Tess) passionate to go. At last, one day in early May, a letter reached her (Tess) from a former friend of her (Tess) mother's, to whom she (Tess) had addressed inquiries long before--a person whom she (Tess) had never seen--that a skilful milkmaid was required at a dairy-house many miles to the southward, and that the dairyman would be glad to have her (Tess) for the summer months.

It was not quite so far off as could have been wished; but it was probably far enough, her (Tess) radius of movement and repute having been so small. To persons of limited spheres, miles are as geographical degrees, parishes as counties, counties as provinces and kingdoms.

On one point she (Tess) was resolved: there should be no more d``Urberville air-castles in the dreams and deeds of her (Tess) new life. She (Tess) would be the dairymaid Tess, and nothing more. Her (Tess) mother knew Tess's feeling on this point so well, though no words had passed between them on the subject, that she (Tess) never alluded to the knightly ancestry now.

Yet such is human inconsistency that one of the interests of the new place to her (Tess) was the accidental virtues of its lying near her (Tess) forefathers' country -LRB-for they were not Blakemore men, though her (Tess) mother was Blakemore to the bone-RRB-. The dairy called Talbothays, for which she (Tess) was bound, stood not remotely from some of the former estates of the d``Urbervilles, near the great family vaults of her (Tess) granddames and their powerful husbands. She (Tess) would be able to look at them, and think not only that d``Urberville, like Babylon, had fallen, but that the individual innocence of a humble descendant could lapse as silently. All the while she (Tess) wondered if any strange good thing might come of her (Tess) being in her (Tess) ancestral land; and some spirit within her (Tess) rose automatically as the sap in the twigs. It was unexpected youth, surging up anew after its temporary check, and bringing with it hope, and the invincible instinct towards self-delight.

END OF PHASE THE SECOND

Phase the Third: The Rally

XVI

On a thyme-scented, bird-hatching morning in May, between two and three years after the return from Trantridge--silent, reconstructive years for Tess Durbeyfield--she (Durbeyfield) left her (Durbeyfield) home for the second time.

Having packed up her (Durbeyfield) luggage so that it could be sent to her (Durbeyfield) later, she (Durbeyfield) started in a hired trap for the little town of Stourcastle, through which it was necessary to pass on her (Durbeyfield) journey, now in a direction almost opposite to that of her (Durbeyfield) first adventuring. On the curve of the nearest hill she (Durbeyfield) looked back regretfully at Marlott and her (Durbeyfield) father's house, although she (Durbeyfield) had been so anxious to get away.

Her (Durbeyfield) kindred dwelling there would probably continue their daily lives as heretofore, with no great diminution of pleasure in their consciousness, although she (Durbeyfield) would be far off, and they deprived of her (Durbeyfield) smile. In a few days the children would engage in their games as merrily as ever, without the sense of any gap left by her (Durbeyfield) departure. This leaving of the younger children she (Durbeyfield) had decided to be for the best; were she (Durbeyfield) to remain they would probably gain less good by her (Durbeyfield) precepts than harm by her (Durbeyfield) example.

She (Durbeyfield) went through Stourcastle without pausing and onward to a junction of highways, where she (Durbeyfield) could await a carrier's van that ran to the south-west; for the railways which engirdled this interior tract of country had never yet struck across it. While waiting, however, there came along a farmer in his (farmer) spring cart, driving approximately in the direction that she (Durbeyfield) wished to pursue. Though he (farmer) was a stranger to her (Durbeyfield) she (Durbeyfield) accepted his (farmer) offer of a seat beside him (farmer), ignoring that its motive was a mere tribute to her (Durbeyfield) countenance. He (farmer) was going to Weatherbury, and by accompanying him (farmer) thither she (Durbeyfield) could walk the remainder of the distance instead of travelling in the van by way of Casterbridge.

Tess did not stop at Weatherbury, after this long drive, further than to make a slight nondescript meal at noon at a cottage to which the farmer recommended her (Tess). Thence she (Tess) started on foot, basket in hand, to reach the wide upland of heath dividing this district from the low-lying meads of a further valley in which the dairy stood that was the aim and end of her (Tess) day's pilgrimage.

Tess had never before visited this part of the country, and yet she (Tess) felt akin to the landscape. Not so very far to the left of her (Tess) she (Tess) could discern a dark patch in the scenery, which inquiry confirmed her (Tess) in supposing to be trees marking the environs of Kingsbere--in the church of which parish the bones of her (Tess) ancestors--her (Tess) useless ancestors--lay entombed.

She (Tess) had no admiration for them now; she (Tess) almost hated them for the dance they had led her (Tess); not a thing of all that had been theirs did she (Tess) retain but the old seal and spoon.

``Pooh--I have as much of mother as father in me!'' (she)
she (Tess) said.
``All my prettiness comes from her (mother), and she (mother) was only a dairymaid.'' (Egdon/Egdon Heath)

The journey over the intervening uplands and lowlands of Egdon, when she (Tess) reached them, was a more troublesome walk than she (Tess) had anticipated, the distance being actually but a few miles. It was two hours, owing to sundry wrong turnings, ere she (Tess) found herself on a summit commanding the long-sought-for vale, the Valley of the Great Dairies, the valley in which milk and butter grew to rankness, and were produced more profusely, if less delicately, than at her (Tess) home--the verdant plain so well watered by the river Var or Froom.

It was intrinsically different from the Vale of Little Dairies, Blackmoor Vale, which, save during her (Tess) disastrous sojourn at Trantridge, she (Tess) had exclusively known till now. The world was drawn to a larger pattern here. The enclosures numbered fifty acres instead of ten, the farmsteads were more extended, the groups of cattle formed tribes hereabout; there only families. These myriads of cows stretching under her (Tess) eyes from the far east to the far west outnumbered any she (Tess) had ever seen at one glance before. The green lea was speckled as thickly with them as a canvas by Van Alsloot or Sallaert with burghers. The ripe hue of the red and dun kine absorbed the evening sunlight, which the white-coated animals returned to the eye in rays almost dazzling, even at the distant elevation on which she (Tess) stood.

The bird's-eye perspective before her (Tess) was not so luxuriantly beautiful, perhaps, as that other one which she (Tess) knew so well; yet it was more cheering. It lacked the intensely blue atmosphere of the rival vale, and its heavy soils and scents; the new air was clear, bracing, ethereal. The river itself, which nourished the grass and cows of these renowned dairies, flowed not like the streams in Blackmoor. Those were slow, silent, often turbid; flowing over beds of mud into which the incautious wader might sink and vanish unawares. The Froom waters were clear as the pure River of Life shown to the Evangelist, rapid as the shadow of a cloud, with pebbly shallows that prattled to the sky all day long. There the water-flower was the lily; the crow-foot here.

Either the change in the quality of the air from heavy to light, or the sense of being amid new scenes where there were no invidious eyes upon her (Evangelist), sent up her (Evangelist) spirits wonderfully. Her (Evangelist) hopes mingled with the sunshine in an ideal photosphere which surrounded her (Evangelist) as she (Evangelist) bounded along against the soft south wind. She (Evangelist) heard a pleasant voice in every breeze, and in every bird's note seemed to lurk a joy.

Her (Evangelist) face had latterly changed with changing states of mind, continually fluctuating between beauty and ordinariness, according as the thoughts were gay or grave. One day she (Evangelist) was pink and flawless; another pale and tragical. When she (Evangelist) was pink she (Evangelist) was feeling less than when pale; her (Evangelist) more perfect beauty accorded with her (Evangelist) less elevated mood; her (Evangelist) more intense mood with her (Evangelist) less perfect beauty. It was her (Evangelist) best face physically that was now set against the south wind.

The irresistible, universal, automatic tendency to find sweet pleasure somewhere, which pervades all life, from the meanest to the highest, had at length mastered Tess.
