Being more finely formed, better educated, and, though the youngest except Retty, more woman than either, she (woman) perceived that only the slightest ordinary care was necessary for holding her (woman) own in Angel Clare's heart against these her (woman) candid friends. But the grave question was, ought she (woman) to do this? There was, to be sure, hardly a ghost of a chance for either of them, in a serious sense; but there was, or had been, a chance of one or the other inspiring him (Clare) with a passing fancy for her (woman), and enjoying the pleasure of his (Clare) attentions while he (Clare) stayed here. Such unequal attachments had led to marriage; and she (woman) had heard from Mrs Crick that Mr Clare had one day asked, in a laughing way, what would be the use of his (Clare) marrying a fine lady, and all the while ten thousand acres of Colonial pasture to feed, and cattle to rear, and corn to reap. A farm-woman would be the only sensible kind of wife for him (Clare). But whether Mr Clare had spoken seriously or not, why should she (wife), who could never conscientiously allow any man to marry her (wife) now, and who had religiously determined that she (wife) never would be tempted to do so, draw off Mr Clare's attention from other women, for the brief happiness of sunning herself in his (Clare) eyes while he (Clare) remained at Talbothays?

XXII

They came downstairs yawning next morning; but skimming and milking were proceeded with as usual, and they went indoors to breakfast. Dairyman Crick was discovered stamping about the house. He (Crick) had received a letter, in which a customer had complained that the butter had a twang.

``And begad, so 't have!'' (the dairyman)
said the dairyman, who held in his (dairyman) left hand a wooden slice on which a lump of butter was stuck.
``Yes--taste for yourself!'' (him)

Several of them gathered round him (dairyman); and Mr Clare tasted, Tess tasted, also the other indoor milkmaids, one or two of the milking-men, and last of all Mrs Crick, who came out from the waiting breakfast-table. There certainly was a twang.

The dairyman, who had thrown himself into abstraction to better realize the taste, and so divine the particular species of noxious weed to which it appertained, suddenly exclaimed--

''`Tis garlic! and I thought there wasn't a blade left in that mead!'' (The dairyman)

Then all the old hands remembered that a certain dry mead, into which a few of the cows had been admitted of late, had, in years gone by, spoilt the butter in the same way. The dairyman had not recognized the taste at that time, and thought the butter bewitched.

``We must overhaul that mead,'' (he)
he (dairyman) resumed;
``this mustn't continny!'' (he)

All having armed themselves with old pointed knives, they went out together. As the inimical plant could only be present in very microscopic dimensions to have escaped ordinary observation, to find it seemed rather a hopeless attempt in the stretch of rich grass before them. However, they formed themselves into line, all assisting, owing to the importance of the search; the dairyman at the upper end with Mr Clare, who had volunteered to help; then Tess, Marian, Izz Huett, and Retty; then Bill Lewell, Jonathan, and the married dairywomen--Beck Knibbs, with her (Marian) wooly black hair and rolling eyes; and flaxen Frances, consumptive from the winter damps of the water-meads--who lived in their respective cottages.

With eyes fixed upon the ground they crept slowly across a strip of the field, returning a little further down in such a manner that, when they should have finished, not a single inch of the pasture but would have fallen under the eye of some one of them. It was a most tedious business, not more than half a dozen shoots of garlic being discoverable in the whole field; yet such was the herb's pungency that probably one bite of it by one cow had been sufficient to season the whole dairy's produce for the day.

Differing one from another in natures and moods so greatly as they did, they yet formed, bending, a curiously uniform row--automatic, noiseless; and an alien observer passing down the neighbouring lane might well have been excused for massing them as

``Hodge'' (an observer)
. As they crept along, stooping low to discern the plant, a soft yellow gleam was reflected from the buttercups into their shaded faces, giving them an elfish, moonlit aspect, though the sun was pouring upon their backs in all the strength of noon.

Angel Clare, who communistically stuck to his (Clare) rule of taking part with the rest in everything, glanced up now and then. It was not, of course, by accident that he (Clare) walked next to Tess.

``Well, how are you?'' (he)
he (Clare) murmured.

``Very well, thank you, sir,'' (she)
she (Tess) replied demurely.

As they had been discussing a score of personal matters only half-an-hour before, the introductory style seemed a little superfluous. But they got no further in speech just then. They crept and crept, the hem of her (Tess) petticoat just touching his (Clare) gaiter, and his (Clare) elbow sometimes brushing hers. At last the dairyman, who came next, could stand it no longer.

``Upon my soul and body, this here stooping do fairly make my back open and shut!'' (he)
he (Clare) exclaimed, straightening himself slowly with an excruciated look till quite upright.
``And you, maidy Tess, you wasn't well a day or two ago--this will make your head ache finely! Don't do any more, if you feel fainty; leave the rest to finish it.'' (Dairyman Crick/Crick)

Dairyman Crick withdrew, and Tess dropped behind. Mr Clare also stepped out of line, and began privateering about for the weed. When she (Tess) found him (Clare) near her (Tess), her (Tess) very tension at what she (Tess) had heard the night before made her (Tess) the first to speak.

``Don't they look pretty?'' (she)
she (Tess) said.

``Who?'' (unknown)

``Izzy Huett and Retty.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess had moodily decided that either of these maidens would make a good farmer's wife, and that she (Tess) ought to recommend them, and obscure her (Tess) own wretched charms.

``Pretty? Well, yes--they are pretty girls--fresh looking. I have often thought so.'' (unknown)

``Though, poor dears, prettiness won't last long!'' (unknown)

``O no, unfortunately.'' (unknown)

``They are excellent dairywomen.'' (unknown)

``Yes: though not better than you.'' (unknown)

``They skim better than I.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

``Do they?'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Clare remained observing them--not without their observing him (Clare).

``She (Izzy) is colouring up,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
continued Tess heroically.

``Who?'' (unknown)

``Retty Priddle.'' (unknown)

``Oh! Why it that?'' (unknown)

``Because you are looking at her (Izzy).'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Self-sacrificing as her (Tess) mood might be, Tess could not well go further and cry,

``Marry one of them, if you really do want a dairywoman and not a lady; and don't think of marrying me!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
She (Tess) followed Dairyman Crick, and had the mournful satisfaction of seeing that Clare remained behind.

From this day she (Tess) forced herself to take pains to avoid him (Clare)--never allowing herself, as formerly, to remain long in his (Clare) company, even if their juxtaposition were purely accidental. She (Tess) gave the other three every chance.

Tess was woman enough to realize from their avowals to herself that Angel Clare had the honour of all the dairymaids in his (Clare) keeping, and her (Tess) perception of his (Clare) care to avoid compromising the happiness of either in the least degree bred a tender respect in Tess for what she (Tess) deemed, rightly or wrongly, the self-controlling sense of duty shown by him (Clare), a quality which she (Tess) had never expected to find in one of the opposite sex, and in the absence of which more than one of the simple hearts who were his (Clare) house-mates might have gone weeping on her (Tess) pilgrimage.

XXIII

The hot weather of July had crept upon them unawares, and the atmosphere of the flat vale hung heavy as an opiate over the dairy-folk, the cows, and the trees. Hot steaming rains fell frequently, making the grass where the cows fed yet more rank, and hindering the late hay-making in the other meads.

It was Sunday morning; the milking was done; the outdoor milkers had gone home. Tess and the other three were dressing themselves rapidly, the whole bevy having agreed to go together to Mellstock Church, which lay some three or four miles distant from the dairy-house. She (Tess) had now been two months at Talbothays, and this was her (Tess) first excursion.

All the preceding afternoon and night heavy thunderstorms had hissed down upon the meads, and washed some of the hay into the river; but this morning the sun shone out all the more brilliantly for the deluge, and the air was balmy and clear.

The crooked lane leading from their own parish to Mellstock ran along the lowest levels in a portion of its length, and when the girls reached the most depressed spot they found that the result of the rain had been to flood the lane over-shoe to a distance of some fifty yards. This would have been no serious hindrance on a week-day; they would have clicked through it in their high pattens and boots quite unconcerned; but on this day of vanity, this Sun's-day, when flesh went forth to coquet with flesh while hypocritically affecting business with spiritual things; on this occasion for wearing their white stockings and thin shoes, and their pink, white, and lilac gowns, on which every mud spot would be visible, the pool was an awkward impediment. They could hear the church-bell calling--as yet nearly a mile off.

``Who would have expected such a rise in the river in summer-time!'' (Marian)
said Marian, from the top of the roadside bank on which they had climbed, and were maintaining a precarious footing in the hope of creeping along its slope till they were past the pool.

``We can't get there anyhow, without walking right through it, or else going round the Turnpike way; and that would make us so very late!'' (Retty/Retty Priddle)
said Retty, pausing hopelessly.

``And I do colour up so hot, walking into church late, and all the people staring round,'' (Marian)
said Marian,
``that I hardly cool down again till we get into the That-it-may-please-Thees.'' (Marian)

While they stood clinging to the bank they heard a splashing round the bend of the road, and presently appeared Angel Clare, advancing along the lane towards them through the water.

Four hearts gave a big throb simultaneously.

His (Clare) aspect was probably as un-Sabbatarian a one as a dogmatic parson's son often presented; his (son) attire being his (son) dairy clothes, long wading boots, a cabbage-leaf inside his (son) hat to keep his (son) head cool, with a thistle-spud to finish him (son) off.

``He (We)'s not going to church,'' (Marian)
said Marian.

``No--I wish he (We) was!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
murmured Tess.

Angel, in fact, rightly or wrongly -LRB-to adopt the safe phrase of evasive controversialists-RRB-, preferred sermons in stones to sermons in churches and chapels on fine summer days. This morning, moreover, he (Angel) had gone out to see if the damage to the hay by the flood was considerable or not. On his (Angel) walk he (Angel) observed the girls from a long distance, though they had been so occupied with their difficulties of passage as not to notice him (Angel). He (Angel) knew that the water had risen at that spot, and that it would quite check their progress. So he (Angel) had hastened on, with a dim idea of how he (Angel) could help them--one of them in particular.

The rosy-cheeked, bright-eyed quartet looked so charming in their light summer attire, clinging to the roadside bank like pigeons on a roof-slope, that he (Angel) stopped a moment to regard them before coming close. Their gauzy skirts had brushed up from the grass innumerable flies and butterflies which, unable to escape, remained caged in the transparent tissue as in an aviary. Angel's eye at last fell upon Tess, the hindmost of the four; she (Tess), being full of suppressed laughter at their dilemma, could not help meeting his (Angel) glance radiantly.

He (Angel) came beneath them in the water, which did not rise over his (Angel) long boots; and stood looking at the entrapped flies and butterflies.

``Are you trying to get to church?'' (he)
he (Angel) said to Marian, who was in front, including the next two in his (Angel) remark, but avoiding Tess.

``Yes, sir; and `tis getting late; and my colour do come up so--'' (unknown)

``I'll carry you through the pool--every Jill of you.'' (unknown)

The whole four flushed as if one heart beat through them.

``I think you can't, sir,'' (Marian)
said Marian.

``It is the only way for you to get past. Stand still. Nonsense--you are not too heavy! I'd carry you all four together. Now, Marian, attend,'' (he)
he (Angel) continued,
``and put your arms round my shoulders, so. Now! Hold on. That's well done.'' (he)

Marian had lowered herself upon his (Angel) arm and shoulder as directed, and Angel strode off with her (Marian), his (Angel) slim figure, as viewed from behind, looking like the mere stem to the great nosegay suggested by hers. They disappeared round the curve of the road, and only his (Angel) sousing footsteps and the top ribbon of Marian's bonnet told where they were. In a few minutes he (Angel) reappeared. Izz Huett was the next in order upon the bank.

``Here he (my) comes,'' (she)
she (Marian) murmured, and they could hear that her (Marian) lips were dry with emotion.
``And I have to put my arms round his (my) neck and look into his (my) face as Marian did.'' (unknown)

``There's nothing in that,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess quickly.

``There's a time for everything,'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
continued Izz, unheeding.
``A time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing; the first is now going to be mine.'' (unknown)

``Fie--it is Scripture, Izz!'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
said Izz,
``I've always a' ear at church for pretty verses.'' (Izz/Izz Huett)

Angel Clare, to whom three-quarters of this performance was a commonplace act of kindness, now approached Izz. She (Tess) quietly and dreamily lowered herself into his (Izz) arms, and Angel methodically marched off with her (Tess). When he (Angel) was heard returning for the third time Retty's throbbing heart could be almost seen to shake her (Tess). He (Angel) went up to the red-haired girl, and while he (Angel) was seizing her (girl) he (Angel) glanced at Tess. His (Angel) lips could not have pronounced more plainly,

``It will soon be you and I.'' (she)
Her (girl) comprehension appeared in her (girl) face; she (girl) could not help it. There was an understanding between them.

Poor little Retty, though by far the lightest weight, was the most troublesome of Clare's burdens. Marian had been like a sack of meal, a dead weight of plumpness under which he (Clare) has literally staggered. Izz had ridden sensibly and calmly. Retty was a bunch of hysterics.

However, he (Izz) got through with the disquieted creature, deposited her (Marian), and returned. Tess could see over the hedge the distant three in a group, standing as he (Izz) had placed them on the next rising ground. It was now her (Tess) turn. She (Tess) was embarrassed to discover that excitement at the proximity of Mr Clare's breath and eyes, which she (Tess) had contemned in her (Tess) companions, was intensified in herself; and as if fearful of betraying her (Tess) secret, she (Tess) paltered with him (Clare) at the last moment.

``I may be able to clim' along the bank perhaps--I can clim' better than they. You must be so tired, Mr Clare!'' (unknown)

``No, no, Tess,'' (he)
said he (Clare) quickly. And almost before she (Tess) was aware, she (Tess) was seated in his (Clare) arms and resting against his (Clare) shoulder.

``Three Leahs to get one Rachel,'' (he)
he (Clare) whispered.

``They are better women than I,'' (she)
she (Tess) replied, magnanimously sticking to her (Tess) resolve.

``Not to me,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Angel.

He (Angel) saw her (Tess) grow warm at this; and they went some steps in silence.

``I hope I am not too heavy?'' (she)
she (Tess) said timidly.

``O no. You should lift Marian! Such a lump. You are like an undulating billow warmed by the sun. And all this fluff of muslin about you is the froth.'' (unknown)

``It is very pretty--if I seem like that to you.'' (unknown)

``Do you know that I have undergone three-quarters of this labour entirely for the sake of the fourth quarter?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``I did not expect such an event to-day.'' (unknown)

``Nor I... The water came up so sudden.'' (she)

That the rise in the water was what she (Tess) understood him (Angel) to refer to, the state of breathing belied. Clare stood still and inclinced his (Clare) face towards hers.

``O Tessy!'' (he)
he (Clare) exclaimed.

The girl's cheeks burned to the breeze, and she (girl) could not look into his (Clare) eyes for her (girl) emotion. It reminded Angel that he (Angel) was somewhat unfairly taking advantage of an accidental position; and he (Angel) went no further with it. No definite words of love had crossed their lips as yet, and suspension at this point was desirable now. However, he (Angel) walked slowly, to make the remainder of the distance as long as possible; but at last they came to the bend, and the rest of their progress was in full view of the other three. The dry land was reached, and he (Angel) set her (girl) down.

Her (girl) friends were looking with round thoughtful eyes at her (girl) and him (Angel), and she (girl) could see that they had been talking of her (girl). He (Angel) hastily bade them farewell, and splashed back along the stretch of submerged road.

The four moved on together as before, till Marian broke the silence by saying--

``No--in all truth; we have no chance against her (you)!'' (Marian)
She (Marian) looked joylessly at Tess.

``What do you mean?'' (unknown)
asked the latter.

``He (I) likes `ee best--the very best! We could see it as he (I) brought `ee. He (I) would have kissed `ee, if you had encouraged him (I) to do it, ever so little.'' (unknown)

``No, no,'' (she)
said she (Marian).

The gaiety with which they had set out had somehow vanished; and yet there was no enmity or malice between them. They were generous young souls; they had been reared in the lonely country nooks where fatalism is a strong sentiment, and they did not blame her (Marian). Such supplanting was to be.

Tess's heart ached. There was no concealing from herself the fact that she (Tess) loved Angel Clare, perhaps all the more passionately from knowing that the others had also lost their hearts to him (Clare). There is contagion in this sentiment, especially among women. And yet that same hungry nature had fought against this, but too feebly, and the natural result had followed.

``I will never stand in your way, nor in the way of either of you!'' (she)
she (Tess) declared to Retty that night in the bedroom -LRB-her (Tess) tears running down-RRB-.
``I can't help this, my dear! I don't think marrying is in his (I) mind at all; but if he (I) were ever to ask me I should refuse him (I), as I should refuse any man.'' (unknown)

``Oh! would you? Why?'' (unknown)
said wondering Retty.

``It cannot be! But I will be plain. Putting myself quite on one side, I don't think he (man) will choose either of you.'' (unknown)

``I have never expected it--thought of it!'' (unknown)
moaned Retty.
``But O! I wish I was dead!'' (The child)

The poor child, torn by a feeling which she (Tess) hardly understood, turned to the other two girls who came upstairs just then.

``We be friends with her (man) again,'' (she)
she (Tess) said to them.
``She (man) thinks no more of his (man) choosing her (man) than we do.'' (unknown)

So the reserve went off, and they were confiding and warm.

``I don't seem to care what I do now,'' (Marian)
said Marian, whose mood was turned to its lowest bass.
``I was going to marry a dairyman at Stickleford, who's asked me twice; but--my soul--I would put an end to myself rather'n be his (dairyman) wife now! Why don't ye speak, Izz?'' (unknown)

``To confess, then,'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
murmured Izz,
``I made sure to-day that he (Izz) was going to kiss me as he (Izz) held me; and I lay still against his (Izz) breast, hoping and hoping, and never moved at all. But he (Izz) did not. I don't like biding here at Talbothays any longer! I shall go hwome.'' (Izz/Izz Huett)

The air of the sleeping-chamber seemed to palpitate with the hopeless passion of the girls. They writhed feverishly under the oppressiveness of an emotion thrust on them by cruel Nature's law--an emotion which they had neither expected nor desired. The incident of the day had fanned the flame that was burning the inside of their hearts out, and the torture was almost more than they could endure. The differences which distinguished them as individuals were abstracted by this passion, and each was but portion of one organism called sex. There was so much frankness and so little jealousy because there was no hope. Each one was a girl of fair common sense, and she (girl) did not delude herself with any vain conceits, or deny her (girl) love, or give herself airs, in the idea of outshining the others. The full recognition of the futility of their infatuation, from a social point of view; its purposeless beginning; its self-bounded outlook; its lack of everything to justify its existence in the eye of civilization -LRB-while lacking nothing in the eye of Nature-RRB-; the one fact that it did exist, ecstasizing them to a killing joy--all this imparted to them a resignation, a dignity, which a practical and sordid expectation of winning him (their) as a husband would have destroyed.

They tossed and turned on their little beds, and the cheese-wring dripped monotonously downstairs.

``B' you awake, Tess?'' (unknown)
whispered one, half-an-hour later.

It was Izz Huett's voice.

Tess replied in the affirmative, whereupon also Retty and Marian suddenly flung the bedclothes off them, and sighed--

``So be we!'' (Marian)

``I wonder what she (Tess) is like--the lady they say his (Izz) family have looked out for him (Izz)!'' (unknown)

``I wonder,'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
said Izz.

``Some lady looked out for him (Izz)?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
gasped Tess, starting.
``I have never heard o' that!'' (unknown)

``O yes--`tis whispered; a young lady of his (Izz) own rank, chosen by his (Izz) family; a Doctor of Divinity's daughter near his (Izz) father's parish of Emminster; he (Izz) don't much care for her (daughter), they say. But he (Izz) is sure to marry her (daughter).'' (unknown)

They had heard so very little of this; yet it was enough to build up wretched dolorous dreams upon, there in the shade of the night. They pictured all the details of his (Izz) being won round to consent, of the wedding preparations, of the bride's happiness, of her (bride) dress and veil, of her (bride) blissful home with him (Izz), when oblivion would have fallen upon themselves as far as he (Izz) and their love were concerned. Thus they talked, and ached, and wept till sleep charmed their sorrow away.

After this disclosure Tess nourished no further foolish thought that there lurked any grave and deliberate import in Clare's attentions to her (Tess). It was a passing summer love of her (Tess) face, for love's own temporary sake--nothing more. And the thorny crown of this sad conception was that she (Tess) whom he (Clare) really did prefer in a cursory way to the rest, she (Tess) who knew herself to be more impassioned in nature, cleverer, more beautiful than they, was in the eyes of propriety far less worthy of him (Clare) than the homelier ones whom he (Clare) ignored.

XXIV

Amid the oozing fatness and warm ferments of the Froom Vale, at a season when the rush of juices could almost be heard below the hiss of fertilization, it was impossible that the most fanciful love should not grow passionate. The ready bosoms existing there were impregnated by their surroundings.

July passed over their heads, and the Thermidorean weather which came in its wake seemed an effort on the part of Nature to match the state of hearts at Talbothays Dairy. The air of the place, so fresh in the spring and early summer, was stagnant and enervating now. Its heavy scents weighed upon them, and at mid-day the landscape seemed lying in a swoon. Ethiopic scorchings browned the upper slopes of the pastures, but there was still bright green herbage here where the watercourses purled. And as Clare was oppressed by the outward heats, so was he (Clare) burdened inwardly by waxing fervour of passion for the soft and silent Tess.

The rains having passed, the uplands were dry. The wheels of the dairyman's spring-cart, as he (dairyman) sped home from market, licked up the pulverized surface of the highway, and were followed by white ribands of dust, as if they had set a thin powder-train on fire. The cows jumped wildly over the five-barred barton-gate, maddened by the gad-fly; Dairyman Crick kept his (Crick) shirt-sleeves permanently rolled up from Monday to Saturday; open windows had no effect in ventilation without open doors, and in the dairy-garden the blackbirds and thrushes crept about under the currant-bushes, rather in the manner of quadrupeds than of winged creatures. The flies in the kitchen were lazy, teasing, and familiar, crawling about in the unwonted places, on the floors, into drawers, and over the backs of the milkmaids' hands. Conversations were concerning sunstroke; while butter-making, and still more butter-keeping, was a despair.

They milked entirely in the meads for coolness and convenience, without driving in the cows. During the day the animals obsequiously followed the shadow of the smallest tree as it moved round the stem with the diurnal roll; and when the milkers came they could hardly stand still for the flies.

On one of these afternoons four or five unmilked cows chanced to stand apart from the general herd, behind the corner of a hedge, among them being Dumpling and Old Pretty, who loved Tess's hands above those of any other maid. When she (maid) rose from her (maid) stool under a finished cow, Angel Clare, who had been observing her (maid) for some time, asked her (maid) if she (maid) would take the aforesaid creatures next. She (maid) silently assented, and with her (maid) stool at arm's length, and the pail against her (maid) knee, went round to where they stood. Soon the sound of Old Pretty's milk fizzing into the pail came through the hedge, and then Angel felt inclined to go round the corner also, to finish off a hard-yielding milcher who had strayed there, he (Angel) being now as capable of this as the dairyman himself.

All the men, and some of the women, when milking, dug their foreheads into the cows and gazed into the pail. But a few--mainly the younger ones--rested their heads sideways. This was Tess Durbeyfield's habit, her (Durbeyfield) temple pressing the milcher's flank, her (Durbeyfield) eyes fixed on the far end of the meadow with the quiet of one lost in meditation. She (Durbeyfield) was milking Old Pretty thus, and the sun chancing to be on the milking-side, it shone flat upon her (Durbeyfield) pink-gowned form and her (Durbeyfield) white curtain-bonnet, and upon her (Durbeyfield) profile, rendering it keen as a cameo cut from the dun background of the cow.

She (Durbeyfield) did not know that Clare had followed her (Durbeyfield) round, and that he (Clare) sat under his (Clare) cow watching her (Durbeyfield). The stillness of her (Durbeyfield) head and features was remarkable: she (Durbeyfield) might have been in a trance, her (Durbeyfield) eyes open, yet unseeing. Nothing in the picture moved but Old Pretty's tail and Tess's pink hands, the latter so gently as to be a rhythmic pulsation only, as if they were obeying a reflex stimulus, like a beating heart.

How very lovable her (Tess) face was to him (Clare). Yet there was nothing ethereal about it; all was real vitality, real warmth, real incarnation. And it was in her (Tess) mouth that this culminated. Eyes almost as deep and speaking he (Clare) had seen before, and cheeks perhaps as fair; brows as arched, a chin and throat almost as shapely; her (Tess) mouth he (Clare) had seen nothing to equal on the face of the earth. To a young man with the least fire in him (man) that little upward lift in the middle of her (Tess) red top lip was distracting, infatuating, maddening. He (lip) had never before seen a woman's lips and teeth which forced upon his (lip) mind with such persistent iteration the old Elizabethan simile of roses filled with snow. Perfect, he (lip), as a lover, might have called them off-hand. But no--they were not perfect. And it was the touch of the imperfect upon the would-be perfect that gave the sweetness, because it was that which gave the humanity.

Clare had studied the curves of those lips so many times that he (Clare) could reproduce them mentally with ease: and now, as they again confronted him (Clare), clothed with colour and life, they sent an _aura_ over his (Clare) flesh, a breeze through his (Clare) nerves, which well nigh produced a qualm; and actually produced, by some mysterious physiological process, a prosaic sneeze.

She (Clare) then became conscious that he (Clare) was observing her (Clare); but she (Clare) would not show it by any change of position, though the curious dream-like fixity disappeared, and a close eye might easily have discerned that the rosiness of her (Clare) face deepened, and then faded till only a tinge of it was left.

The influence that had passed into Clare like an excitation from the sky did not die down. Resolutions, reticences, prudences, fears, fell back like a defeated battalion. He (Clare) jumped up from his (Clare) seat, and, leaving his (Clare) pail to be kicked over if the milcher had such a mind, went quickly towards the desire of his (Clare) eyes, and, kneeling down beside her (Clare), clasped her (Clare) in his (Clare) arms.

Tess was taken completely by surprise, and she (Tess) yielded to his (Clare) embrace with unreflecting inevitableness. Having seen that it was really her (Tess) lover who had advanced, and no one else, her (Tess) lips parted, and she (Tess) sank upon him (lover) in her (Tess) momentary joy, with something very like an ecstatic cry.

He (lover) had been on the point of kissing that too tempting mouth, but he (lover) checked himself, for tender conscience' sake.

``Forgive me, Tess dear!'' (he)
he (lover) whispered.
``I ought to have asked. I--did not know what I was doing. I do not mean it as a liberty. I am devoted to you, Tessy, dearest, in all sincerity!'' (unknown)

Old Pretty by this time had looked round, puzzled; and seeing two people crouching under her (Tess) where, by immemorial custom, there should have been only one, lifted her (Tess) hind leg crossly.

``She (Tess) is angry--she (Tess) doesn't know what we mean--she (Tess)'ll kick over the milk!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
exclaimed Tess, gently striving to free herself, her (Tess) eyes concerned with the quadruped's actions, her (Tess) heart more deeply concerned with herself and Clare.

She (Tess) slipped up from her (Tess) seat, and they stood together, his (Clare) arm still encircling her (Tess). Tess's eyes, fixed on distance, began to fill.

``Why do you cry, my darling?'' (he)
he (Clare) said.

``O--I don't know!'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured.

As she (Tess) saw and felt more clearly the position she (Tess) was in she (Tess) became agitated and tried to withdraw.

``Well, I have betrayed my feeling, Tess, at last,'' (he)
said he (Clare), with a curious sigh of desperation, signifying unconsciously that his (Clare) heart had outrun his (Clare) judgement.
``That I--love you dearly and truly I need not say. But I--it shall go no further now--it distresses you--I am as surprised as you are. You will not think I have presumed upon your defencelessness--been too quick and unreflecting, will you?'' (unknown)

``N'--I can't tell.'' (He)

He (Clare) had allowed her (Tess) to free herself; and in a minute or two the milking of each was resumed. Nobody had beheld the gravitation of the two into one; and when the dairyman came round by that screened nook a few minutes later, there was not a sign to reveal that the markedly sundered pair were more to each other than mere acquaintance. Yet in the interval since Crick's last view of them something had occurred which changed the pivot of the universe for their two natures; something which, had he (Crick) known its quality, the dairyman would have despised, as a practical man; yet which was based upon a more stubborn and resistless tendency than a whole heap of so-called practicalities. A veil had been whisked aside; the tract of each one's outlook was to have a new horizon thenceforward--for a short time or for a long.

END OF PHASE THE THIRD

Phase the Fourth: The Consequence

XXV

Clare, restless, went out into the dusk when evening drew on, she (their) who had won him (Clare) having retired to her (their) chamber.

The night was as sultry as the day. There was no coolness after dark unless on the grass. Roads, garden-paths, the house-fronts, the barton-walls were warm as hearths, and reflected the noontime temperature into the noctambulist's face.

He (Clare) sat on the east gate of the dairy-yard, and knew not what to think of himself. Feeling had indeed smothered judgement that day.

Since the sudden embrace, three hours before, the twain had kept apart. She (twain) seemed stilled, almost alarmed, at what had occurred, while the novelty, unpremeditation, mastery of circumstance disquieted him (Clare)--palpitating, contemplative being that he (Clare) was. He (Clare) could hardly realize their true relations to each other as yet, and what their mutual bearing should be before third parties thenceforward.

Angel had come as pupil to this dairy in the idea that his (Angel) temporary existence here was to be the merest episode in his (Angel) life, soon passed through and early forgotten; he (Angel) had come as to a place from which as from a screened alcove he (Angel) could calmly view the absorbing world without, and, apostrophizing it with Walt Whitman--

Crowds of men and women attired in the usual costumes, How curious you are to me!--

resolve upon a plan for plunging into that world anew. But behold, the absorbing scene had been imported hither. What had been the engrossing world had dissolved into an uninteresting outer dumb-show; while here, in this apparently dim and unimpassioned place, novelty had volcanically started up, as it had never, for him (Walt), started up elsewhere.

Every window of the house being open, Clare could hear across the yard each trivial sound of the retiring household. The dairy-house, so humble, so insignificant, so purely to him (Clare) a place of constrained sojourn that he (Clare) had never hitherto deemed it of sufficient importance to be reconnoitred as an object of any quality whatever in the landscape; what was it now? The aged and lichened brick gables breathed forth

``Stay!'' (unknown)
The windows smiled, the door coaxed and beckoned, the creeper blushed confederacy. A personality within it was so far-reaching in her (Clare) influence as to spread into and make the bricks, mortar, and whole overhanging sky throb with a burning sensibility. Whose was this mighty personality? A milkmaid's.

It was amazing, indeed, to find how great a matter the life of the obscure dairy had become to him (Clare). And though new love was to be held partly responsible for this, it was not solely so. Many besides Angel have learnt that the magnitude of lives is not as to their external displacements, but as to their subjective experiences. The impressionable peasant leads a larger, fuller, more dramatic life than the pachydermatous king. Looking at it thus, he (king) found that life was to be seen of the same magnitude here as elsewhere.

Despite his (king) heterodoxy, faults, and weaknesses, Clare was a man with a conscience. Tess was no insignificant creature to toy with and dismiss; but a woman living her (woman) precious life--a life which, to herself who endured or enjoyed it, possessed as great a dimension as the life of the mightiest to himself. Upon her (woman) sensations the whole world depended to Tess; through her (Tess) existence all her (Tess) fellow-creatures existed, to her (Tess). The universe itself only came into being for Tess on the particular day in the particular year in which she (Tess) was born.

This consciousness upon which he (Clare) had intruded was the single opportunity of existence ever vouchsafed to Tess by an unsympathetic First Cause--her (Tess) all; her (Tess) every and only chance. How then should he (Clare) look upon her (Tess) as of less consequence than himself; as a pretty trifle to caress and grow weary of; and not deal in the greatest seriousness with the affection which he (Clare) knew that he (Clare) had awakened in her (Tess)--so fervid and so impressionable as she (Tess) was under her (Tess) reserve--in order that it might not agonize and wreck her (Tess)?

To encounter her (Tess) daily in the accustomed manner would be to develop what had begun. Living in such close relations, to meet meant to fall into endearment; flesh and blood could not resist it; and, having arrived at no conclusion as to the issue of such a tendency, he (Clare) decided to hold aloof for the present from occupations in which they would be mutually engaged. As yet the harm done was small.

But it was not easy to carry out the resolution never to approach her (Tess). He (Clare) was driven towards her (Tess) by every heave of his (Clare) pulse.

He (Clare) thought he (Clare) would go and see his (Clare) friends. It might be possible to sound them upon this. In less than five months his (Clare) term here would have ended, and after a few additional months spent upon other farms he (Clare) would be fully equipped in agricultural knowledge and in a position to start on his (Clare) own account. Would not a farmer want a wife, and should a farmer's wife be a drawing-room wax-figure, or a woman who understood farming? Notwithstanding the pleasing answer returned to him (farmer) by the silence, he (farmer) resolved to go his (farmer) journey.

One morning when they sat down to breakfast at Talbothays Dairy some maid observed that she (maid) had not seen anything of Mr Clare that day.

``O no,'' (Dairyman Crick/Crick)
said Dairyman Crick.
``Mr Clare has gone hwome to Emminster to spend a few days wi' his (Clare) kinsfolk.'' (ones)

For four impassioned ones around that table the sunshine of the morning went out at a stroke, and the birds muffled their song. But neither girl by word or gesture revealed her (girl) blankness.

``He (Clare)'s getting on towards the end of his (Clare) time wi' me,'' (the dairyman)
added the dairyman, with a phlegm which unconsciously was brutal;
``and so I suppose he (Clare) is beginning to see about his (Clare) plans elsewhere.'' (the dairyman)

``How much longer is he (Clare) to bide here?'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
asked Izz Huett, the only one of the gloom-stricken bevy who could trust her (girl) voice with the question.

The others waited for the dairyman's answer as if their lives hung upon it; Retty, with parted lips, gazing on the tablecloth, Marian with heat added to her (Marian) redness, Tess throbbing and looking out at the meads.

``Well, I can't mind the exact day without looking at my memorandum-book,'' (Dairyman Crick/Crick)
replied Crick, with the same intolerable unconcern.
``And even that may be altered a bit. He (Clare)'ll bide to get a little practice in the calving out at the straw-yard, for certain. He (Clare)'ll hang on till the end of the year I should say.'' (unknown)

Four months or so of torturing ecstasy in his (Crick) society--of

``pleasure girdled about with pain'' (unknown)
. After that the blackness of unutterable night.

At this moment of the morning Angel Clare was riding along a narrow lane ten miles distant from the breakfasters, in the direction of his (Clare) father's Vicarage at Emminster, carrying, as well as he (Clare) could, a little basket which contained some black-puddings and a bottle of mead, sent by Mrs Crick, with her (Crick) kind respects, to his (Clare) parents. The white lane stretched before him (Clare), and his (Clare) eyes were upon it; but they were staring into next year, and not at the lane. He (Clare) loved her (Crick); ought he (Clare) to marry her (Crick)? Dared he (Clare) to marry her (Crick)? What would his (Clare) mother and his (Clare) brothers say? What would he (Clare) himself say a couple of years after the event? That would depend upon whether the germs of staunch comradeship underlay the temporary emotion, or whether it were a sensuous joy in her (mother) form only, with no substratum of everlastingness.

His (Clare) father's hill-surrounded little town, the Tudor church-tower of red stone, the clump of trees near the Vicarage, came at last into view beneath him (Tudor), and he (Tudor) rode down towards the well-known gate. Casting a glance in the direction of the church before entering his (Tudor) home, he (Tudor) beheld standing by the vestry-door a group of girls, of ages between twelve and sixteen, apparently awaiting the arrival of some other one, who in a moment became visible; a figure somewhat older than the school-girls, wearing a broad-brimmed hat and highly-starched cambric morning-gown, with a couple of books in her (Tudor) hand.

Clare knew her (Tudor) well. He (Clare) could not be sure that she (Tudor) observed him (Clare); he (Clare) hoped she (Tudor) did not, so as to render it unnecessary that he (Clare) should go and speak to her (Tudor), blameless creature that she (Tudor) was. An overpowering reluctance to greet her (Tudor) made him (Clare) decide that she (Tudor) had not seen him (Clare). The young lady was Miss Mercy Chant, the only daughter of his (Clare) father's neighbour and friend, whom it was his (Clare) parents' quiet hope that he (Clare) might wed some day. She (daughter) was great at Antinomianism and Bible-classes, and was plainly going to hold a class now. Clare's mind flew to the impassioned, summer-steeped heathens in the Var Vale, their rosy faces court-patched with cow-droppings; and to one the most impassioned of them all.

It was on the impulse of the moment that he (Clare) had resolved to trot over to Emminster, and hence had not written to apprise his (Clare) mother and father, aiming, however, to arrive about the breakfast hour, before they should have gone out to their parish duties. He (Clare) was a little late, and they had already sat down to the morning meal. The group at the table jumped up to welcome him (Clare) as soon as he (Clare) entered. They were his (Clare) father and mother, his (Clare) brother the Reverend Felix--curate at a town in the adjoining county, home for the inside of a fortnight--and his (Clare) other brother, the Reverend Cuthbert, the classical scholar, and Fellow and Dean of his (Dean) College, down from Cambridge for the long vacation. His (Dean) mother appeared in a cap and silver spectacles, and his (Dean) father looked what in fact he (Dean) was--an earnest, God-fearing man, somewhat gaunt, in years about sixty-five, his (Dean) pale face lined with thought and purpose. Over their heads hung the picture of Angel's sister, the eldest of the family, sixteen years his (Angel) senior, who had married a missionary and gone out to Africa.

Old Mr Clare was a clergyman of a type which, within the last twenty years, has well nigh dropped out of contemporary life. A spiritual descendant in the direct line from Wycliff, Huss, Luther, Calvin; an Evangelical of the Evangelicals, a Conversionist, a man of Apostolic simplicity in life and thought, he (man) had in his (man) raw youth made up his (man) mind once for all in the deeper questions of existence, and admitted no further reasoning on them thenceforward. He (man) was regarded even by those of his (man) own date and school of thinking as extreme; while, on the other hand, those totally opposed to him (man) were unwillingly won to admiration for his (man) thoroughness, and for the remarkable power he (man) showed in dismissing all question as to principles in his (man) energy for applying them. He (man) loved Paul of Tarsus, liked St John, hated St James as much as he (James) dared, and regarded with mixed feelings Timothy, Titus, and Philemon. The New Testament was less a Christiad then a Pauliad to his (Philemon) intelligence--less an argument than an intoxication. His (Philemon) creed of determinism was such that it almost amounted to a vice, and quite amounted, on its negative side, to a renunciative philosophy which had cousinship with that of Schopenhauer and Leopardi. He (Philemon) despised the Canons and Rubric, swore by the Articles, and deemed himself consistent through the whole category--which in a way he (Philemon) might have been. One thing he (Philemon) certainly was--sincere.

To the aesthetic, sensuous, pagan pleasure in natural life and lush womanhood which his (Philemon) son Angel had lately been experiencing in Var Vale, his (Angel) temper would have been antipathetic in a high degree, had he (Angel) either by inquiry or imagination been able to apprehend it. Once upon a time Angel had been so unlucky as to say to his (Angel) father, in a moment of irritation, that it might have resulted far better for mankind if Greece had been the source of the religion of modern civilization, and not Palestine; and his (Angel) father's grief was of that blank description which could not realize that there might lurk a thousandth part of a truth, much less a half truth or a whole truth, in such a proposition. He (Angel) had simply preached austerely at Angel for some time after. But the kindness of his (Angel) heart was such that he (Angel) never resented anything for long, and welcomed his (Angel) son to-day with a smile which was as candidly sweet as a child's.

Angel sat down, and the place felt like home; yet he (Angel) did not so much as formerly feel himself one of the family gathered there. Every time that he (Angel) returned hither he (Angel) was conscious of this divergence, and since he (Angel) had last shared in the Vicarage life it had grown even more distinctly foreign to his (Angel) own than usual. Its transcendental aspirations--still unconsciously based on the geocentric view of things, a zenithal paradise, a nadiral hell--were as foreign to his (Angel) own as if they had been the dreams of people on another planet. Latterly he (Angel) had seen only Life, felt only the great passionate pulse of existence, unwarped, uncontorted, untrammelled by those creeds which futilely attempt to check what wisdom would be content to regulate.

On their part they saw a great difference in him (Angel), a growing divergence from the Angel Clare of former times. It was chiefly a difference in his (Angel) manner that they noticed just now, particularly his (Angel) brothers. He (Angel) was getting to behave like a farmer; he (Angel) flung his (Angel) legs about; the muscles of his (Angel) face had grown more expressive; his (Angel) eyes looked as much information as his (Angel) tongue spoke, and more. The manner of the scholar had nearly disappeared; still more the manner of the drawing-room young man. A prig would have said that he (man) had lost culture, and a prude that he (man) had become coarse. Such was the contagion of domiciliary fellowship with the Talbothays nymphs and swains.

After breakfast he (man) walked with his (man) two brothers, non-evangelical, well-educated, hall-marked young men, correct to their remotest fibre, such unimpeachable models as are turned out yearly by the lathe of a systematic tuition. They were both somewhat short-sighted, and when it was the custom to wear a single eyeglass and string they wore a single eyeglass and string; when it was the custom to wear a double glass they wore a double glass; when it was the custom to wear spectacles they wore spectacles straightway, all without reference to the particular variety of defect in their own vision. When Wordsworth was enthroned they carried pocket copies; and when Shelley was belittled they allowed him (Shelley) to grow dusty on their shelves. When Correggio's Holy Families were admired, they admired Correggio's Holy Families; when he (Shelley) was decried in favour of Velasquez, they sedulously followed suit without any personal objection.

If these two noticed Angel's growing social ineptness, he (Angel) noticed their growing mental limitations. Felix seemed to him (Angel) all Church; Cuthbert all College. His (Angel) Diocesan Synod and Visitations were the mainsprings of the world to the one; Cambridge to the other. Each brother candidly recognized that there were a few unimportant score of millions of outsiders in civilized society, persons who were neither University men nor churchmen; but they were to be tolerated rather than reckoned with and respected.

They were both dutiful and attentive sons, and were regular in their visits to their parents. Felix, though an offshoot from a far more recent point in the devolution of theology than his (brother) father, was less self-sacrificing and disinterested. More tolerant than his (brother) father of a contradictory opinion, in its aspect as a danger to its holder, he (brother) was less ready than his (brother) father to pardon it as a slight to his (brother) own teaching. Cuthbert was, upon the whole, the more liberal-minded, though, with greater subtlety, he (brother) had not so much heart.

As they walked along the hillside Angel's former feeling revived in him (Angel)--that whatever their advantages by comparison with himself, neither saw or set forth life as it really was lived. Perhaps, as with many men, their opportunities of observation were not so good as their opportunities of expression. Neither had an adequate conception of the complicated forces at work outside the smooth and gentle current in which they and their associates floated. Neither saw the difference between local truth and universal truth; that what the inner world said in their clerical and academic hearing was quite a different thing from what the outer world was thinking.

``I suppose it is farming or nothing for you now, my dear fellow,'' (Felix)
Felix was saying, among other things, to his (their) youngest brother, as he (their) looked through his (their) spectacles at the distant fields with sad austerity.
``And, therefore, we must make the best of it. But I do entreat you to endeavour to keep as much as possible in touch with moral ideals. Farming, of course, means roughing it externally; but high thinking may go with plain living, nevertheless.'' (unknown)

``Of course it may,'' (Angel)
said Angel.
``Was it not proved nineteen hundred years ago--if I may trespass upon your domain a little? Why should you think, Felix, that I am likely to drop my high thinking and my moral ideals?'' (unknown)

``Well, I fancied, from the tone of your letters and our conversation--it may be fancy only--that you were somehow losing intellectual grasp. Hasn't it struck you, Cuthbert?'' (unknown)

``Now, Felix,'' (Angel)
said Angel drily,
``we are very good friends, you know; each of us treading our allotted circles; but if it comes to intellectual grasp, I think you, as a contented dogmatist, had better leave mine alone, and inquire what has become of yours.'' (Angel)

They returned down the hill to dinner, which was fixed at any time at which their father's and mother's morning work in the parish usually concluded. Convenience as regarded afternoon callers was the last thing to enter into the consideration of unselfish Mr and Mrs Clare; though the three sons were sufficiently in unison on this matter to wish that their parents would conform a little to modern notions.

The walk had made them hungry, Angel in particular, who was now an outdoor man, accustomed to the profuse _dapes inemptae_ of the dairyman's somewhat coarsely-laden table. But neither of the old people had arrived, and it was not till the sons were almost tired of waiting that their parents entered. The self-denying pair had been occupied in coaxing the appetites of some of their sick parishioners, whom they, somewhat inconsistently, tried to keep imprisoned in the flesh, their own appetites being quite forgotten.

The family sat down to table, and a frugal meal of cold viands was deposited before them. Angel looked round for Mrs Crick's black-puddings, which he (Angel) had directed to be nicely grilled as they did them at the dairy, and of which he (Angel) wished his (Angel) father and mother to appreciate the marvellous herbal savours as highly as he (Angel) did himself.

``Ah! you are looking for the black-puddings, my dear boy,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
observed Clare's mother.
``But I am sure you will not mind doing without them as I am sure your father and I shall not, when you know the reason. I suggested to him (father) that we should take Mrs Crick's kind present to the children of the man who can earn nothing just now because of his (man) attacks of delirium tremens; and he (man) agreed that it would be a great pleasure to them; so we did.'' (unknown)

``Of course,'' (Angel)
said Angel cheerfully, looking round for the mead.

``I found the mead so extremely alcoholic,'' (mother)
continued his (Angel) mother,
``that it was quite unfit for use as a beverage, but as valuable as rum or brandy in an emergency; so I have put it in my medicine-closet.'' (mother)

``We never drink spirits at this table, on principle,'' (father)
added his (Angel) father.

``But what shall I tell the dairyman's wife?'' (Angel)
said Angel.

``The truth, of course,'' (father)
said his (Angel) father.

``I rather wanted to say we enjoyed the mead and the black-puddings very much. She (wife) is a kind, jolly sort of body, and is sure to ask me directly I return.'' (unknown)

``You cannot, if we did not,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
Mr Clare answered lucidly.

``Ah--no; though that mead was a drop of pretty tipple.'' (unknown)

``A what?'' (Cuthbert)
said Cuthbert and Felix both.

``Oh--`tis an expression they use down at Talbothays,'' (Angel)
replied Angel, blushing. He (Angel) felt that his (Angel) parents were right in their practice if wrong in their want of sentiment, and said no more.

XXVI

It was not till the evening, after family prayers, that Angel found opportunity of broaching to his (Angel) father one or two subjects near his (Angel) heart. He (Angel) had strung himself up to the purpose while kneeling behind his (Angel) brothers on the carpet, studying the little nails in the heels of their walking boots. When the service was over they went out of the room with their mother, and Mr Clare and himself were left alone.

The young man first discussed with the elder his (man) plans for the attainment of his (man) position as a farmer on an extensive scale--either in England or in the Colonies. His (man) father then told him (man) that, as he (man) had not been put to the expense of sending Angel up to Cambridge, he (Angel) had felt it his (Angel) duty to set by a sum of money every year towards the purchase or lease of land for him (Angel) some day, that he (Angel) might not feel himself unduly slighted.

``As far as worldly wealth goes,'' (father)
continued his (Angel) father,
``you will no doubt stand far superior to your brothers in a few years.'' (father)

This considerateness on old Mr Clare's part led Angel onward to the other and dearer subject. He (Angel) observed to his (Angel) father that he (Angel) was then six-and-twenty, and that when he (Angel) should start in the farming business he (Angel) would require eyes in the back of his (Angel) head to see to all matters--some one would be necessary to superintend the domestic labours of his (Angel) establishment whilst he (Angel) was afield. Would it not be well, therefore, for him (Angel) to marry?

His (Angel) father seemed to think this idea not unreasonable; and then Angel put the question--

``What kind of wife do you think would be best for me as a thrifty hard-working farmer?'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

``A truly Christian woman, who will be a help and a comfort to you in your goings-out and your comings-in. Beyond that, it really matters little. Such an one can be found; indeed, my earnest-minded friend and neighbour, Dr Chant--'' (unknown)

``But ought she (woman) not primarily to be able to milk cows, churn good butter, make immense cheeses; know how to sit hens and turkeys and rear chickens, to direct a field of labourers in an emergency, and estimate the value of sheep and calves?'' (unknown)

``Yes; a farmer's wife; yes, certainly. It would be desirable.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
Mr Clare, the elder, had plainly never thought of these points before.
``I was going to add,'' (he)
he (Clare) said,
``that for a pure and saintly woman you will not find one more to your true advantage, and certainly not more to your mother's mind and my own, than your friend Mercy, whom you used to show a certain interest in. It is true that my neighbour Chant's daughter had lately caught up the fashion of the younger clergy round about us for decorating the Communion-table--altar, as I was shocked to hear her (daughter) call it one day--with flowers and other stuff on festival occasions. But her (daughter) father, who is quite as opposed to such flummery as I, says that can be cured. It is a mere girlish outbreak which, I am sure, will not be permanent.'' (he)

``Yes, yes; Mercy is good and devout, I know. But, father, don't you think that a young woman equally pure and virtuous as Miss Chant, but one who, in place of that lady's ecclesiastical accomplishments, understands the duties of farm life as well as a farmer himself, would suit me infinitely better?'' (father)

His (Clare) father persisted in his (father) conviction that a knowledge of a farmer's wife's duties came second to a Pauline view of humanity; and the impulsive Angel, wishing to honour his (Angel) father's feelings and to advance the cause of his (Angel) heart at the same time, grew specious. He (Angel) said that fate or Providence had thrown in his (Angel) way a woman who possessed every qualification to be the helpmate of an agriculturist, and was decidedly of a serious turn of mind. He (Angel) would not say whether or not she (woman) had attached herself to the sound Low Church School of his (Angel) father; but she (woman) would probably be open to conviction on that point; she (woman) was a regular church-goer of simple faith; honest-hearted, receptive, intelligent, graceful to a degree, chaste as a vestal, and, in personal appearance, exceptionally beautiful.

``Is she (lady) of a family such as you would care to marry into--a lady, in short?'' (mother)
asked his (church-goer) startled mother, who had come softly into the study during the conversation.

``She (lady) is not what in common parlance is called a lady,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Angel, unflinchingly,
``for she (lady) is a cottager's daughter, as I am proud to say. But she (lady) IS a lady, nevertheless--in feeling and nature.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

``Mercy Chant is of a very good family.'' (unknown)

``Pooh!--what's the advantage of that, mother?'' (Angel)
said Angel quickly.
``How is family to avail the wife of a man who has to rough it as I have, and shall have to do?'' (unknown)

``Mercy is accomplished. And accomplishments have their charm,'' (mother)
returned his (Angel) mother, looking at him (Angel) through her (mother) silver spectacles.

``As to external accomplishments, what will be the use of them in the life I am going to lead?--while as to her (wife) reading, I can take that in hand. She (wife)'ll be apt pupil enough, as you would say if you knew her (wife). She (wife)'s brim full of poetry--actualized poetry, if I may use the expression. She (wife) LIVES what paper-poets only write... And she (wife) is an unimpeachable Christian, I am sure; perhaps of the very tribe, genus, and species you desire to propagate.'' (unknown)

``O Angel, you are mocking!'' (unknown)

``Mother, I beg pardon. But as she (Mother) really does attend Church almost every Sunday morning, and is a good Christian girl, I am sure you will tolerate any social shortcomings for the sake of that quality, and feel that I may do worse than choose her (girl).'' (Angel)
Angel waxed quite earnest on that rather automatic orthodoxy in his (Angel) beloved Tess which -LRB-never dreaming that it might stand him (Angel) in such good stead-RRB- he (Angel) had been prone to slight when observing it practised by her (Tess) and the other milkmaids, because of its obvious unreality amid beliefs essentially naturalistic.

In their sad doubts as to whether their son had himself any right whatever to the title he (son) claimed for the unknown young woman, Mr and Mrs Clare began to feel it as an advantage not to be overlooked that she (Clare) at least was sound in her (Clare) views; especially as the conjunction of the pair must have arisen by an act of Providence; for Angel never would have made orthodoxy a condition of his (Angel) choice. They said finally that it was better not to act in a hurry, but that they would not object to see her (Clare).

Angel therefore refrained from declaring more particulars now. He (Angel) felt that, single-minded and self-sacrificing as his (Angel) parents were, there yet existed certain latent prejudices of theirs, as middle-class people, which it would require some tact to overcome. For though legally at liberty to do as he (Angel) chose, and though their daughter-in-law's qualifications could make no practical difference to their lives, in the probability of her (daughter-in-law) living far away from them, he (Angel) wished for affection's sake not to wound their sentiment in the most important decision of his (Angel) life.

He (Angel) observed his (Angel) own inconsistencies in dwelling upon accidents in Tess's life as if they were vital features. It was for herself that he (Angel) loved Tess; her (Tess) soul, her (Tess) heart, her (Tess) substance--not for her (Tess) skill in the dairy, her (Tess) aptness as his (Angel) scholar, and certainly not for her (Tess) simple formal faith-professions. Her (Tess) unsophisticated open-air existence required no varnish of conventionality to make it palatable to him (Angel). He (Angel) held that education had as yet but little affected the beats of emotion and impulse on which domestic happiness depends. It was probable that, in the lapse of ages, improved systems of moral and intellectual training would appreciably, perhaps considerably, elevate the involuntary and even the unconscious instincts of human nature; but up to the present day, culture, as far as he (Angel) could see, might be said to have affected only the mental epiderm of those lives which had been brought under its influence. This belief was confirmed by his (Angel) experience of women, which, having latterly been extended from the cultivated middle-class into the rural community, had taught him (Angel) how much less was the intrinsic difference between the good and wise woman of one social stratum and the good and wise woman of another social stratum, than between the good and bad, the wise and the foolish, of the same stratum or class.

It was the morning of his (Angel) departure. His (Angel) brothers had already left the Vicarage to proceed on a walking tour in the north, whence one was to return to his (Angel) college, and the other to his (Angel) curacy. Angel might have accompanied them, but preferred to rejoin his (Angel) sweetheart at Talbothays. He (Angel) would have been an awkward member of the party; for, though the most appreciative humanist, the most ideal religionist, even the best-versed Christologist of the three, there was alienation in the standing consciousness that his (Angel) squareness would not fit the round hole that had been prepared for him (Angel). To neither Felix nor Cuthbert had he (Angel) ventured to mention Tess.

His (Angel) mother made him (Angel) sandwiches, and his (Angel) father accompanied him (Angel), on his (Angel) own mare, a little way along the road. Having fairly well advanced his (Angel) own affairs, Angel listened in a willing silence, as they jogged on together through the shady lanes, to his (Angel) father's account of his (Angel) parish difficulties, and the coldness of brother clergymen whom he (Angel) loved, because of his (Angel) strict interpretations of the New Testament by the light of what they deemed a pernicious Calvinistic doctrine.

``Pernicious!'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Mr Clare, with genial scorn; and he (Clare) proceeded to recount experiences which would show the absurdity of that idea. He (Clare) told of wondrous conversions of evil livers of which he (Clare) had been the instrument, not only amongst the poor, but amongst the rich and well-to-do; and he (Clare) also candidly admitted many failures.

As an instance of the latter, he (Clare) mentioned the case of a young upstart squire named d``Urberville, living some forty miles off, in the neighbourhood of Trantridge.

``Not one of the ancient d``Urbervilles of Kingsbere and other places?'' asked his (Clare) son.

``That curiously historic worn-out family with its ghostly legend of the coach-and-four?'' (unknown)

``O no. The original d

``Urbervilles decayed and disappeared sixty or eighty years ago--at least, I believe so. This seems to be a new family which had taken the name; for the credit of the former knightly line I hope they are spurious, I'm sure. But it is odd to hear you express interest in old families. I thought you set less store by them even than I.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

``You misapprehend me, father; you often do,'' (I.)
said Angel with a little impatience.
``Politically I am sceptical as to the virtue of their being old. Some of the wise even among themselves `exclaim against their own succession,'' (I)
as Hamlet puts it; but lyrically, dramatically, and even historically, I am tenderly attached to them.''

This distinction, though by no means a subtle one, was yet too subtle for Mr Clare the elder, and he (Clare) went on with the story he (Clare) had been about to relate; which was that after the death of the senior so-called d``Urberville, the young man developed the most culpable passions, though he (man) had a blind mother, whose condition should have made him (man) know better. A knowledge of his (man) career having come to the ears of Mr Clare, when he (Clare) was in that part of the country preaching missionary sermons, he (Clare) boldly took occasion to speak to the delinquent on his (Clare) spiritual state. Though he (Clare) was a stranger, occupying another's pulpit, he (Clare) had felt this to be his (Clare) duty, and took for his (Clare) text the words from St Luke:

``Thou fool, this night thy soul shall be required of thee!'' (unknown)
The young man much resented this directness of attack, and in the war of words which followed when they met he (man) did not scruple publicly to insult Mr Clare, without respect for his (Clare) gray hairs.

Angel flushed with distress.

``Dear father,'' (he)
he (Angel) said sadly,
``I wish you would not expose yourself to such gratuitous pain from scoundrels!'' (he)

``Pain?'' (father face)
said his (Angel) father, his (Angel) rugged face shining in the ardour of self-abnegation. ``The only pain to me was pain on his (father) account, poor, foolish young man. Do you suppose his (father) incensed words could give me any pain, or even his (father) blows? ``Being reviled we bless; being persecuted we suffer it; being defamed we entreat; we are made as the filth of the world, and as the offscouring of all things unto this day.
'' Those ancient and noble words to the Corinthians are strictly true at this present hour.'' (unknown)

``Not blows, father? He (father) did not proceed to blows?'' (unknown)

``No, he (father) did not. Though I have borne blows from men in a mad state of intoxication.'' (unknown)

``No!'' (unknown)

``A dozen times, my boy. What then? I have saved them from the guilt of murdering their own flesh and blood thereby; and they have lived to thank me, and praise God.'' (unknown)

``May this young man do the same!'' (Angel)
said Angel fervently.
``But I fear otherwise, from what you say.'' (unknown)

``We'll hope, nevertheless,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Mr Clare.
``And I continue to pray for him (man), though on this side of the grave we shall probably never meet again. But, after all, one of those poor words of mine may spring up in his (man) heart as a good seed some day.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Now, as always, Clare's father was sanguine as a child; and though the younger could not accept his (father) parent's narrow dogma, he (father) revered his (father) practice and recognized the hero under the pietist. Perhaps he (father) revered his (father) father's practice even more now than ever, seeing that, in the question of making Tessy his (father) wife, his (father) father had not once thought of inquiring whether she (wife) were well provided or penniless. The same unworldliness was what had necessitated Angel's getting a living as a farmer, and would probably keep his (Angel) brothers in the position of poor parsons for the term of their activities; yet Angel admired it none the less. Indeed, despite his (Angel) own heterodoxy, Angel often felt that he (Angel) was nearer to his (Angel) father on the human side than was either of his (Angel) brethren.

XXVII

An up-hill and down-hill ride of twenty-odd miles through a garish mid-day atmosphere brought him (Angel) in the afternoon to a detached knoll a mile or two west of Talbothays, whence he (Angel) again looked into that green trough of sappiness and humidity, the valley of the Var or Froom. Immediately he (Angel) began to descend from the upland to the fat alluvial soil below, the atmosphere grew heavier; the languid perfume of the summer fruits, the mists, the hay, the flowers, formed therein a vast pool of odour which at this hour seemed to make the animals, the very bees and butterflies drowsy. Clare was now so familiar with the spot that he (Clare) knew the individual cows by their names when, a long distance off, he (Clare) saw them dotted about the meads. It was with a sense of luxury that he (Clare) recognized his (Clare) power of viewing life here from its inner side, in a way that had been quite foreign to him (Clare) in his (Clare) student-days; and, much as he (Clare) loved his (Clare) parents, he (Clare) could not help being aware that to come here, as now, after an experience of home-life, affected him (Clare) like throwing off splints and bandages; even the one customary curb on the humours of English rural societies being absent in this place, Talbothays having no resident landlord.

Not a human being was out of doors at the dairy. The denizens were all enjoying the usual afternoon nap of an hour or so which the exceedingly early hours kept in summer-time rendered a necessity. At the door the wood-hooped pails, sodden and bleached by infinite scrubbings, hung like hats on a stand upon the forked and peeled limb of an oak fixed there for that purpose; all of them ready and dry for the evening milking. Angel entered, and went through the silent passages of the house to the back quarters, where he (Angel) listened for a moment. Sustained snores came from the cart-house, where some of the men were lying down; the grunt and squeal of sweltering pigs arose from the still further distance. The large-leaved rhubarb and cabbage plants slept too, their broad limp surfaces hanging in the sun like half-closed umbrellas.

He (Angel) unbridled and fed his (Angel) horse, and as he (Angel) re-entered the house the clock struck three. Three was the afternoon skimming-hour; and, with the stroke, Clare heard the creaking of the floor-boards above, and then the touch of a descending foot on the stairs. It was Tess's, who in another moment came down before his (Clare) eyes.

She (Tess) had not heard him (Clare) enter, and hardly realized his (Clare) presence there. She (Tess) was yawning, and he (Clare) saw the red interior of her (Tess) mouth as if it had been a snake's. She (Tess) had stretched one arm so high above her (Tess) coiled-up cable of hair that he (Clare) could see its satin delicacy above the sunburn; her (Tess) face was flushed with sleep, and her (Tess) eyelids hung heavy over their pupils. The brim-fulness of her (Tess) nature breathed from her (Tess). It was a moment when a woman's soul is more incarnate than at any other time; when the most spiritual beauty bespeaks itself flesh; and sex takes the outside place in the presentation.

Then those eyes flashed brightly through their filmy heaviness, before the remainder of her (Tess) face was well awake. With an oddly compounded look of gladness, shyness, and surprise, she (Tess) exclaimed--

``O Mr Clare! How you frightened me--I--'' (she)

There had not at first been time for her (Tess) to think of the changed relations which his (Tess) declaration had introduced; but the full sense of the matter rose up in her (Tess) face when she (Tess) encountered Clare's tender look as he (Clare) stepped forward to the bottom stair.

``Dear, darling Tessy!'' (he)
he (Clare) whispered, putting his (Clare) arm round her (Tess), and his (Clare) face to her (Tess) flushed cheek.
``Don't, for Heaven's sake, Mister me any more. I have hastened back so soon because of you!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess's excitable heart beat against his (Clare) by way of reply; and there they stood upon the red-brick floor of the entry, the sun slanting in by the window upon his (Clare) back, as he (Clare) held her (Tess) tightly to his (Clare) breast; upon her (Tess) inclining face, upon the blue veins of her (Tess) temple, upon her (Tess) naked arm, and her (Tess) neck, and into the depths of her (Tess) hair. Having been lying down in her (Tess) clothes she (Tess) was warm as a sunned cat. At first she (Tess) would not look straight up at him (Clare), but her (Tess) eyes soon lifted, and his (Clare) plumbed the deepness of the ever-varying pupils, with their radiating fibrils of blue, and black, and gray, and violet, while she (Tess) regarded him (Clare) as Eve at her (Tess) second waking might have regarded Adam.

``I've got to go a-skimming,'' (she)
she (Tess) pleaded,
``and I have on'y old Deb to help me to-day. Mrs Crick is gone to market with Mr Crick, and Retty is not well, and the others are gone out somewhere, and won't be home till milking.'' (she)

As they retreated to the milk-house Deborah Fyander appeared on the stairs.

``I have come back, Deborah,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Mr Clare, upwards.
``So I can help Tess with the skimming; and, as you are very tired, I am sure, you needn't come down till milking-time.'' (unknown)

Possibly the Talbothays milk was not very thoroughly skimmed that afternoon. Tess was in a dream wherein familiar objects appeared as having light and shade and position, but no particular outline. Every time she (Tess) held the skimmer under the pump to cool it for the work her (Tess) hand trembled, the ardour of his (Clare) affection being so palpable that she (Tess) seemed to flinch under it like a plant in too burning a sun.

Then he (Clare) pressed her (Tess) again to his (Clare) side, and when she (Tess) had done running her (Tess) forefinger round the leads to cut off the cream-edge, he (Clare) cleaned it in nature's way; for the unconstrained manners of Talbothays dairy came convenient now.

``I may as well say it now as later, dearest,'' (he)
he (Clare) resumed gently.
``I wish to ask you something of a very practical nature, which I have been thinking of ever since that day last week in the meads. I shall soon want to marry, and, being a farmer, you see I shall require for my wife a woman who knows all about the management of farms. Will you be that woman, Tessy?'' (He)

He (Clare) put it that way that she (Tess) might not think he (Clare) had yielded to an impulse of which his (Clare) head would disapprove.

She (Tess) turned quite careworn. She (Tess) had bowed to the inevitable result of proximity, the necessity of loving him (Clare); but she (Tess) had not calculated upon this sudden corollary, which, indeed, Clare had put before her (Tess) without quite meaning himself to do it so soon. With pain that was like the bitterness of dissolution she (Tess) murmured the words of her (Tess) indispensable and sworn answer as an honourable woman.

``O Mr Clare--I cannot be your wife--I cannot be!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

The sound of her (Tess) own decision seemed to break Tess's very heart, and she (Tess) bowed her (Tess) face in her (Tess) grief.

``But, Tess!'' (he)
he (Clare) said, amazed at her (Tess) reply, and holding her (Tess) still more greedily close.
``Do you say no? Surely you love me?'' (unknown)

``O yes, yes! And I would rather be yours than anybody's in the world,'' (the girl)
returned the sweet and honest voice of the distressed girl.
``But I CANNOT marry you!'' (unknown)

``Tess,'' (he)
he (Clare) said, holding her (Tess) at arm's length,
``you are engaged to marry some one else!'' (he)

``No, no!'' (unknown)

``Then why do you refuse me?'' (unknown)

``I don't want to marry! I have not thought of doing it. I cannot! I only want to love you.'' (unknown)

``But why?'' (she)

Driven to subterfuge, she (Tess) stammered--

``Your father is a parson, and your mother wouldn' like you to marry such as me. She (mother) will want you to marry a lady.'' (she)

``Nonsense--I have spoken to them both. That was partly why I went home.'' (unknown)

``I feel I cannot--never, never!'' (she)
she (Tess) echoed.

``Is it too sudden to be asked thus, my Pretty?'' (unknown)

``Yes--I did not expect it.'' (unknown)

``If you will let it pass, please, Tessy, I will give you time,'' (he)
he (Clare) said.
``It was very abrupt to come home and speak to you all at once. I'll not allude to it again for a while.'' (She)

She (Tess) again took up the shining skimmer, held it beneath the pump, and began anew. But she (Tess) could not, as at other times, hit the exact under-surface of the cream with the delicate dexterity required, try as she (Tess) might; sometimes she (Tess) was cutting down into the milk, sometimes in the air. She (Tess) could hardly see, her (Tess) eyes having filled with two blurring tears drawn forth by a grief which, to this her (Tess) best friend and dear advocate, she (Tess) could never explain.

``I can't skim--I can't!'' (she)
she (Tess) said, turning away from him (friend).

Not to agitate and hinder her (Tess) longer, the considerate Clare began talking in a more general way:

You quite misapprehend my parents. They are the most simple-mannered people alive, and quite unambitious. They are two of the few remaining Evangelical school. Tessy, are you an Evangelical?''

``I don't know.'' (unknown)

``You go to church very regularly, and our parson here is not very High, they tell me.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
