Tess's ideas on the views of the parish clergyman, whom she (Tess) heard every week, seemed to be rather more vague than Clare's, who had never heard him (Clare) at all.

``I wish I could fix my mind on what I hear there more firmly than I do,'' (she)
she (Tess) remarked as a safe generality.
``It is often a great sorrow to me.'' (She)

She (Tess) spoke so unaffectedly that Angel was sure in his (Angel) heart that his (Angel) father could not object to her (Tess) on religious grounds, even though she (Tess) did not know whether her (Tess) principles were High, Low or Broad. He (Angel) himself knew that, in reality, the confused beliefs which she (Tess) held, apparently imbibed in childhood, were, if anything, Tractarian as to phraseology, and Pantheistic as to essence. Confused or otherwise, to disturb them was his (Angel) last desire:

Leave thou thy sister, when she (sister) prays, Her (sister) early Heaven, her (sister) happy views; Nor thou with shadow'd hint confuse A life that leads melodious days.

He (Angel) had occasionally thought the counsel less honest than musical; but he (Angel) gladly conformed to it now.

He (Angel) spoke further of the incidents of his (Angel) visit, of his (Angel) father's mode of life, of his (Angel) zeal for his (Angel) principles; she (sister) grew serener, and the undulations disappeared from her (sister) skimming; as she (sister) finished one lead after another he (Angel) followed her (sister), and drew the plugs for letting down the milk.

``I fancied you looked a little downcast when you came in,'' (she)
she (sister) ventured to observe, anxious to keep away from the subject of herself.

``Yes--well, my father had been talking a good deal to me of his (father) troubles and difficulties, and the subject always tends to depress me. He (father) is so zealous that he (father) gets many snubs and buffetings from people of a different way of thinking from himself, and I don't like to hear of such humiliations to a man of his (man) age, the more particularly as I don't think earnestness does any good when carried so far. He (man) has been telling me of a very unpleasant scene in which he (man) took part quite recently. He (man) went as the deputy of some missionary society to preach in the neighbourhood of Trantridge, a place forty miles from here, and made it his (man) business to expostulate with a lax young cynic he (man) met with somewhere about there--son of some landowner up that way--and who has a mother afflicted with blindness. My father addressed himself to the gentleman point-blank, and there was quite a disturbance. It was very foolish of my father, I must say, to intrude his (father) conversation upon a stranger when the probabilities were so obvious that it would be useless. But whatever he (father) thinks to be his (father) duty, that he (father)'ll do, in season or out of season; and, of course, he (father) makes many enemies, not only among the absolutely vicious, but among the easy-going, who hate being bothered. He (father) says he (father) glories in what happened, and that good may be done indirectly; but I wish he (father) would not wear himself out now he (father) is getting old, and would leave such pigs to their wallowing.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess's look had grown hard and worn, and her (Tess) ripe mouth tragical; but she (Tess) no longer showed any tremulousness. Clare's revived thoughts of his (Clare) father prevented his (Clare) noticing her (Tess) particularly; and so they went on down the white row of liquid rectangles till they had finished and drained them off, when the other maids returned, and took their pails, and Deb came to scald out the leads for the new milk. As Tess withdrew to go afield to the cows he (Clare) said to her (Tess) softly--

``And my question, Tessy?'' (he)

``O no--no!'' (she)
replied she (Tess) with grave hopelessness, as one who had heard anew the turmoil of her (Tess) own past in the allusion to Alec d``Urberville. ``It CAN
``T be!'' (She)

She (Tess) went out towards the mead, joining the other milkmaids with a bound, as if trying to make the open air drive away her (Tess) sad constraint. All the girls drew onward to the spot where the cows were grazing in the farther mead, the bevy advancing with the bold grace of wild animals--the reckless, unchastened motion of women accustomed to unlimited space--in which they abandoned themselves to the air as a swimmer to the wave. It seemed natural enough to him (swimmer) now that Tess was again in sight to choose a mate from unconstrained Nature, and not from the abodes of Art.

XXVIII

Her (Tess) refusal, though unexpected, did not permanently daunt Clare. His (Clare) experience of women was great enough for him (Clare) to be aware that the negative often meant nothing more than the preface to the affirmative; and it was little enough for him (Clare) not to know that in the manner of the present negative there lay a great exception to the dallyings of coyness. That she (Tess) had already permitted him (Clare) to make love to her (Tess) he (Clare) read as an additional assurance, not fully trowing that in the fields and pastures to

``sigh gratis'' (he)
is by no means deemed waste; love-making being here more often accepted inconsiderately and for its own sweet sake than in the carking, anxious homes of the ambitious, where a girl's craving for an establishment paralyzes her (girl) healthy thought of a passion as an end.

``Tess, why did you say `no' in such a positive way?'' (he)
he (Clare) asked her (girl) in the course of a few days.

She (girl) started.

``Don't ask me. I told you why--partly. I am not good enough--not worthy enough.'' (unknown)

``How? Not fine lady enough?'' (unknown)

``Yes--something like that,'' (she)
murmured she (girl).
``Your friends would scorn me.'' (unknown)

``Indeed, you mistake them--my father and mother. As for my brothers, I don't care--'' (He)
He (Clare) clasped his (Clare) fingers behind her (girl) back to keep her (girl) from slipping away.
``Now--you did not mean it, sweet?--I am sure you did not! You have made me so restless that I cannot read, or play, or do anything. I am in no hurry, Tess, but I want to know--to hear from your own warm lips--that you will some day be mine--any time you may choose; but some day?'' (She)

She (girl) could only shake her (girl) head and look away from him (Clare).

Clare regarded her (girl) attentively, conned the characters of her (girl) face as if they had been hieroglyphics. The denial seemed real.

``Then I ought not to hold you in this way--ought I? I have no right to you--no right to seek out where you are, or walk with you! Honestly, Tess, do you love any other man?'' (unknown)

``How can you ask?'' (she)
she (girl) said, with continued self-suppression.

``I almost know that you do not. But then, why do you repulse me?'' (unknown)

``I don't repulse you. I like you to--tell me you love me; and you may always tell me so as you go about with me--and never offend me.'' (unknown)

``But you will not accept me as a husband?'' (unknown)

``Ah--that's different--it is for your good, indeed, my dearest! O, believe me, it is only for your sake! I don't like to give myself the great happiness o' promising to be yours in that way--because--because I am SURE I ought not to do it.'' (unknown)

``But you will make me happy!'' (unknown)

``Ah--you think so, but you don't know!'' (he)

At such times as this, apprehending the grounds of her (girl) refusal to be her (girl) modest sense of incompetence in matters social and polite, he (Clare) would say that she (girl) was wonderfully well-informed and versatile--which was certainly true, her (girl) natural quickness and her (girl) admiration for him (Clare) having led her (girl) to pick up his (Clare) vocabulary, his (Clare) accent, and fragments of his (Clare) knowledge, to a surprising extent. After these tender contests and her (girl) victory she (girl) would go away by herself under the remotest cow, if at milking-time, or into the sedge or into her (girl) room, if at a leisure interval, and mourn silently, not a minute after an apparently phlegmatic negative.

The struggle was so fearful; her (girl) own heart was so strongly on the side of his (Clare)--two ardent hearts against one poor little conscience-- that she (girl) tried to fortify her (girl) resolution by every means in her (girl) power. She (girl) had come to Talbothays with a made-up mind. On no account could she (girl) agree to a step which might afterwards cause bitter rueing to her (girl) husband for his (husband) blindness in wedding her (girl). And she (girl) held that what her (girl) conscience had decided for her (girl) when her (girl) mind was unbiassed ought not to be overruled now.

``Why don't somebody tell him (husband) all about me?'' (she)
she (girl) said.
``It was only forty miles off--why hasn't it reached here? Somebody must know!'' (nobody)

Yet nobody seemed to know; nobody told him (husband).

For two or three days no more was said. She (girl) guessed from the sad countenances of her (girl) chamber companions that they regarded her (girl) not only as the favourite, but as the chosen; but they could see for themselves that she (girl) did not put herself in his (husband) way.

Tess had never before known a time in which the thread of her (Tess) life was so distinctly twisted of two strands, positive pleasure and positive pain. At the next cheese-making the pair were again left alone together. The dairyman himself had been lending a hand; but Mr Crick, as well as his (Crick) wife, seemed latterly to have acquired a suspicion of mutual interest between these two; though they walked so circumspectly that suspicion was but of the faintest. Anyhow, the dairyman left them to themselves.

They were breaking up the masses of curd before putting them into the vats. The operation resembled the act of crumbling bread on a large scale; and amid the immaculate whiteness of the curds Tess Durbeyfield's hands showed themselves of the pinkness of the rose. Angel, who was filling the vats with his (Angel) handful, suddenly ceased, and laid his (Angel) hands flat upon hers. Her (Durbeyfield) sleeves were rolled far above the elbow, and bending lower he (Angel) kissed the inside vein of her (Durbeyfield) soft arm.

Although the early September weather was sultry, her (Durbeyfield) arm, from her (Durbeyfield) dabbling in the curds, was as cold and damp to his (Angel) mouth as a new-gathered mushroom, and tasted of the whey. But she (Durbeyfield) was such a sheaf of susceptibilities that her (Durbeyfield) pulse was accelerated by the touch, her (Durbeyfield) blood driven to her (Durbeyfield) finder-ends, and the cool arms flushed hot. Then, as though her (Durbeyfield) heart had said,

``Is coyness longer necessary? Truth is truth between man and woman, as between man and man,'' (she)
she (Durbeyfield) lifted her (Durbeyfield) eyes and they beamed devotedly into his (Angel), as her (Durbeyfield) lip rose in a tender half-smile.

``Do you know why I did that, Tess?'' (he)
he (Angel) said.

``Because you love me very much!'' (unknown)

``Yes, and as a preliminary to a new entreaty.'' (unknown)

``Not AGAIN!'' (She)

She (Durbeyfield) looked a sudden fear that her (Durbeyfield) resistance might break down under her (Durbeyfield) own desire.

``O, Tessy!'' (he)
he (Angel) went on,
``I CANNOT think why you are so tantalizing. Why do you disappoint me so? You seem almost like a coquette, upon my life you do--a coquette of the first urban water! They blow hot and blow cold, just as you do, and it is the very last sort of thing to expect to find in a retreat like Talbothays. ... And yet, dearest,'' (he)
he (Angel) quickly added, observing now the remark had cut her (Durbeyfield),
``I know you to be the most honest, spotless creature that ever lived. So how can I suppose you a flirt? Tess, why don't you like the idea of being my wife, if you love me as you seem to do?'' (her)

``I have never said I don't like the idea, and I never could say it; because--it isn't true!'' (lip)

The stress now getting beyond endurance, her (Durbeyfield) lip quivered, and she (Durbeyfield) was obliged to go away. Clare was so pained and perplexed that he (Clare) ran after and caught her (Durbeyfield) in the passage.

``Tell me, tell me!'' (he)
he (Clare) said, passionately clasping her (Durbeyfield), in forgetfulness of his (Clare) curdy hands:
``do tell me that you won't belong to anybody but me!'' (her)

``I will, I will tell you!'' (she)
she (Durbeyfield) exclaimed.
``And I will give you a complete answer, if you will let me go now. I will tell you my experiences--all about myself--all!'' (unknown)

``Your experiences, dear; yes, certainly; any number.'' (He)
He (Clare) expressed assent in loving satire, looking into her (Durbeyfield) face.
``My Tess, no doubt, almost as many experiences as that wild convolvulus out there on the garden hedge, that opened itself this morning for the first time. Tell me anything, but don't use that wretched expression any more about not being worthy of me.'' (unknown)

``I will try--not! And I'll give you my reasons to-morrow--next week.'' (unknown)

``Say on Sunday?'' (unknown)

``Yes, on Sunday.'' (she)

At last she (Durbeyfield) got away, and did not stop in her (Durbeyfield) retreat till she (Durbeyfield) was in the thicket of pollard willows at the lower side of the barton, where she (Durbeyfield) could be quite unseen. Here Tess flung herself down upon the rustling undergrowth of spear-grass, as upon a bed, and remained crouching in palpitating misery broken by momentary shoots of joy, which her (Tess) fears about the ending could not altogether suppress.

In reality, she (Tess) was drifting into acquiescence. Every see-saw of her (Tess) breath, every wave of her (Tess) blood, every pulse singing in her (Tess) ears, was a voice that joined with nature in revolt against her (Tess) scrupulousness. Reckless, inconsiderate acceptance of him (Tess); to close with him (Tess) at the altar, revealing nothing, and chancing discovery; to snatch ripe pleasure before the iron teeth of pain could have time to shut upon her (Tess): that was what love counselled; and in almost a terror of ecstasy Tess divined that, despite her (Tess) many months of lonely self-chastisement, wrestlings, communings, schemes to lead a future of austere isolation, love's counsel would prevail.

The afternoon advanced, and still she (Tess) remained among the willows. She (Tess) heard the rattle of taking down the pails from the forked stands; the

``waow-waow!'' (She)
which accompanied the getting together of the cows. But she (Tess) did not go to the milking. They would see her (Tess) agitation; and the dairyman, thinking the cause to be love alone, would good-naturedly tease her (Tess); and that harassment could not be borne.

Her (Tess) lover must have guessed her (Tess) overwrought state, and invented some excuse for her (Tess) non-appearance, for no inquiries were made or calls given. At half-past six the sun settled down upon the levels with the aspect of a great forge in the heavens; and presently a monstrous pumpkin-like moon arose on the other hand. The pollard willows, tortured out of their natural shape by incessant choppings, became spiny-haired monsters as they stood up against it. She (Tess) went in and upstairs without a light.

It was now Wednesday. Thursday came, and Angel looked thoughtfully at her (Tess) from a distance, but intruded in no way upon her (Tess). The indoor milkmaids, Marian and the rest, seemed to guess that something definite was afoot, for they did not force any remarks upon her (Marian) in the bedchamber. Friday passed; Saturday. To-morrow was the day.

``I shall give way--I shall say yes--I shall let myself marry him (myself)--I cannot help it!'' (she)
she (Marian) jealously panted, with her (Marian) hot face to the pillow that night, on hearing one of the other girls sigh his (Angel) name in her (Marian) sleep.
``I can't bear to let anybody have him (myself) but me! Yet it is a wrong to him (myself), and may kill him (myself) when he (myself) knows! O my heart--O--O--O!'' (unknown)

XXIX

``Now, who mid ye think I've heard news o' this morning?'' (Dairyman Crick/Crick)
said Dairyman Crick, as he (Crick) sat down to breakfast next day, with a riddling gaze round upon the munching men and maids.
``Now, just who mid ye think?'' (unknown)

One guessed, and another guessed. Mrs Crick did not guess, because she (Crick) knew already.

``Well,'' (the dairyman Dollop)
said the dairyman,
''`tis that slack-twisted `hore's-bird of a feller, Jack Dollop. He (Dollop)'s lately got married to a widow-woman.'' (the dairyman Dollop)

``Not Jack Dollop? A villain--to think o' that!'' (a milker)
said a milker.

The name entered quickly into Tess Durbeyfield's consciousness, for it was the name of the lover who had wronged his (lover) sweetheart, and had afterwards been so roughly used by the young woman's mother in the butter-churn.

``And had he (Dollop) married the valiant matron's daughter, as he (Dollop) promised?'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
asked Angel Clare absently, as he (Clare) turned over the newspaper he (Clare) was reading at the little table to which he (Clare) was always banished by Mrs Crick, in her (Crick) sense of his (Clare) gentility.

``Not he (Dollop), sir. Never meant to,'' (the dairyman)
replied the dairyman.
``As I say, `tis a widow-woman, and she (daughter) had money, it seems--fifty poun' a year or so; and that was all he (Dollop) was after. They were married in a great hurry; and then she (daughter) told him (Dollop) that by marrying she (daughter) had lost her (daughter) fifty poun' a year. Just fancy the state o' my gentleman's mind at that news! Never such a cat-and-dog life as they've been leading ever since! Serves him (gentleman) well beright. But onluckily the poor woman gets the worst o`t.'' (Mrs Crick)

``Well, the silly body should have told en sooner that the ghost of her (woman) first man would trouble him (man),'' (Mrs Crick)
said Mrs Crick.

``Ay, ay,'' (the dairyman)
responded the dairyman indecisively.
``Still, you can see exactly how 'twas. She (woman) wanted a home, and didn't like to run the risk of losing him (man). Don't ye think that was something like it, maidens?'' (He)

He (dairyman) glanced towards the row of girls.

``She (woman) ought to ha' told him (man) just before they went to church, when he (man) could hardly have backed out,'' (Marian)
exclaimed Marian.

``Yes, she (woman) ought,'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
agreed Izz.

``She (woman) must have seen what he (man) was after, and should ha' refused him (man),'' (unknown)
cried Retty spasmodically.

``And what do you say, my dear?'' (the dairyman)
asked the dairyman of Tess.

``I think she (woman) ought--to have told him (man) the true state of things--or else refused him (man)--I don't know,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
replied Tess, the bread-and-butter choking her (Tess).

``Be cust if I'd have done either o`t,'' (Beck Knibbs)
said Beck Knibbs, a married helper from one of the cottages.
``All's fair in love and war. I'd ha' married en just as she (woman) did, and if he (cust)'d said two words to me about not telling him (cust) beforehand anything whatsomdever about my first chap that I hadn't chose to tell, I'd ha' knocked him (chap) down wi' the rolling-pin--a scram little feller like he (feller)! Any woman could do it.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

The laughter which followed this sally was supplemented only by a sorry smile, for form's sake, from Tess. What was comedy to them was tragedy to her (Tess); and she (Tess) could hardly bear their mirth. She (Tess) soon rose from table, and, with an impression that Clare would soon follow her (Tess), went along a little wriggling path, now stepping to one side of the irrigating channels, and now to the other, till she (Tess) stood by the main stream of the Var. Men had been cutting the water-weeds higher up the river, and masses of them were floating past her (Tess)--moving islands of green crow-foot, whereon she (Tess) might almost have ridden; long locks of which weed had lodged against the piles driven to keep the cows from crossing.

Yes, there was the pain of it. This question of a woman telling her (woman) story--the heaviest of crosses to herself--seemed but amusement to others. It was as if people should laugh at martyrdom.

``Tessy!'' (her)
came from behind her (woman), and Clare sprang across the gully, alighting beside her (woman) feet.
``My wife--soon!'' (unknown)

``No, no; I cannot. For your sake, O Mr Clare; for your sake, I say no!'' (unknown)

``Tess!'' (unknown)

``Still I say no!'' (she)
she (woman) repeated.

Not expecting this, he (Clare) had put his (Clare) arm lightly round her (woman) waist the moment after speaking, beneath her (woman) hanging tail of hair. -LRB-The younger dairymaids, including Tess, breakfasted with their hair loose on Sunday mornings before building it up extra high for attending church, a style they could not adopt when milking with their heads against the cows.-RRB- If she (Tess) had said

``Yes'' (she)
instead of
``No'' (she)
he (Clare) would have kissed her (Tess); it had evidently been his (Clare) intention; but her (Tess) determined negative deterred his (Clare) scrupulous heart. Their condition of domiciliary comradeship put her (Tess), as the woman, to such disadvantage by its enforced intercourse, that he (Clare) felt it unfair to her (woman) to exercise any pressure of blandishment which he (Clare) might have honestly employed had she (woman) been better able to avoid him (Clare). He (Clare) released her (woman) momentarily-imprisoned waist, and withheld the kiss.

It all turned on that release. What had given her (woman) strength to refuse him (Clare) this time was solely the tale of the widow told by the dairyman; and that would have been overcome in another moment. But Angel said no more; his (Angel) face was perplexed; he (Angel) went away.

Day after day they met--somewhat less constantly than before; and thus two or three weeks went by. The end of September drew near, and she (woman) could see in his (Angel) eye that he (Angel) might ask her (woman) again.

His (Angel) plan of procedure was different now--as though he (Angel) had made up his (Angel) mind that her (woman) negatives were, after all, only coyness and youth startled by the novelty of the proposal. The fitful evasiveness of her (woman) manner when the subject was under discussion countenanced the idea. So he (Angel) played a more coaxing game; and while never going beyond words, or attempting the renewal of caresses, he (Angel) did his (Angel) utmost orally.

In this way Clare persistently wooed her (woman) in undertones like that of the purling milk--at the cow's side, at skimmings, at butter-makings, at cheese-makings, among broody poultry, and among farrowing pigs--as no milkmaid was ever wooed before by such a man.

Tess knew that she (Tess) must break down. Neither a religious sense of a certain moral validity in the previous union nor a conscientious wish for candour could hold out against it much longer. She (Tess) loved him (man) so passionately, and he (man) was so godlike in her (Tess) eyes; and being, though untrained, instinctively refined, her (Tess) nature cried for his (man) tutelary guidance. And thus, though Tess kept repeating to herself,

``I can never be his (Clare) wife,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
the words were vain. A proof of her (Tess) weakness lay in the very utterance of what calm strength would not have taken the trouble to formulate. Every sound of his (man) voice beginning on the old subject stirred her (Tess) with a terrifying bliss, and she (Tess) coveted the recantation she (Tess) feared.

His (man) manner was--what man's is not?--so much that of one who would love and cherish and defend her (Tess) under any conditions, changes, charges, or revelations, that her (Tess) gloom lessened as she (Tess) basked in it. The season meanwhile was drawing onward to the equinox, and though it was still fine, the days were much shorter. The dairy had again worked by morning candlelight for a long time; and a fresh renewal of Clare's pleading occurred one morning between three and four.

She (Tess) had run up in her (Tess) bedgown to his (Clare) door to call him (Clare) as usual; then had gone back to dress and call the others; and in ten minutes was walking to the head of the stairs with the candle in her (Tess) hand. At the same moment he (Clare) came down his (Clare) steps from above in his (Clare) shirt-sleeves and put his (Clare) arm across the stairway.

``Now, Miss Flirt, before you go down,'' (he)
he (Clare) said peremptorily.
``It is a fortnight since I spoke, and this won't do any longer. You MUST tell me what you mean, or I shall have to leave this house. My door was ajar just now, and I saw you. For your own safety I must go. You don't know. Well? Is it to be yes at last?'' (unknown)

``I am only just up, Mr Clare, and it is too early to take me to task!'' (she)
she (Tess) pouted. ``You need not call me Flirt.
``Tis cruel and untrue. Wait till by and by. Please wait till by and by! I will really think seriously about it between now and then. Let me go downstairs!'' (She)

She (Tess) looked a little like what he (Clare) said she (Tess) was as, holding the candle sideways, she (Tess) tried to smile away the seriousness of her (Tess) words.

``Call me Angel, then, and not Mr Clare.'' (unknown)

``Angel.'' (unknown)

``Angel dearest--why not?'' (unknown)

''`Twould mean that I agree, wouldn't it?'' (unknown)

``It would only mean that you love me, even if you cannot marry me; and you were so good as to own that long ago.'' (unknown)

``Very well, then,

``Angel dearest', if I MUST,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
she (Tess) murmured, looking at her (Tess) candle, a roguish curl coming upon her (Tess) mouth, notwithstanding her (Tess) suspense.

Clare had resolved never to kiss her (Tess) until he (Clare) had obtained her (Tess) promise; but somehow, as Tess stood there in her (Tess) prettily tucked-up milking gown, her (Tess) hair carelessly heaped upon her (Tess) head till there should be leisure to arrange it when skimming and milking were done, he (Clare) broke his (Clare) resolve, and brought his (Clare) lips to her (Tess) cheek for one moment. She (Tess) passed downstairs very quickly, never looking back at him (Clare) or saying another word. The other maids were already down, and the subject was not pursued. Except Marian, they all looked wistfully and suspiciously at the pair, in the sad yellow rays which the morning candles emitted in contrast with the first cold signals of the dawn without.

When skimming was done--which, as the milk diminished with the approach of autumn, was a lessening process day by day--Retty and the rest went out. The lovers followed them.

``Our tremulous lives are so different from theirs, are they not?'' (he)
he (Clare) musingly observed to her (Marian), as he (Clare) regarded the three figures tripping before him (Clare) through the frigid pallor of opening day.

``Not so very different, I think,'' (she)
she (Marian) said.

``Why do you think that?'' (unknown)

``There are very few women's lives that are not--tremulous,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
Tess replied, pausing over the new word as if it impressed her (Tess).
``There's more in those three than you think.'' (unknown)

``What is in them?'' (unknown)

``Almost either of 'em,'' (she)
she (Tess) began,
``would make--perhaps would make--a properer wife than I. And perhaps they love you as well as I--almost.'' (she)

``O, Tessy!'' (she)

There were signs that it was an exquisite relief to her (Tess) to hear the impatient exclamation, though she (Tess) had resolved so intrepidly to let generosity make one bid against herself. That was now done, and she (Tess) had not the power to attempt self-immolation a second time then. They were joined by a milker from one of the cottages, and no more was said on that which concerned them so deeply. But Tess knew that this day would decide it.

In the afternoon several of the dairyman's household and assistants went down to the meads as usual, a long way from the dairy, where many of the cows were milked without being driven home. The supply was getting less as the animals advanced in calf, and the supernumerary milkers of the lush green season had been dismissed.

The work progressed leisurely. Each pailful was poured into tall cans that stood in a large spring-waggon which had been brought upon the scene; and when they were milked, the cows trailed away. Dairyman Crick, who was there with the rest, his (Crick) wrapper gleaming miraculously white against a leaden evening sky, suddenly looked at his (Crick) heavy watch.

``Why, `tis later than I thought,'' (he)
he (Crick) said.
``Begad! We shan't be soon enough with this milk at the station, if we don't mind. There's no time to-day to take it home and mix it with the bulk afore sending off. It must go to station straight from here. Who'll drive it across?'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Mr Clare volunteered to do so, though it was none of his (Clare) business, asking Tess to accompany him (Clare). The evening, though sunless, had been warm and muggy for the season, and Tess had come out with her (Tess) milking-hood only, naked-armed and jacketless; certainly not dressed for a drive. She (Tess) therefore replied by glancing over her (Tess) scant habiliments; but Clare gently urged her (Tess). She (Tess) assented by relinquishing her (Tess) pail and stool to the dairyman to take home, and mounted the spring-waggon beside Clare.

XXX

In the diminishing daylight they went along the level roadway through the meads, which stretched away into gray miles, and were backed in the extreme edge of distance by the swarthy and abrupt slopes of Egdon Heath. On its summit stood clumps and stretches of fir-trees, whose notched tips appeared like battlemented towers crowning black-fronted castles of enchantment.

They were so absorbed in the sense of being close to each other that they did not begin talking for a long while, the silence being broken only by the clucking of the milk in the tall cans behind them. The lane they followed was so solitary that the hazel nuts had remained on the boughs till they slipped from their shells, and the blackberries hung in heavy clusters. Every now and then Angel would fling the lash of his (Angel) whip round one of these, pluck it off, and give it to his (Angel) companion.

The dull sky soon began to tell its meaning by sending down herald-drops of rain, and the stagnant air of the day changed into a fitful breeze which played about their faces. The quick-silvery glaze on the rivers and pools vanished; from broad mirrors of light they changed to lustreless sheets of lead, with a surface like a rasp. But that spectacle did not affect her (their) preoccupation. Her (their) countenance, a natural carnation slightly embrowned by the season, had deepened its tinge with the beating of the rain-drops; and her (their) hair, which the pressure of the cows' flanks had, as usual, caused to tumble down from its fastenings and stray beyond the curtain of her (their) calico bonnet, was made clammy by the moisture, till it hardly was better than seaweed.

``I ought not to have come, I suppose,'' (she)
she (their) murmured, looking at the sky.

``I am sorry for the rain,'' (he)
said he (their).
``But how glad I am to have you here!'' (Egdon/Egdon Heath)

Remote Egdon disappeared by degree behind the liquid gauze. The evening grew darker, and the roads being crossed by gates, it was not safe to drive faster than at a walking pace. The air was rather chill.

``I am so afraid you will get cold, with nothing upon your arms and shoulders,'' (he)
he (Egdon) said.
``Creep close to me, and perhaps the drizzle won't hurt you much. I should be sorrier still if I did not think that the rain might be helping me.'' (She)

She (their) imperceptibly crept closer, and he (Egdon) wrapped round them both a large piece of sail-cloth, which was sometimes used to keep the sun off the milk-cans. Tess held it from slipping off him (Egdon) as well as herself, Clare's hands being occupied.

``Now we are all right again. Ah--no we are not! It runs down into my neck a little, and it must still more into yours. That's better. Your arms are like wet marble, Tess. Wipe them in the cloth. Now, if you stay quiet, you will not get another drop. Well, dear--about that question of mine--that long-standing question?'' (he)

The only reply that he (Clare) could hear for a little while was the smack of the horse's hoofs on the moistening road, and the cluck of the milk in the cans behind them.

``Do you remember what you said?'' (unknown)

``I do,'' (she)
she (Tess) replied.

``Before we get home, mind.'' (unknown)

``I'll try.'' (He)

He (Clare) said no more then. As they drove on, the fragment of an old manor house of Caroline date rose against the sky, and was in due course passed and left behind.

``That,'' (he)
he (Clare) observed, to entertain her (Caroline), ``is an interesting old place--one of the several seats which belonged to an ancient Norman family formerly of great influence in this county, the d
``Urbervilles. I never pass one of their residences without thinking of them. There is something very sad in the extinction of a family of renown, even if it was fierce, domineering, feudal renown.'' (her)

``Yes,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

They crept along towards a point in the expanse of shade just at hand at which a feeble light was beginning to assert its presence, a spot where, by day, a fitful white streak of steam at intervals upon the dark green background denoted intermittent moments of contact between their secluded world and modern life. Modern life stretched out its steam feeler to this point three or four times a day, touched the native existences, and quickly withdrew its feeler again, as if what it touched had been uncongenial.

They reached the feeble light, which came from the smoky lamp of a little railway station; a poor enough terrestrial star, yet in one sense of more importance to Talbothays Dairy and mankind than the celestial ones to which it stood in such humiliating contrast. The cans of new milk were unladen in the rain, Tess getting a little shelter from a neighbouring holly tree.

Then there was the hissing of a train, which drew up almost silently upon the wet rails, and the milk was rapidly swung can by can into the truck. The light of the engine flashed for a second upon Tess Durbeyfield's figure, motionless under the great holly tree. No object could have looked more foreign to the gleaming cranks and wheels than this unsophisticated girl, with the round bare arms, the rainy face and hair, the suspended attitude of a friendly leopard at pause, the print gown of no date or fashion, and the cotton bonnet drooping on her (girl) brow.

She (girl) mounted again beside her (girl) lover, with a mute obedience characteristic of impassioned natures at times, and when they had wrapped themselves up over head and ears in the sailcloth again, they plunged back into the now thick night. Tess was so receptive that the few minutes of contact with the whirl of material progress lingered in her (Tess) thought.

``Londoners will drink it at their breakfasts to-morrow, won't they?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked.
``Strange people that we have never seen.'' (unknown)

``Yes--I suppose they will. Though not as we send it. When its strength has been lowered, so that it may not get up into their heads.'' (unknown)

``Noble men and noble women, ambassadors and centurions, ladies and tradeswomen, and babies who have never seen a cow.'' (unknown)

``Well, yes; perhaps; particularly centurions.'' (unknown)

``Who don't know anything of us, and where it comes from; or think how we two drove miles across the moor to-night in the rain that it might reach 'em in time?'' (unknown)

``We did not drive entirely on account of these precious Londoners; we drove a little on our own--on account of that anxious matter which you will, I am sure, set at rest, dear Tess. Now, permit me to put it in this way. You belong to me already, you know; your heart, I mean. Does it not?'' (unknown)

``You know as well as I. O yes--yes!'' (unknown)

``Then, if your heart does, why not your hand?'' (unknown)

``My only reason was on account of you--on account of a question. I have something to tell you--'' (unknown)

``But suppose it to be entirely for my happiness, and my worldly convenience also?'' (unknown)

``O yes; if it is for your happiness and worldly convenience. But my life before I came here--I want--'' (unknown)

``Well, it is for my convenience as well as my happiness. If I have a very large farm, either English or colonial, you will be invaluable as a wife to me; better than a woman out of the largest mansion in the country. So please--please, dear Tessy, disabuse your mind of the feeling that you will stand in my way.'' (unknown)

``But my history. I want you to know it--you must let me tell you--you will not like me so well!'' (unknown)

``Tell it if you wish to, dearest. This precious history then. Yes, I was born at so and so, Anno Domini--'' (she)

``I was born at Marlott,'' (she)
she (Tess) said, catching at his (lover) words as a help, lightly as they were spoken.
``And I grew up there. And I was in the Sixth Standard when I left school, and they said I had great aptness, and should make a good teacher, so it was settled that I should be one. But there was trouble in my family; father was not very industrious, and he (father) drank a little.'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes. Poor child! Nothing new.'' (He)
He (lover) pressed her (Tess) more closely to his (lover) side.

``And then--there is something very unusual about it--about me. I--I was--'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess's breath quickened.

``Yes, dearest. Never mind.'' (unknown)

``I--I--am not a Durbeyfield, but a d

``Urberville--a descendant of the same family as those that owned the old house we passed. And--we are all gone to nothing!'' (unknown)

``A d

``Urberville!--Indeed! And is that all the trouble, dear Tess?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Tess) answered faintly.

``Well--why should I love you less after knowing this?'' (unknown)

``I was told by the dairyman that you hated old families.'' (He)

He (lover) laughed.

``Well, it is true, in one sense. I do hate the aristocratic principle of blood before everything, and do think that as reasoners the only pedigrees we ought to respect are those spiritual ones of the wise and virtuous, without regard to corporal paternity. But I am extremely interested in this news--you can have no idea how interested I am! Are you not interested yourself in being one of that well-known line?'' (unknown)

``No. I have thought it sad--especially since coming here, and knowing that many of the hills and fields I see once belonged to my father's people. But other hills and field belonged to Retty's people, and perhaps others to Marian's, so that I don't value it particularly.'' (unknown)

``Yes--it is surprising how many of the present tillers of the soil were once owners of it, and I sometimes wonder that a certain school of politicians don't make capital of the circumstance; but they don't seem to know it... I wonder that I did not see the resemblance of your name to d

``Urberville, and trace the manifest corruption. And this was the carking secret!'' (She)

She (Tess) had not told. At the last moment her (Tess) courage had failed her (Tess); she (Tess) feared his (lover) blame for not telling him (lover) sooner; and her (Tess) instinct of self-preservation was stronger than her (Tess) candour.

``Of course,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
continued the unwitting Clare, ``I should have been glad to know you to be descended exclusively from the long-suffering, dumb, unrecorded rank and file of the English nation, and not from the self-seeking few who made themselves powerful at the expense of the rest. But I am corrupted away from that by my affection for you, Tess -LRB-he (you) laughed as he (you) spoke-RRB-, and made selfish likewise. For your own sake I rejoice in your descent. Society is hopelessly snobbish, and this fact of your extraction may make an appreciable difference to its acceptance of you as my wife, after I have made you the well-read woman that I mean to make you. My mother too, poor soul, will think so much better of you on account of it. Tess, you must spell your name correctly--d
``Urberville--from this very day.'' (unknown)

``I like the other way rather best.'' (unknown)

``But you MUST, dearest! Good heavens, why dozens of mushroom millionaires would jump at such a possession! By the bye, there's one of that kidney who has taken the name--where have I heard of him (you)?--Up in the neighbourhood of The Chase, I think. Why, he (Chase) is the very man who had that rumpus with my father I told you of. What an odd coincidence!'' (unknown)

``Angel, I think I would rather not take the name! It is unlucky, perhaps!'' (She)

She (Tess) was agitated.

``Now then, Mistress Teresa d

``Urberville, I have you. Take my name, and so you will escape yours! The secret is out, so why should you any longer refuse me?'' (unknown)

``If it is SURE to make you happy to have me as your wife, and you feel that you do wish to marry me, VERY, VERY much--'' (unknown)

``I do, dearest, of course!'' (unknown)

``I mean, that it is only your wanting me very much, and being hardly able to keep alive without me, whatever my offences, that would make me feel I ought to say I will.'' (unknown)

``You will--you do say it, I know! You will be mine for ever and ever.'' (He)

He (Clare) clasped her (Tess) close and kissed her (Tess).

``Yes!'' (She)

She (Tess) had no sooner said it than she (Tess) burst into a dry hard sobbing, so violent that it seemed to rend her (Tess). Tess was not a hysterical girl by any means, and he (Clare) was surprised.

``Why do you cry, dearest?'' (unknown)

``I can't tell--quite!--I am so glad to think--of being yours, and making you happy!'' (unknown)

``But this does not seem very much like gladness, my Tessy!'' (unknown)

``I mean--I cry because I have broken down in my vow! I said I would die unmarried!'' (unknown)

``But, if you love me you would like me to be your husband?'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes, yes! But O, I sometimes wish I had never been born!'' (unknown)

``Now, my dear Tess, if I did not know that you are very much excited, and very inexperienced, I should say that remark was not very complimentary. How came you to wish that if you care for me? Do you care for me? I wish you would prove it in some way.'' (unknown)

``How can I prove it more than I have done?'' (she)
she (Tess) cried, in a distraction of tenderness.
``Will this prove it more?'' (She)

She (Tess) clasped his (Clare) neck, and for the first time Clare learnt what an impassioned woman's kisses were like upon the lips of one whom she (woman) loved with all her (woman) heart and soul, as Tess loved him (Clare).

``There--now do you believe?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked, flushed, and wiping her (Tess) eyes.

``Yes. I never really doubted--never, never!'' (he)

So they drove on through the gloom, forming one bundle inside the sail-cloth, the horse going as he (Clare) would, and the rain driving against them. She (Tess) had consented. She (Tess) might as well have agreed at first. The

``appetite for joy'' (unknown)
which pervades all creation, that tremendous force which sways humanity to its purpose, as the tide sways the helpless weed, was not to be controlled by vague lucubrations over the social rubric.

``I must write to my mother,'' (she)
she (Tess) said.
``You don't mind my doing that?'' (unknown)

``Of course not, dear child. You are a child to me, Tess, not to know how very proper it is to write to your mother at such a time, and how wrong it would be in me to object. Where does she (mother) live?'' (unknown)

``At the same place--Marlott. On the further side of Blackmoor Vale.'' (unknown)

``Ah, then I HAVE seen you before this summer--'' (unknown)

``Yes; at that dance on the green; but you would not dance with me. O, I hope that is of no ill-omen for us now!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

XXXI

Tess wrote a most touching and urgent letter to her (Tess) mother the very next day, and by the end of the week a response to her (Tess) communication arrived in Joan Durbeyfield's wandering last-century hand.

DEAR TESS,--

J write these few lines Hoping they will find you well, as they leave me at Present, thank God for it. Dear Tess, we are all glad to Hear that you are going really to be married soon. But with respect to your question, Tess, J say between ourselves, quite private but very strong, that on no account do you say a word of your Bygone Trouble to him (God). J did not tell everything to your Father, he (Father) being so Proud on account of his (Father) Respectability, which, perhaps, your Intended is the same. Many a woman--some of the Highest in the Land--have had a Trouble in their time; and why should you Trumpet yours when others don't Trumpet theirs? No girl would be such a Fool, specially as it is so long ago, and not your Fault at all. J shall answer the same if you ask me fifty times. Besides, you must bear in mind that, knowing it to be your Childish Nature to tell all that's in your heart--so simple!--J made you promise me never to let it out by Word or Deed, having your Welfare in my Mind; and you most solemnly did promise it going from this Door. J have not named either that Question or your coming marriage to your Father, as he (Father) would blab it everywhere, poor Simple Man.

Dear Tess, keep up your Spirits, and we mean to send you a Hogshead of Cyder for you Wedding, knowing there is not much in your parts, and thin Sour Stuff what there is. So no more at present, and with kind love to your Young Man.--From your affectte. Mother,

J. DURBEYFIELD

``O mother, mother!'' (J.)
murmured Tess.

She (Tess) was recognizing how light was the touch of events the most oppressive upon Mrs Durbeyfield's elastic spirit. Her (Durbeyfield) mother did not see life as Tess saw it. That haunting episode of bygone days was to her (Tess) mother but a passing accident. But perhaps her (Tess) mother was right as to the course to be followed, whatever she (mother) might be in her (mother) reasons. Silence seemed, on the face of it, best for her (mother) adored one's happiness: silence it should be.

Thus steadied by a command from the only person in the world who had any shadow of right to control her (mother) action, Tess grew calmer. The responsibility was shifted, and her (Tess) heart was lighter than it had been for weeks. The days of declining autumn which followed her (Tess) assent, beginning with the month of October, formed a season through which she (Tess) lived in spiritual altitudes more nearly approaching ecstasy than any other period of her (Tess) life.

There was hardly a touch of earth in her (Tess) love for Clare. To her (Tess) sublime trustfulness he (Clare) was all that goodness could be--knew all that a guide, philosopher, and friend should know. She (Tess) thought every line in the contour of his (philosopher) person the perfection of masculine beauty, his (philosopher) soul the soul of a saint, his (philosopher) intellect that of a seer. The wisdom of her (Tess) love for him (philosopher), as love, sustained her (Tess) dignity; she (Tess) seemed to be wearing a crown. The compassion of his (philosopher) love for her (Tess), as she (Tess) saw it, made her (Tess) lift up her (Tess) heart to him (philosopher) in devotion. He (philosopher) would sometimes catch her (Tess) large, worshipful eyes, that had no bottom to them looking at him (philosopher) from their depths, as if she (Tess) saw something immortal before her (Tess).

She (Tess) dismissed the past--trod upon it and put it out, as one treads on a coal that is smouldering and dangerous.

She (Tess) had not known that men could be so disinterested, chivalrous, protective, in their love for women as he (philosopher). Angel Clare was far from all that she (Tess) thought him (Clare) in this respect; absurdly far, indeed; but he (Clare) was, in truth, more spiritual than animal; he (Clare) had himself well in hand, and was singularly free from grossness. Though not cold-natured, he (Clare) was rather bright than hot--less Byronic than Shelleyan; could love desperately, but with a love more especially inclined to the imaginative and ethereal; it was a fastidious emotion which could jealously guard the loved one against his (Clare) very self. This amazed and enraptured Tess, whose slight experiences had been so infelicitous till now; and in her (Tess) reaction from indignation against the male sex she (Tess) swerved to excess of honour for Clare.

They unaffectedly sought each other's company; in her (Tess) honest faith she (Tess) did not disguise her (Tess) desire to be with him (Clare). The sum of her (Tess) instincts on this matter, if clearly stated, would have been that the elusive quality of her (Tess) sex which attracts men in general might be distasteful to so perfect a man after an avowal of love, since it must in its very nature carry with it a suspicion of art.

The country custom of unreserved comradeship out of doors during betrothal was the only custom she (Tess) knew, and to her (Tess) it had no strangeness; though it seemed oddly anticipative to Clare till he (Clare) saw how normal a thing she (Tess), in common with all the other dairy-folk, regarded it. Thus, during this October month of wonderful afternoons they roved along the meads by creeping paths which followed the brinks of trickling tributary brooks, hopping across by little wooden bridges to the other side, and back again. They were never out of the sound of some purling weir, whose buzz accompanied their own murmuring, while the beams of the sun, almost as horizontal as the mead itself, formed a pollen of radiance over the landscape. They saw tiny blue fogs in the shadows of trees and hedges, all the time that there was bright sunshine elsewhere. The sun was so near the ground, and the sward so flat, that the shadows of Clare and Tess would stretch a quarter of a mile ahead of them, like two long fingers pointing afar to where the green alluvial reaches abutted against the sloping sides of the vale.

Men were at work here and there--for it was the season for

``taking up'' (Men)
the meadows, or digging the little waterways clear for the winter irrigation, and mending their banks where trodden down by the cows. The shovelfuls of loam, black as jet, brought there by the river when it was as wide as the whole valley, were an essence of soils, pounded champaigns of the past, steeped, refined, and subtilized to extraordinary richness, out of which came all the fertility of the mead, and of the cattle grazing there.

Clare hardily kept his (Clare) arm round her (it) waist in sight of these watermen, with the air of a man who was accustomed to public dalliance, though actually as shy as she (it) who, with lips parted and eyes askance on the labourers, wore the look of a wary animal the while.

``You are not ashamed of owning me as yours before them!'' (she)
she (it) said gladly.

``O no!'' (unknown)

``But if it should reach the ears of your friends at Emminster that you are walking about like this with me, a milkmaid--'' (unknown)

``The most bewitching milkmaid ever seen.'' (unknown)

``They might feel it a hurt to their dignity.'' (unknown)

``My dear girl--a d

``Urberville hurt the dignity of a Clare! It is a grand card to play--that of your belonging to such a family, and I am reserving it for a grand effect when we are married, and have the proofs of your descent from Parson Tringham. Apart from that, my future is to be totally foreign to my family--it will not affect even the surface of their lives. We shall leave this part of England--perhaps England itself--and what does it matter how people regard us here? You will like going, will you not?'' (She)

She (it) could answer no more than a bare affirmative, so great was the emotion aroused in her (it) at the thought of going through the world with him (man) as his (man) own familiar friend. Her (it) feelings almost filled her (it) ears like a babble of waves, and surged up to her (it) eyes. She (it) put her (it) hand in his (man), and thus they went on, to a place where the reflected sun glared up from the river, under a bridge, with a molten-metallic glow that dazzled their eyes, though the sun itself was hidden by the bridge. They stood still, whereupon little furred and feathered heads popped up from the smooth surface of the water; but, finding that the disturbing presences had paused, and not passed by, they disappeared again. Upon this river-brink they lingered till the fog began to close round them--which was very early in the evening at this time of the year--settling on the lashes of her (itself) eyes, where it rested like crystals, and on his (it) brows and hair.

They walked later on Sundays, when it was quite dark. Some of the dairy-people, who were also out of doors on the first Sunday evening after their engagement, heard her (itself) impulsive speeches, ecstasized to fragments, though they were too far off to hear the words discoursed; noted the spasmodic catch in her (itself) remarks, broken into syllables by the leapings of her (itself) heart, as she (itself) walked leaning on his (it) arm; her (itself) contented pauses, the occasional little laugh upon which her (itself) soul seemed to ride--the laugh of a woman in company with the man she (itself) loves and has won from all other women--unlike anything else in nature. They marked the buoyancy of her (itself) tread, like the skim of a bird which has not quite alighted.

Her (itself) affection for him (man) was now the breath and life of Tess's being; it enveloped her (Tess) as a photosphere, irradiated her (Tess) into forgetfulness of her (Tess) past sorrows, keeping back the gloomy spectres that would persist in their attempts to touch her (Tess)--doubt, fear, moodiness, care, shame. She (Tess) knew that they were waiting like wolves just outside the circumscribing light, but she (Tess) had long spells of power to keep them in hungry subjection there.

A spiritual forgetfulness co-existed with an intellectual remembrance. She (Tess) walked in brightness, but she (Tess) knew that in the background those shapes of darkness were always spread. They might be receding, or they might be approaching, one or the other, a little every day.

One evening Tess and Clare were obliged to sit indoors keeping house, all the other occupants of the domicile being away. As they talked she (Tess) looked thoughtfully up at him (Clare), and met his (Clare) two appreciative eyes.

``I am not worthy of you--no, I am not!'' (she)
she (Tess) burst out, jumping up from her (Tess) low stool as though appalled at his (Clare) homage, and the fulness of her (Tess) own joy thereat.

Clare, deeming the whole basis of her (Tess) excitement to be that which was only the smaller part of it, said--

``I won't have you speak like it, dear Tess! Distinction does not consist in the facile use of a contemptible set of conventions, but in being numbered among those who are true, and honest, and just, and pure, and lovely, and of good report--as you are, my Tess.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

She (Tess) struggled with the sob in her (Tess) throat. How often had that string of excellences made her (Tess) young heart ache in church of late years, and how strange that he (Clare) should have cited them now.

``Why didn't you stay and love me when I--was sixteen; living with my little sisters and brothers, and you danced on the green? O, why didn't you, why didn't you!'' (she)
she (Tess) said, impetuously clasping her (Tess) hands.

Angel began to comfort and reassure her (Tess), thinking to himself, truly enough, what a creature of moods she (Tess) was, and how careful he (Angel) would have to be of her (Tess) when she (Tess) depended for her (Tess) happiness entirely on him (Angel).

``Ah--why didn't I stay!'' (he)
he (Angel) said.
``That is just what I feel. If I had only known! But you must not be so bitter in your regret--why should you be?'' (the woman)

With the woman's instinct to hide she (Tess) diverged hastily--

``I should have had four years more of your heart than I can ever have now. Then I should not have wasted my time as I have done--I should have had so much longer happiness!'' (she)

It was no mature woman with a long dark vista of intrigue behind her (Tess) who was tormented thus, but a girl of simple life, not yet one-and twenty, who had been caught during her (girl) days of immaturity like a bird in a springe. To calm herself the more completely, she (girl) rose from her (girl) little stool and left the room, overturning the stool with her (girl) skirts as she (girl) went.

He (Angel) sat on by the cheerful firelight thrown from a bundle of green ash-sticks laid across the dogs; the sticks snapped pleasantly, and hissed out bubbles of sap from their ends. When she (girl) came back she (girl) was herself again.

``Do you not think you are just a wee bit capricious, fitful, Tess?'' (he)
he (Angel) said, good-humouredly, as he (Angel) spread a cushion for her (girl) on the stool, and seated himself in the settle beside her (girl).
``I wanted to ask you something, and just then you ran away.'' (unknown)

``Yes, perhaps I am capricious,'' (she)
she (girl) murmured. She (girl) suddenly approached him (Angel), and put a hand upon each of his (Angel) arms.
``No, Angel, I am not really so--by nature, I mean!'' (him)
The more particularly to assure him (Angel) that she (girl) was not, she (girl) placed herself close to him (Angel) in the settle, and allowed her (girl) head to find a resting-place against Clare's shoulder.
``What did you want to ask me--I am sure I will answer it,'' (she)
she (girl) continued humbly.

``Well, you love me, and have agreed to marry me, and hence there follows a thirdly,

``When shall the day be?''' (unknown)

``I like living like this.'' (unknown)

``But I must think of starting in business on my own hook with the new year, or a little later. And before I get involved in the multifarious details of my new position, I should like to have secured my partner.'' (unknown)

``But,'' (she)
she (girl) timidly answered,
``to talk quite practically, wouldn't it be best not to marry till after all that?--Though I can't bear the thought o' your going away and leaving me here!'' (she)

``Of course you cannot--and it is not best in this case. I want you to help me in many ways in making my start. When shall it be? Why not a fortnight from now?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (girl) said, becoming grave:
``I have so many things to think of first.'' (she)

``But--'' (He)

He (Clare) drew her (girl) gently nearer to him (Clare).

The reality of marriage was startling when it loomed so near. Before discussion of the question had proceeded further there walked round the corner of the settle into the full firelight of the apartment Mr Dairyman Crick, Mrs Crick, and two of the milkmaids.

Tess sprang like an elastic ball from his (Crick) side to her (Tess) feet, while her (Tess) face flushed and her (Tess) eyes shone in the firelight.

``I knew how it would be if I sat so close to him (you)!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried, with vexation.
``I said to myself, they are sure to come and catch us! But I wasn't really sitting on his (you) knee, though it might ha' seemed as if I was almost!'' (unknown)

``Well--if so be you hadn't told us, I am sure we shouldn't ha' noticed that ye had been sitting anywhere at all in this light,'' (the dairyman)
replied the dairyman. He (dairyman) continued to his (dairyman) wife, with the stolid mien of a man who understood nothing of the emotions relating to matrimony--
``Now, Christianer, that shows that folks should never fancy other folks be supposing things when they bain't. O no, I should never ha' thought a word of where she (you) was a sitting to, if she (you) hadn't told me--not I.'' (a man)

``We are going to be married soon,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare, with improvised phlegm.

``Ah--and be ye! Well, I am truly glad to hear it, sir. I've thought you mid do such a thing for some time. She (you)'s too good for a dairymaid--I said so the very first day I zid her (you)--and a prize for any man; and what's more, a wonderful woman for a gentleman-farmer's wife; he (man) won't be at the mercy of his (man) baily wi' her (wife) at his (man) side.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Somehow Tess disappeared. She (Tess) had been even more struck with the look of the girls who followed Crick than abashed by Crick's blunt praise.

After supper, when she (Tess) reached her (Tess) bedroom, they were all present. A light was burning, and each damsel was sitting up whitely in her (damsel) bed, awaiting Tess, the whole like a row of avenging ghosts.

But she (Tess) saw in a few moments that there was no malice in their mood. They could scarcely feel as a loss what they had never expected to have. Their condition was objective, contemplative.

``He (man)'s going to marry her (wife)!'' (Retty/Retty Priddle)
murmured Retty, never taking eyes off Tess.
``How her (wife) face do show it!'' (unknown)

``You BE going to marry him (man)?'' (Marian)
asked Marian.

``Yes,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``When?'' (unknown)

``Some day.'' (unknown)

They thought that this was evasiveness only.

``YES--going to MARRY him (man)--a gentleman!'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
repeated Izz Huett.

And by a sort of fascination the three girls, one after another, crept out of their beds, and came and stood barefooted round Tess. Retty put her (Tess) hands upon Tess's shoulders, as if to realize her (Tess) friend's corporeality after such a miracle, and the other two laid their arms round her (Tess) waist, all looking into her (Tess) face.

``How it do seem! Almost more than I can think of!'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
said Izz Huett.

Marian kissed Tess.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured as she (Tess) withdrew her (Tess) lips.

``Was that because of love for her (wife), or because other lips have touched there by now?'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
continued Izz drily to Marian.

``I wasn't thinking o' that,'' (Marian)
said Marian simply.
``I was on'y feeling all the strangeness o`t--that she (wife) is to be his (man) wife, and nobody else. I don't say nay to it, nor either of us, because we did not think of it--only loved him (man). Still, nobody else is to marry'n in the world--no fine lady, nobody in silks and satins; but she (lady) who do live like we.'' (unknown)

``Are you sure you don't dislike me for it?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess in a low voice.

They hung about her (Tess) in their white nightgowns before replying, as if they considered their answer might lie in her (Tess) look.

``I don't know--I don't know,'' (Retty/Retty Priddle)
murmured Retty Priddle.
``I want to hate `ee; but I cannot!'' (unknown)

``That's how I feel,'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
echoed Izz and Marian.
``I can't hate her (lady). Somehow she (lady) hinders me!'' (unknown)

``He (man) ought to marry one of you,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
murmured Tess.

``Why?'' (unknown)

``You are all better than I.'' (unknown)

``We better than you?'' (the girls)
said the girls in a low, slow whisper.
``No, no, dear Tess!'' (unknown)

``You are!'' (she)
she (Tess) contradicted impetuously. And suddenly tearing away from their clinging arms she (Tess) burst into a hysterical fit of tears, bowing herself on the chest of drawers and repeating incessantly,
``O yes, yes, yes!'' (she)

Having once given way she (Tess) could not stop her (Tess) weeping.

``He (man) ought to have had one of you!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried.
``I think I ought to make him (man) even now! You would be better for him (man) than--I don't know what I'm saying! O! O!'' (her)

They went up to her (Tess) and clasped her (Tess) round, but still her (Tess) sobs tore her (Tess).

``Get some water,'' (Marian)
said Marian,
``She (Tess)'s upset by us, poor thing, poor thing!'' (Marian)

They gently led her (Marian) back to the side of her (Marian) bed, where they kissed her (Marian) warmly.

``You are best for`n,'' (Marian)
said Marian.
``More ladylike, and a better scholar than we, especially since he (scholar) had taught `ee so much. But even you ought to be proud. You BE proud, I'm sure!'' (unknown)

``Yes, I am,'' (she)
she (Marian) said;
``and I am ashamed at so breaking down.'' (she)

When they were all in bed, and the light was out, Marian whispered across to her (Marian)--

``You will think of us when you be his (scholar) wife, Tess, and of how we told `ee that we loved him (scholar), and how we tried not to hate you, and did not hate you, and could not hate you, because you were his (scholar) choice, and we never hoped to be chose by him (scholar).'' (Marian)

They were not aware that, at these words, salt, stinging tears trickled down upon Tess's pillow anew, and how she (Tess) resolved, with a bursting heart, to tell all her (Tess) history to Angel Clare, despite her (Tess) mother's command--to let him (Clare) for whom she (Tess) lived and breathed despise her (Tess) if he (Clare) would, and her (Tess) mother regard her (Tess) as a fool, rather then preserve a silence which might be deemed a treachery to him (fool), and which somehow seemed a wrong to these.

XXXII

This penitential mood kept her (Tess) from naming the wedding-day. The beginning of November found its date still in abeyance, though he (fool) asked her (Tess) at the most tempting times. But Tess's desire seemed to be for a perpetual betrothal in which everything should remain as it was then.

The meads were changing now; but it was still warm enough in early afternoons before milking to idle there awhile, and the state of dairy-work at this time of year allowed a spare hour for idling. Looking over the damp sod in the direction of the sun, a glistening ripple of gossamer webs was visible to their eyes under the luminary, like the track of moonlight on the sea. Gnats, knowing nothing of their brief glorification, wandered across the shimmer of this pathway, irradiated as if they bore fire within them, then passed out of its line, and were quite extinct. In the presence of these things he (luminary) would remind her (luminary) that the date was still the question.

Or he (luminary) would ask her (luminary) at night, when he (luminary) accompanied her (luminary) on some mission invented by Mrs Crick to give him (luminary) the opportunity. This was mostly a journey to the farmhouse on the slopes above the vale, to inquire how the advanced cows were getting on in the straw-barton to which they were relegated. For it was a time of the year that brought great changes to the world of kine. Batches of the animals were sent away daily to this lying-in hospital, where they lived on straw till their calves were born, after which event, and as soon as the calf could walk, mother and offspring were driven back to the dairy. In the interval which elapsed before the calves were sold there was, of course, little milking to be done, but as soon as the calf had been taken away the milkmaids would have to set to work as usual.

Returning from one of these dark walks they reached a great gravel-cliff immediately over the levels, where they stood still and listened. The water was now high in the streams, squirting through the weirs, and tinkling under culverts; the smallest gullies were all full; there was no taking short cuts anywhere, and foot-passengers were compelled to follow the permanent ways. From the whole extent of the invisible vale came a multitudinous intonation; it forced upon their fancy that a great city lay below them, and that the murmur was the vociferation of its populace.

``It seems like tens of thousands of them,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess;
``holding public-meetings in their market-places, arguing, preaching, quarrelling, sobbing, groaning, praying, and cursing.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Clare was not particularly heeding.

``Did Crick speak to you to-day, dear, about his (Crick) not wanting much assistance during the winter months?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``The cows are going dry rapidly.'' (unknown)

``Yes. Six or seven went to the straw-barton yesterday, and three the day before, making nearly twenty in the straw already. Ah--is it that the farmer don't want my help for the calving? O, I am not wanted here any more! And I have tried so hard to--'' (unknown)

``Crick didn't exactly say that he (Crick) would no longer require you. But, knowing what our relations were, he (Crick) said in the most good-natured and respectful manner possible that he (Crick) supposed on my leaving at Christmas I should take you with me, and on my asking what he (Crick) would do without you he (Crick) merely observed that, as a matter of fact, it was a time of year when he (Crick) could do with a very little female help. I am afraid I was sinner enough to feel rather glad that he (sinner) was in this way forcing your hand.'' (unknown)

``I don't think you ought to have felt glad, Angel. Because `tis always mournful not to be wanted, even if at the same time `tis convenient.'' (unknown)

``Well, it is convenient--you have admitted that.'' (He)
He (Clare) put his (Clare) finger upon her (Tess) cheek.
``Ah!'' (he)
he (Clare) said.

``What?'' (unknown)

``I feel the red rising up at her (your) having been caught! But why should I trifle so! We will not trifle--life is too serious.'' (unknown)

``It is. Perhaps I saw that before you did.'' (She)

She (Tess) was seeing it then. To decline to marry him (Clare) after all--in obedience to her (Tess) emotion of last night--and leave the dairy, meant to go to some strange place, not a dairy; for milkmaids were not in request now calving-time was coming on; to go to some arable farm where no divine being like Angel Clare was. She (Tess) hated the thought, and she (Tess) hated more the thought of going home.

``So that, seriously, dearest Tess,'' (he)
he (Clare) continued,
``since you will probably have to leave at Christmas, it is in every way desirable and convenient that I should carry you off then as my property. Besides, if you were not the most uncalculating girl in the world you would know that we could not go on like this for ever.'' (he)

``I wish we could. That it would always be summer and autumn, and you always courting me, and always thinking as much of me as you have done through the past summer-time!'' (unknown)

``I always shall.'' (unknown)

``O, I know you will!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried, with a sudden fervour of faith in him (Clare).
``Angel, I will fix the day when I will become yours for always!'' (unknown)

Thus at last it was arranged between them, during that dark walk home, amid the myriads of liquid voices on the right and left.

When they reached the dairy Mr and Mrs Crick were promptly told--with injunctions of secrecy; for each of the lovers was desirous that the marriage should be kept as private as possible. The dairyman, though he (dairyman) had thought of dismissing her (Crick) soon, now made a great concern about losing her (Crick). What should he (dairyman) do about his (dairyman) skimming? Who would make the ornamental butter-pats for the Anglebury and Sandbourne ladies? Mrs Crick congratulated Tess on the shilly-shallying having at last come to an end, and said that directly she (Crick) set eyes on Tess she (Tess) divined that she (Tess) was to be the chosen one of somebody who was no common outdoor man; Tess had looked so superior as she (Tess) walked across the barton on that afternoon of her (Tess) arrival; that she (Tess) was of a good family she (Tess) could have sworn. In point of fact Mrs Crick did remember thinking that Tess was graceful and good-looking as she (Tess) approached; but the superiority might have been a growth of the imagination aided by subsequent knowledge.

Tess was now carried along upon the wings of the hours, without the sense of a will. The word had been given; the number of the day written down. Her (Tess) naturally bright intelligence had begun to admit the fatalistic convictions common to field-folk and those who associate more extensively with natural phenomena than with their fellow-creatures; and she (Tess) accordingly drifted into that passive responsiveness to all things her (Tess) lover suggested, characteristic of the frame of mind.

But she (Tess) wrote anew to her (Tess) mother, ostensibly to notify the wedding-day; really to again implore her (Tess) advice. It was a gentleman who had chosen her (Tess), which perhaps her (Tess) mother had not sufficiently considered. A post-nuptial explanation, which might be accepted with a light heart by a rougher man, might not be received with the same feeling by him (man). But this communication brought no reply from Mrs Durbeyfield.

Despite Angel Clare's plausible representation to himself and to Tess of the practical need for their immediate marriage, there was in truth an element of precipitancy in the step, as became apparent at a later date. He (Angel) loved her (Tess) dearly, though perhaps rather ideally and fancifully than with the impassioned thoroughness of her (Tess) feeling for him (Angel). He (Angel) had entertained no notion, when doomed as he (Angel) had thought to an unintellectual bucolic life, that such charms as he (Angel) beheld in this idyllic creature would be found behind the scenes. Unsophistication was a thing to talk of; but he (Angel) had not known how it really struck one until he (Angel) came here. Yet he (Angel) was very far from seeing his (Angel) future track clearly, and it might be a year or two before he (Angel) would be able to consider himself fairly started in life. The secret lay in the tinge of recklessness imparted to his (Angel) career and character by the sense that he (Angel) had been made to miss his (Angel) true destiny through the prejudices of his (Angel) family.

``Don't you think `twould have been better for us to wait till you were quite settled in your midland farm?'' (she)
she (Angel) once asked timidly. -LRB-A midland farm was the idea just then.-RRB-

``To tell the truth, my Tess, I don't like you to be left anywhere away from my protection and sympathy.'' (unknown)

The reason was a good one, so far as it went. His (Angel) influence over her (Angel) had been so marked that she (Angel) had caught his (Angel) manner and habits, his (Angel) speech and phrases, his (Angel) likings and his (Angel) aversions. And to leave her (Angel) in farmland would be to let her (Angel) slip back again out of accord with him (Angel). He (Angel) wished to have her (Angel) under his (Angel) charge for another reason. His (Angel) parents had naturally desired to see her (Angel) once at least before he (Angel) carried her (Angel) off to a distant settlement, English or colonial; and as no opinion of theirs was to be allowed to change his (Angel) intention, he (Angel) judged that a couple of months' life with him (Angel) in lodgings whilst seeking for an advantageous opening would be of some social assistance to her (Angel) at what she (Angel) might feel to be a trying ordeal--her (Angel) presentation to his (Angel) mother at the Vicarage.

Next, he (Angel) wished to see a little of the working of a flour-mill, having an idea that he (Angel) might combine the use of one with corn-growing. The proprietor of a large old water-mill at Wellbridge--once the mill of an Abbey--had offered him (Angel) the inspection of his (Angel) time-honoured mode of procedure, and a hand in the operations for a few days, whenever he (Angel) should choose to come. Clare paid a visit to the place, some few miles distant, one day at this time, to inquire particulars, and returned to Talbothays in the evening. She (proprietor) found him (Clare) determined to spend a short time at the Wellbridge flour-mills. And what had determined him (Clare)? Less the opportunity of an insight into grinding and bolting than the casual fact that lodgings were to be obtained in that very farmhouse which, before its mutilation, had been the mansion of a branch of the d``Urberville family. This was always how Clare settled practical questions; by a sentiment which had nothing to do with them. They decided to go immediately after the wedding, and remain for a fortnight, instead of journeying to towns and inns.

``Then we will start off to examine some farms on the other side of London that I have heard of,'' (he)
he (Clare) said,
``and by March or April we will pay a visit to my father and mother.'' (he)

Questions of procedure such as these arose and passed, and the day, the incredible day, on which she (proprietor) was to become his (Clare), loomed large in the near future. The thirty-first of December, New Year's Eve, was the date. His (Clare) wife, she (wife) said to herself. Could it ever be? Their two selves together, nothing to divide them, every incident shared by them; why not? And yet why?

One Sunday morning Izz Huett returned from church, and spoke privately to Tess.

``You was not called home this morning.'' (unknown)

``What?'' (unknown)

``It should ha' been the first time of asking to-day,'' (she)
she (Tess) answered, looking quietly at Tess.
``You meant to be married New Year's Eve, deary?'' (unknown)

The other returned a quick affirmative.

``And there must be three times of asking. And now there be only two Sundays left between.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess felt her (Tess) cheek paling; Izz was right; of course there must be three. Perhaps he (Izz) had forgotten! If so, there must be a week's postponement, and that was unlucky. How could she (Tess) remind her (Tess) lover? She (Tess) who had been so backward was suddenly fired with impatience and alarm lest she (Tess) should lose her (Tess) dear prize.

A natural incident relieved her (Tess) anxiety. Izz mentioned the omission of the banns to Mrs Crick, and Mrs Crick assumed a matron's privilege of speaking to Angel on the point.

``Have ye forgot 'em, Mr Clare? The banns, I mean.'' (unknown)

``No, I have not forgot 'em,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
says Clare.

As soon as he (Clare) caught Tess alone he (Clare) assured her (Tess):

``Don't let them tease you about the banns. A licence will be quieter for us, and I have decided on a licence without consulting you. So if you go to church on Sunday morning you will not hear your own name, if you wished to.'' (he)

``I didn't wish to hear it, dearest,'' (she)
she (Tess) said proudly.

But to know that things were in train was an immense relief to Tess notwithstanding, who had well-nigh feared that somebody would stand up and forbid the banns on the ground of her (Tess) history. How events were favouring her (Tess)!

``I don't quite feel easy,'' (she)
she (Tess) said to herself.
``All this good fortune may be scourged out of me afterwards by a lot of ill. That's how Heaven mostly does. I wish I could have had common banns!'' (unknown)

But everything went smoothly. She (Tess) wondered whether he (Clare) would like her (Tess) to be married in her (Tess) present best white frock, or if she (Tess) ought to buy a new one. The question was set at rest by his (Clare) forethought, disclosed by the arrival of some large packages addressed to her (Tess).
