Inside them she (Tess) found a whole stock of clothing, from bonnet to shoes, including a perfect morning costume, such as would well suit the simple wedding they planned. He (Clare) entered the house shortly after the arrival of the packages, and heard her (Tess) upstairs undoing them.

A minute later she (Tess) came down with a flush on her (Tess) face and tears in her (Tess) eyes.

``How thoughtful you've been!'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured, her (Tess) cheek upon his (Clare) shoulder.
``Even to the gloves and handkerchief! My own love--how good, how kind!'' (unknown)

``No, no, Tess; just an order to a tradeswoman in London--nothing more.'' (him)

And to divert her (Tess) from thinking too highly of him (Clare), he (Clare) told her (Tess) to go upstairs, and take her (Tess) time, and see if it all fitted; and, if not, to get the village sempstress to make a few alterations.

She (Tess) did return upstairs, and put on the gown. Alone, she (Tess) stood for a moment before the glass looking at the effect of her (Tess) silk attire; and then there came into her (Tess) head her (Tess) mother's ballad of the mystic robe--

That never would become that wife That had once done amiss,

which Mrs Durbeyfield had used to sing to her (Durbeyfield) as a child, so blithely and so archly, her (Durbeyfield) foot on the cradle, which she (Durbeyfield) rocked to the tune. Suppose this robe should betray her (Durbeyfield) by changing colour, as her (Durbeyfield) robe had betrayed Queen Guinevere. Since she (Durbeyfield) had been at the dairy she (Durbeyfield) had not once thought of the lines till now.

XXXIII

Angel felt that he (Angel) would like to spend a day with her (Durbeyfield) before the wedding, somewhere away from the dairy, as a last jaunt in her (Durbeyfield) company while there were yet mere lover and mistress; a romantic day, in circumstances that would never be repeated; with that other and greater day beaming close ahead of them. During the preceding week, therefore, he (lover) suggested making a few purchases in the nearest town, and they started together.

Clare's life at the dairy had been that of a recluse in respect the world of his (recluse) own class. For months he (recluse) had never gone near a town, and, requiring no vehicle, had never kept one, hiring the dairyman's cob or gig if he (dairyman) rode or drove. They went in the gig that day.

And then for the first time in their lives they shopped as partners in one concern. It was Christmas Eve, with its loads a holly and mistletoe, and the town was very full of strangers who had come in from all parts of the country on account of the day. Tess paid the penalty of walking about with happiness superadded to beauty on her (Tess) countenance by being much stared at as she (Tess) moved amid them on his (dairyman) arm.

In the evening they returned to the inn at which they had put up, and Tess waited in the entry while Angel went to see the horse and gig brought to the door. The general sitting-room was full of guests, who were continually going in and out. As the door opened and shut each time for the passage of these, the light within the parlour fell full upon Tess's face. Two men came out and passed by her (Tess) among the rest. One of them had stared her (Tess) up and down in surprise, and she (Tess) fancied he (Angel) was a Trantridge man, though that village lay so many miles off that Trantridge folk were rarities here.

``A comely maid that,'' (unknown)
said the other.

``True, comely enough. But unless I make a great mistake--'' (he)
And he (Angel) negatived the remainder of the definition forthwith.

Clare had just returned from the stable-yard, and, confronting the man on the threshold, heard the words, and saw the shrinking of Tess. The insult to her (Tess) stung him (Clare) to the quick, and before he (Clare) had considered anything at all he (Clare) struck the man on the chin with the full force of his (Clare) fist, sending him (Clare) staggering backwards into the passage.

The man recovered himself, and seemed inclined to come on, and Clare, stepping outside the door, put himself in a posture of defence. But his (Clare) opponent began to think better of the matter. He (Clare) looked anew at Tess as he (Clare) passed her (Tess), and said to Clare--

``I beg pardon, sir; 'twas a complete mistake. I thought she (maid) was another woman, forty miles from here.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Clare, feeling then that he (Clare) had been too hasty, and that he (Clare) was, moreover, to blame for leaving her (Tess) standing in an inn-passage, did what he (Clare) usually did in such cases, gave the man five shillings to plaster the blow; and thus they parted, bidding each other a pacific good night. As soon as Clare had taken the reins from the ostler, and the young couple had driven off, the two men went in the other direction.

``And was it a mistake?'' (unknown)
said the second one.

``Not a bit of it. But I didn't want to hurt the gentleman's feelings--not I.'' (the lovers)

In the meantime the lovers were driving onward.

``Could we put off our wedding till a little later?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
Tess asked in a dry dull voice.
``I mean if we wished?'' (unknown)

``No, my love. Calm yourself. Do you mean that the fellow may have time to summon me for assault?'' (he)
he (Clare) asked good-humouredly.

``No--I only meant--if it should have to be put off.'' (she)

What she (Tess) meant was not very clear, and he (Clare) directed her (Tess) to dismiss such fancies from her (Tess) mind, which she (Tess) obediently did as well as she (Tess) could. But she (Tess) was grave, very grave, all the way home; till she (Tess) thought,

``We shall go away, a very long distance, hundreds of miles from these parts, and such as this can never happen again, and no ghost of the past reach there.'' (she)

They parted tenderly that night on the landing, and Clare ascended to his (Clare) attic. Tess sat up getting on with some little requisites, lest the few remaining days should not afford sufficient time. While she (Tess) sat she (Tess) heard a noise in Angel's room overhead, a sound of thumping and struggling. Everybody else in the house was asleep, and in her (Tess) anxiety lest Clare should be ill she (Tess) ran up and knocked at his (Clare) door, and asked him (Clare) what was the matter.

``Oh, nothing, dear,'' (he)
he (Clare) said from within.
``I am so sorry I disturbed you! But the reason is rather an amusing one: I fell asleep and dreamt that I was fighting that fellow again who insulted you, and the noise you heard was my pummelling away with my fists at my portmanteau, which I pulled out to-day for packing. I am occasionally liable to these freaks in my sleep. Go to bed and think of it no more.'' (unknown)

This was the last drachm required to turn the scale of her (Tess) indecision. Declare the past to him (Clare) by word of mouth she (Tess) could not; but there was another way. She (Tess) sat down and wrote on the four pages of a note-sheet a succinct narrative of those events of three or four years ago, put it into an envelope, and directed it to Clare. Then, lest the flesh should again be weak, she (Tess) crept upstairs without any shoes and slipped the note under his (Clare) door.

Her (Tess) night was a broken one, as it well might be, and she (Tess) listened for the first faint noise overhead. It came, as usual; he (Clare) descended, as usual. She (Tess) descended. He (Clare) met her (Tess) at the bottom of the stairs and kissed her (Tess). Surely it was as warmly as ever!

He (Clare) looked a little disturbed and worn, she (Tess) thought. But he (Clare) said not a word to her (Tess) about her (Tess) revelation, even when they were alone. Could he (Clare) have had it? Unless he (Clare) began the subject she (Tess) felt that she (Tess) could say nothing. So the day passed, and it was evident that whatever he (Clare) thought he (Clare) meant to keep to himself. Yet he (Clare) was frank and affectionate as before. Could it be that her (Tess) doubts were childish? that he (Clare) forgave her (Tess); that he (Clare) loved her (Tess) for what she (Tess) was, just as she (Tess) was, and smiled at her (Tess) disquiet as at a foolish nightmare? Had he (Clare) really received her (Tess) note? She (Tess) glanced into his (Clare) room, and could see nothing of it. It might be that he (Clare) forgave her (Tess). But even if he (Clare) had not received it she (Tess) had a sudden enthusiastic trust that he (Clare) surely would forgive her (Tess).

Every morning and night he (Clare) was the same, and thus New Year's Eve broke--the wedding day.

The lovers did not rise at milking-time, having through the whole of this last week of their sojourn at the dairy been accorded something of the position of guests, Tess being honoured with a room of her (Tess) own. When they arrived downstairs at breakfast-time they were surprised to see what effects had been produced in the large kitchen for their glory since they had last beheld it. At some unnatural hour of the morning the dairyman had caused the yawning chimney-corner to be whitened, and the brick hearth reddened, and a blazing yellow damask blower to be hung across the arch in place of the old grimy blue cotton one with a black sprig pattern which had formerly done duty there. This renovated aspect of what was the focus indeed of the room on a full winter morning threw a smiling demeanour over the whole apartment.

``I was determined to do summat in honour o`t'' (the dairyman)
, said the dairyman.
``And as you wouldn't hear of my gieing a rattling good randy wi' fiddles and bass-viols complete, as we should ha' done in old times, this was all I could think o' as a noiseless thing.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess's friends lived so far off that none could conveniently have been present at the ceremony, even had any been asked; but as a fact nobody was invited from Marlott. As for Angel's family, he (Angel) had written and duly informed them of the time, and assured them that he (Angel) would be glad to see one at least of them there for the day if he (Angel) would like to come. His (Angel) brothers had not replied at all, seeming to be indignant with him (Angel); while his (Angel) father and mother had written a rather sad letter, deploring his (Angel) precipitancy in rushing into marriage, but making the best of the matter by saying that, though a dairywoman was the last daughter-in-law they could have expected, their son had arrived at an age which he (son) might be supposed to be the best judge.

This coolness in his (son) relations distressed Clare less than it would have done had he (Clare) been without the grand card with which he (Clare) meant to surprise them ere long. To produce Tess, fresh from the dairy, as a d``Urberville and a lady, he (I) had felt to be temerarious and risky; hence he (I) had concealed her (lady) lineage till such time as, familiarized with worldly ways by a few months' travel and reading with him (I), he (I) could take her (lady) on a visit to his (I) parents and impart the knowledge while triumphantly producing her (lady) as worthy of such an ancient line. It was a pretty lover's dream, if no more. Perhaps Tess's lineage had more value for himself than for anybody in the world beside.

Her (Tess) perception that Angel's bearing towards her (Tess) still remained in no whit altered by her (Tess) own communication rendered Tess guiltily doubtful if he (Angel) could have received it. She (Tess) rose from breakfast before he (Angel) had finished, and hastened upstairs. It had occurred to her (Tess) to look once more into the queer gaunt room which had been Clare's den, or rather eyrie, for so long, and climbing the ladder she (Tess) stood at the open door of the apartment, regarding and pondering. She (Tess) stooped to the threshold of the doorway, where she (Tess) had pushed in the note two or three days earlier in such excitement. The carpet reached close to the sill, and under the edge of the carpet she (Tess) discerned the faint white margin of the envelope containing her (Tess) letter to him (Clare), which he (Clare) obviously had never seen, owing to her (Tess) having in her (Tess) haste thrust it beneath the carpet as well as beneath the door.

With a feeling of faintness she (Tess) withdrew the letter. There it was--sealed up, just as it had left her (Tess) hands. The mountain had not yet been removed. She (Tess) could not let him (Clare) read it now, the house being in full bustle of preparation; and descending to her (Tess) own room she (Tess) destroyed the letter there.

She (Tess) was so pale when he (Clare) saw her (Tess) again that he (Clare) felt quite anxious. The incident of the misplaced letter she (Tess) had jumped at as if it prevented a confession; but she (Tess) knew in her (Tess) conscience that it need not; there was still time. Yet everything was in a stir; there was coming and going; all had to dress, the dairyman and Mrs Crick having been asked to accompany them as witnesses; and reflection or deliberate talk was well-nigh impossible. The only minute Tess could get to be alone with Clare was when they met upon the landing.

``I am so anxious to talk to you--I want to confess all my faults and blunders!'' (she)
she (Tess) said with attempted lightness.

``No, no--we can't have faults talked of--you must be deemed perfect to-day at least, my Sweet!'' (he)
he (Clare) cried.
``We shall have plenty of time, hereafter, I hope, to talk over our failings. I will confess mine at the same time.'' (unknown)

``But it would be better for me to do it now, I think, so that you could not say--'' (unknown)

``Well, my quixotic one, you shall tell me anything--say, as soon as we are settled in our lodging; not now. I, too, will tell you my faults then. But do not let us spoil the day with them; they will be excellent matter for a dull time.'' (unknown)

``Then you don't wish me to, dearest?'' (unknown)

``I do not, Tessy, really.'' (unknown)

The hurry of dressing and starting left no time for more than this. Those words of his (Clare) seemed to reassure her (Tess) on further reflection. She (Tess) was whirled onward through the next couple of critical hours by the mastering tide of her (Tess) devotion to him (Clare), which closed up further meditation. Her (Tess) one desire, so long resisted, to make herself his (Clare), to call him (Clare) her (Tess) lord, her (Tess) own--then, if necessary, to die--had at last lifted her (Tess) up from her (Tess) plodding reflective pathway. In dressing, she (Tess) moved about in a mental cloud of many-coloured idealities, which eclipsed all sinister contingencies by its brightness.

The church was a long way off, and they were obliged to drive, particularly as it was winter. A closed carriage was ordered from a roadside inn, a vehicle which had been kept there ever since the old days of post-chaise travelling. It had stout wheel-spokes, and heavy felloes a great curved bed, immense straps and springs, and a pole like a battering-ram. The postilion was a venerable

``boy'' (The postilion)
of sixty--a martyr to rheumatic gout, the result of excessive exposure in youth, counter-acted by strong liquors--who had stood at inn-doors doing nothing for the whole five-and-twenty years that had elapsed since he (martyr) had no longer been required to ride professionally, as if expecting the old times to come back again. He (martyr) had a permanent running wound on the outside of his (martyr) right leg, originated by the constant bruisings of aristocratic carriage-poles during the many years that he (martyr) had been in regular employ at the King's Arms, Casterbridge.

Inside this cumbrous and creaking structure, and behind this decayed conductor, the _partie carre_ took their seats--the bride and bridegroom and Mr and Mrs Crick. Angel would have liked one at least of his (Angel) brothers to be present as groomsman, but their silence after his (Angel) gentle hint to that effect by letter had signified that they did not care to come. They disapproved of the marriage, and could not be expected to countenance it. Perhaps it was as well that they could not be present. They were not worldly young fellows, but fraternizing with dairy-folk would have struck unpleasantly upon their biased niceness, apart from their views of the match.

Upheld by the momentum of the time, Tess knew nothing of this, did not see anything, did not know the road they were taking to the church. She (Tess) knew that Angel was close to her (Tess); all the rest was a luminous mist. She (Tess) was a sort of celestial person, who owed her (Tess) being to poetry--one of those classical divinities Clare was accustomed to talk to her (Tess) about when they took their walks together.

The marriage being by licence there were only a dozen or so of people in the church; had there been a thousand they would have produced no more effect upon her (Tess). They were at stellar distances from her (Tess) present world. In the ecstatic solemnity with which she (Tess) swore her (Tess) faith to him (Clare) the ordinary sensibilities of sex seemed a flippancy. At a pause in the service, while they were kneeling together, she (Tess) unconsciously inclined herself towards him (Clare), so that her (Tess) shoulder touched his (Clare) arm; she (Tess) had been frightened by a passing thought, and the movement had been automatic, to assure herself that he (Clare) was really there, and to fortify her (Tess) belief that his (Clare) fidelity would be proof against all things.

Clare knew that she (Tess) loved him (Clare)--every curve of her (Tess) form showed that-- but he (Clare) did not know at that time the full depth of her (Tess) devotion, its single-mindedness, its meekness; what long-suffering it guaranteed, what honesty, what endurance, what good faith.

As they came out of church the ringers swung the bells off their rests, and a modest peal of three notes broke forth--that limited amount of expression having been deemed sufficient by the church builders for the joys of such a small parish. Passing by the tower with her (Tess) husband on the path to the gate she (Tess) could feel the vibrant air humming round them from the louvred belfry in the circle of sound, and it matched the highly-charged mental atmosphere in which she (Tess) was living.

This condition of mind, wherein she (Tess) felt glorified by an irradiation not her (Tess) own, like the angel whom St John saw in the sun, lasted till the sound of the church bells had died away, and the emotions of the wedding-service had calmed down. Her (Tess) eyes could dwell upon details more clearly now, and Mr and Mrs Crick having directed their own gig to be sent for them, to leave the carriage to the young couple, she (Crick) observed the build and character of that conveyance for the first time. Sitting in silence she (Crick) regarded it long.

``I fancy you seem oppressed, Tessy,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Crick) answered, putting her (Crick) hand to her (Crick) brow.
``I tremble at many things. It is all so serious, Angel. Among other things I seem to have seen this carriage before, to be very well acquainted with it. It is very odd--I must have seen it in a dream.'' (unknown)

``Oh--you have heard the legend of the d

``Urberville Coach--that well-known superstition of this county about your family when they were very popular here; and this lumbering old thing reminds you of it.'' (unknown)

``I have never heard of it to my knowledge,'' (she)
said she (Crick).
``What is the legend--may I know it?'' (unknown)

``Well--I would rather not tell it in detail just now. A certain d

``Urberville of the sixteenth or seventeenth century committed a dreadful crime in his (my) family coach; and since that time members of the family see or hear the old coach whenever--But I'll tell you another day--it is rather gloomy. Evidently some dim knowledge of it has been brought back to your mind by the sight of this venerable caravan.'' (unknown)

``I don't remember hearing it before,'' (she)
she (Crick) murmured.
``Is it when we are going to die, Angel, that members of my family see it, or is it when we have committed a crime?'' (unknown)

``Now, Tess!'' (He)

He (Clare) silenced her (Crick) by a kiss.

By the time they reached home she (Crick) was contrite and spiritless. She (Crick) was Mrs Angel Clare, indeed, but had she (Crick) any moral right to the name? Was she (Crick) not more truly Mrs Alexander d``Urberville? Could intensity of love justify what might be considered in upright souls as culpable reticence? She (Tess) knew not what was expected of women in such cases; and she (Tess) had no counsellor.

However, when she (Tess) found herself alone in her (Tess) room for a few minutes--the last day this on which she (Tess) was ever to enter it--she (Tess) knelt down and prayed. She (Tess) tried to pray to God, but it was her (Tess) husband who really had her (Tess) supplication. Her (Tess) idolatry of this man was such that she (Tess) herself almost feared it to be ill-omened. She (Tess) was conscious of the notion expressed by Friar Laurence:

``These violent delights have violent ends.'' (Friar Laurence)
It might be too desperate for human conditions--too rank, to wild, too deadly.

``O my love, why do I love you so!'' (she)
she (Mrs) whispered there alone;
``for she (Tess) you love is not my real self, but one in my image; the one I might have been!'' (she)

Afternoon came, and with it the hour for departure. They had decided to fulfil the plan of going for a few days to the lodgings in the old farmhouse near Wellbridge Mill, at which he (Alexander) meant to reside during his (Alexander) investigation of flour processes. At two o'clock there was nothing left to do but to start. All the servantry of the dairy were standing in the red-brick entry to see them go out, the dairyman and his (dairyman) wife following to the door. Tess saw her (Tess) three chamber-mates in a row against the wall, pensively inclining their heads. She (Tess) had much questioned if they would appear at the parting moment; but there they were, stoical and staunch to the last. She (Tess) knew why the delicate Retty looked so fragile, and Izz so tragically sorrowful, and Marian so blank; and she (Marian) forgot her (Marian) own dogging shadow for a moment in contemplating theirs.

She (Marian) impulsively whispered to him (Izz)--

``Will you kiss 'em all, once, poor things, for the first and last time?'' (him)

Clare had not the least objection to such a farewell formality--which was all that it was to him (Clare)--and as he (Clare) passed them he (Clare) kissed them in succession where they stood, saying

``Goodbye'' (he)
to each as he (Clare) did so. When they reached the door Tess femininely glanced back to discern the effect of that kiss of charity; there was no triumph in her (Tess) glance, as there might have been. If there had it would have disappeared when she (Tess) saw how moved the girls all were. The kiss had obviously done harm by awakening feelings they were trying to subdue.

Of all this Clare was unconscious. Passing on to the wicket-gate he (Clare) shook hands with the dairyman and his (Clare) wife, and expressed his (Clare) last thanks to them for their attentions; after which there was a moment of silence before they had moved off. It was interrupted by the crowing of a cock. The white one with the rose comb had come and settled on the palings in front of the house, within a few yards of them, and his (Clare) notes thrilled their ears through, dwindling away like echoes down a valley of rocks.

``Oh?'' (Mrs Crick)
said Mrs Crick.
``An afternoon crow!'' (men)

Two men were standing by the yard gate, holding it open.

``That's bad,'' (unknown)
one murmured to the other, not thinking that the words could be heard by the group at the door-wicket.

The cock crew again--straight towards Clare.

``Well!'' (the dairyman)
said the dairyman.

``I don't like to hear him (Laurence)!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess to her (Tess) husband.
``Tell the man to drive on. Goodbye, goodbye!'' (The cock crew)

The cock crew again.

``Hoosh! Just you be off, sir, or I'll twist your neck!'' (the dairyman)
said the dairyman with some irritation, turning to the bird and driving him (dairyman) away. And to his (dairyman) wife as they went indoors:
``Now, to think o' that just to-day! I've not heard his (Laurence) crow of an afternoon all the year afore.'' (wife)

``It only means a change in the weather,'' (she)
said she (wife);
``not what you think: `tis impossible!'' (she)

XXXIV

They drove by the level road along the valley to a distance of a few miles, and, reaching Wellbridge, turned away from the village to the left, and over the great Elizabethan bridge which gives the place half its name. Immediately behind it stood the house wherein they had engaged lodgings, whose exterior features are so well known to all travellers through the Froom Valley; once portion of a fine manorial residence, and the property and seat of a d``Urberville, but since its partial demolition a farmhouse.

``Welcome to one of your ancestral mansions!'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare as he (Clare) handed her (wife) down. But he (Clare) regretted the pleasantry; it was too near a satire.

On entering they found that, though they had only engaged a couple of rooms, the farmer had taken advantage of their proposed presence during the coming days to pay a New Year's visit to some friends, leaving a woman from a neighbouring cottage to minister to their few wants. The absoluteness of possession pleased them, and they realized it as the first moment of their experience under their own exclusive roof-tree.

But he (minister) found that the mouldy old habitation somewhat depressed his (minister) bride. When the carriage was gone they ascended the stairs to wash their hands, the charwoman showing the way. On the landing Tess stopped and started.

``What's the matter?'' (he)
said he (minister).

``Those horrid women!'' (she)
she (Tess) answered with a smile.
``How they frightened me.'' (He)

He (minister) looked up, and perceived two life-size portraits on panels built into the masonry. As all visitors to the mansion are aware, these paintings represent women of middle age, of a date some two hundred years ago, whose lineaments once seen can never be forgotten. The long pointed features, narrow eye, and smirk of the one, so suggestive of merciless treachery; the bill-hook nose, large teeth, and bold eye of the other suggesting arrogance to the point of ferocity, haunt the beholder afterwards in his (minister) dreams.

``Whose portraits are those?'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
asked Clare of the charwoman.

``I have been told by old folk that they were ladies of the d``Urberville family, the ancient lords of this manor,'' she (women) said,

``Owing to their being builded into the wall they can't be moved away.'' (the lords)

The unpleasantness of the matter was that, in addition to their effect upon Tess, her (Tess) fine features were unquestionably traceable in these exaggerated forms. He (minister) said nothing of this, however, and, regretting that he (minister) had gone out of his (minister) way to choose the house for their bridal time, went on into the adjoining room. The place having been rather hastily prepared for them, they washed their hands in one basin. Clare touched hers under the water.

``Which are my fingers and which are yours?'' (he)
he (Clare) said, looking up.
``They are very much mixed.'' (unknown)

``They are all yours,'' (she)
said she (Tess), very prettily, and endeavoured to be gayer than she (Tess) was. He (Clare) had not been displeased with her (Tess) thoughtfulness on such an occasion; it was what every sensible woman would show: but Tess knew that she (Tess) had been thoughtful to excess, and struggled against it.

The sun was so low on that short last afternoon of the year that it shone in through a small opening and formed a golden staff which stretched across to her (Tess) skirt, where it made a spot like a paint-mark set upon her (Tess). They went into the ancient parlour to tea, and here they shared their first common meal alone. Such was their childishness, or rather his (Tess), that he (Tess) found it interesting to use the same bread-and-butter plate as herself, and to brush crumbs from her (Tess) lips with his (Tess) own. He (Tess) wondered a little that she (Tess) did not enter into these frivolities with his (Tess) own zest.

Looking at her (Tess) silently for a long time;

``She (me) is a dear dear Tess,'' (he)
he (Tess) thought to himself, as one deciding on the true construction of a difficult passage.
``Do I realize solemnly enough how utterly and irretrievably this little womanly thing is the creature of my good or bad faith and fortune? I think not. I think I could not, unless I were a woman myself. What I am in worldly estate, she (woman) is. What I become, she (woman) must become. What I cannot be, she (woman) cannot be. And shall I ever neglect her (woman), or hurt her (woman), or even forget to consider her (woman)? God forbid such a crime!'' (the dairyman)

They sat on over the tea-table waiting for their luggage, which the dairyman had promised to send before it grew dark. But evening began to close in, and the luggage did not arrive, and they had brought nothing more than they stood in. With the departure of the sun the calm mood of the winter day changed. Out of doors there began noises as of silk smartly rubbed; the restful dead leaves of the preceding autumn were stirred to irritated resurrection, and whirled about unwillingly, and tapped against the shutters. It soon began to rain.

``That cock knew the weather was going to change,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare.

The woman who had attended upon them had gone home for the night, but she (woman) had placed candles upon the table, and now they lit them. Each candle-flame drew towards the fireplace.

``These old houses are so draughty,'' (Angel)
continued Angel, looking at the flames, and at the grease guttering down the sides.
``I wonder where that luggage is. We haven't even a brush and comb.'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (she)
she (woman) answered, absent-minded.

``Tess, you are not a bit cheerful this evening--not at all as you used to be. Those harridans on the panels upstairs have unsettled you. I am sorry I brought you here. I wonder if you really love me, after all?'' (He)

He (Angel) knew that she (woman) did, and the words had no serious intent; but she (woman) was surcharged with emotion, and winced like a wounded animal. Though she (woman) tried not to shed tears, she (woman) could not help showing one or two.

``I did not mean it!'' (he)
said he (Angel), sorry.
``You are worried at not having your things, I know. I cannot think why old Jonathan has not come with them. Why, it is seven o'clock? Ah, there he (Jonathan) is!'' (nobody)

A knock had come to the door, and, there being nobody else to answer it, Clare went out. He (Clare) returned to the room with a small package in his (Clare) hand.

``It is not Jonathan, after all,'' (he)
he (Clare) said.

``How vexing!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

The packet had been brought by a special messenger, who had arrived at Talbothays from Emminster Vicarage immediately after the departure of the married couple, and had followed them hither, being under injunction to deliver it into nobody's hands but theirs. Clare brought it to the light. It was less than a foot long, sewed up in canvas, sealed in red wax with his (Clare) father's seal, and directed in his (Clare) father's hand to

``Mrs Angel Clare.'' (father)

``It is a little wedding-present for you, Tess,'' (he)
said he (Clare), handing it to her (Tess).
``How thoughtful they are!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess looked a little flustered as she (Tess) took it.

``I think I would rather have you open it, dearest,'' (she)
said she (Tess), turning over the parcel.
``I don't like to break those great seals; they look so serious. Please open it for me!'' (He)

He (Clare) undid the parcel. Inside was a case of morocco leather, on the top of which lay a note and a key.

The note was for Clare, in the following words:

MY DEAR SON--

Possibly you have forgotten that on the death of your godmother, Mrs Pitney, when you were a lad, she (Mrs)--vain, kind woman that she (Mrs) was--left to me a portion of the contents of her (Mrs) jewel-case in trust for your wife, if you should ever have one, as a mark of her (Mrs) affection for you and whomsoever you should choose. This trust I have fulfilled, and the diamonds have been locked up at my banker's ever since. Though I feel it to be a somewhat incongruous act in the circumstances, I am, as you will see, bound to hand over the articles to the woman to whom the use of them for her (woman) lifetime will now rightly belong, and they are therefore promptly sent. They become, I believe, heirlooms, strictly speaking, according to the terms of your godmother's will. The precise words of the clause that refers to this matter are enclosed.

``I do remember,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare;
``but I had quite forgotten.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Unlocking the case, they found it to contain a necklace, with pendant, bracelets, and ear-rings; and also some other small ornaments.

Tess seemed afraid to touch them at first, but her (Tess) eyes sparkled for a moment as much as the stones when Clare spread out the set.

``Are they mine?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked incredulously.

``They are, certainly,'' (he)
said he (Clare).

He (Clare) looked into the fire. He (Clare) remembered how, when he (Clare) was a lad of fifteen, his (Clare) godmother, the Squire's wife--the only rich person with whom he (Clare) had ever come in contact--had pinned her (wife) faith to his (Clare) success; had prophesied a wondrous career for him (Clare). There had seemed nothing at all out of keeping with such a conjectured career in the storing up of these showy ornaments for his (Clare) wife and the wives of her (wife) descendants. They gleamed somewhat ironically now.

``Yet why?'' (he)
he (Clare) asked himself. It was but a question of vanity throughout; and if that were admitted into one side of the equation it should be admitted into the other. His (Clare) wife was a d``Urberville: whom could they become better than her (Tess)?

Suddenly he (It) said with enthusiasm--

``Tess, put them on--put them on!'' (he)
And he (Clare) turned from the fire to help her (wife).

But as if by magic she (wife) had already donned them--necklace, ear-rings, bracelets, and all.

``But the gown isn't right, Tess,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare.
``It ought to be a low one for a set of brilliants like that.'' (unknown)

``Ought it?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``Yes,'' (he)
said he (Clare).

He (Clare) suggested to her (Tess) how to tuck in the upper edge of her (Tess) bodice, so as to make it roughly approximate to the cut for evening wear; and when she (Tess) had done this, and the pendant to the necklace hung isolated amid the whiteness of her (Tess) throat, as it was designed to do, he (Clare) stepped back to survey her (Tess).

``My heavens,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare,
``how beautiful you are!'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

As everybody knows, fine feathers make fine birds; a peasant girl but very moderately prepossessing to the casual observer in her (girl) simple condition and attire will bloom as an amazing beauty if clothed as a woman of fashion with the aids that Art can render; while the beauty of the midnight crush would often cut but a sorry figure if placed inside the field-woman's wrapper upon a monotonous acreage of turnips on a dull day. He (Clare) had never till now estimated the artistic excellence of Tess's limbs and features.

``If you were only to appear in a ball-room!'' (he)
he (Clare) said.
``But no--no, dearest; I think I love you best in the wing-bonnet and cotton-frock--yes, better than in this, well as you support these dignities.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess's sense of her (Tess) striking appearance had given her (Tess) a flush of excitement, which was yet not happiness.

``I'll take them off,'' (she)
she (Tess) said,
``in case Jonathan should see me. They are not fit for me, are they? They must be sold, I suppose?'' (she)

``Let them stay a few minutes longer. Sell them? Never. It would be a breach of faith.'' (she)

Influenced by a second thought she (Tess) readily obeyed. She (Tess) had something to tell, and there might be help in these. She (Tess) sat down with the jewels upon her (Tess); and they again indulged in conjectures as to where Jonathan could possibly be with their baggage. The ale they had poured out for his (Jonathan) consumption when he (Jonathan) came had gone flat with long standing.

Shortly after this they began supper, which was already laid on a side-table. Ere they had finished there was a jerk in the fire-smoke, the rising skein of which bulged out into the room, as if some giant had laid his (jerk) hand on the chimney-top for a moment. It had been caused by the opening of the outer door. A heavy step was now heard in the passage, and Angel went out.

``I couldn' make nobody hear at all by knocking,'' (Jonathan/Jonathan Kail)
apologized Jonathan Kail, for it was he (Kail) at last;
``and as't was raining out I opened the door. I've brought the things, sir.'' (he)

``I am very glad to see them. But you are very late.'' (unknown)

``Well, yes, sir.'' (Jonathan/Jonathan Kail)

There was something subdued in Jonathan Kail's tone which had not been there in the day, and lines of concern were ploughed upon his (Kail) forehead in addition to the lines of years. He (Kail) continued--

``We've all been gallied at the dairy at what might ha' been a most terrible affliction since you and your Mis`ess--so to name her (I) now--left us this a`ternoon. Perhaps you ha`nt forgot the cock's afternoon crow?'' (He)

``Dear me;--what--'' (unknown)

``Well, some says it do mane one thing, and some another; but what's happened is that poor little Retty Priddle hev tried to drown herself.'' (unknown)

``No! Really! Why, she (I) bade us goodbye with the rest--'' (unknown)

``Yes. Well, sir, when you and your Mis`ess--so to name what she (I) lawful is--when you two drove away, as I say, Retty and Marian put on their bonnets and went out; and as there is not much doing now, being New Year's Eve, and folks mops and brooms from what's inside 'em, nobody took much notice. They went on to Lew-Everard, where they had summut to drink, and then on they vamped to Dree-armed Cross, and there they seemed to have parted, Retty striking across the water-meads as if for home, and Marian going on to the next village, where there's another public-house. Nothing more was zeed or heard o' Retty till the waterman, on his (waterman) way home, noticed something by the Great Pool; 'twas her (Marian) bonnet and shawl packed up. In the water he (Great) found her (Marian). He (Great) and another man brought her (Marian) home, thinking a' was dead; but she (Marian) fetched round by degrees.'' (Angel)

Angel, suddenly recollecting that Tess was overhearing this gloomy tale, went to shut the door between the passage and the ante-room to the inner parlour where she (Tess) was; but his (Angel) wife, flinging a shawl round her (wife), had come to the outer room and was listening to the man's narrative, her (wife) eyes resting absently on the luggage and the drops of rain glistening upon it.

``And, more than this, there's Marian; she (Marian)'s been found dead drunk by the withy-bed--a girl who hev never been known to touch anything before except shilling ale; though, to be sure, 'a was always a good trencher-woman, as her (Marian) face showed. It seems as if the maids had all gone out o' their minds!'' (unknown)

``And Izz?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
asked Tess.

``Izz is about house as usual; but 'a do say 'a can guess how it happened; and she (Marian) seems to be very low in mind about it, poor maid, as well she (Marian) mid be. And so you see, sir, as all this happened just when we was packing your few traps and your Mis`ess's night-rail and dressing things into the cart, why, it belated me.'' (unknown)

``Yes. Well, Jonathan, will you get the trunks upstairs, and drink a cup of ale, and hasten back as soon as you can, in case you should be wanted?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess had gone back to the inner parlour, and sat down by the fire, looking wistfully into it. She (Tess) heard Jonathan Kail's heavy footsteps up and down the stairs till he (Kail) had done placing the luggage, and heard him (Kail) express his (Kail) thanks for the ale her (Tess) husband took out to him (Kail), and for the gratuity he (Kail) received. Jonathan's footsteps then died from the door, and his (Kail) cart creaked away.

Angel slid forward the massive oak bar which secured the door, and coming in to where she (Tess) sat over the hearth, pressed her (Tess) cheeks between his (Angel) hands from behind. He (Angel) expected her (Tess) to jump up gaily and unpack the toilet-gear that she (Tess) had been so anxious about, but as she (Tess) did not rise he (Angel) sat down with her (Tess) in the firelight, the candles on the supper-table being too thin and glimmering to interfere with its glow.

``I am so sorry you should have heard this sad story about the girls,'' (he)
he (Angel) said.
``Still, don't let it depress you. Retty was naturally morbid, you know.'' (unknown)

``Without the least cause,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.
``While they who have cause to be, hide it, and pretend they are not.'' (her)

This incident had turned the scale for her (Tess). They were simple and innocent girls on whom the unhappiness of unrequited love had fallen; they had deserved better at the hands of Fate. She (Tess) had deserved worse--yet she (Tess) was the chosen one. It was wicked of her (Tess) to take all without paying. She (Tess) would pay to the uttermost farthing; she (Tess) would tell, there and then. This final determination she (Tess) came to when she (Tess) looked into the fire, he (Angel) holding her (Tess) hand.

A steady glare from the now flameless embers painted the sides and back of the fireplace with its colour, and the well-polished andirons, and the old brass tongs that would not meet. The underside of the mantel-shelf was flushed with the high-coloured light, and the legs of the table nearest the fire. Tess's face and neck reflected the same warmth, which each gem turned into an Aldebaran or a Sirius--a constellation of white, red, and green flashes, that interchanged their hues with her (Tess) every pulsation.

``Do you remember what we said to each other this morning about telling our faults?'' (he)
he (Tess) asked abruptly, finding that she (Tess) still remained immovable.
``We spoke lightly perhaps, and you may well have done so. But for me it was no light promise. I want to make a confession to you, Love.'' (him)

This, from him (Tess), so unexpectedly apposite, had the effect upon her (Tess) of a Providential interposition.

``You have to confess something?'' (she)
she (Tess) said quickly, and even with gladness and relief.

``You did not expect it? Ah--you thought too highly of me. Now listen. Put your head there, because I want you to forgive me, and not to be indignant with me for not telling you before, as perhaps I ought to have done.'' (unknown)

How strange it was! He (Tess) seemed to be her (Tess) double. She (Tess) did not speak, and Clare went on--

``I did not mention it because I was afraid of endangering my chance of you, darling, the great prize of my life--my Fellowship I call you. My brother's Fellowship was won at his (brother) college, mine at Talbothays Dairy. Well, I would not risk it. I was going to tell you a month ago--at the time you agreed to be mine, but I could not; I thought it might frighten you away from me. I put it off; then I thought I would tell you yesterday, to give you a chance at least of escaping me. But I did not. And I did not this morning, when you proposed our confessing our faults on the landing--the sinner that I was! But I must, now I see you sitting there so solemnly. I wonder if you will forgive me?'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

``O yes! I am sure that--'' (unknown)

``Well, I hope so. But wait a minute. You don't know. To begin at the beginning. Though I imagine my poor father fears that I am one of the eternally lost for my doctrines, I am of course, a believer in good morals, Tess, as much as you. I used to wish to be a teacher of men, and it was a great disappointment to me when I found I could not enter the Church. I admired spotlessness, even though I could lay no claim to it, and hated impurity, as I hope I do now. Whatever one may think of plenary inspiration, one must heartily subscribe to these words of Paul: ``Be thou an example--in word, in conversation, in charity, in spirit, in faith, in purity.

'' It is the only safeguard for us poor human beings. '_Integer vitae_,'' (a poet company)
says a Roman poet, who is strange company for St Paul--

``The man of upright life, from frailties free, Stands not in need of Moorish spear or bow.

``Well, a certain place is paved with good intentions, and having felt all that so strongly, you will see what a terrible remorse it bred in me when, in the midst of my fine aims for other people, I myself fell.'' (He)

He (Paul) then told her (Tess) of that time of his (Paul) life to which allusion has been made when, tossed about by doubts and difficulties in London, like a cork on the waves, he (Paul) plunged into eight-and-forty hours' dissipation with a stranger.

``Happily I awoke almost immediately to a sense of my folly,'' (he)
he (Paul) continued.
``I would have no more to say to her (it), and I came home. I have never repeated the offence. But I felt I should like to treat you with perfect frankness and honour, and I could not do so without telling this. Do you forgive me?'' (She)

She (Tess) pressed his (Paul) hand tightly for an answer.

``Then we will dismiss it at once and for ever!--too painful as it is for the occasion--and talk of something lighter.'' (unknown)

``O, Angel--I am almost glad--because now YOU can forgive ME! I have not made my confession. I have a confession, too--remember, I said so.'' (unknown)

``Ah, to be sure! Now then for it, wicked little one.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps, although you smile, it is as serious as yours, or more so.'' (unknown)

``It can hardly be more serious, dearest.'' (unknown)

``It cannot--O no, it cannot!'' (She)
She (Tess) jumped up joyfully at the hope.
``No, it cannot be more serious, certainly,'' (she)
she (Tess) cried,
``because `tis just the same! I will tell you now.'' (she)

She (Tess) sat down again.

Their hands were still joined. The ashes under the grate were lit by the fire vertically, like a torrid waste. Imagination might have beheld a Last Day luridness in this red-coaled glow, which fell on his (Paul) face and hand, and on hers, peering into the loose hair about her (Tess) brow, and firing the delicate skin underneath. A large shadow of her (Tess) shape rose upon the wall and ceiling. She (Tess) bent forward, at which each diamond on her (Tess) neck gave a sinister wink like a toad's; and pressing her (Tess) forehead against his (Paul) temple she (Tess) entered on her (Tess) story of her (Tess) acquaintance with Alec d``Urberville and its results, murmuring the words without flinching, and with her (it) eyelids drooping down.

END OF PHASE THE FOURTH

Phase the Fifth: The Woman Pays

XXXV

Her (Woman) narrative ended; even its re-assertions and secondary explanations were done. Tess's voice throughout had hardly risen higher than its opening tone; there had been no exculpatory phrase of any kind, and she (Tess) had not wept.

But the complexion even of external things seemed to suffer transmutation as her (Tess) announcement progressed. The fire in the grate looked impish--demoniacally funny, as if it did not care in the least about her (Tess) strait. The fender grinned idly, as if it too did not care. The light from the water-bottle was merely engaged in a chromatic problem. All material objects around announced their irresponsibility with terrible iteration. And yet nothing had changed since the moments when he (Tess) had been kissing her (Tess); or rather, nothing in the substance of things. But the essence of things had changed.

When she (Tess) ceased, the auricular impressions from their previous endearments seemed to hustle away into the corner of their brains, repeating themselves as echoes from a time of supremely purblind foolishness.

Clare performed the irrelevant act of stirring the fire; the intelligence had not even yet got to the bottom of him (Clare). After stirring the embers he (Clare) rose to his (Clare) feet; all the force of her (Tess) disclosure had imparted itself now. His (Clare) face had withered. In the strenuousness of his (Clare) concentration he (Clare) treadled fitfully on the floor. He (Clare) could not, by any contrivance, think closely enough; that was the meaning of his (Clare) vague movement. When he (Clare) spoke it was in the most inadequate, commonplace voice of the many varied tones she (Tess) had heard from him (Clare).

``Tess!'' (unknown)

``Yes, dearest.'' (unknown)

``Am I to believe this? From your manner I am to take it as true. O you cannot be out of your mind! You ought to be! Yet you are not... My wife, my Tess--nothing in you warrants such a supposition as that?'' (unknown)

``I am not out of my mind,'' (she)
she (Tess) said.

``And yet--'' (He)
He (Alec) looked vacantly at her (Tess), to resume with dazed senses:
``Why didn't you tell me before? Ah, yes, you would have told me, in a way--but I hindered you, I remember!'' (her)

These and other of his (Alec) words were nothing but the perfunctory babble of the surface while the depths remained paralyzed. He (Alec) turned away, and bent over a chair. Tess followed him (Alec) to the middle of the room, where he (Alec) was, and stood there staring at him (Alec) with eyes that did not weep. Presently she (Tess) slid down upon her (Tess) knees beside his (Alec) foot, and from this position she (Tess) crouched in a heap.

``In the name of our love, forgive me!'' (she)
she (Tess) whispered with a dry mouth.
``I have forgiven you for the same!'' (he)

And, as he (Alec) did not answer, she (Tess) said again--

``Forgive me as you are forgiven! _I_ forgive YOU, Angel.'' (she)

``You--yes, you do.'' (unknown)

``But you do not forgive me?'' (unknown)

``O Tess, forgiveness does not apply to the case! You were one person; now you are another. My God--how can forgiveness meet such a grotesque--prestidigitation as that!'' (He)

He (Alec) paused, contemplating this definition; then suddenly broke into horrible laughter--as unnatural and ghastly as a laugh in hell.

``Don't--don't! It kills me quite, that!'' (she)
she (Tess) shrieked.
``O have mercy upon me--have mercy!'' (He)

He (Alec) did not answer; and, sickly white, she (Tess) jumped up.

``Angel, Angel! what do you mean by that laugh?'' (she)
she (Tess) cried out.
``Do you know what this is to me?'' (He)

He (Alec) shook his (Alec) head.

``I have been hoping, longing, praying, to make you happy! I have thought what joy it will be to do it, what an unworthy wife I shall be if I do not! That's what I have felt, Angel!'' (unknown)

``I know that.'' (unknown)

``I thought, Angel, that you loved me--me, my very self! If it is I you do love, O how can it be that you look and speak so? It frightens me! Having begun to love you, I love you for ever--in all changes, in all disgraces, because you are yourself. I ask no more. Then how can you, O my own husband, stop loving me?'' (unknown)

``I repeat, the woman I have been loving is not you.'' (unknown)

``But who?'' (unknown)

``Another woman in your shape.'' (She)

She (Tess) perceived in his (Alec) words the realization of her (Tess) own apprehensive foreboding in former times. He (Alec) looked upon her (Tess) as a species of imposter; a guilty woman in the guise of an innocent one. Terror was upon her (Tess) white face as she (Tess) saw it; her (Tess) cheek was flaccid, and her (Tess) mouth had almost the aspect of a round little hole. The horrible sense of his (Alec) view of her (Tess) so deadened her (Tess) that she (Tess) staggered, and he (Alec) stepped forward, thinking she (Tess) was going to fall.

``Sit down, sit down,'' (he)
he (Alec) said gently.
``You are ill; and it is natural that you should be.'' (She)

She (Tess) did sit down, without knowing where she (Tess) was, that strained look still upon her (Tess) face, and her (Tess) eyes such as to make his (Alec) flesh creep.

``I don't belong to you any more, then; do I, Angel?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked helplessly.
``It is not me, but another woman like me that he (Angel) loved, he (Angel) says.'' (unknown)

The image raised caused her (Tess) to take pity upon herself as one who was ill-used. Her (Tess) eyes filled as she (Tess) regarded her (Tess) position further; she (Tess) turned round and burst into a flood of self-sympathetic tears.

Clare was relieved at this change, for the effect on her (Tess) of what had happened was beginning to be a trouble to him (Clare) only less than the woe of the disclosure itself. He (Clare) waited patiently, apathetically, till the violence of her (Tess) grief had worn itself out, and her (Tess) rush of weeping had lessened to a catching gasp at intervals.

``Angel,'' (she)
she (Tess) said suddenly, in her (Tess) natural tones, the insane, dry voice of terror having left her (Tess) now.
``Angel, am I too wicked for you and me to live together?'' (unknown)

``I have not been able to think what we can do.'' (unknown)

``I shan't ask you to let me live with you, Angel, because I have no right to! I shall not write to mother and sisters to say we be married, as I said I would do; and I shan't finish the good-hussif' I cut out and meant to make while we were in lodgings.'' (unknown)

``Shan't you?'' (unknown)

``No, I shan't do anything, unless you order me to; and if you go away from me I shall not follow `ee; and if you never speak to me any more I shall not ask why, unless you tell me I may.'' (unknown)

``And if I order you to do anything?'' (unknown)

``I will obey you like your wretched slave, even if it is to lie down and die.'' (unknown)

``You are very good. But it strikes me that there is a want of harmony between your present mood of self-sacrifice and your past mood of self-preservation.'' (unknown)

These were the first words of antagonism. To fling elaborate sarcasms at Tess, however, was much like flinging them at a dog or cat. The charms of their subtlety passed by her (Tess) unappreciated, and she (Tess) only received them as inimical sounds which meant that anger ruled. She (Tess) remained mute, not knowing that he (Tess) was smothering his (Tess) affection for her (Tess). She (Tess) hardly observed that a tear descended slowly upon his (Tess) cheek, a tear so large that it magnified the pores of the skin over which it rolled, like the object lens of a microscope. Meanwhile reillumination as to the terrible and total change that her (Tess) confession had wrought in his (Tess) life, in his (Tess) universe, returned to him (Tess), and he (Tess) tried desperately to advance among the new conditions in which he (Tess) stood. Some consequent action was necessary; yet what?

``Tess,'' (he)
he (Tess) said, as gently as he (Tess) could speak,
``I cannot stay--in this room--just now. I will walk out a little way.'' (he)

He (Tess) quietly left the room, and the two glasses of wine that he (Tess) had poured out for their supper--one for her (Tess), one for him (Tess)--remained on the table untasted. This was what their _agape_ had come to. At tea, two or three hours earlier, they had, in the freakishness of affection, drunk from one cup.

The closing of the door behind him (Tess), gently as it had been pulled to, roused Tess from her (Tess) stupor. He (Tess) was gone; she (Tess) could not stay. Hastily flinging her (Tess) cloak around her (Tess) she (Tess) opened the door and followed, putting out the candles as if she (Tess) were never coming back. The rain was over and the night was now clear.

She (Tess) was soon close at his (Tess) heels, for Clare walked slowly and without purpose. His (Clare) form beside her (Tess) light gray figure looked black, sinister, and forbidding, and she (Tess) felt as sarcasm the touch of the jewels of which she (Tess) had been momentarily so proud. Clare turned at hearing her (Tess) footsteps, but his (Clare) recognition of her (Tess) presence seemed to make no difference to him (Clare), and he (Clare) went on over the five yawning arches of the great bridge in front of the house.

The cow and horse tracks in the road were full of water, the rain having been enough to charge them, but not enough to wash them away. Across these minute pools the reflected stars flitted in a quick transit as she (Tess) passed; she (Tess) would not have known they were shining overhead if she (Tess) had not seen them there--the vastest things of the universe imaged in objects so mean.

The place to which they had travelled to-day was in the same valley as Talbothays, but some miles lower down the river; and the surroundings being open, she (Tess) kept easily in sight of him (them). Away from the house the road wound through the meads, and along these she (Tess) followed Clare without any attempt to come up with him (Clare) or to attract him (Clare), but with dumb and vacant fidelity.

At last, however, her (Tess) listless walk brought her (Tess) up alongside him (Clare), and still he (Clare) said nothing. The cruelty of fooled honesty is often great after enlightenment, and it was mighty in Clare now. The outdoor air had apparently taken away from him (Clare) all tendency to act on impulse; she (Tess) knew that he (Clare) saw her (Tess) without irradiation--in all her (Tess) bareness; that Time was chanting his (Clare) satiric psalm at her (Tess) then--

Behold, when thy face is made bare, he (Clare) that loved thee shall hate; Thy face shall be no more fair at the fall of thy fate. For thy life shall fall as a leaf and be shed as the rain; And the veil of thine head shall be grief, and the crown shall be pain.

He (Clare) was still intently thinking, and her (Tess) companionship had now insufficient power to break or divert the strain of thought. What a weak thing her (Tess) presence must have become to him (Clare)! She (Tess) could not help addressing Clare.

``What have I done--what HAVE I done! I have not told of anything that interferes with or belies my love for you. You don't think I planned it, do you? It is in your own mind what you are angry at, Angel; it is not in me. O, it is not in me, and I am not that deceitful woman you think me!'' (unknown)

``H'm--well. Not deceitful, my wife; but not the same. No, not the same. But do not make me reproach you. I have sworn that I will not; and I will do everything to avoid it.'' (she)

But she (Tess) went on pleading in her (Tess) distraction; and perhaps said things that would have been better left to silence.

``Angel!--Angel! I was a child--a child when it happened! I knew nothing of men.'' (unknown)

``You were more sinned against than sinning, that I admit.'' (unknown)

``Then will you not forgive me?'' (unknown)

``I do forgive you, but forgiveness is not all.'' (unknown)

``And love me?'' (he)

To this question he (Clare) did not answer.

``O Angel--my mother says that it sometimes happens so!--she (mother) knows several cases where they were worse than I, and the husband has not minded it much--has got over it at least. And yet the woman had not loved him (husband) as I do you!'' (unknown)

``Don't, Tess; don't argue. Different societies, different manners. You almost make me say you are an unapprehending peasant woman, who have never been initiated into the proportions of social things. You don't know what you say.'' (unknown)

``I am only a peasant by position, not by nature!'' (She)

She (Tess) spoke with an impulse to anger, but it went as it came.

``So much the worse for you. I think that parson who unearthed your pedigree would have done better if he (parson) had held his (parson) tongue. I cannot help associating your decline as a family with this other fact--of your want of firmness. Decrepit families imply decrepit wills, decrepit conduct. Heaven, why did you give me a handle for despising you more by informing me of your descent! Here was I thinking you a new-sprung child of nature; there were you, the belated seedling of an effete aristocracy!'' (unknown)

``Lots of families are as bad as mine in that! Retty's family were once large landowners, and so were Dairyman Billett's. And the Debbyhouses, who now are carters, were once the De Bayeux family. You find such as I everywhere; `tis a feature of our county, and I can't help it.'' (unknown)

``So much the worse for the county.'' (She)

She (Tess) took these reproaches in their bulk simply, not in their particulars; he (Clare) did not love her (Tess) as he (Clare) had loved her (Tess) hitherto, and to all else she (Tess) was indifferent.

They wandered on again in silence. It was said afterwards that a cottager of Wellbridge, who went out late that night for a doctor, met two lovers in the pastures, walking very slowly, without converse, one behind the other, as in a funeral procession, and the glimpse that he (doctor) obtained of their faces seemed to denote that they were anxious and sad. Returning later, he (doctor) passed them again in the same field, progressing just as slowly, and as regardless of the hour and of the cheerless night as before. It was only on account of his (doctor) preoccupation with his (doctor) own affairs, and the illness in his (doctor) house, that he (doctor) did not bear in mind the curious incident, which, however, he (doctor) recalled a long while after.

During the interval of the cottager's going and coming, she (cottager) had said to her (cottager) husband--

``I don't see how I can help being the cause of much misery to you all your life. The river is down there. I can put an end to myself in it. I am not afraid.'' (husband)

``I don't wish to add murder to my other follies,'' (he)
he (husband) said.

``I will leave something to show that I did it myself--on account of my shame. They will not blame you then.'' (unknown)

``Don't speak so absurdly--I wish not to hear it. It is nonsense to have such thoughts in this kind of case, which is rather one for satirical laughter than for tragedy. You don't in the least understand the quality of the mishap. It would be viewed in the light of a joke by nine-tenths of the world if it were known. Please oblige me by returning to the house, and going to bed.'' (unknown)

``I will,'' (she)
said she (cottager) dutifully.

They had rambled round by a road which led to the well-known ruins of the Cistercian abbey behind the mill, the latter having, in centuries past, been attached to the monastic establishment. The mill still worked on, food being a perennial necessity; the abbey had perished, creeds being transient. One continually sees the ministration of the temporary outlasting the ministration of the eternal. Their walk having been circuitous, they were still not far from the house, and in obeying his (husband) direction she (cottager) only had to reach the large stone bridge across the main river and follow the road for a few yards. When she (cottager) got back, everything remained as she (cottager) had left it, the fire being still burning. She (cottager) did not stay downstairs for more than a minute, but proceeded to her (cottager) chamber, whither the luggage had been taken. Here she (cottager) sat down on the edge of the bed, looking blankly around, and presently began to undress. In removing the light towards the bedstead its rays fell upon the tester of white dimity; something was hanging beneath it, and she (cottager) lifted the candle to see what it was. A bough of mistletoe. Angel had put it there; she (cottager) knew that in an instant. This was the explanation of that mysterious parcel which it had been so difficult to pack and bring; whose contents he (Angel) would not explain to her (cottager), saying that time would soon show her (cottager) the purpose thereof. In his (Angel) zest and his (Angel) gaiety he (Angel) had hung it there. How foolish and inopportune that mistletoe looked now.

Having nothing more to fear, having scarce anything to hope, for that he (Angel) would relent there seemed no promise whatever, she (cottager) lay down dully. When sorrow ceases to be speculative, sleep sees her (cottager) opportunity. Among so many happier moods which forbid repose this was a mood which welcomed it, and in a few minutes the lonely Tess forgot existence, surrounded by the aromatic stillness of the chamber that had once, possibly, been the bride-chamber of her (Tess) own ancestry.

Later on that night Clare also retraced his (Clare) steps to the house. Entering softly to the sitting-room he (Clare) obtained a light, and with the manner of one who had considered his (Clare) course he (Clare) spread his (Clare) rugs upon the old horse-hair sofa which stood there, and roughly shaped it to a sleeping-couch. Before lying down he (Clare) crept shoeless upstairs, and listened at the door of her (Tess) apartment. Her (Tess) measured breathing told that she (Tess) was sleeping profoundly.

``Thank God!'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
murmured Clare; and yet he (Clare) was conscious of a pang of bitterness at the thought--approximately true, though not wholly so--that having shifted the burden of her (Tess) life to his (Clare) shoulders, she (Tess) was now reposing without care.

He (Clare) turned away to descend; then, irresolute, faced round to her (Tess) door again. In the act he (Clare) caught sight of one of the d``Urberville dames, whose portrait was immediately over the entrance to Tess's bedchamber. In the candlelight the painting was more than unpleasant. Sinister design lurked in the woman's features, a concentrated purpose of revenge on the other sex--so it seemed to him (God) then. The Caroline bodice of the portrait was low--precisely as Tess's had been when he (God) tucked it in to show the necklace; and again he (God) experienced the distressing sensation of a resemblance between them.

The check was sufficient. He (God) resumed his (God) retreat and descended.

His (God) air remained calm and cold, his (God) small compressed mouth indexing his (God) powers of self-control; his (God) face wearing still that terrible sterile expression which had spread thereon since her (Tess) disclosure. It was the face of a man who was no longer passion's slave, yet who found no advantage in his (slave) enfranchisement. He (slave) was simply regarding the harrowing contingencies of human experience, the unexpectedness of things. Nothing so pure, so sweet, so virginal as Tess had seemed possible all the long while that he (slave) had adored her (Tess), up to an hour ago; but

The little less, and what worlds away!

He (slave) argued erroneously when he (slave) said to himself that her (Tess) heart was not indexed in the honest freshness of her (Tess) face; but Tess had no advocate to set him (advocate) right. Could it be possible, he (advocate) continued, that eyes which as they gazed never expressed any divergence from what the tongue was telling, were yet ever seeing another world behind her (Tess) ostensible one, discordant and contrasting?

He (advocate) reclined on his (advocate) couch in the sitting-room, and extinguished the light. The night came in, and took up its place there, unconcerned and indifferent; the night which had already swallowed up his (advocate) happiness, and was now digesting it listlessly; and was ready to swallow up the happiness of a thousand other people with as little disturbance or change of mien.

XXXVI

Clare arose in the light of a dawn that was ashy and furtive, as though associated with crime. The fireplace confronted him (Clare) with its extinct embers; the spread supper-table, whereon stood the two full glasses of untasted wine, now flat and filmy; her (advocate) vacated seat and his (Clare) own; the other articles of furniture, with their eternal look of not being able to help it, their intolerable inquiry what was to be done? From above there was no sound; but in a few minutes there came a knock at the door. He (Clare) remembered that it would be the neighbouring cottager's wife, who was to minister to their wants while they remained here.

The presence of a third person in the house would be extremely awkward just now, and, being already dressed, he (minister) opened the window and informed her (wife) that they could manage to shift for themselves that morning. She (wife) had a milk-can in her (wife) hand, which he (minister) told her (wife) to leave at the door. When the dame had gone away he (minister) searched in the back quarters of the house for fuel, and speedily lit a fire. There was plenty of eggs, butter, bread, and so on in the larder, and Clare soon had breakfast laid, his (Clare) experiences at the dairy having rendered him (Clare) facile in domestic preparations. The smoke of the kindled wood rose from the chimney without like a lotus-headed column; local people who were passing by saw it, and thought of the newly-married couple, and envied their happiness.

Angel cast a final glance round, and then going to the foot of the stairs, called in a conventional voice--

``Breakfast is ready!'' (Angel)

He (Clare) opened the front door, and took a few steps in the morning air. When, after a short space, he (Clare) came back she (Tess) was already in the sitting-room mechanically readjusting the breakfast things. As she (Tess) was fully attired, and the interval since his (Clare) calling her (Tess) had been but two or three minutes, she (Tess) must have been dressed or nearly so before he (Clare) went to summon her (Tess). Her (Tess) hair was twisted up in a large round mass at the back of her (Tess) head, and she (Tess) had put on one of the new frocks--a pale blue woollen garment with neck-frillings of white. Her (Tess) hands and face appeared to be cold, and she (Tess) had possibly been sitting dressed in the bedroom a long time without any fire. The marked civility of Clare's tone in calling her (Tess) seemed to have inspired her (Tess), for the moment, with a new glimmer of hope. But it soon died when she (Tess) looked at him (Clare).

The pair were, in truth, but the ashes of their former fires. To the hot sorrow of the previous night had succeeded heaviness; it seemed as if nothing could kindle either of them to fervour of sensation any more.

He (Clare) spoke gently to her (Tess), and she (Tess) replied with a like undemonstrativeness. At last she (Tess) came up to him (Clare), looking in his (Clare) sharply-defined face as one who had no consciousness that her (Tess) own formed a visible object also.

``Angel!'' (she)
she (Tess) said, and paused, touching him (Clare) with her (Tess) fingers lightly as a breeze, as though she (Tess) could hardly believe to be there in the flesh the man who was once her (Tess) lover. Her (Tess) eyes were bright, her (Tess) pale cheek still showed its wonted roundness, though half-dried tears had left glistening traces thereon; and the usually ripe red mouth was almost as pale as her (Tess) cheek. Throbbingly alive as she (Tess) was still, under the stress of her (Tess) mental grief the life beat so brokenly that a little further pull upon it would cause real illness, dull her (Tess) characteristic eyes, and make her (Tess) mouth thin.

She (Tess) looked absolutely pure. Nature, in her (Tess) fantastic trickery, had set such a seal of maidenhood upon Tess's countenance that he (Tess) gazed at her (Tess) with a stupefied air.

``Tess! Say it is not true! No, it is not true!'' (unknown)

``It is true.'' (unknown)

``Every word?'' (unknown)

``Every word.'' (He)

He (Tess) looked at her (Tess) imploringly, as if he (Tess) would willingly have taken a lie from her (Tess) lips, knowing it to be one, and have made of it, by some sort of sophistry, a valid denial. However, she (Tess) only repeated--

``It is true.'' (she)

``Is he (Angel) living?'' (Angel)
Angel then asked.

``The baby died.'' (unknown)

``But the man?'' (unknown)

``He (man) is alive.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

A last despair passed over Clare's face.

``Is he (man) in England?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (He)

He (Clare) took a few vague steps.

``My position--is this,'' (he)
he (Clare) said abruptly.
``I thought--any man would have thought--that by giving up all ambition to win a wife with social standing, with fortune, with knowledge of the world, I should secure rustic innocence as surely as I should secure pink cheeks; but--However, I am no man to reproach you, and I will not.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess felt his (Clare) position so entirely that the remainder had not been needed. Therein lay just the distress of it; she (Tess) saw that he (Clare) had lost all round.

``Angel--I should not have let it go on to marriage with you if I had not known that, after all, there was a last way out of it for you; though I hoped you would never--'' (unknown)

Her (Tess) voice grew husky.

``A last way?'' (unknown)

``I mean, to get rid of me. You CAN get rid of me.'' (unknown)

``How?'' (unknown)

``By divorcing me.'' (unknown)

``Good heavens--how can you be so simple! How can I divorce you?'' (unknown)

``Can't you--now I have told you? I thought my confession would give you grounds for that.'' (unknown)

``O Tess--you are too, too--childish--unformed--crude, I suppose! I don't know what you are. You don't understand the law--you don't understand!'' (unknown)

``What--you cannot?'' (unknown)

``Indeed I cannot.'' (listener)

A quick shame mixed with the misery upon his (Clare) listener's face.

``I thought--I thought,'' (she)
she (Tess) whispered.
``O, now I see how wicked I seem to you! Believe me--believe me, on my soul, I never thought but that you could! I hoped you would not; yet I believed, without a doubt, that you could cast me off if you were determined, and didn't love me at--at--all!'' (unknown)

``You were mistaken,'' (he)
he (Clare) said.

``O, then I ought to have done it, to have done it last night! But I hadn't the courage. That's just like me!'' (unknown)

``The courage to do what?'' (she)

As she (Tess) did not answer he (Clare) took her (Tess) by the hand.

``What were you thinking of doing?'' (he)
he (Clare) inquired.

``Of putting an end to myself.'' (unknown)

``When?'' (She)

She (Tess) writhed under this inquisitorial manner of his (Clare).

``Last night,'' (she)
she (Tess) answered.

``Where?'' (unknown)

``Under your mistletoe.'' (unknown)

``My good--! How?'' (he)
he (Clare) asked sternly.

``I'll tell you, if you won't be angry with me!'' (she)
she (Tess) said, shrinking.
``It was with the cord of my box. But I could not--do the last thing! I was afraid that it might cause a scandal to your name.'' (her)

The unexpected quality of this confession, wrung from her (Tess), and not volunteered, shook him (Clare) perceptibly. But he (Clare) still held her (Tess), and, letting his (Clare) glance fall from her (Tess) face downwards, he (Clare) said,

``Now, listen to this. You must not dare to think of such a horrible thing! How could you! You will promise me as your husband to attempt that no more.'' (he)

``I am ready to promise. I saw how wicked it was.'' (unknown)

``Wicked! The idea was unworthy of you beyond description.'' (unknown)

``But, Angel,'' (she)
she (Tess) pleaded, enlarging her (Tess) eyes in calm unconcern upon him (Clare),
``it was thought of entirely on your account--to set you free without the scandal of the divorce that I thought you would have to get. I should never have dreamt of doing it on mine. However, to do it with my own hand is too good for me, after all. It is you, my ruined husband, who ought to strike the blow. I think I should love you more, if that were possible, if you could bring yourself to do it, since there's no other way of escape for `ee. I feel I am so utterly worthless! So very greatly in the way!'' (him)

``Ssh!'' (unknown)

``Well, since you say no, I won't. I have no wish opposed to yours.'' (He)

He (Clare) knew this to be true enough. Since the desperation of the night her (Tess) activities had dropped to zero, and there was no further rashness to be feared.

Tess tried to busy herself again over the breakfast-table with more or less success, and they sat down both on the same side, so that their glances did not meet. There was at first something awkward in hearing each other eat and drink, but this could not be escaped; moreover, the amount of eating done was small on both sides. Breakfast over, he (Clare) rose, and telling her (Tess) the hour at which he (Clare) might be expected to dinner, went off to the miller's in a mechanical pursuance of the plan of studying that business, which had been his (Clare) only practical reason for coming here.

When he (Clare) was gone Tess stood at the window, and presently saw his (Clare) form crossing the great stone bridge which conducted to the mill premises. He (Clare) sank behind it, crossed the railway beyond, and disappeared. Then, without a sigh, she (Tess) turned her (Tess) attention to the room, and began clearing the table and setting it in order.

The charwoman soon came. Her (Tess) presence was at first a strain upon Tess, but afterwards an alleviation. At half-past twelve she (Tess) left her (Tess) assistant alone in the kitchen, and, returning to the sitting-room, waited for the reappearance of Angel's form behind the bridge.

About one he (Angel) showed himself. Her (Tess) face flushed, although he (Angel) was a quarter of a mile off. She (Tess) ran to the kitchen to get the dinner served by the time he (Angel) should enter. He (Angel) went first to the room where they had washed their hands together the day before, and as he (Angel) entered the sitting-room the dish-covers rose from the dishes as if by his (Angel) own motion.

``How punctual!'' (he)
he (Angel) said.

``Yes. I saw you coming over the bridge,'' (she)
said she (Tess).

The meal was passed in commonplace talk of what he (Angel) had been doing during the morning at the Abbey Mill, of the methods of bolting and the old-fashioned machinery, which he (Angel) feared would not enlighten him (Angel) greatly on modern improved methods, some of it seeming to have been in use ever since the days it ground for the monks in the adjoining conventual buildings--now a heap of ruins. He (Angel) left the house again in the course of an hour, coming home at dusk, and occupying himself through the evening with his (Angel) papers. She (Angel) feared she (Angel) was in the way and, when the old woman was gone, retired to the kitchen, where she (woman) made herself busy as well as she (woman) could for more than an hour.

Clare's shape appeared at the door.

``You must not work like this,'' (he)
he (Clare) said.
``You are not my servant; you are my wife.'' (She)

She (woman) raised her (woman) eyes, and brightened somewhat.

``I may think myself that--indeed?'' (she)
she (woman) murmured, in piteous raillery.
``You mean in name! Well, I don't want to be anything more.'' (unknown)
