There was not much time, however, for thought or elusion, and she (Tess) yielded as calmly as she (Tess) could to the necessity of letting him (Tess) overtake her (Tess). She (Tess) saw that he (Tess) was excited, less by the speed of his (Tess) walk than by the feelings within him (Tess).

``Tess!'' (he)
he (Alec) said.

She (Tess) slackened speed without looking round.

``Tess!'' (he)
he (Alec) repeated.
``It is I--Alec d'Urberville.'' (She)

She (Tess) then looked back at him (Alec), and he (Alec) came up.

``I see it is,'' (she)
she (Tess) answered coldly.

``Well--is that all? Yet I deserve no more! Of course,'' (he)
he (Alec) added, with a slight laugh,
``there is something of the ridiculous to your eyes in seeing me like this. But--I must put up with that. ... I heard you had gone away; nobody knew where. Tess, you wonder why I have followed you?'' (he)

``I do, rather; and I would that you had not, with all my heart!'' (unknown)

``Yes--you may well say it,'' (he)
he (Alec) returned grimly, as they moved onward together, she (Tess) with unwilling tread.
``But don't mistake me; I beg this because you may have been led to do so in noticing--if you did notice it--how your sudden appearance unnerved me down there. It was but a momentary faltering; and considering what you have been to me, it was natural enough. But will helped me through it--though perhaps you think me a humbug for saying it--and immediately afterwards I felt that of all persons in the world whom it was my duty and desire to save from the wrath to come--sneer if you like--the woman whom I had so grievously wronged was that person. I have come with that sole purpose in view--nothing more.'' (unknown)

There was the smallest vein of scorn in her (Tess) words of rejoinder:

``Have you saved yourself? Charity begins at home, they say.'' (unknown)

''_I_ have done nothing!'' (he)
said he (Alec) indifferently. ``Heaven, as I have been telling my hearers, has done all. No amount of contempt that you can pour upon me, Tess, will equal what I have poured upon myself--the old Adam of my former years! Well, it is a strange story; believe it or not; but I can tell you the means by which my conversion was brought about, and I hope you will be interested enough at least to listen. Have you ever heard the name of the parson of Emminster--you must have done do?--old Mr Clare; one of the most earnest of his (Clare) school; one of the few intense men left in the Church; not so intense as the extreme wing of Christian believers with which I have thrown in my lot, but quite an exception among the Established clergy, the younger of whom are gradually attenuating the true doctrines by their sophistries, till they are but the shadow of what they were. I only differ from him (Christian) on the question of Church and State--the interpretation of the text,
``Come out from among them and be ye separate, saith the Lord'--that's all. He (Lord) is one who, I firmly believe, has been the humble means of saving more souls in this country than any other man you can name. You have heard of him (man)?'' (unknown)

``I have,'' (she)
she (Tess) said.

``He (man) came to Trantridge two or three years ago to preach on behalf of some missionary society; and I, wretched fellow that I was, insulted him (fellow) when, in his (fellow) disinterestedness, he (fellow) tried to reason with me and show me the way. He (fellow) did not resent my conduct, he (fellow) simply said that some day I should receive the first-fruits of the Spirit--that those who came to scoff sometimes remained to pray. There was a strange magic in his (fellow) words. They sank into my mind. But the loss of my mother hit me most; and by degrees I was brought to see daylight. Since then my one desire has been to hand on the true view to others, and that is what I was trying to do to-day; though it is only lately that I have preached hereabout. The first months of my ministry have been spent in the North of England among strangers, where I preferred to make my earliest clumsy attempts, so as to acquire courage before undergoing that severest of all tests of one's sincerity, addressing those who have known one, and have been one's companions in the days of darkness. If you could only know, Tess, the pleasure of having a good slap at yourself, I am sure--'' (she)

``Don't go on with it!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried passionately, as she (Tess) turned away from him (Alec) to a stile by the wayside, on which she (Tess) bent herself.
``I can't believe in such sudden things! I feel indignant with you for talking to me like this, when you know--when you know what harm you've done me! You, and those like you, take your fill of pleasure on earth by making the life of such as me bitter and black with sorrow; and then it is a fine thing, when you have had enough of that, to think of securing your pleasure in heaven by becoming converted! Out upon such--I don't believe in you--I hate it!'' (unknown)

``Tess,'' (he)
he (Alec) insisted;
``don't speak so! It came to me like a jolly new idea! And you don't believe me? What don't you believe?'' (he)

``Your conversion. Your scheme of religion.'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (She)

She (Tess) dropped her (Tess) voice.

``Because a better man than you does not believe in such.'' (unknown)

``What a woman's reason! Who is this better man?'' (unknown)

``I cannot tell you.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (he)
he (Alec) declared, a resentment beneath his (Alec) words seeming ready to spring out at a moment's notice,
``God forbid that I should say I am a good man--and you know I don't say any such thing. I am new to goodness, truly; but newcomers see furthest sometimes.'' (he)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Tess) replied sadly.
``But I cannot believe in your conversion to a new spirit. Such flashes as you feel, Alec, I fear don't last!'' (she)

Thus speaking she (Tess) turned from the stile over which she (Tess) had been leaning, and faced him (Alec); whereupon his (Alec) eyes, falling casually upon the familiar countenance and form, remained contemplating her (Tess). The inferior man was quiet in him (man) now; but it was surely not extracted, nor even entirely subdued.

``Don't look at me like that!'' (he)
he (man) said abruptly.

Tess, who had been quite unconscious of her (Tess) action and mien, instantly withdrew the large dark gaze of her (Tess) eyes, stammering with a flush,

``I beg your pardon!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
And there was revived in her (Tess) the wretched sentiment which had often come to her (Tess) before, that in inhabiting the fleshly tabernacle with which Nature had endowed her (Tess) she (Tess) was somehow doing wrong.

``No, no! Don't beg my pardon. But since you wear a veil to hide your good looks, why don't you keep it down?'' (She)

She (Tess) pulled down the veil, saying hastily,

``It was mostly to keep off the wind.'' (She)

``It may seem harsh of me to dictate like this,'' (he)
he (man) went on;
``but it is better that I should not look too often on you. It might be dangerous.'' (he)

``Ssh!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``Well, women's faces have had too much power over me already for me not to fear them! An evangelist has nothing to do with such as they; and it reminds me of the old times that I would forget!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

After this their conversation dwindled to a casual remark now and then as they rambled onward, Tess inwardly wondering how far he (man) was going with her (Tess), and not liking to send him (man) back by positive mandate. Frequently when they came to a gate or stile they found painted thereon in red or blue letters some text of Scripture, and she (Tess) asked him (man) if he (man) knew who had been at the pains to blazon these announcements. He (man) told her (Tess) that the man was employed by himself and others who were working with him (man) in that district, to paint these reminders that no means might be left untried which might move the hearts of a wicked generation.

At length the road touched the spot called

``Cross-in-Hand.'' (unknown)
Of all spots on the bleached and desolate upland this was the most forlorn. It was so far removed from the charm which is sought in landscape by artists and view-lovers as to reach a new kind of beauty, a negative beauty of tragic tone. The place took its name from a stone pillar which stood there, a strange rude monolith, from a stratum unknown in any local quarry, on which was roughly carved a human hand. Differing accounts were given of its history and purport. Some authorities stated that a devotional cross had once formed the complete erection thereon, of which the present relic was but the stump; others that the stone as it stood was entire, and that it had been fixed there to mark a boundary or place of meeting. Anyhow, whatever the origin of the relic, there was and is something sinister, or solemn, according to mood, in the scene amid which it stands; something tending to impress the most phlegmatic passer-by.

``I think I must leave you now,'' (he)
he (passer-by) remarked, as they drew near to this spot.
``I have to preach at Abbot's-Cernel at six this evening, and my way lies across to the right from here. And you upset me somewhat too, Tessy--I cannot, will not, say why. I must go away and get strength. ... How is it that you speak so fluently now? Who has taught you such good English?'' (unknown)

``I have learnt things in my troubles,'' (she)
she (passer-by) said evasively.

``What troubles have you had?'' (She)

She (passer-by) told him (passer-by) of the first one--the only one that related to him (passer-by).

D``Urberville was struck mute. ``I knew nothing of this till now!'' he (passer-by) next murmured.

``Why didn't you write to me when you felt your trouble coming on?'' (She)

She (passer-by) did not reply; and he (passer-by) broke the silence by adding:

``Well--you will see me again.'' (he)

``No,'' (she)
she (passer-by) answered.
``Do not again come near me!'' (unknown)

``I will think. But before we part come here.'' (He)
He (passer-by) stepped up to the pillar.
``This was once a Holy Cross. Relics are not in my creed; but I fear you at moments--far more than you need fear me at present; and to lessen my fear, put your hand upon that stone hand, and swear that you will never tempt me--by your charms or ways.'' (unknown)

``Good God--how can you ask what is so unnecessary! All that is furthest from my thought!'' (unknown)

``Yes--but swear it.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess, half frightened, gave way to his (passer-by) importunity; placed her (Tess) hand upon the stone and swore.

``I am sorry you are not a believer,'' (he)
he (passer-by) continued;
``that some unbeliever should have got hold of you and unsettled your mind. But no more now. At home at least I can pray for you; and I will; and who knows what may not happen? I'm off. Goodbye!'' (he)

He (passer-by) turned to a hunting-gate in the hedge and, without letting his (passer-by) eyes again rest upon her (Tess), leapt over and struck out across the down in the direction of Abbot's-Cernel. As he (Abbot) walked his (Abbot) pace showed perturbation, and by-and-by, as if instigated by a former thought, he (Abbot) drew from his (Abbot) pocket a small book, between the leaves of which was folded a letter, worn and soiled, as from much re-reading. D``Urberville opened the letter. It was dated several months before this time, and was signed by Parson Clare.

The letter began by expressing the writer's unfeigned joy at d``Urberville's conversion, and thanked him (writer) for his (writer) kindness in communicating with the parson on the subject. It expressed Mr Clare's warm assurance of forgiveness for d``Urberville's former conduct and his (Clare) interest in the young man's plans for the future. He (Clare), Mr Clare, would much have liked to see d``Urberville in the Church to whose ministry he (Clare) had devoted so many years of his (Clare) own life, and would have helped him (Clare) to enter a theological college to that end; but since his (Clare) correspondent had possibly not cared to do this on account of the delay it would have entailed, he (Clare) was not the man to insist upon its paramount importance. Every man must work as he (man) could best work, and in the method towards which he (man) felt impelled by the Spirit.

D``Urberville read and re-read this letter, and seemed to quiz himself cynically. He (man) also read some passages from memoranda as he (man) walked till his (man) face assumed a calm, and apparently the image of Tess no longer troubled his (man) mind.

She (Tess) meanwhile had kept along the edge of the hill by which lay her (Tess) nearest way home. Within the distance of a mile she (Tess) met a solitary shepherd.

``What is the meaning of that old stone I have passed?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked of him (Abbot).
``Was it ever a Holy Cross?'' (unknown)

``Cross--no; `twer not a cross!

``Tis a thing of ill-omen, Miss.. It was put up in wuld times by the relations of a malefactor who was tortured there by nailing his (shepherd) hand to a post and afterwards hung. The bones lie underneath. They say he (shepherd) sold his (shepherd) soul to the devil, and that he (shepherd) walks at times.'' (She)

She (Tess) felt the _petite mort_ at this unexpectedly gruesome information, and left the solitary man behind her (Tess). It was dusk when she (Tess) drew near to Flintcomb-Ash, and in the lane at the entrance to the hamlet she (Tess) approached a girl and her (Tess) lover without their observing her (Tess). They were talking no secrets, and the clear unconcerned voice of the young woman, in response to the warmer accents of the man, spread into the chilly air as the one soothing thing within the dusky horizon, full of a stagnant obscurity upon which nothing else intruded. For a moment the voices cheered the heart of Tess, till she (Tess) reasoned that this interview had its origin, on one side or the other, in the same attraction which had been the prelude to her (Tess) own tribulation. When she (Tess) came close, the girl turned serenely and recognized her (Tess), the young man walking off in embarrassment. The woman was Izz Huett, whose interest in Tess's excursion immediately superseded her (Tess) own proceedings. Tess did not explain very clearly its results, and Izz, who was a girl of tact, began to speak of her (girl) own little affair, a phase of which Tess had just witnessed.

``He (shepherd) is Amby Seedling, the chap who used to sometimes come and help at Talbothays,'' (she)
she (Tess) explained indifferently.
``He (shepherd) actually inquired and found out that I had come here, and has followed me. He (shepherd) says he (shepherd)'s been in love wi' me these two years. But I've hardly answered him (shepherd).'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

XLVI

Several days had passed since her (Tess) futile journey, and Tess was afield. The dry winter wind still blew, but a screen of thatched hurdles erected in the eye of the blast kept its force away from her (Tess). On the sheltered side was a turnip-slicing machine, whose bright blue hue of new paint seemed almost vocal in the otherwise subdued scene. Opposite its front was a long mound or

``grave'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
, in which the roots had been preserved since early winter. Tess was standing at the uncovered end, chopping off with a bill-hook the fibres and earth from each root, and throwing it after the operation into the slicer. A man was turning the handle of the machine, and from its trough came the newly-cut swedes, the fresh smell of whose yellow chips was accompanied by the sounds of the snuffling wind, the smart swish of the slicing-blades, and the choppings of the hook in Tess's leather-gloved hand.

The wide acreage of blank agricultural brownness, apparent where the swedes had been pulled, was beginning to be striped in wales of darker brown, gradually broadening to ribands. Along the edge of each of these something crept upon ten legs, moving without haste and without rest up and down the whole length of the field; it was two horses and a man, the plough going between them, turning up the cleared ground for a spring sowing.

For hours nothing relieved the joyless monotony of things. Then, far beyond the ploughing-teams, a black speck was seen. It had come from the corner of a fence, where there was a gap, and its tendency was up the incline, towards the swede-cutters. From the proportions of a mere point it advanced to the shape of a ninepin, and was soon perceived to be a man in black, arriving from the direction of Flintcomb-Ash. The man at the slicer, having nothing else to do with his (man) eyes, continually observed the comer, but Tess, who was occupied, did not perceive him (man) till her (Tess) companion directed her (Tess) attention to his (man) approach.

It was not her (Tess) hard taskmaster, Farmer Groby; it was one in a semi-clerical costume, who now represented what had once been the free-and-easy Alec d``Urberville. Not being hot at his (shepherd) preaching there was less enthusiasm about him (shepherd) now, and the presence of the grinder seemed to embarrass him (shepherd). A pale distress was already on Tess's face, and she (Tess) pulled her (Tess) curtained hood further over it.

D``Urberville came up and said quietly--

``I want to speak to you, Tess.'' (unknown)

``You have refused my last request, not to come near me!'' (she)
said she (Tess).

``Yes, but I have a good reason.'' (unknown)

``Well, tell it.'' (unknown)

``It is more serious than you may think.'' (He)

He (Alec) glanced round to see if he (Alec) were overheard. They were at some distance from the man who turned the slicer, and the movement of the machine, too, sufficiently prevented Alec's words reaching other ears. D``Urberville placed himself so as to screen Tess from the labourer, turning his (labourer) back to the latter.

``It is this,'' (he)
he (Alec) continued, with capricious compunction.
``In thinking of your soul and mine when we last met, I neglected to inquire as to your worldly condition. You were well dressed, and I did not think of it. But I see now that it is hard--harder than it used to be when I--knew you--harder than you deserve. Perhaps a good deal of it is owning to me!'' (She)

She (Tess) did not answer, and he (Alec) watched her (Tess) inquiringly, as, with bent head, her (Tess) face completely screened by the hood, she (Tess) resumed her (Tess) trimming of the swedes. By going on with her (Tess) work she (Tess) felt better able to keep him (Alec) outside her (Tess) emotions.

``Tess,'' (he)
he (Alec) added, with a sigh of discontent,--
``yours was the very worst case I ever was concerned in! I had no idea of what had resulted till you told me. Scamp that I was to foul that innocent life! The whole blame was mine--the whole unconventional business of our time at Trantridge. You, too, the real blood of which I am but the base imitation, what a blind young thing you were as to possibilities! I say in all earnestness that it is a shame for parents to bring up their girls in such dangerous ignorance of the gins and nets that the wicked may set for them, whether their motive be a good one or the result of simple indifference.'' (he)

Tess still did no more than listen, throwing down one globular root and taking up another with automatic regularity, the pensive contour of the mere fieldwoman alone marking her (Tess).

``But it is not that I came to say,'' (unknown)
d``Urberville went on.
``My circumstances are these. I have lost my mother since you were at Trantridge, and the place is my own. But I intend to sell it, and devote myself to missionary work in Africa. A devil of a poor hand I shall make at the trade, no doubt. However, what I want to ask you is, will you put it in my power to do my duty--to make the only reparation I can make for the trick played you: that is, will you be my wife, and go with me? ... I have already obtained this precious document. It was my old mother's dying wish.'' (He)

He (Alec) drew a piece of parchment from his (Alec) pocket, with a slight fumbling of embarrassment.

``What is it?'' (she)
said she (Tess).

``A marriage licence.'' (unknown)

``O no, sir--no!'' (she)
she (Tess) said quickly, starting back.

``You will not? Why is that?'' (he)

And as he (Alec) asked the question a disappointment which was not entirely the disappointment of thwarted duty crossed d``Urberville's face. It was unmistakably a symptom that something of his (I) old passion for her (mother) had been revived; duty and desire ran hand-in-hand.

``Surely,'' (he)
he (Alec) began again, in more impetuous tones, and then looked round at the labourer who turned the slicer.

Tess, too, felt that the argument could not be ended there. Informing the man that a gentleman had come to see her (Tess), with whom she (Tess) wished to walk a little way, she (Tess) moved off with d``Urberville across the zebra-striped field. When they reached the first newly-ploughed section he (I) held out his (I) hand to help her (mother) over it; but she (mother) stepped forward on the summits of the earth-rolls as if she (mother) did not see him (I).

``You will not marry me, Tess, and make me a self-respecting man?'' (he)
he (gentleman) repeated, as soon as they were over the furrows.

``I cannot.'' (unknown)

``But why?'' (unknown)

``You know I have no affection for you.'' (unknown)

``But you would get to feel that in time, perhaps--as soon as you really could forgive me?'' (unknown)

``Never!'' (unknown)

``Why so positive?'' (unknown)

``I love somebody else.'' (him)

The words seemed to astonish him (gentleman).

``You do?'' (he)
he (gentleman) cried.
``Somebody else? But has not a sense of what is morally right and proper any weight with you?'' (unknown)

``No, no, no--don't say that!'' (unknown)

``Anyhow, then, your love for this other man may be only a passing feeling which you will overcome--'' (unknown)

``No--no.'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes! Why not?'' (unknown)

``I cannot tell you.'' (unknown)

``You must in honour!'' (unknown)

``Well then ... I have married him (man).'' (unknown)

``Ah!'' (he)
he (gentleman) exclaimed; and he (gentleman) stopped dead and gazed at her (Tess).

``I did not wish to tell--I did not mean to!'' (she)
she (Tess) pleaded.
``It is a secret here, or at any rate but dimly known. So will you, PLEASE will you, keep from questioning me? You must remember that we are now strangers.'' (unknown)

``Strangers--are we? Strangers!'' (unknown)

For a moment a flash of his (gentleman) old irony marked his (gentleman) face; but he (gentleman) determinedly chastened it down.

``Is that man your husband?'' (he)
he (gentleman) asked mechanically, denoting by a sign the labourer who turned the machine.

``That man!'' (she)
she (Tess) said proudly.
``I should think not!'' (unknown)

``Who, then?'' (unknown)

``Do not ask what I do not wish to tell!'' (she)
she (Tess) begged, and flashed her (Tess) appeal to him (gentleman) from her (Tess) upturned face and lash-shadowed eyes.

D``Urberville was disturbed.

``But I only asked for your sake!'' (he)
he (gentleman) retorted hotly. ``Angels of heaven!--God forgive me for such an expression--I came here, I swear, as I thought for your good. Tess--don't look at me so--I cannot stand your looks! There never were such eyes, surely, before Christianity or since! There--I won't lose my head; I dare not. I own that the sight of you had waked up my love for you, which, I believed, was extinguished with all such feelings. But I thought that our marriage might be a sanctification for us both. ``The unbelieving husband is sanctified by the wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the husband,
'' I said to myself. But my plan is dashed from me; and I must bear the disappointment!'' (the husband)

He (gentleman) moodily reflected with his (gentleman) eyes on the ground.

``Married. Married! ... Well, that being so,'' (he)
he (gentleman) added, quite calmly, tearing the licence slowly into halves and putting them in his (gentleman) pocket;
``that being prevented, I should like to do some good to you and your husband, whoever he (husband) may be. There are many questions that I am tempted to ask, but I will not do so, of course, in opposition to your wishes. Though, if I could know your husband, I might more easily benefit him (husband) and you. Is he (husband) on this farm?'' (he)

``No,'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured.
``He (husband) is far away.'' (unknown)

``Far away? From YOU? What sort of husband can he (husband) be?'' (unknown)

``O, do not speak against him (husband)! It was through you! He (husband) found out--'' (unknown)

``Ah, is it so! ... That's sad, Tess!'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``But to stay away from you--to leave you to work like this!'' (unknown)

``He (husband) does not leave me to work!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried, springing to the defence of the absent one with all her (Tess) fervour.
``He (husband) don't know it! It is by my own arrangement.'' (unknown)

``Then, does he (husband) write?'' (unknown)

``I--I cannot tell you. There are things which are private to ourselves.'' (unknown)

``Of course that means that he (husband) does not. You are a deserted wife, my fair Tess--'' (he)

In an impulse he (gentleman) turned suddenly to take her (Tess) hand; the buff-glove was on it, and he (gentleman) seized only the rough leather fingers which did not express the life or shape of those within.

``You must not--you must not!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried fearfully, slipping her (Tess) hand from the glove as from a pocket, and leaving it in his (gentleman) grasp.
``O, will you go away--for the sake of me and my husband--go, in the name of your own Christianity!'' (unknown)

``Yes, yes; I will,'' (he)
he (gentleman) said abruptly, and thrusting the glove back to her (Tess) he (gentleman) turned to leave. Facing round, however, he (gentleman) said,
``Tess, as God is my judge, I meant no humbug in taking your hand!'' (he)

A pattering of hoofs on the soil of the field, which they had not noticed in their preoccupation, ceased close behind them; and a voice reached her (Tess) ear:

``What the devil are you doing away from your work at this time o' day?'' (Farmer)

Farmer Groby had espied the two figures from the distance, and had inquisitively ridden across, to learn what was their business in his (Farmer) field.

``Don't speak like that to her (Tess)!'' (unknown)
said d``Urberville, his (devil) face blackening with something that was not Christianity.

``Indeed, Mister! And what mid Methodist pa`sons have to do with she (Tess)?'' (unknown)

``Who is the fellow?'' (unknown)
asked d``Urberville, turning to Tess.

She (Tess) went close up to him (fellow).

``Go--I do beg you!'' (she)
she (Tess) said.

``What! And leave you to that tyrant? I can see in his (tyrant) face what a churl he (tyrant) is.'' (unknown)

``He (tyrant) won't hurt me. HE (tyrant)

``S not in love with me. I can leave at Lady-Day.'' (unknown)

``Well, I have no right but to obey, I suppose. But--well, goodbye!'' (defender sort)

Her (Tess) defender, whom she (Tess) dreaded more than her (Tess) assailant, having reluctantly disappeared, the farmer continued his (farmer) reprimand, which Tess took with the greatest coolness, that sort of attack being independent of sex. To have as a master this man of stone, who would have cuffed her (Tess) if he (man) had dared, was almost a relief after her (Tess) former experiences. She (Tess) silently walked back towards the summit of the field that was the scene of her (Tess) labour, so absorbed in the interview which had just taken place that she (Tess) was hardly aware that the nose of Groby's horse almost touched her (Tess) shoulders.

``If so be you make an agreement to work for me till Lady-Day, I'll see that you carry it out,'' (he)
he (man) growled.
''`Od rot the women--now `tis one thing, and then `tis another. But I'll put up with it no longer!'' (he)

Knowing very well that he (man) did not harass the other women of the farm as he (man) harassed her (Tess) out of spite for the flooring he (man) had once received, she (Tess) did for one moment picture what might have been the result if she (Tess) had been free to accept the offer just made her (Tess) of being the monied Alec's wife. It would have lifted her (Tess) completely out of subjection, not only to her (Tess) present oppressive employer, but to a whole world who seemed to despise her (Tess).

``But no, no!'' (she)
she (Tess) said breathlessly;
``I could not have married him (tyrant) now! He (tyrant) is so unpleasant to me.'' (she)

That very night she (Tess) began an appealing letter to Clare, concealing from him (Clare) her (Tess) hardships, and assuring him (Clare) of her (Tess) undying affection. Any one who had been in a position to read between the lines would have seen that at the back of her (Tess) great love was some monstrous fear--almost a desperation--as to some secret contingencies which were not disclosed. But again she (Tess) did not finish her (Tess) effusion; he (Clare) had asked Izz to go with him (Clare), and perhaps he (Clare) did not care for her (Tess) at all. She (Tess) put the letter in her (Tess) box, and wondered if it would ever reach Angel's hands.

After this her (Tess) daily tasks were gone through heavily enough, and brought on the day which was of great import to agriculturists--the day of the Candlemas Fair. It was at this fair that new engagements were entered into for the twelve months following the ensuing Lady-Day, and those of the farming population who thought of changing their places duly attended at the county-town where the fair was held. Nearly all the labourers on Flintcomb-Ash farm intended flight, and early in the morning there was a general exodus in the direction of the town, which lay at a distance of from ten to a dozen miles over hilly country. Though Tess also meant to leave at the quarter-day, she (Tess) was one of the few who did not go to the fair, having a vaguely-shaped hope that something would happen to render another outdoor engagement unnecessary.

It was a peaceful February day, of wonderful softness for the time, and one would almost have thought that winter was over. She (Tess) had hardly finished her (Tess) dinner when d``Urberville's figure darkened the window of the cottage wherein she (me) was a lodger, which she (me) had all to herself to-day.

Tess jumped up, but her (Tess) visitor had knocked at the door, and she (Tess) could hardly in reason run away. D``Urberville's knock, his (visitor) walk up to the door, had some indescribable quality of difference from his (visitor) air when she (Tess) last saw him (visitor). They seemed to be acts of which the doer was ashamed. She (Tess) thought that she (Tess) would not open the door; but, as there was no sense in that either, she (Tess) arose, and having lifted the latch stepped back quickly. He (doer) came in, saw her (Tess), and flung himself down into a chair before speaking.

``Tess--I couldn't help it!'' (he)
he (Tess) began desperately, as he (Tess) wiped his (Tess) heated face, which had also a superimposed flush of excitement.
``I felt that I must call at least to ask how you are. I assure you I had not been thinking of you at all till I saw you that Sunday; now I cannot get rid of your image, try how I may! It is hard that a good woman should do harm to a bad man; yet so it is. If you would only pray for me, Tess!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

The suppressed discontent of his (Tess) manner was almost pitiable, and yet Tess did not pity him (Tess).

``How can I pray for you,'' (she)
she (Tess) said,
``when I am forbidden to believe that the great Power who moves the world would alter His (man) plans on my account?'' (she)

``You really think that?'' (unknown)

``Yes. I have been cured of the presumption of thinking otherwise.'' (unknown)

``Cured? By whom?'' (unknown)

``By my husband, if I must tell.'' (unknown)

``Ah--your husband--your husband! How strange it seems! I remember you hinted something of the sort the other day. What do you really believe in these matters, Tess?'' (he)
he (Tess) asked.
``You seem to have no religion--perhaps owing to me.'' (unknown)

``But I have. Though I don't believe in anything supernatural.'' (unknown)

D``Urberville looked at her (Tess) with misgiving.

``Then do you think that the line I take is all wrong?'' (unknown)

``A good deal of it.'' (unknown)

``H'm--and yet I've felt so sure about it,'' (he)
he (Tess) said uneasily.

``I believe in the SPIRIT of the Sermon on the Mount, and so did my dear husband... But I don't believe--'' (she)

Here she (Tess) gave her (Tess) negations.

``The fact is,'' (husband)
said d``Urberville drily,
``whatever your dear husband believed you accept, and whatever he (husband) rejected you reject, without the least inquiry or reasoning on your own part. That's just like you women. Your mind is enslaved to his (husband).'' (unknown)

``Ah, because he (husband) knew everything!'' (she)
said she (Tess), with a triumphant simplicity of faith in Angel Clare that the most perfect man could hardly have deserved, much less her (Tess) husband.

``Yes, but you should not take negative opinions wholesale from another person like that. A pretty fellow he (fellow) must be to teach you such scepticism!'' (unknown)

``He (fellow) never forced my judgement! He (fellow) would never argue on the subject with me! But I looked at it in this way; what he (fellow) believed, after inquiring deep into doctrines, was much more likely to be right than what I might believe, who hadn't looked into doctrines at all.'' (unknown)

``What used he (fellow) to say? He (fellow) must have said something?'' (She)

She (Tess) reflected; and with her (Tess) acute memory for the letter of Angel Clare's remarks, even when she (Tess) did not comprehend their spirit, she (Tess) recalled a merciless polemical syllogism that she (Tess) had heard him (Clare) use when, as it occasionally happened, he (Clare) indulged in a species of thinking aloud with her (Tess) at his (Clare) side. In delivering it she (Tess) gave also Clare's accent and manner with reverential faithfulness.

``Say that again,'' (She)
asked d``Urberville, who had listened with the greatest attention.

She (fellow) repeated the argument, and d``Urberville thoughtfully murmured the words after her (fellow).

``Anything else?'' (he)
he (Clare) presently asked.

``He (fellow) said at another time something like this'' (she)
; and she (Tess) gave another, which might possibly have been paralleled in many a work of the pedigree ranging from the _Dictionnaire Philosophique_ to Huxley's _Essays_.

``Ah--ha! How do you remember them?'' (unknown)

``I wanted to believe what he (fellow) believed, though he (fellow) didn't wish me to; and I managed to coax him (fellow) to tell me a few of his (fellow) thoughts. I can't say I quite understand that one; but I know it is right.'' (unknown)

``H'm. Fancy your being able to teach me what you don't know yourself!'' (He)

He (Huxley) fell into thought.

``And so I threw in my spiritual lot with his (fellow),'' (she)
she (Tess) resumed.
``I didn't wish it to be different. What's good enough for him (fellow) is good enough for me.'' (unknown)

``Does he (fellow) know that you are as big an infidel as he (fellow)?'' (unknown)

``No--I never told him (fellow)--if I am an infidel.'' (unknown)

``Well--you are better off to-day that I am, Tess, after all! You don't believe that you ought to preach my doctrine, and, therefore, do no despite to your conscience in abstaining. I do believe I ought to preach it, but, like the devils, I believe and tremble, for I suddenly leave off preaching it, and give way to my passion for you.'' (unknown)

``How?'' (unknown)

``Why,'' (he)
he (Huxley) said aridly;
``I have come all the way here to see you to-day! But I started from home to go to Casterbridge Fair, where I have undertaken to preach the Word from a waggon at half-past two this afternoon, and where all the brethren are expecting me this minute. Here's the announcement.'' (he)

He (Huxley) drew from his (Huxley) breast-pocket a poster whereon was printed the day, hour, and place of meeting, at which he (Huxley), d``Urberville, would preach the Gospel as aforesaid.

``But how can you get there?'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess, looking at the clock.

``I cannot get there! I have come here.'' (unknown)

``What, you have really arranged to preach, and--'' (unknown)

``I have arranged to preach, and I shall not be there--by reason of my burning desire to see a woman whom I once despised!--No, by my word and truth, I never despised you; if I had I should not love you now! Why I did not despise you was on account of your being unsmirched in spite of all; you withdrew yourself from me so quickly and resolutely when you saw the situation; you did not remain at my pleasure; so there was one petticoat in the world for whom I had no contempt, and you are she (woman). But you may well despise me now! I thought I worshipped on the mountains, but I find I still serve in the groves! Ha! ha!'' (unknown)

``O Alec d

``Urberville! what does this mean? What have I done!'' (unknown)

``Done?'' (he)
he (Huxley) said, with a soulless sneer in the word.
``Nothing intentionally. But you have been the means--the innocent means--of my backsliding, as they call it. I ask myself, am I, indeed, one of those `servants of corruption' who, `after they have escaped the pollutions of the world, are again entangled therein and overcome'-- whose latter end is worse than their beginning?'' (He)
He (Huxley) laid his (Huxley) hand on her (Tess) shoulder.
``Tess, my girl, I was on the way to, at least, social salvation till I saw you again!'' (he)
he (Huxley) said freakishly shaking her (Tess), as if she (Tess) were a child.
``And why then have you tempted me? I was firm as a man could be till I saw those eyes and that mouth again--surely there never was such a maddening mouth since Eve's!'' (unknown)
His (Huxley) voice sank, and a hot archness shot from his (Huxley) own black eyes.
``You temptress, Tess; you dear damned witch of Babylon--I could not resist you as soon as I met you again!'' (unknown)

``I couldn't help your seeing me again!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess, recoiling.

``I know it--I repeat that I do not blame you. But the fact remains. When I saw you ill-used on the farm that day I was nearly mad to think that I had no legal right to protect you--that I could not have it; whilst he (I) who has it seems to neglect you utterly!'' (unknown)

``Don't speak against him (I)--he (I) is absent!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried in much excitement.
``Treat him (I) honourably--he (I) has never wronged you! O leave his (I) wife before any scandal spreads that may do harm to his (I) honest name!'' (unknown)

``I will--I will,'' (he)
he (Huxley) said, like a man awakening from a luring dream.
``I have broken my engagement to preach to those poor drunken boobies at the fair--it is the first time I have played such a practical joke. A month ago I should have been horrified at such a possibility. I'll go away--to swear--and--ah, can I! to keep away.'' (unknown)
Then, suddenly:
``One clasp, Tessy--one! Only for old friendship--'' (unknown)

``I am without defence. Alec! A good man's honour is in my keeping-- think--be ashamed!'' (unknown)

``Pooh! Well, yes--yes!'' (He)

He (Huxley) clenched his (Huxley) lips, mortified with himself for his (Huxley) weakness. His (Huxley) eyes were equally barren of worldly and religious faith. The corpses of those old fitful passions which had lain inanimate amid the lines of his (Huxley) face ever since his (Huxley) reformation seemed to wake and come together as in a resurrection. He (Huxley) went out indeterminately.

Though d``Urberville had declared that this breach of his (Alec) engagement to-day was the simple backsliding of a believer, Tess's words, as echoed from Angel Clare, had made a deep impression upon him (Clare), and continued to do so after he (Clare) had left her (Tess). He (Clare) moved on in silence, as if his (Clare) energies were benumbed by the hitherto undreamt-of possibility that his (Clare) position was untenable. Reason had had nothing to do with his (Clare) whimsical conversion, which was perhaps the mere freak of a careless man in search of a new sensation, and temporarily impressed by his (man) mother's death.

The drops of logic Tess had let fall into the sea of his (man) enthusiasm served to chill its effervescence to stagnation. He (man) said to himself, as he (man) pondered again and again over the crystallized phrases that she (Tess) had handed on to him (man),

``That clever fellow little thought that, by telling her (Tess) those things, he (man) might be paving my way back to her (Tess)!'' (him)

XLVII

It is the threshing of the last wheat-rick at Flintcomb-Ash farm. The dawn of the March morning is singularly inexpressive, and there is nothing to show where the eastern horizon lies. Against the twilight rises the trapezoidal top of the stack, which has stood forlornly here through the washing and bleaching of the wintry weather.

When Izz Huett and Tess arrived at the scene of operations only a rustling denoted that others had preceded them; to which, as the light increased, there were presently added the silhouettes of two men on the summit. They were busily

``unhaling'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
the rick, that is, stripping off the thatch before beginning to throw down the sheaves; and while this was in progress Izz and Tess, with the other women-workers, in their whitey-brown pinners, stood waiting and shivering, Farmer Groby having insisted upon their being on the spot thus early to get the job over if possible by the end of the day. Close under the eaves of the stack, and as yet barely visible, was the red tyrant that the women had come to serve--a timber-framed construction, with straps and wheels appertaining-- the threshing-machine which, whilst it was going, kept up a despotic demand upon the endurance of their muscles and nerves.

A little way off there was another indistinct figure; this one black, with a sustained hiss that spoke of strength very much in reserve. The long chimney running up beside an ash-tree, and the warmth which radiated from the spot, explained without the necessity of much daylight that here was the engine which was to act as the _primum mobile_ of this little world. By the engine stood a dark, motionless being, a sooty and grimy embodiment of tallness, in a sort of trance, with a heap of coals by his side: it was the engine-man. The isolation of his (his) manner and colour lent him (his) the appearance of a creature from Tophet, who had strayed into the pellucid smokelessness of this region of yellow grain and pale soil, with which he (his) had nothing in common, to amaze and to discompose its aborigines.

What he (his) looked he (his) felt. He (his) was in the agricultural world, but not of it. He (his) served fire and smoke; these denizens of the fields served vegetation, weather, frost, and sun. He (his) travelled with his (his) engine from farm to farm, from county to county, for as yet the steam threshing-machine was itinerant in this part of Wessex. He (his) spoke in a strange northern accent; his (his) thoughts being turned inwards upon himself, his (his) eye on his (his) iron charge, hardly perceiving the scenes around him (his), and caring for them not at all: holding only strictly necessary intercourse with the natives, as if some ancient doom compelled him (his) to wander here against his (his) will in the service of his (his) Plutonic master. The long strap which ran from the driving-wheel of his (his) engine to the red thresher under the rick was the sole tie-line between agriculture and him (his).

While they uncovered the sheaves he (his) stood apathetic beside his (his) portable repository of force, round whose hot blackness the morning air quivered. He (his) had nothing to do with preparatory labour. His (his) fire was waiting incandescent, his (his) steam was at high pressure, in a few seconds he (his) could make the long strap move at an invisible velocity. Beyond its extent the environment might be corn, straw, or chaos; it was all the same to him (his). If any of the autochthonous idlers asked him (his) what he (his) called himself, he (his) replied shortly,

``an engineer.'' (he)

The rick was unhaled by full daylight; the men then took their places, the women mounted, and the work began. Farmer Groby--or, as they called him (Farmer),

``he (engineer)'' (him)
--had arrived ere this, and by his (Farmer) orders Tess was placed on the platform of the machine, close to the man who fed it, her (Tess) business being to untie every sheaf of corn handed on to her (Tess) by Izz Huett, who stood next, but on the rick; so that the feeder could seize it and spread it over the revolving drum, which whisked out every grain in one moment.

They were soon in full progress, after a preparatory hitch or two, which rejoiced the hearts of those who hated machinery. The work sped on till breakfast time, when the thresher was stopped for half an hour; and on starting again after the meal the whole supplementary strength of the farm was thrown into the labour of constructing the straw-rick, which began to grow beside the stack of corn. A hasty lunch was eaten as they stood, without leaving their positions, and then another couple of hours brought them near to dinner-time; the inexorable wheel continuing to spin, and the penetrating hum of the thresher to thrill to the very marrow all who were near the revolving wire-cage.

The old men on the rising straw-rick talked of the past days when they had been accustomed to thresh with flails on the oaken barn-floor; when everything, even to winnowing, was effected by hand-labour, which, to their thinking, though slow, produced better results. Those, too, on the corn-rick talked a little; but the perspiring ones at the machine, including Tess, could not lighten their duties by the exchange of many words. It was the ceaselessness of the work which tried her (Tess) so severely, and began to make her (Tess) wish that she (Tess) had never some to Flintcomb-Ash. The women on the corn-rick--Marian, who was one of them, in particular--could stop to drink ale or cold tea from the flagon now and then, or to exchange a few gossiping remarks while they wiped their faces or cleared the fragments of straw and husk from their clothing; but for Tess there was no respite; for, as the drum never stopped, the man who fed it could not stop, and she (Tess), who had to supply the man with untied sheaves, could not stop either, unless Marian changed places with her (Marian), which she (Marian) sometimes did for half an hour in spite of Groby's objections that she (Marian) was too slow-handed for a feeder.

For some probably economical reason it was usually a woman who was chosen for this particular duty, and Groby gave as his (man) motive in selecting Tess that she (Tess) was one of those who best combined strength with quickness in untying, and both with staying power, and this may have been true. The hum of the thresher, which prevented speech, increased to a raving whenever the supply of corn fell short of the regular quantity. As Tess and the man who fed could never turn their heads she (Tess) did not know that just before the dinner-hour a person had come silently into the field by the gate, and had been standing under a second rick watching the scene and Tess in particular. He (man) was dressed in a tweed suit of fashionable pattern, and he (man) twirled a gay walking-cane.

``Who is that?'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
said Izz Huett to Marian. She (Marian) had at first addressed the inquiry to Tess, but the latter could not hear it.

``Somebody's fancy-man, I s`pose,'' (Marian)
said Marian laconically.

``I'll lay a guinea he (engineer)'s after Tess.'' (unknown)

``O no.

``Tis a ranter pa`son who's been sniffing after her (Tess) lately; not a dandy like this.'' (unknown)

``Well--this is the same man.'' (unknown)

``The same man as the preacher? But he (man)'s quite different!'' (unknown)

``He (man) hev left off his (man) black coat and white neckercher, and hev cut off his (man) whiskers; but he (man)'s the same man for all that.'' (unknown)

``D'ye really think so? Then I'll tell her (Tess),'' (Marian)
said Marian.

``Don't. She (Tess)'ll see him (man) soon enough, good-now.'' (unknown)

``Well, I don't think it at all right for him (man) to join his (man) preaching to courting a married woman, even though her (woman) husband mid be abroad, and she (woman), in a sense, a widow.'' (unknown)

``Oh--he (man) can do her (woman) no harm,'' (Izz/Izz Huett)
said Izz drily.
``Her (woman) mind can no more be heaved from that one place where it do bide than a stooded waggon from the hole he (man)'s in. Lord love `ee, neither court-paying, nor preaching, nor the seven thunders themselves, can wean a woman when `twould be better for her (woman) that she (woman) should be weaned.'' (unknown)

Dinner-time came, and the whirling ceased; whereupon Tess left her (Tess) post, her (Tess) knees trembling so wretchedly with the shaking of the machine that she (Tess) could scarcely walk.

``You ought to het a quart o' drink into `ee, as I've done,'' (Marian)
said Marian.
``You wouldn't look so white then. Why, souls above us, your face is as if you'd been hagrode!'' (Marian)

It occurred to the good-natured Marian that, as Tess was so tired, her (Tess) discovery of her (Tess) visitor's presence might have the bad effect of taking away her (Tess) appetite; and Marian was thinking of inducing Tess to descend by a ladder on the further side of the stack when the gentleman came forward and looked up.

Tess uttered a short little

``Oh!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
And a moment after she (Tess) said, quickly,
``I shall eat my dinner here--right on the rick.'' (she)

Sometimes, when they were so far from their cottages, they all did this; but as there was rather a keen wind going to-day, Marian and the rest descended, and sat under the straw-stack.

The newcomer was, indeed, Alec d``Urberville, the late Evangelist, despite his (Evangelist) changed attire and aspect. It was obvious at a glance that the original _Weltlust_ had come back; that he (Evangelist) had restored himself, as nearly as a man could do who had grown three or four years older, to the old jaunty, slapdash guise under which Tess had first known her (Tess) admirer, and cousin so-called. Having decided to remain where she (Tess) was, Tess sat down among the bundles, out of sight of the ground, and began her (Tess) meal; till, by-and-by, she (Tess) heard footsteps on the ladder, and immediately after Alec appeared upon the stack--now an oblong and level platform of sheaves. He (Alec) strode across them, and sat down opposite of her (Tess) without a word.

Tess continued to eat her (Tess) modest dinner, a slice of thick pancake which she (Tess) had brought with her (Tess). The other workfolk were by this time all gathered under the rick, where the loose straw formed a comfortable retreat.

``I am here again, as you see,'' (unknown)
said d``Urberville.

``Why do you trouble me so!'' (she)
she (Marian) cried, reproach flashing from her (Marian) very finger-ends.

``I trouble YOU? I think I may ask, why do you trouble me?'' (unknown)

``Sure, I don't trouble you any-when!'' (unknown)

``You say you don't? But you do! You haunt me. Those very eyes that you turned upon me with such a bitter flash a moment ago, they come to me just as you showed them then, in the night and in the day! Tess, ever since you told me of that child of ours, it is just as if my feelings, which have been flowing in a strong puritanical stream, had suddenly found a way open in the direction of you, and had all at once gushed through. The religious channel is left dry forthwith; and it is you who have done it!'' (She)

She (Marian) gazed in silence.

``What--you have given up your preaching entirely?'' (she)
she (Marian) asked. She (Marian) had gathered from Angel sufficient of the incredulity of modern thought to despise flash enthusiasm; but, as a woman, she (woman) was somewhat appalled.

In affected severity d``Urberville continued--

``Entirely. I have broken every engagement since that afternoon I was to address the drunkards at Casterbridge Fair. The deuce only knows what I am thought of by the brethren. Ah-ha! The brethren! No doubt they pray for me--weep for me; for they are kind people in their way. But what do I care? How could I go on with the thing when I had lost my faith in it?--it would have been hypocrisy of the basest kind! Among them I should have stood like Hymenaeus and Alexander, who were delivered over to Satan that they might learn not to blaspheme. What a grand revenge you have taken! I saw you innocent, and I deceived you. Four years after, you find me a Christian enthusiast; you then work upon me, perhaps to my complete perdition! But Tess, my coz, as I used to call you, this is only my way of talking, and you must not look so horribly concerned. Of course you have done nothing except retain your pretty face and shapely figure. I saw it on the rick before you saw me--that tight pinafore-thing sets it off, and that wing-bonnet--you field-girls should never wear those bonnets if you wish to keep out of danger.'' (He)
He (Angel) regarded her (woman) silently for a few moments, and with a short cynical laugh resumed:
``I believe that if the bachelor-apostle, whose deputy I thought I was, had been tempted by such a pretty face, he (deputy) would have let go the plough for her (deputy) sake as I do!'' (He)

Tess attempted to expostulate, but at this juncture all her (Tess) fluency failed her (Tess), and without heeding he (Angel) added:

``Well, this paradise that you supply is perhaps as good as any other, after all. But to speak seriously, Tess.'' (he)
D``Urberville rose and came nearer, reclining sideways amid the sheaves, and resting upon his (deputy) elbow.
``Since I last saw you, I have been thinking of what you said that HE (deputy) said. I have come to the conclusion that there does seem rather a want of common-sense in these threadbare old propositions; how I could have been so fired by poor Parson Clare's enthusiasm, and have gone so madly to work, transcending even him (deputy), I cannot make out! As for what you said last time, on the strength of your wonderful husband's intelligence--whose name you have never told me--about having what they call an ethical system without any dogma, I don't see my way to that at all.'' (unknown)

``Why, you can have the religion of loving-kindness and purity at least, if you can't have--what do you call it--dogma.'' (unknown)

``O no! I'm a different sort of fellow from that! If there's nobody to say, ``Do this, and it will be a good thing for you after you are dead; do that, and if will be a bad thing for you,

'' I can't warm up. Hang it, I am not going to feel responsible for my deeds and passions if there's nobody to be responsible to; and if I were you, my dear, I wouldn't either!'' (She)

She (Tess) tried to argue, and tell him (Angel) that he (Angel) had mixed in his (Angel) dull brain two matters, theology and morals, which in the primitive days of mankind had been quite distinct. But owing to Angel Clare's reticence, to her (Tess) absolute want of training, and to her (Tess) being a vessel of emotions rather than reasons, she (Tess) could not get on.

``Well, never mind,'' (he)
he (Clare) resumed.
``Here I am, my love, as in the old times!'' (unknown)

``Not as then--never as then--`tis different!'' (she)
she (Tess) entreated.
``And there was never warmth with me! O why didn't you keep your faith, if the loss of it has brought you to speak to me like this!'' (unknown)

``Because you've knocked it out of me; so the evil be upon your sweet head! Your husband little thought how his (husband) teaching would recoil upon him (husband)! Ha-ha--I'm awfully glad you have made an apostate of me all the same! Tess, I am more taken with you than ever, and I pity you too. For all your closeness, I see you are in a bad way--neglected by one who ought to cherish you.'' (She)

She (Tess) could not get her (Tess) morsels of food down her (Tess) throat; her (Tess) lips were dry, and she (Tess) was ready to choke. The voices and laughs of the workfolk eating and drinking under the rick came to her (Tess) as if they were a quarter of a mile off.

``It is cruelty to me!'' (she)
she (Tess) said.
``How--how can you treat me to this talk, if you care ever so little for me?'' (unknown)

``True, true,'' (he)
he (Clare) said, wincing a little. ``I did not come to reproach you for my deeds. I came Tess, to say that I don't like you to be working like this, and I have come on purpose for you. You say you have a husband who is not I. Well, perhaps you have; but I've never seen him (husband), and you've not told me his (husband) name; and altogether he (husband) seems rather a mythological personage. However, even if you have one, I think I am nearer to you than he (husband) is. I, at any rate, try to help you out of trouble, but he (husband) does not, bless his (husband) invisible face! The words of the stern prophet Hosea that I used to read come back to me. Don't you know them, Tess?--``And she (Tess) shall follow after her (Tess) lover, but she (Tess) shall not overtake him (lover); and she (Tess) shall seek him (lover), but shall not find him (lover); then shall she (Tess) say, I will go and return to my first husband; for then was it better with me than now!
'' ... Tess, my trap is waiting just under the hill, and--darling mine, not his (Clare)!--you know the rest.'' (me)

Her (Tess) face had been rising to a dull crimson fire while he (Clare) spoke; but she (Tess) did not answer.

``You have been the cause of my backsliding,'' (he)
he (Clare) continued, stretching his (Clare) arm towards her (Tess) waist;
``you should be willing to share it, and leave that mule you call husband for ever.'' (he)

One of her (Tess) leather gloves, which she (Tess) had taken off to eat her (Tess) skimmer-cake, lay in her (Tess) lap, and without the slightest warning she (Tess) passionately swung the glove by the gauntlet directly in his (Clare) face. It was heavy and thick as a warrior's, and it struck him (Clare) flat on the mouth. Fancy might have regarded the act as the recrudescence of a trick in which her (Tess) armed progenitors were not unpractised. Alec fiercely started up from his (Alec) reclining position. A scarlet oozing appeared where her (Tess) blow had alighted, and in a moment the blood began dropping from his (Alec) mouth upon the straw. But he (Alec) soon controlled himself, calmly drew his (Alec) handkerchief from his (Alec) pocket, and mopped his (Alec) bleeding lips.

She (Tess) too had sprung up, but she (Tess) sank down again.

``Now, punish me!'' (she)
she (Tess) said, turning up her (Tess) eyes to him (Alec) with the hopeless defiance of the sparrow's gaze before its captor twists its neck.
``Whip me, crush me; you need not mind those people under the rick! I shall not cry out. Once victim, always victim--that's the law!'' (unknown)

``O no, no, Tess,'' (he)
he (captor) said blandly.
``I can make full allowance for this. Yet you most unjustly forget one thing, that I would have married you if you had not put it out of my power to do so. Did I not ask you flatly to be my wife--hey? Answer me.'' (unknown)

``You did.'' (unknown)

``And you cannot be. But remember one thing!'' (him)
His (captor) voice hardened as his (captor) temper got the better of him (captor) with the recollection of his (captor) sincerity in asking her (Tess) and her (Tess) present ingratitude, and he (captor) stepped across to her (Tess) side and held her (Tess) by the shoulders, so that she (Tess) shook under his (captor) grasp.
``Remember, my lady, I was your master once! I will be your master again. If you are any man's wife you are mine!'' (unknown)

The threshers now began to stir below.

``So much for our quarrel,'' (he)
he (captor) said, letting her (Tess) go.
``Now I shall leave you, and shall come again for your answer during the afternoon. You don't know me yet! But I know you.'' (She)

She (Tess) had not spoken again, remaining as if stunned. D``Urberville retreated over the sheaves, and descended the ladder, while the workers below rose and stretched their arms, and shook down the beer they had drunk. Then the threshing-machine started afresh; and amid the renewed rustle of the straw Tess resumed her (Tess) position by the buzzing drum as one in a dream, untying sheaf after sheaf in endless succession.

XLVIII

In the afternoon the farmer made it known that the rick was to be finished that night, since there was a moon by which they could see to work, and the man with the engine was engaged for another farm on the morrow. Hence the twanging and humming and rustling proceeded with even less intermission than usual.

It was not till

``nammet'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
-time, about three o-clock, that Tess raised her (Tess) eyes and gave a momentary glance round. She (Tess) felt but little surprise at seeing that Alec d``Urberville had come back, and was standing under the hedge by the gate. He (man) had seen her (man) lift her (man) eyes, and waved his (man) hand urbanely to her (man), while he (man) blew her (man) a kiss. It meant that their quarrel was over. Tess looked down again, and carefully abstained from gazing in that direction.

Thus the afternoon dragged on. The wheat-rick shrank lower, and the straw-rick grew higher, and the corn-sacks were carted away. At six o'clock the wheat-rick was about shoulder-high from the ground. But the unthreshed sheaves remaining untouched seemed countless still, notwithstanding the enormous numbers that had been gulped down by the insatiable swallower, fed by the man and Tess, through whose two young hands the greater part of them had passed. And the immense stack of straw where in the morning there had been nothing, appeared as the faeces of the same buzzing red glutton. From the west sky a wrathful shine--all that wild March could afford in the way of sunset--had burst forth after the cloudy day, flooding the tired and sticky faces of the threshers, and dyeing them with a coppery light, as also the flapping garments of the women, which clung to them like dull flames.

A panting ache ran through the rick. The man who fed was weary, and Tess could see that the red nape of his (man) neck was encrusted with dirt and husks. She (Tess) still stood at her (Tess) post, her (Tess) flushed and perspiring face coated with the corndust, and her (Tess) white bonnet embrowned by it. She (Tess) was the only woman whose place was upon the machine so as to be shaken bodily by its spinning, and the decrease of the stack now separated her (Tess) from Marian and Izz, and prevented their changing duties with her (Tess) as they had done. The incessant quivering, in which every fibre of her (Tess) frame participated, had thrown her (Tess) into a stupefied reverie in which her (Tess) arms worked on independently of her (Tess) consciousness. She (Tess) hardly knew where she (Tess) was, and did not hear Izz Huett tell her (Tess) from below that her (Tess) hair was tumbling down.

By degrees the freshest among them began to grow cadaverous and saucer-eyed. Whenever Tess lifted her (Tess) head she (Tess) beheld always the great upgrown straw-stack, with the men in shirt-sleeves upon it, against the gray north sky; in front of it the long red elevator like a Jacob's ladder, on which a perpetual stream of threshed straw ascended, a yellow river running uphill, and spouting out on the top of the rick.

She (Tess) knew that Alec d``Urberville was still on the scene, observing her (Tess) from some point or other, though she (Tess) could not say where. There was an excuse for his (Alec) remaining, for when the threshed rick drew near its final sheaves a little ratting was always done, and men unconnected with the threshing sometimes dropped in for that performance--sporting characters of all descriptions, gents with terriers and facetious pipes, roughs with sticks and stones.

But there was another hour's work before the layer of live rats at the base of the stack would be reached; and as the evening light in the direction of the Giant's Hill by Abbot's-Cernel dissolved away, the white-faced moon of the season arose from the horizon that lay towards Middleton Abbey and Shottsford on the other side. For the last hour or two Marian had felt uneasy about Tess, whom she (Tess) could not get near enough to speak to, the other women having kept up their strength by drinking ale, and Tess having done without it through traditionary dread, owing to its results at her (Tess) home in childhood. But Tess still kept going: if she (Tess) could not fill her (Tess) part she (Tess) would have to leave; and this contingency, which she (Tess) would have regarded with equanimity and even with relief a month or two earlier, had become a terror since d``Urberville had begun to hover round her (Tess).

The sheaf-pitchers and feeders had now worked the rick so low that people on the ground could talk to them. To Tess's surprise Farmer Groby came up on the machine to her (Tess), and said that if she (Tess) desired to join her (Tess) friend he (friend) did not wish her (Tess) to keep on any longer, and would send somebody else to take her (Tess) place. The

``friend'' (unknown)
was d``Urberville, she (Tess) knew, and also that this concession had been granted in obedience to the request of that friend, or enemy. She (Tess) shook her (Tess) head and toiled on.

The time for the rat-catching arrived at last, and the hunt began. The creatures had crept downwards with the subsidence of the rick till they were all together at the bottom, and being now uncovered from their last refuge, they ran across the open ground in all directions, a loud shriek from the by-this-time half-tipsy Marian informing her (Marian) companions that one of the rats had invaded her (Marian) person--a terror which the rest of the women had guarded against by various schemes of skirt-tucking and self-elevation. The rat was at last dislodged, and, amid the barking of dogs, masculine shouts, feminine screams, oaths, stampings, and confusion as of Pandemonium, Tess untied her (Tess) last sheaf; the drum slowed, the whizzing ceased, and she (Tess) stepped from the machine to the ground.

Her (Tess) lover, who had only looked on at the rat-catching, was promptly at her (Tess) side.

``What--after all--my insulting slap, too!'' (she)
said she (Tess) in an underbreath. She (Tess) was so utterly exhausted that she (Tess) had not strength to speak louder.

``I should indeed be foolish to feel offended at anything you say or do,'' (he)
he (Alec) answered, in the seductive voice of the Trantridge time.
``How the little limbs tremble! You are as weak as a bled calf, you know you are; and yet you need have done nothing since I arrived. How could you be so obstinate? However, I have told the farmer that he (farmer) has no right to employ women at steam-threshing. It is not proper work for them; and on all the better class of farms it has been given up, as he (farmer) knows very well. I will walk with you as far as your home.'' (unknown)

``O yes,'' (she)
she (Tess) answered with a jaded gait.
``Walk wi' me if you will! I do bear in mind that you came to marry me before you knew o' my state. Perhaps--perhaps you are a little better and kinder than I have been thinking you were. Whatever is meant as kindness I am grateful for; whatever is meant in any other way I am angered at. I cannot sense your meaning sometimes.'' (unknown)

``If I cannot legitimize our former relations at least I can assist you. And I will do it with much more regard for your feelings than I formerly showed. My religious mania, or whatever it was, is over. But I retain a little good nature; I hope I do. Now, Tess, by all that's tender and strong between man and woman, trust me! I have enough and more than enough to put you out of anxiety, both for yourself and your parents and sisters. I can make them all comfortable if you will only show confidence in me.'' (unknown)

``Have you seen 'em lately?'' (she)
she (Tess) quickly inquired.

``Yes. They didn't know where you were. It was only by chance that I found you here.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

The cold moon looked aslant upon Tess's fagged face between the twigs of the garden-hedge as she (Tess) paused outside the cottage which was her (Tess) temporary home, d``Urberville pausing beside her (woman).

``Don't mention my little brothers and sisters--don't make me break down quite!'' (she)
she (Tess) said.
``If you want to help them--God knows they need it--do it without telling me. But no, no!'' (she)
she (Tess) cried.
``I will take nothing from you, either for them or for me!'' (He)

He (Alec) did not accompany her (Tess) further, since, as she (Tess) lived with the household, all was public indoors. No sooner had she (Tess) herself entered, laved herself in a washing-tub, and shared supper with the family than she (Tess) fell into thought, and withdrawing to the table under the wall, by the light of her (Tess) own little lamp wrote in a passionate mood--

MY OWN HUSBAND,--

Let me call you so--I must--even if it makes you angry to think of such an unworthy wife as I. I must cry to you in my trouble--I have no one else! I am so exposed to temptation, Angel. I fear to say who it is, and I do not like to write about it at all. But I cling to you in a way you cannot think! Can you not come to me now, at once, before anything terrible happens? O, I know you cannot, because you are so far away! I think I must die if you do not come soon, or tell me to come to you. The punishment you have measured out to me is deserved--I do know that-- well deserved--and you are right and just to be angry with me. But, Angel, please, please, not to be just--only a little kind to me, even if I do not deserve it, and come to me! If you would come, I could die in your arms! I would be well content to do that if so be you had forgiven me!

Angel, I live entirely for you. I love you too much to blame you for going away, and I know it was necessary you should find a farm. Do not think I shall say a word of sting or bitterness. Only come back to me. I am desolate without you, my darling, O, so desolate! I do not mind having to work: but if you will send me one little line, and say,

``I am coming soon,'' (me)
I will bide on, Angel--O, so cheerfully!

It has been so much my religion ever since we were married to be faithful to you in every thought and look, that even when a man speaks a compliment to me before I am aware, it seems wronging you. Have you never felt one little bit of what you used to feel when we were at the dairy? If you have, how can you keep away from me? I am the same women, Angel, as you fell in love with; yes, the very same!--not the one you disliked but never saw. What was the past to me as soon as I met you? It was a dead thing altogether. I became another woman, filled full of new life from you. How could I be the early one? Why do you not see this? Dear, if you would only be a little more conceited, and believe in yourself so far as to see that you were strong enough to work this change in me, you would perhaps be in a mind to come to me, your poor wife.

How silly I was in my happiness when I thought I could trust you always to love me! I ought to have known that such as that was not for poor me. But I am sick at heart, not only for old times, but for the present. Think--think how it do hurt my heart not to see you ever--ever! Ah, if I could only make your dear heart ache one little minute of each day as mine does every day and all day long, it might lead you to show pity to your poor lonely one.

People still say that I am rather pretty, Angel -LRB-handsome is the word they use, since I wish to be truthful-RRB-. Perhaps I am what they say. But I do not value my good looks; I only like to have them because they belong to you, my dear, and that there may be at least one thing about me worth your having. So much have I felt this, that when I met with annoyance on account of the same, I tied up my face in a bandage as long as people would believe in it. O Angel, I tell you all this not from vanity--you will certainly know I do not--but only that you may come to me!

If you really cannot come to me, will you let me come to you? I am, as I say, worried, pressed to do what I will not do. It cannot be that I shall yield one inch, yet I am in terror as to what an accident might lead to, and I so defenceless on account of my first error. I cannot say more about this--it makes me too miserable. But if I break down by falling into some fearful snare, my last state will be worse than my first. O God, I cannot think of it! Let me come at once, or at once come to me!

I would be content, ay, glad, to live with you as your servant, if I may not as your wife; so that I could only be near you, and get glimpses of you, and think of you as mine.

The daylight has nothing to show me, since you are not here, and I don't like to see the rooks and starlings in the field, because I grieve and grieve to miss you who used to see them with me. I long for only one thing in heaven or earth or under the earth, to meet you, my own dear! Come to me--come to me, and save me from what threatens me!--

Your faithful heartbroken

TESS

XLIX

The appeal duly found its way to the breakfast-table of the quiet Vicarage to the westward, in that valley where the air is so soft and the soil so rich that the effort of growth requires but superficial aid by comparison with the tillage at Flintcomb-Ash, and where to Tess the human world seemed so different -LRB-though it was much the same-RRB-. It was purely for security that she (Tess) had been requested by Angel to send her (Tess) communications through his (Angel) father, whom he (Angel) kept pretty well informed of his (Angel) changing addresses in the country he (Angel) had gone to exploit for himself with a heavy heart.

``Now,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said old Mr Clare to his (Clare) wife, when he (Clare) had read the envelope,
``if Angel proposes leaving Rio for a visit home at the end of next month, as he (Angel) told us that he (Angel) hoped to do, I think this may hasten his (Angel) plans; for I believe it to be from his (Angel) wife.'' (he)
He (Clare) breathed deeply at the thought of her (wife); and the letter was redirected to be promptly sent on to Angel.

``Dear fellow, I hope he (Angel) will get home safely,'' (Mrs Clare/Mrs Angel Clare)
murmured Mrs Clare.
``To my dying day I shall feel that he (Angel) has been ill-used. You should have sent him (Angel) to Cambridge in spite of his (Angel) want of faith and given him (Angel) the same chance as the other boys had. He (Angel) would have grown out of it under proper influence, and perhaps would have taken Orders after all. Church or no Church, it would have been fairer to him (Angel).'' (Mrs Clare/Mrs Angel Clare)

This was the only wail with which Mrs Clare ever disturbed her (Clare) husband's peace in respect to their sons. And she (Clare) did not vent this often; for she (Clare) was as considerate as she (Clare) was devout, and knew that his (husband) mind too was troubled by doubts as to his (husband) justice in this matter. Only too often had she (Clare) heard him (husband) lying awake at night, stifling sighs for Angel with prayers. But the uncompromising Evangelical did not even now hold that he (Angel) would have been justified in giving his (Angel) son, an unbeliever, the same academic advantages that he (Angel) had given to the two others, when it was possible, if not probable, that those very advantages might have been used to decry the doctrines which he (Angel) had made it his (Angel) life's mission and desire to propagate, and the mission of his (Angel) ordained sons likewise. To put with one hand a pedestal under the feet of the two faithful ones, and with the other to exalt the unfaithful by the same artificial means, he (Angel) deemed to be alike inconsistent with his (Angel) convictions, his (Angel) position, and his (Angel) hopes. Nevertheless, he (Angel) loved his (Angel) misnamed Angel, and in secret mourned over this treatment of him (Angel) as Abraham might have mourned over the doomed Isaac while they went up the hill together. His (Isaac) silent self-generated regrets were far bitterer than the reproaches which his (Isaac) wife rendered audible.

They blamed themselves for this unlucky marriage. If Angel had never been destined for a farmer he (Angel) would never have been thrown with agricultural girls. They did not distinctly know what had separated him (Angel) and his (Angel) wife, nor the date on which the separation had taken place. At first they had supposed it must be something of the nature of a serious aversion. But in his (Angel) later letters he (Angel) occasionally alluded to the intention of coming home to fetch her (wife); from which expressions they hoped the division might not owe its origin to anything so hopelessly permanent as that. He (Angel) had told them that she (wife) was with her (wife) relatives, and in their doubts they had decided not to intrude into a situation which they knew no way of bettering.

The eyes for which Tess's letter was intended were gazing at this time on a limitless expanse of country from the back of a mule which was bearing him (Angel) from the interior of the South-American Continent towards the coast. His (Angel) experiences of this strange land had been sad. The severe illness from which he (Angel) had suffered shortly after his (Angel) arrival had never wholly left him (Angel), and he (Angel) had by degrees almost decided to relinquish his (Angel) hope of farming here, though, as long as the bare possibility existed of his (Angel) remaining, he (Angel) kept this change of view a secret from his (Angel) parents.

The crowds of agricultural labourers who had come out to the country in his (Angel) wake, dazzled by representations of easy independence, had suffered, died, and wasted away. He (Angel) would see mothers from English farms trudging along with their infants in their arms, when the child would be stricken with fever and would die; the mother would pause to dig a hole in the loose earth with her (mother) bare hands, would bury the babe therein with the same natural grave-tools, shed one tear, and again trudge on.

Angel's original intention had not been emigration to Brazil but a northern or eastern farm in his (Angel) own country. He (Angel) had come to this place in a fit of desperation, the Brazil movement among the English agriculturists having by chance coincided with his (Angel) desire to escape from his (Angel) past existence.

During this time of absence he (Angel) had mentally aged a dozen years. What arrested him (Angel) now as of value in life was less its beauty than its pathos. Having long discredited the old systems of mysticism, he (Angel) now began to discredit the old appraisements of morality. He (Angel) thought they wanted readjusting. Who was the moral man? Still more pertinently, who was the moral woman? The beauty or ugliness of a character lay not only in its achievements, but in its aims and impulses; its true history lay, not among things done, but among things willed.

How, then, about Tess?
