``He (gentleman) has married her (Tess),'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)
Joan whispered.
``Go inside.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Clare saw her (Joan) efforts for reticence, and asked--

``Do you think Tess would wish me to try and find her (Tess)? If not, of course--'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

``I don't think she (Tess) would.'' (unknown)

``Are you sure?'' (unknown)

``I am sure she (Tess) wouldn't.'' (He)

He (Clare) was turning away; and then he (Clare) thought of Tess's tender letter.

``I am sure she (Tess) would!'' (he)
he (Clare) retorted passionately.
``I know her (Tess) better than you do.'' (unknown)

``That's very likely, sir; for I have never really known her (Tess).'' (unknown)

``Please tell me her (Tess) address, Mrs Durbeyfield, in kindness to a lonely wretched man!'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
Tess's mother again restlessly swept her (Tess) cheek with her (mother) vertical hand, and seeing that he (Clare) suffered, she (mother) at last said, is a low voice--

``She (Tess) is at Sandbourne.'' (she)

``Ah--where there? Sandbourne has become a large place, they say.'' (unknown)

``I don't know more particularly than I have said--Sandbourne. For myself, I was never there.'' (Joan/Joan Durbeyfield)

It was apparent that Joan spoke the truth in this, and he (Clare) pressed her (Joan) no further.

``Are you in want of anything?'' (he)
he (Clare) said gently.

``No, sir,'' (she)
she (Joan) replied.
``We are fairly well provided for.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Without entering the house Clare turned away. There was a station three miles ahead, and paying off his (Clare) coachman, he (Clare) walked thither. The last train to Sandbourne left shortly after, and it bore Clare on its wheels.

LV

At eleven o'clock that night, having secured a bed at one of the hotels and telegraphed his (Clare) address to his (Clare) father immediately on his (Clare) arrival, he (Clare) walked out into the streets of Sandbourne. It was too late to call on or inquire for any one, and he (Clare) reluctantly postponed his (Clare) purpose till the morning. But he (Clare) could not retire to rest just yet.

This fashionable watering-place, with its eastern and its western stations, its piers, its groves of pines, its promenades, and its covered gardens, was, to Angel Clare, like a fairy place suddenly created by the stroke of a wand, and allowed to get a little dusty. An outlying eastern tract of the enormous Egdon Waste was close at hand, yet on the very verge of that tawny piece of antiquity such a glittering novelty as this pleasure city had chosen to spring up. Within the space of a mile from its outskirts every irregularity of the soil was prehistoric, every channel an undisturbed British trackway; not a sod having been turned there since the days of the Caesars. Yet the exotic had grown here, suddenly as the prophet's gourd; and had drawn hither Tess.

By the midnight lamps he (prophet) went up and down the winding way of this new world in an old one, and could discern between the trees and against the stars the lofty roofs, chimneys, gazebos, and towers of the numerous fanciful residences of which the place was composed. It was a city of detached mansions; a Mediterranean lounging-place on the English Channel; and as seen now by night it seemed even more imposing than it was.

The sea was near at hand, but not intrusive; it murmured, and he (prophet) thought it was the pines; the pines murmured in precisely the same tones, and he (prophet) thought they were the sea.

Where could Tess possibly be, a cottage-girl, his (prophet) young wife, amidst all this wealth and fashion? The more he (prophet) pondered, the more was he (prophet) puzzled. Were there any cows to milk here? There certainly were no fields to till. She (wife) was most probably engaged to do something in one of these large houses; and he (prophet) sauntered along, looking at the chamber-windows and their lights going out one by one, and wondered which of them might be hers.

Conjecture was useless, and just after twelve o'clock he (prophet) entered and went to bed. Before putting out his (prophet) light he (prophet) re-read Tess's impassioned letter. Sleep, however, he (prophet) could not--so near her (Tess), yet so far from her (Tess)--and he (prophet) continually lifted the window-blind and regarded the backs of the opposite houses, and wondered behind which of the sashes she (Tess) reposed at that moment.

He (prophet) might almost as well have sat up all night. In the morning he (prophet) arose at seven, and shortly after went out, taking the direction of the chief post-office. At the door he (chief) met an intelligent postman coming out with letters for the morning delivery.

``Do you know the address of a Mrs Clare?'' (Angel)
asked Angel. The postman shook his (postman) head.

Then, remembering that she (Tess) would have been likely to continue the use of her (Tess) maiden name, Clare said--

``Of a Miss Durbeyfield?'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

``Durbeyfield?'' (the postman)

This also was strange to the postman addressed.

``There's visitors coming and going every day, as you know, sir,'' (he)
he (postman) said;
``and without the name of the house `tis impossible to find 'em.'' (he)

One of his (postman) comrades hastening out at that moment, the name was repeated to him (postman).

``I know no name of Durbeyfield; but there is the name of d

``Urberville at The Herons,'' (unknown)
said the second.

``That's it!'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
cried Clare, pleased to think that she (Tess) had reverted to the real pronunciation.
``What place is The Herons?'' (unknown)

``A stylish lodging-house.

``Tis all lodging-houses here, bless `ee.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Clare received directions how to find the house, and hastened thither, arriving with the milkman. The Herons, though an ordinary villa, stood in its own grounds, and was certainly the last place in which one would have expected to find lodgings, so private was its appearance. If poor Tess was a servant here, as he (servant) feared, she (Tess) would go to the back-door to that milkman, and he (servant) was inclined to go thither also. However, in his (servant) doubts he (servant) turned to the front, and rang.

The hour being early, the landlady herself opened the door. Clare inquired for Teresa d``Urberville or Durbeyfield.

``Mrs d'Urberville?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

Tess, then, passed as a married woman, and he (Clare) felt glad, even though she (Tess) had not adopted his (Clare) name.

``Will you kindly tell her (Mrs) that a relative is anxious to see her (Mrs)?'' (unknown)

``It is rather early. What name shall I give, sir?'' (unknown)

``Angel.'' (unknown)

``Mr Angel?'' (unknown)

``No; Angel. It is my Christian name. She (Mrs)'ll understand.'' (unknown)

``I'll see if she (Mrs) is awake.'' (He)

He (Clare) was shown into the front room--the dining-room--and looked out through the spring curtains at the little lawn, and the rhododendrons and other shrubs upon it. Obviously her (Tess) position was by no means so bad as he (Clare) had feared, and it crossed his (Clare) mind that she (Tess) must somehow have claimed and sold the jewels to attain it. He (Clare) did not blame her (Tess) for one moment. Soon his (Clare) sharpened ear detected footsteps upon the stairs, at which his (Clare) heart thumped so painfully that he (Clare) could hardly stand firm.

``Dear me! what will she (Mrs) think of me, so altered as I am!'' (he)
he (Clare) said to himself; and the door opened.

Tess appeared on the threshold--not at all as he (Clare) had expected to see her (Tess)--bewilderingly otherwise, indeed. Her (Tess) great natural beauty was, if not heightened, rendered more obvious by her (Tess) attire. She (Tess) was loosely wrapped in a cashmere dressing-gown of gray-white, embroidered in half-mourning tints, and she (Tess) wore slippers of the same hue. Her (Tess) neck rose out of a frill of down, and her (Tess) well-remembered cable of dark-brown hair was partially coiled up in a mass at the back of her (Tess) head and partly hanging on her (Tess) shoulder--the evident result of haste.

He (Clare) had held out his (Clare) arms, but they had fallen again to his (Clare) side; for she (Tess) had not come forward, remaining still in the opening of the doorway. Mere yellow skeleton that he (Clare) was now, he (Clare) felt the contrast between them, and thought his (Clare) appearance distasteful to her (Tess).

``Tess!'' (he)
he (Clare) said huskily,
``can you forgive me for going away? Can't you--come to me? How do you get to be--like this?'' (he)

``It is too late,'' (she)
said she (Tess), her (Tess) voice sounding hard through the room, her (Tess) eyes shining unnaturally.

``I did not think rightly of you--I did not see you as you were!'' (he)
he (Clare) continued to plead.
``I have learnt to since, dearest Tessy mine!'' (unknown)

``Too late, too late!'' (she)
she (Tess) said, waving her (Tess) hand in the impatience of a person whose tortures cause every instant to seem an hour.
``Don't come close to me, Angel! No--you must not. Keep away.'' (unknown)

``But don't you love me, my dear wife, because I have been so pulled down by illness? You are not so fickle--I am come on purpose for you--my mother and father will welcome you now!'' (unknown)

``Yes--O, yes, yes! But I say, I say it is too late.'' (She)

She (Tess) seemed to feel like a fugitive in a dream, who tries to move away, but cannot.

``Don't you know all--don't you know it? Yet how do you come here if you do not know?'' (unknown)

``I inquired here and there, and I found the way.'' (unknown)

``I waited and waited for you,'' (she)
she (Tess) went on, her (Tess) tones suddenly resuming their old fluty pathos.
``But you did not come! And I wrote to you, and you did not come! He (father) kept on saying you would never come any more, and that I was a foolish woman. He (father) was very kind to me, and to mother, and to all of us after father's death. He (father)--'' (unknown)

``I don't understand.'' (unknown)

``He (father) has won me back to him (father).'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Clare looked at her (Tess) keenly, then, gathering her (Tess) meaning, flagged like one plague-stricken, and his (Clare) glance sank; it fell on her (Tess) hands, which, once rosy, were now white and more delicate.

She (Tess) continued--

``He (father) is upstairs. I hate him (father) now, because he (father) told me a lie--that you would not come again; and you HAVE come! These clothes are what he (father)'s put upon me: I didn't care what he (father) did wi' me! But--will you go away, Angel, please, and never come any more?'' (She)

They stood fixed, their baffled hearts looking out of their eyes with a joylessness pitiful to see. Both seemed to implore something to shelter them from reality.

``Ah--it is my fault!'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare.

But he (Clare) could not get on. Speech was as inexpressive as silence. But he (Clare) had a vague consciousness of one thing, though it was not clear to him (Clare) till later; that his (Clare) original Tess had spiritually ceased to recognize the body before him (Clare) as hers--allowing it to drift, like a corpse upon the current, in a direction dissociated from its living will.

A few instants passed, and he (Clare) found that Tess was gone. His (Clare) face grew colder and more shrunken as he (Clare) stood concentrated on the moment, and a minute or two after, he (Clare) found himself in the street, walking along he (Clare) did not know whither.

LVI

Mrs Brooks, the lady who was the householder at The Herons and owner of all the handsome furniture, was not a person of an unusually curious turn of mind. She (Brooks) was too deeply materialized, poor woman, by her (Brooks) long and enforced bondage to that arithmetical demon Profit-and-Loss, to retain much curiousity for its own sake, and apart from possible lodgers' pockets. Nevertheless, the visit of Angel Clare to her (Brooks) well-paying tenants, Mr and Mrs d``Urberville, as she (Urberville) deemed them, was sufficiently exceptional in point of time and manner to reinvigorate the feminine proclivity which had been stifled down as useless save in its bearings to the letting trade.

Tess had spoken to her (Tess) husband from the doorway, without entering the dining-room, and Mrs Brooks, who stood within the partly-closed door of her (Brooks) own sitting-room at the back of the passage, could hear fragments of the conversation--if conversation it could be called--between those two wretched souls. She (Brooks) heard Tess re-ascend the stairs to the first floor, and the departure of Clare, and the closing of the front door behind him (Clare). Then the door of the room above was shut, and Mrs Brooks knew that Tess had re-entered her (Tess) apartment. As the young lady was not fully dressed, Mrs Brooks knew that she (Brooks) would not emerge again for some time.

She (Brooks) accordingly ascended the stairs softly, and stood at the door of the front room--a drawing-room, connected with the room immediately behind it -LRB-which was a bedroom-RRB- by folding-doors in the common manner. This first floor, containing Mrs Brooks's best apartments, had been taken by the week by the d``Urbervilles. The back room was now in silence; but from the drawing-room there came sounds.

All that she (Brooks) could at first distinguish of them was one syllable, continually repeated in a low note of moaning, as if it came from a soul bound to some Ixionian wheel--

``O--O--O!'' (she)

Then a silence, then a heavy sigh, and again--

``O--O--O!'' (The landlady)

The landlady looked through the keyhole. Only a small space of the room inside was visible, but within that space came a corner of the breakfast table, which was already spread for the meal, and also a chair beside. Over the seat of the chair Tess's face was bowed, her (Tess) posture being a kneeling one in front of it; her (Tess) hands were clasped over her (Tess) head, the skirts of her (Tess) dressing-gown and the embroidery of her (Tess) night-gown flowed upon the floor behind her (Tess), and her (Tess) stockingless feet, from which the slippers had fallen, protruded upon the carpet. It was from her (Tess) lips that came the murmur of unspeakable despair.

Then a man's voice from the adjoining bedroom--

``What's the matter?'' (a man)

She (Tess) did not answer, but went on, in a tone which was a soliloquy rather than an exclamation, and a dirge rather than a soliloquy. Mrs Brooks could only catch a portion:

``And then my dear, dear husband came home to me ... and I did not know it! ... And you had used your cruel persuasion upon me ... you did not stop using it--no--you did not stop! My little sisters and brothers and my mother's needs--they were the things you moved me by ... and you said my husband would never come back--never; and you taunted me, and said what a simpleton I was to expect him (husband)! ... And at last I believed you and gave way! ... And then he (husband) came back! Now he (husband) is gone. Gone a second time, and I have lost him (husband) now for ever ... and he (husband) will not love me the littlest bit ever any more--only hate me! ... O yes, I have lost him (husband) now--again because of--you!'' (Mrs Brooks)
In writhing, with her (Brooks) head on the chair, she (Brooks) turned her (Brooks) face towards the door, and Mrs Brooks could see the pain upon it, and that her (Brooks) lips were bleeding from the clench of her (Brooks) teeth upon them, and that the long lashes of her (Brooks) closed eyes stuck in wet tags to her (Brooks) cheeks. She (Brooks) continued:
``And he (husband) is dying--he (husband) looks as if he (husband) is dying! ... And my sin will kill him (husband) and not kill me! ... O, you have torn my life all to pieces ... made me be what I prayed you in pity not to make me be again! ... My own true husband will never, never--O God--I can't bear this!--I cannot!'' (She)

There were more and sharper words from the man; then a sudden rustle; she (Brooks) had sprung to her (Brooks) feet. Mrs Brooks, thinking that the speaker was coming to rush out of the door, hastily retreated down the stairs.

She (Brooks) need not have done so, however, for the door of the sitting-room was not opened. But Mrs Brooks felt it unsafe to watch on the landing again, and entered her (Brooks) own parlour below.

She (Brooks) could hear nothing through the floor, although she (Brooks) listened intently, and thereupon went to the kitchen to finish her (Brooks) interrupted breakfast. Coming up presently to the front room on the ground floor she (Brooks) took up some sewing, waiting for her (Brooks) lodgers to ring that she (Brooks) might take away the breakfast, which she (Brooks) meant to do herself, to discover what was the matter if possible. Overhead, as she (Brooks) sat, she (Brooks) could now hear the floorboards slightly creak, as if some one were walking about, and presently the movement was explained by the rustle of garments against the banisters, the opening and the closing of the front door, and the form of Tess passing to the gate on her (Tess) way into the street. She (Tess) was fully dressed now in the walking costume of a well-to-do young lady in which she (Tess) had arrived, with the sole addition that over her (Tess) hat and black feathers a veil was drawn.

Mrs Brooks had not been able to catch any word of farewell, temporary or otherwise, between her (Brooks) tenants at the door above. They might have quarrelled, or Mr d``Urberville might still be asleep, for he (God) was not an early riser.

She (me) went into the back room, which was more especially her (me) own apartment, and continued her (me) sewing there. The lady lodger did not return, nor did the gentleman ring his (gentleman) bell. Mrs Brooks pondered on the delay, and on what probable relation the visitor who had called so early bore to the couple upstairs. In reflecting she (Brooks) leant back in her (Brooks) chair.

As she (Brooks) did so her (Brooks) eyes glanced casually over the ceiling till they were arrested by a spot in the middle of its white surface which she (Brooks) had never noticed there before. It was about the size of a wafer when she (Brooks) first observed it, but it speedily grew as large as the palm of her (Brooks) hand, and then she (Brooks) could perceive that it was red. The oblong white ceiling, with this scarlet blot in the midst, had the appearance of a gigantic ace of hearts.

Mrs Brooks had strange qualms of misgiving. She (Brooks) got upon the table, and touched the spot in the ceiling with her (Brooks) fingers. It was damp, and she (Brooks) fancied that it was a blood stain.

Descending from the table, she (Brooks) left the parlour, and went upstairs, intending to enter the room overhead, which was the bedchamber at the back of the drawing-room. But, nerveless woman as she (woman) had now become, she (woman) could not bring herself to attempt the handle. She (woman) listened. The dead silence within was broken only by a regular beat.

Drip, drip, drip.

Mrs Brooks hastened downstairs, opened the front door, and ran into the street. A man she (Brooks) knew, one of the workmen employed at an adjoining villa, was passing by, and she (Brooks) begged him (man) to come in and go upstairs with her (Brooks); she (Brooks) feared something had happened to one of her (Brooks) lodgers. The workman assented, and followed her (Brooks) to the landing.

She (Brooks) opened the door of the drawing-room, and stood back for him (workman) to pass in, entering herself behind him (workman). The room was empty; the breakfast--a substantial repast of coffee, eggs, and a cold ham--lay spread upon the table untouched, as when she (Brooks) had taken it up, excepting that the carving-knife was missing. She (Brooks) asked the man to go through the folding-doors into the adjoining room.

He (man) opened the doors, entered a step or two, and came back almost instantly with a rigid face.

``My good God, the gentleman in bed is dead! I think he (God) has been hurt with a knife--a lot of blood had run down upon the floor!'' (the tramp)

The alarm was soon given, and the house which had lately been so quiet resounded with the tramp of many footsteps, a surgeon among the rest. The wound was small, but the point of the blade had touched the heart of the victim, who lay on his (victim) back, pale, fixed, dead, as if he (victim) had scarcely moved after the infliction of the blow. In a quarter of an hour the news that a gentleman who was a temporary visitor to the town had been stabbed in his (gentleman) bed, spread through every street and villa of the popular watering-place.

LVII

Meanwhile Angel Clare had walked automatically along the way by which he (Clare) had come, and, entering his (Clare) hotel, sat down over the breakfast, staring at nothingness. He (Clare) went on eating and drinking unconsciously till on a sudden he (Clare) demanded his (Clare) bill; having paid which, he (Clare) took his (Clare) dressing-bag in his (Clare) hand, the only luggage he (Clare) had brought with him (Clare), and went out.

At the moment of his (Clare) departure a telegram was handed to him (Clare)--a few words from his (Clare) mother, stating that they were glad to know his (Clare) address, and informing him (Clare) that his (Clare) brother Cuthbert had proposed to and been accepted by Mercy Chant.

Clare crumpled up the paper and followed the route to the station; reaching it, he (Clare) found that there would be no train leaving for an hour and more. He (Clare) sat down to wait, and having waited a quarter of an hour felt that he (Clare) could wait there no longer. Broken in heart and numbed, he (Clare) had nothing to hurry for; but he (Clare) wished to get out of a town which had been the scene of such an experience, and turned to walk to the first station onward, and let the train pick him (Clare) up there.

The highway that he (Clare) followed was open, and at a little distance dipped into a valley, across which it could be seen running from edge to edge. He (Clare) had traversed the greater part of this depression, and was climbing the western acclivity when, pausing for breath, he (Clare) unconsciously looked back. Why he (Clare) did so he (Clare) could not say, but something seemed to impel him (Clare) to the act. The tape-like surface of the road diminished in his (Clare) rear as far as he (Clare) could see, and as he (Clare) gazed a moving spot intruded on the white vacuity of its perspective.

It was a human figure running. Clare waited, with a dim sense that somebody was trying to overtake him (Clare).

The form descending the incline was a woman's, yet so entirely was his (Clare) mind blinded to the idea of his (Clare) wife's following him (Clare) that even when she (wife) came nearer he (Clare) did not recognize her (wife) under the totally changed attire in which he (Clare) now beheld her (wife). It was not till she (wife) was quite close that he (Clare) could believe her (wife) to be Tess.

``I saw you--turn away from the station--just before I got there--and I have been following you all this way!'' (She)

She (Tess) was so pale, so breathless, so quivering in every muscle, that he (Clare) did not ask her (Tess) a single question, but seizing her (Tess) hand, and pulling it within his (Clare) arm, he (Clare) led her (Tess) along. To avoid meeting any possible wayfarers he (Clare) left the high road and took a footpath under some fir-trees. When they were deep among the moaning boughs he (Clare) stopped and looked at her (Tess) inquiringly.

``Angel,'' (she)
she (Tess) said, as if waiting for this,
``do you know what I have been running after you for? To tell you that I have killed him (Angel)!'' (she)
A pitiful white smile lit her (Tess) face as she (Tess) spoke.

``What!'' (he)
said he (Clare), thinking from the strangeness of her (Tess) manner that she (Tess) was in some delirium.

``I have done it--I don't know how,'' (she)
she (Tess) continued.
``Still, I owed it to you, and to myself, Angel. I feared long ago, when I struck him (Angel) on the mouth with my glove, that I might do it some day for the trap he (Angel) set for me in my simple youth, and his (Angel) wrong to you through me. He (Angel) has come between us and ruined us, and now he (Angel) can never do it any more. I never loved him (Angel) at all, Angel, as I loved you. You know it, don't you? You believe it? You didn't come back to me, and I was obliged to go back to him (Angel). Why did you go away--why did you--when I loved you so? I can't think why you did it. But I don't blame you; only, Angel, will you forgive me my sin against you, now I have killed him (Angel)? I thought as I ran along that you would be sure to forgive me now I have done that. It came to me as a shining light that I should get you back that way. I could not bear the loss of you any longer--you don't know how entirely I was unable to bear your not loving me! Say you do now, dear, dear husband; say you do, now I have killed him (husband)!'' (unknown)

``I do love you, Tess--O, I do--it is all come back!'' (he)
he (Clare) said, tightening his (Clare) arms round her (Tess) with fervid pressure.
``But how do you mean--you have killed him (husband)?'' (unknown)

``I mean that I have,'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured in a reverie.

``What, bodily? Is he (husband) dead?'' (unknown)

``Yes. He (husband) heard me crying about you, and he (husband) bitterly taunted me; and called you by a foul name; and then I did it. My heart could not bear it. He (husband) had nagged me about you before. And then I dressed myself and came away to find you.'' (he)

By degrees he (Clare) was inclined to believe that she (Tess) had faintly attempted, at least, what she (Tess) said she (Tess) had done; and his (Clare) horror at her (Tess) impulse was mixed with amazement at the strength of her (Tess) affection for himself, and at the strangeness of its quality, which had apparently extinguished her (Tess) moral sense altogether. Unable to realize the gravity of her (Tess) conduct, she (Tess) seemed at last content; and he (Clare) looked at her (Tess) as she (Tess) lay upon his (Clare) shoulder, weeping with happiness, and wondered what obscure strain in the d``Urberville blood had led to this aberration--if it were an aberration. There momentarily flashed through his (husband) mind that the family tradition of the coach and murder might have arisen because the d``Urbervilles had been known to do these things. As well as his (husband) confused and excited ideas could reason, he (husband) supposed that in the moment of mad grief of which she (it) spoke, her (it) mind had lost its balance, and plunged her (it) into this abyss.

It was very terrible if true; if a temporary hallucination, sad. But, anyhow, here was this deserted wife of his (husband), this passionately-fond woman, clinging to him (husband) without a suspicion that he (husband) would be anything to her (woman) but a protector. He (husband) saw that for him (husband) to be otherwise was not, in her (woman) mind, within the region of the possible. Tenderness was absolutely dominant in Clare at last. He (Clare) kissed her (woman) endlessly with his (Clare) white lips, and held her (woman) hand, and said--

``I will not desert you! I will protect you by every means in my power, dearest love, whatever you may have done or not have done!'' (He)

They then walked on under the trees, Tess turning her (Tess) head every now and then to look at him (Clare). Worn and unhandsome as he (Clare) had become, it was plain that she (Tess) did not discern the least fault in his (Clare) appearance. To her (Tess) he (Clare) was, as of old, all that was perfection, personally and mentally. He (Clare) was still her (Tess) Antinous, her (Tess) Apollo even; his (Clare) sickly face was beautiful as the morning to her (Tess) affectionate regard on this day no less than when she (Tess) first beheld him (Clare); for was it not the face of the one man on earth who had loved her (Tess) purely, and who had believed in her (Tess) as pure!

With an instinct as to possibilities, he (man) did not now, as he (man) had intended, make for the first station beyond the town, but plunged still farther under the firs, which here abounded for miles. Each clasping the other round the waist they promenaded over the dry bed of fir-needles, thrown into a vague intoxicating atmosphere at the consciousness of being together at last, with no living soul between them; ignoring that there was a corpse. Thus they proceeded for several miles till Tess, arousing herself, looked about her (Tess), and said, timidly--

``Are we going anywhere in particular?'' (her)

``I don't know, dearest. Why?'' (unknown)

``I don't know.'' (unknown)

``Well, we might walk a few miles further, and when it is evening find lodgings somewhere or other--in a lonely cottage, perhaps. Can you walk well, Tessy?'' (unknown)

``O yes! I could walk for ever and ever with your arm round me!'' (unknown)

Upon the whole it seemed a good thing to do. Thereupon they quickened their pace, avoiding high roads, and following obscure paths tending more or less northward. But there was an unpractical vagueness in their movements throughout the day; neither one of them seemed to consider any question of effectual escape, disguise, or long concealment. Their every idea was temporary and unforefending, like the plans of two children.

At mid-day they drew near to a roadside inn, and Tess would have entered it with him (Tess) to get something to eat, but he (Tess) persuaded her (Tess) to remain among the trees and bushes of this half-woodland, half-moorland part of the country till he (Tess) should come back. Her (Tess) clothes were of recent fashion; even the ivory-handled parasol that she (Tess) carried was of a shape unknown in the retired spot to which they had now wandered; and the cut of such articles would have attracted attention in the settle of a tavern. He (Tess) soon returned, with food enough for half-a-dozen people and two bottles of wine--enough to last them for a day or more, should any emergency arise.

They sat down upon some dead boughs and shared their meal. Between one and two o'clock they packed up the remainder and went on again.

``I feel strong enough to walk any distance,'' (she)
said she (Tess).

``I think we may as well steer in a general way towards the interior of the country, where we can hide for a time, and are less likely to be looked for than anywhere near the coast,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
Clare remarked.
``Later on, when they have forgotten us, we can make for some port.'' (She)

She (Tess) made no reply to this beyond that of grasping him (Clare) more tightly, and straight inland they went. Though the season was an English May, the weather was serenely bright, and during the afternoon it was quite warm. Through the latter miles of their walk their footpath had taken them into the depths of the New Forest, and towards evening, turning the corner of a lane, they perceived behind a brook and bridge a large board on which was painted in white letters,

``This desirable Mansion to be Let Furnished'' (some London agents)
; particulars following, with directions to apply to some London agents. Passing through the gate they could see the house, an old brick building of regular design and large accommodation.

``I know it,'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare.
``It is Bramshurst Court. You can see that it is shut up, and grass is growing on the drive.'' (unknown)

``Some of the windows are open,'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)
said Tess.

``Just to air the rooms, I suppose.'' (unknown)

``All these rooms empty, and we without a roof to our heads!'' (unknown)

``You are getting tired, my Tess!'' (he)
he (Clare) said.
``We'll stop soon.'' (he)
And kissing her (Tess) sad mouth, he (Clare) again led her (Tess) onwards.

He (Clare) was growing weary likewise, for they had wandered a dozen or fifteen miles, and it became necessary to consider what they should do for rest. They looked from afar at isolated cottages and little inns, and were inclined to approach one of the latter, when their hearts failed them, and they sheered off. At length their gait dragged, and they stood still.

``Could we sleep under the trees?'' (she)
she (Tess) asked.

He (Clare) thought the season insufficiently advanced.

``I have been thinking of that empty mansion we passed,'' (he)
he (Clare) said.
``Let us go back towards it again.'' (unknown)

They retraced their steps, but it was half an hour before they stood without the entrance-gate as earlier. He (Clare) then requested her (Tess) to stay where she (Tess) was, whilst he (Clare) went to see who was within.

She (Tess) sat down among the bushes within the gate, and Clare crept towards the house. His (Clare) absence lasted some considerable time, and when he (Clare) returned Tess was wildly anxious, not for herself, but for him (Clare). He (Clare) had found out from a boy that there was only an old woman in charge as caretaker, and she (woman) only came there on fine days, from the hamlet near, to open and shut the windows. She (woman) would come to shut them at sunset.

``Now, we can get in through one of the lower windows, and rest there,'' (he)
said he (caretaker).

Under his (caretaker) escort she (woman) went tardily forward to the main front, whose shuttered windows, like sightless eyeballs, excluded the possibility of watchers. The door was reached a few steps further, and one of the windows beside it was open. Clare clambered in, and pulled Tess in after him (Clare).

Except the hall, the rooms were all in darkness, and they ascended the staircase. Up here also the shutters were tightly closed, the ventilation being perfunctorily done, for this day at least, by opening the hall-window in front and an upper window behind. Clare unlatched the door of a large chamber, felt his (Clare) way across it, and parted the shutters to the width of two or three inches. A shaft of dazzling sunlight glanced into the room, revealing heavy, old-fashioned furniture, crimson damask hangings, and an enormous four-post bedstead, along the head of which were carved running figures, apparently Atalanta's race.

``Rest at last!'' (he)
said he (Clare), setting down his (Clare) bag and the parcel of viands.

They remained in great quietness till the caretaker should have come to shut the windows: as a precaution, putting themselves in total darkness by barring the shutters as before, lest the woman should open the door of their chamber for any casual reason. Between six and seven o'clock she (woman) came, but did not approach the wing they were in. They heard her (woman) close the windows, fasten them, lock the door, and go away. Then Clare again stole a chink of light from the window, and they shared another meal, till by-and-by they were enveloped in the shades of night which they had no candle to disperse.

LVIII

The night was strangely solemn and still. In the small hours she (woman) whispered to him (Clare) the whole story of how he (Clare) had walked in his (Clare) sleep with her (woman) in his (Clare) arms across the Froom stream, at the imminent risk of both their lives, and laid her (woman) down in the stone coffin at the ruined abbey. He (Clare) had never known of that till now.

``Why didn't you tell me next day?'' (he)
he (Clare) said.
``It might have prevented much misunderstanding and woe.'' (unknown)

``Don't think of what's past!'' (she)
said she (woman).
``I am not going to think outside of now. Why should we! Who knows what to-morrow has in store?'' (unknown)

But it apparently had no sorrow. The morning was wet and foggy, and Clare, rightly informed that the caretaker only opened the windows on fine days, ventured to creep out of their chamber and explore the house, leaving Tess asleep. There was no food on the premises, but there was water, and he (Clare) took advantage of the fog to emerge from the mansion and fetch tea, bread, and butter from a shop in a little place two miles beyond, as also a small tin kettle and spirit-lamp, that they might get fire without smoke. His (Clare) re-entry awoke her (Tess); and they breakfasted on what he (Clare) had brought.

They were indisposed to stir abroad, and the day passed, and the night following, and the next, and next; till, almost without their being aware, five days had slipped by in absolute seclusion, not a sight or sound of a human being disturbing their peacefulness, such as it was. The changes of the weather were their only events, the birds of the New Forest their only company. By tacit consent they hardly once spoke of any incident of the past subsequent to their wedding-day. The gloomy intervening time seemed to sink into chaos, over which the present and prior times closed as if it never had been. Whenever he (their) suggested that they should leave their shelter, and go forwards towards Southampton or London, she (it) showed a strange unwillingness to move.

``Why should we put an end to all that's sweet and lovely!'' (she)
she (it) deprecated.
``What must come will come.'' (unknown)
And, looking through the shutter-chink:
``All is trouble outside there; inside here content.'' (He)

He (their) peeped out also. It was quite true; within was affection, union, error forgiven: outside was the inexorable.

``And--and,'' (she)
she (it) said, pressing her (it) cheek against his (their),
``I fear that what you think of me now may not last. I do not wish to outlive your present feeling for me. I would rather not. I would rather be dead and buried when the time comes for you to despise me, so that it may never be known to me that you despised me.'' (she)

``I cannot ever despise you.'' (unknown)

``I also hope that. But considering what my life has been, I cannot see why any man should, sooner or later, be able to help despising me... How wickedly mad I was! Yet formerly I never could bear to hurt a fly or a worm, and the sight of a bird in a cage used often to make me cry.'' (unknown)

They remained yet another day. In the night the dull sky cleared, and the result was that the old caretaker at the cottage awoke early. The brilliant sunrise made her (it) unusually brisk; she (it) decided to open the contiguous mansion immediately, and to air it thoroughly on such a day. Thus it occurred that, having arrived and opened the lower rooms before six o'clock, she (it) ascended to the bedchambers, and was about to turn the handle of the one wherein they lay. At that moment she (it) fancied she (it) could hear the breathing of persons within. Her (it) slippers and her (it) antiquity had rendered her (it) progress a noiseless one so far, and she (it) made for instant retreat; then, deeming that her (it) hearing might have deceived her (it), she (it) turned anew to the door and softly tried the handle. The lock was out of order, but a piece of furniture had been moved forward on the inside, which prevented her (it) opening the door more than an inch or two. A stream of morning light through the shutter-chink fell upon the faces of the pair, wrapped in profound slumber, Tess's lips being parted like a half-opened flower near his (Tess) cheek. The caretaker was so struck with their innocent appearance, and with the elegance of Tess's gown hanging across a chair, her (Tess) silk stockings beside it, the pretty parasol, and the other habits in which she (Tess) had arrived because she (Tess) had none else, that her (Tess) first indignation at the effrontery of tramps and vagabonds gave way to a momentary sentimentality over this genteel elopement, as it seemed. She (Tess) closed the door, and withdrew as softly as she (Tess) had come, to go and consult with her (Tess) neighbours on the odd discovery.

Not more than a minute had elapsed after her (Tess) withdrawal when Tess woke, and then Clare. Both had a sense that something had disturbed them, though they could not say what; and the uneasy feeling which it engendered grew stronger. As soon as he (Clare) was dressed he (Clare) narrowly scanned the lawn through the two or three inches of shutter-chink.

``I think we will leave at once,'' (he)
said he (Clare).
``It is a fine day. And I cannot help fancying somebody is about the house. At any rate, the woman will be sure to come to-day.'' (She)

She (Tess) passively assented, and putting the room in order, they took up the few articles that belonged to them, and departed noiselessly. When they had got into the Forest she (Tess) turned to take a last look at the house.

``Ah, happy house--goodbye!'' (she)
she (Tess) said.
``My life can only be a question of a few weeks. Why should we not have stayed there?'' (unknown)

``Don't say it, Tess! We shall soon get out of this district altogether. We'll continue our course as we've begun it, and keep straight north. Nobody will think of looking for us there. We shall be looked for at the Wessex ports if we are sought at all. When we are in the north we will get to a port and away.'' (her)

Having thus persuaded her (Tess), the plan was pursued, and they kept a bee-line northward. Their long repose at the manor-house lent them walking power now; and towards mid-day they found that they were approaching the steepled city of Melchester, which lay directly in their way. He (Clare) decided to rest her (Tess) in a clump of trees during the afternoon, and push onward under cover of darkness. At dusk Clare purchased food as usual, and their night march began, the boundary between Upper and Mid-Wessex being crossed about eight o'clock.

To walk across country without much regard to roads was not new to Tess, and she (Tess) showed her (Tess) old agility in the performance. The intercepting city, ancient Melchester, they were obliged to pass through in order to take advantage of the town bridge for crossing a large river that obstructed them. It was about midnight when they went along the deserted streets, lighted fitfully by the few lamps, keeping off the pavement that it might not echo their footsteps. The graceful pile of cathedral architecture rose dimly on their left hand, but it was lost upon them now. Once out of the town they followed the turnpike-road, which after a few miles plunged across an open plain.

Though the sky was dense with cloud, a diffused light from some fragment of a moon had hitherto helped them a little. But the moon had now sunk, the clouds seemed to settle almost on their heads, and the night grew as dark as a cave. However, they found their way along, keeping as much on the turf as possible that their tread might not resound, which it was easy to do, there being no hedge or fence of any kind. All around was open loneliness and black solitude, over which a stiff breeze blew.

They had proceeded thus gropingly two or three miles further when on a sudden Clare became conscious of some vast erection close in his (Clare) front, rising sheer from the grass. They had almost struck themselves against it.

``What monstrous place is this?'' (Angel)
said Angel.

``It hums,'' (she)
said she (Angel).
``Hearken!'' (He)

He (Angel) listened. The wind, playing upon the edifice, produced a booming tune, like the note of some gigantic one-stringed harp. No other sound came from it, and lifting his (Angel) hand and advancing a step or two, Clare felt the vertical surface of the structure. It seemed to be of solid stone, without joint or moulding. Carrying his (Clare) fingers onward he (Clare) found that what he (Clare) had come in contact with was a colossal rectangular pillar; by stretching out his (Clare) left hand he (Clare) could feel a similar one adjoining. At an indefinite height overhead something made the black sky blacker, which had the semblance of a vast architrave uniting the pillars horizontally. They carefully entered beneath and between; the surfaces echoed their soft rustle; but they seemed to be still out of doors. The place was roofless. Tess drew her (Tess) breath fearfully, and Angel, perplexed, said--

``What can it be?'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Feeling sideways they encountered another tower-like pillar, square and uncompromising as the first; beyond it another and another. The place was all doors and pillars, some connected above by continuous architraves.

``A very Temple of the Winds,'' (he)
he (Angel) said.

The next pillar was isolated; others composed a trilithon; others were prostrate, their flanks forming a causeway wide enough for a carriage; and it was soon obvious that they made up a forest of monoliths grouped upon the grassy expanse of the plain. The couple advanced further into this pavilion of the night till they stood in its midst.

``It is Stonehenge!'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)
said Clare.

``The heathen temple, you mean?'' (unknown)

``Yes. Older than the centuries; older than the d

``Urbervilles! Well, what shall we do, darling? We may find shelter further on.'' (Tess/Tess Durbeyfield/Durbeyfield)

But Tess, really tired by this time, flung herself upon an oblong slab that lay close at hand, and was sheltered from the wind by a pillar. Owing to the action of the sun during the preceding day, the stone was warm and dry, in comforting contrast to the rough and chill grass around, which had damped her (Tess) skirts and shoes.

``I don't want to go any further, Angel,'' (she)
she (Tess) said, stretching out her (Tess) hand for his (Clare).
``Can't we bide here?'' (unknown)

``I fear not. This spot is visible for miles by day, although it does not seem so now.'' (unknown)

``One of my mother's people was a shepherd hereabouts, now I think of it. And you used to say at Talbothays that I was a heathen. So now I am at home.'' (He)

He (Clare) knelt down beside her (Tess) outstretched form, and put his (Clare) lips upon hers.

``Sleepy are you, dear? I think you are lying on an altar.'' (unknown)

``I like very much to be here,'' (she)
she (Tess) murmured.
``It is so solemn and lonely--after my great happiness--with nothing but the sky above my face. It seems as if there were no folk in the world but we two; and I wish there were not--except `Liza-Lu.'' (Clare/Mr Clare/Angel)

Clare though she (Tess) might as well rest here till it should get a little lighter, and he (Clare) flung his (Clare) overcoat upon her (Tess), and sat down by her (Tess) side.

``Angel, if anything happens to me, will you watch over

``Liza-Lu for my sake?'' (unknown)
she (Tess) asked, when they had listened a long time to the wind among the pillars.

``I will.'' (unknown)

``She (we) is so good and simple and pure. O, Angel--I wish you would marry her (we) if you lose me, as you will do shortly. O, if you would!'' (unknown)

``If I lose you I lose all! And she (we) is my sister-in-law.'' (unknown)

``That's nothing, dearest. People marry sister-laws continually about Marlott; and

``Liza-Lu is so gentle and sweet, and she (we) is growing so beautiful. O, I could share you with her (we) willingly when we are spirits! If you would train her (we) and teach her (we), Angel, and bring her (we) up for your own self! ... She (we) had all the best of me without the bad of me; and if she (we) were to become yours it would almost seem as if death had not divided us... Well, I have said it. I won't mention it again.'' (She)

She (Tess) ceased, and he (Clare) fell into thought. In the far north-east sky he (Clare) could see between the pillars a level streak of light. The uniform concavity of black cloud was lifting bodily like the lid of a pot, letting in at the earth's edge the coming day, against which the towering monoliths and trilithons began to be blackly defined.

``Did they sacrifice to God here?'' (she)
asked she (Tess).

``No,'' (he)
said he (Clare).

``Who to?'' (unknown)

``I believe to the sun. That lofty stone set away by itself is in the direction of the sun, which will presently rise behind it.'' (unknown)

``This reminds me, dear,'' (she)
she (Tess) said.
``You remember you never would interfere with any belief of mine before we were married? But I knew your mind all the same, and I thought as you thought--not from any reasons of my own, but because you thought so. Tell me now, Angel, do you think we shall meet again after we are dead? I want to know.'' (He)

He (Clare) kissed her (Tess) to avoid a reply at such a time.

``O, Angel--I fear that means no!'' (she)
said she (Tess), with a suppressed sob.
``And I wanted so to see you again--so much, so much! What--not even you and I, Angel, who love each other so well?'' (he)

Like a greater than himself, to the critical question at the critical time he (Clare) did not answer; and they were again silent. In a minute or two her (Tess) breathing became more regular, her (Tess) clasp of his (Clare) hand relaxed, and she (Tess) fell asleep. The band of silver paleness along the east horizon made even the distant parts of the Great Plain appear dark and near; and the whole enormous landscape bore that impress of reserve, taciturnity, and hesitation which is usual just before day. The eastward pillars and their architraves stood up blackly against the light, and the great flame-shaped Sun-stone beyond them; and the Stone of Sacrifice midway. Presently the night wind died out, and the quivering little pools in the cup-like hollows of the stones lay still. At the same time something seemed to move on the verge of the dip eastward--a mere dot. It was the head of a man approaching them from the hollow beyond the Sun-stone. Clare wished they had gone onward, but in the circumstances decided to remain quiet. The figure came straight towards the circle of pillars in which they were.

He (Clare) heard something behind him (Clare), the brush of feet. Turning, he (Clare) saw over the prostrate columns another figure; then before he (Clare) was aware, another was at hand on the right, under a trilithon, and another on the left. The dawn shone full on the front of the man westward, and Clare could discern from this that he (Clare) was tall, and walked as if trained. They all closed in with evident purpose. Her (Clare) story then was true! Springing to his (Clare) feet, he (Clare) looked around for a weapon, loose stone, means of escape, anything. By this time the nearest man was upon him (man).

``It is no use, sir,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``There are sixteen of us on the Plain, and the whole country is reared.'' (unknown)

``Let her (Angel) finish her (Angel) sleep!'' (he)
he (man) implored in a whisper of the men as they gathered round.

When they saw where she (Clare) lay, which they had not done till then, they showed no objection, and stood watching her (Clare), as still as the pillars around. He (man) went to the stone and bent over her (Clare), holding one poor little hand; her (Clare) breathing now was quick and small, like that of a lesser creature than a woman. All waited in the growing light, their faces and hands as if they were silvered, the remainder of their figures dark, the stones glistening green-gray, the Plain still a mass of shade. Soon the light was strong, and a ray shone upon her (woman) unconscious form, peering under her (woman) eyelids and waking her (woman).

``What is it, Angel?'' (she)
she (woman) said, starting up.
``Have they come for me?'' (unknown)

``Yes, dearest,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``They have come.'' (unknown)

``It is as it should be,'' (she)
she (woman) murmured.
``Angel, I am almost glad--yes, glad! This happiness could not have lasted. It was too much. I have had enough; and now I shall not live for you to despise me!'' (She)

She (woman) stood up, shook herself, and went forward, neither of the men having moved.

``I am ready,'' (she)
she (woman) said quietly.

LIX

The city of Wintoncester, that fine old city, aforetime capital of Wessex, lay amidst its convex and concave downlands in all the brightness and warmth of a July morning. The gabled brick, tile, and freestone houses had almost dried off for the season their integument of lichen, the streams in the meadows were low, and in the sloping High Street, from the West Gateway to the medival cross, and from the medival cross to the bridge, that leisurely dusting and sweeping was in progress which usually ushers in an old-fashioned market-day.

From the western gate aforesaid the highway, as every Wintoncestrian knows, ascends a long and regular incline of the exact length of a measured mile, leaving the houses gradually behind. Up this road from the precincts of the city two persons were walking rapidly, as if unconscious of the trying ascent--unconscious through preoccupation and not through buoyancy. They had emerged upon this road through a narrow, barred wicket in a high wall a little lower down. They seemed anxious to get out of the sight of the houses and of their kind, and this road appeared to offer the quickest means of doing so. Though they were young, they walked with bowed heads, which gait of grief the sun's rays smiled on pitilessly.

One of the pair was Angel Clare, the other a tall budding creature--half girl, half woman--a spiritualized image of Tess, slighter than she (Tess), but with the same beautiful eyes--Clare's sister-in-law, ``Liza-Lu. Their pale faces seemed to have shrunk to half their natural size. They moved on hand in hand, and never spoke a word, the drooping of their heads being that of Giotto's

``Two Apostles'' (unknown)
.

When they had nearly reached the top of the great West Hill the clocks in the town struck eight. Each gave a start at the notes, and, walking onward yet a few steps, they reached the first milestone, standing whitely on the green margin of the grass, and backed by the down, which here was open to the road. They entered upon the turf, and, impelled by a force that seemed to overrule their will, suddenly stood still, turned, and waited in paralyzed suspense beside the stone.

The prospect from this summit was almost unlimited. In the valley beneath lay the city they had just left, its more prominent buildings showing as in an isometric drawing--among them the broad cathedral tower, with its Norman windows and immense length of aisle and nave, the spires of St Thomas's, the pinnacled tower of the College, and, more to the right, the tower and gables of the ancient hospice, where to this day the pilgrim may receive his (pilgrim) dole of bread and ale. Behind the city swept the rotund upland of St Catherine's Hill; further off, landscape beyond landscape, till the horizon was lost in the radiance of the sun hanging above it.

Against these far stretches of country rose, in front of the other city edifices, a large red-brick building, with level gray roofs, and rows of short barred windows bespeaking captivity, the whole contrasting greatly by its formalism with the quaint irregularities of the Gothic erections. It was somewhat disguised from the road in passing it by yews and evergreen oaks, but it was visible enough up here. The wicket from which the pair had lately emerged was in the wall of this structure. From the middle of the building an ugly flat-topped octagonal tower ascended against the east horizon, and viewed from this spot, on its shady side and against the light, it seemed the one blot on the city's beauty. Yet it was with this blot, and not with the beauty, that the two gazers were concerned.

Upon the cornice of the tower a tall staff was fixed. Their eyes were riveted on it. A few minutes after the hour had struck something moved slowly up the staff, and extended itself upon the breeze. It was a black flag.

``Justice'' (the President)
was done, and the President of the Immortals, in Aeschylean phrase, had ended his (President) sport with Tess. And the d``Urberville knights and dames slept on in their tombs unknowing. The two speechless gazers bent themselves down to the earth, as if in prayer, and remained thus a long time, absolutely motionless: the flag continued to wave silently. As soon as they had strength, they arose, joined hands again, and went on.
